column2: The great money crunch of 1969 appears to be approaching its climax. Risk-free, overnight loans are commanding interest rates of 10 per cent and more. Bankers and economists are starting to warn publicly that the further credit tightening by the Federal Reserve System could send the economy into a tailspin of recession.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today upheld an extraordinary order to a Federal judge in New York City to sentence four men in a hijack conspiracy case.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 19 -- President Nixon's Vietnamese peace plan, replete as it was with assurances that South Vietnam is not to be abandoned, has left few in Saigon in any doubt that Mr. Nixon aims to extricate the United States from the war as soon as he decently can.
PRAGUE, May 19 -- Czechoslovak and Soviet army units started week-long maneuvers somewhere on this country's soil today.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that it would close a major satellite tracking station in Australia soon as an economy measure.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- From 16,000 to 25,000 young men now in graduate school have received their draft induction notices but have had their induction postponed until the end of the school year.

The great money crunch of 1969 appears to be approaching its climax. Risk-free, overnight loans are commanding interest rates of 10 per cent and more. Bankers and economists are starting to warn publicly that the further credit tightening by the Federal Reserve System could send the economy into a tailspin of recession.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today upheld an extraordinary order to a Federal judge in New York City to sentence four men in a hijack conspiracy case.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 19 -- President Nixon's Vietnamese peace plan, replete as it was with assurances that South Vietnam is not to be abandoned, has left few in Saigon in any doubt that Mr. Nixon aims to extricate the United States from the war as soon as he decently can.

Two recent dispatches from the Pentagon's Dr. John S. Foster (news stories May 12, 13) argue that the United States will not have sufficient second-strike capability by the mid-1970's. He estimates that 90 or 95 per cent of our land-based Minuteman force and some undisclosed proportion of our manned bombers would be destroyed on the ground by a Soviet first strike. This information is presented to still the opposition to the ABM Safeguard system.

MOSCOW, May 19 -- The 14th game of the 24-game World Chess Championship match series between Tigran Petrosian, titleholder, and his compatriot and challenger, Boris Spassky, was adjourned today at Moscow's Variety Theater in a position favorable to the champion.
PRAGUE, May 19 -- Czechoslovak and Soviet army units started week-long maneuvers somewhere on this country's soil today.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that it would close a major satellite tracking station in Australia soon as an economy measure.
WASHINGTON, May 19 -- From 16,000 to 25,000 young men now in graduate school have received their draft induction notices but have had their induction postponed until the end of the school year.
BOGOTA, Colombia, May 20 (UPI) -- A Colombian jet airliner with 59 persons aboard was hijacked today and diverted at gunpoint to Cuba by four armed men. It landed in Havana around noon.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- A committee of the American Bar Association, citing eight canons of judicial ethics, concluded today that former Justice Abe Fortas's relationship with Louis E. Wolfson was "clearly contrary'' to the ethical code.

An official Bonn spokesman has characterized West Germany's refusal to raise the value of the mark as "final" and "valid for eternity." But the speculators' odds are still weighted heavily on the side of revaluation. Of the more than $4 to $5 billion of foreign funds that recently poured into Germany, only about $1 billion have thus far flowed out.

How fiendishly clever of Chancellor Kurt Kiesinger to adopt the policies of the neo-Nazi National Democratic party in order to defeat them in the coming elections. Of course, one must ask oneself what the use is of defeating them, if one adopts their policies.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The problem of textile imports "won't go away," Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans said today, disclosing that he expected to have a plan ready for presentation to President Nixon in two weeks.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- In an effort to reach a common allied bargaining position and to spur some movement in the Paris peace negotiations, President Nixon has agreed to meet with President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam on Midway Island June 8.

BIRMINGHAM, May 20 -- The National Urban League has set up 20 new action programs, at a cost of a half-million dollars, to strengthen the economic, social and political power of the poor masses in the black ghettos of America.

LIMA, Peru, May 19 (AP) -- The Government reacted sharply today to reports that the United States has suspended military sales to Peru by announcing that the forthcoming visit by Governor Rockefeller on a fact-finding mission would be "inopportune."

HOUSTON, May 20 -- Dr. Charles A. Berry, director of medical research and operations of the Manned Spacecraft Center here, said tonight that all three Apollo 10 astronauts appeared to be in excellent health.
ATHENS, May 20 (AP) -- Britain and West Germany advanced to the quarter-finals of the women's Federation Cup team tennis competition today.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy, challenging the Nixon Administration's military tactics in Vietnam, charged today that bloody assaults such as those in the battle for Apbia Mountain were "senseless and irresponsible."

IT WAS ladies' day on Seventh Avenue and environs yesterday as fall fashion openings continued. You know, the kind of ladies who don't care to look like Indians and who insist on linings for their sheer-top dresses, or at least wear underwear.
The Manhattan Borough President's proposal to provide an expressway "around the horn" of lower Manhattan instead of across it apparently cannot be advanced because of a lack of Federal funds.

PARIS, May 20 -- Xuan Thuy, North Vietnam's chief negotiator, declared today that maintenance of the Government of President Nguyen Van Thieu in power by the United States would prevent "any progress" at the Paris peace talks.
SALEM, Ore., May 20 -- Lee Johnson, a Republican, was sworn into office as Oregon's Attorney General today after a six-and-a-half-month legal battle.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, May 20 -- Queen Elizabeth II attended the opening session today of the General Assembly of the Church of Scotland.

Earnings of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., for the first fiscal quarter, which ended April 30, rose to $3,902,000, or 46 cents a share, from $2,976,000, or 35 cents a share, Bruce A. Gimbel, president, told the annual meeting here yesterday.

A new rule of the Federal Maritime Commission imposing penalties on waterfront termidle loading and unloading of nal operators for failure to hantrucks expeditiously could cause a serious loss of business for the Port of New York, a waterfront labor official declared yesterday.
MOSCOW, May 20 -- President Nikolai V. Podgorny tonight joined the Mongolian leader, Yumzhagiin Tsedenbal in a joint denunciation of Communist China.

The wantonly destructive, terroristic attacks launched by the Communists in South Vietnam, primarily at innocent civilians i th heavily populated areas, is strongly indicative of what li s in store for the citizens of South Vietnam if the United States and other allies ontinu t participate in the Paris t lks (erroneously called peace negotiations) and agree to a cessation of military activity.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- President Nixon released today a comprehensive report on communications policy that President Johnson commissioned in 1967 but pigeon holed just before leaving the White House.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- President Nixon is scheduled to send to Congress next week a plan for turning the United States Post Office into a public corporation. Mr. Nixon briefed Congressional leaders on the project this morning. The conversion will require Congressional approval.
DENVER, May 20 -- Conservatives dedicated to the defeat of one of the nation's most ambitious school integration plans tonight won two controlling seats on the Denver Board of Education.

EIGHTEEN months ago, Edwin (Eddie) Goodman decided that there was more to life than working in his father's store. So he left Bergdorf Goodman and Event to work helping small businessmen get started in Bed-ford-Stuyvesant.

IN THE ASHAU VALLEY, South Vietnam, May 20 -- American paratroops and South Vietnamese forces drove the North Vietnamese from Apbia Mountain today and pursued the enemy toward Laos, little more than a mile away.
One stockholder remarked sotto voce yesterday at the annual meeting of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation that a motion picture ought to be made about the company's stockholder session.

Now that the city authorities have acted to insure that tenants in uncontrolled apartments will pay fair rents, they should also make provision for fair treatment for landlords of controlled buildings.

The old pugnacious Kennedy spirit is beginning to be heard again in the Senate. Less than a year since the death of his brother Robert (June 6), Senator Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts is emerging as the most outspoken political critic of the Nixon Administration.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 20 -- Unease and resentment are Spreading at Harvard University over the appointment of a special committee to investigate "possible misconduct" of teaching staff members during the recent disorders.

The last time the New York Yankees played the Athletics, in Oakland 10 days ago, they gave the proceedings a clownish aspect by making eight errors in three games, five of them in one inning. Last night in Yankee Stadium, they confined their clowning to the clubhouse after a 2-1 victory that stretched their winning streak to six games.

ATHENS, May 20 -- Stavros Niarchos, the Greek shipping man, today defeated his rival, Aristotle S. Onassis, in the second round of their latest contest, in which the prize will be a lucrative Greek oil-refinery concession.

It was a great night for two-hit games in baseball, especially by pitchers trying to prove a point. Sam McDowell threw one as Cleveland defeated Kansas City, 4-1, and Tony Cloninger threw another as Cincinnati shackled Philadelphia, 4-0.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Secretary of the Treasury David M. Kennedy urged Congress today to enact the Administration's anti-inflationary tax program promptly, without trying to add major tax reforms to it.

Mayor Lindsay's discovery of $79.7-million in additional revenues, which the Mayor said ended the city's fiscal crisis, was in the best tradition of buried treasures suddenly unearthed by Mayors, Governors and even Presidents.
WASHINGTON, May 2O -- The Federal Trade Commission proposed a regulation today that would require all forms of cigarette advertisements to carry the warning that cigarette smoking "may cause death."
As a life-long Republican I should like to take issue with the party chiefs who are urging the President to "Think Republican'' in the choi e of new members of the Supreme Court.

TRENTON, May 20 (AP) -- The New Jersey Assembly ignored a plea from Gov. Richard J. Hughes today and postponed until after the summer recess action on bills designed to strengthen the powers of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor to deal with organized crime.

John Doar, in his ninth and final month as president of the Board of Education -- a span of time so short really that a man should just now be sorting out his goals and philosophies -- said yesterday that it had been a period of "strenuous experience'' but one that convinced him that the city and its school system were governable.

The program last night at the Whitney Museum of American Art was devoted to two musical works by Philip Glass and a film -- actually three films -- by Richard Serra. Taken together, they added up to an evening of immense uneventfulness.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday the closing of an incinerator in Queens that "has thrown up into the air of New York 3.5 tons of dirt every working day" since it went into operation in 1937.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- A Congressman and a scientist called today for a ban on military tests that would release poison gases into the air and disease-causing germs into the environment.

VIENTIANE, Laos, May 20 -- Prince Souvanna Phouma, the Laotian Premier, called today for an early end of the war in Laos, saying it would allow him and his Government to take a vigorous role in the search for peace in Vietnam.

The election of H. Prentice Browning as vice chairman of the board of the National Bank of North America, effective June 1, was announced yesterday. He formerly was president of the American Fletcher National Bank and Trust Company of Indianapolis.
Majestic Prince apparently will get to run in the Belmont Stakes after all.

BANGKOK, Thailand, May 20 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers reaffirmed today United States assurances that if the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization declined to act to protect an Asian member from attack, the United States was ready to give assistance on its own.

GREEN BAY, Wis., May 20 (UPI) -- Jerry Kramer, star Green Bay Packers' guard, has announced his retirement from professional football in an unusual way -- by titling his new book "Jerry Kramer's Farewell to Football."

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, May 20 -- The Rhodesian Prime Minister, Ian D. Smith, announced tonight that the "intractable attitude" of the British Government had ended all hope of a negotiated settlement of the dispute over his country's seizure of independence.

Gordon E. Crosby Jr., chairman and president of the USLIFE Corporation, told stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday that he ex pected 1969 earnings to exceed the company's stated objective of a 12 per cent annual average.
The First National City Corporation charged yesterday that the American consumer has been the forgotten man in the debate over control of one-bank holding companies.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Army dropped all court martial charges today against the last three of eight antiwar soldiers at Fort Jackson, S. C., who were originally charged two months ago with "the serious offense" of speaking out publicly against the war in Vietnam.

The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it had signed an agreement with the Bunker-Ramo Corporation under which Bunker-Ramo would provide desk-top terminal equipment for the exchange's new block automation system.
A subway passenger who reportedly attacked a transit patrolman with a metal pipe was shot and killed by the policeman last night.
" We're all human and we all make mistakes, even the men who make Rolls-Royce."

MILAN, Italy, May 20 -- With $5.4-billion of monetary reserves, an aggressive export industry and recent international payments surpluses averaging more than $500-million a year, Italy is coming under increasing external pressure to raise the value of the lira.

Despite the rain, the local qualifying round for the New Jersey area to decide 16 places in the United States Open qualifying round was completed yesterday. The 16 qualifiers will automatically be eligible for the sectional trials on June 3.

RUFUS PARNELL JONES was a tough kid in a tough suburb of Los Angeles. He enjoyed fights -- anybody, any time. His family was poor. He was a high-school dropout with vague objectives. His best job was as a cement finisher.

The city's Department of Consumer Affairs announced yesterday that it was preparing a regulation that would require supermarkets and some retail stores to label merchandise they sell with the cost for an ounce or a pound in addition to the total price.
About 1,500 people are expected at a party on Monday to raise money "to keep New York City cool this summer."
Madison Square Garden, where the seating capacity is set by Fire Department laws, hooked into cable television yesterday and expanded its viewing capacity as well as treasury.

Three Democratic candidates for Mayor denounced Robert F. Wagner and Controller Mario A. Procaccino yesterday for refusing to participate in free public service television debates, thereby cutting off a televised discussion of the issues to all candidates.
Prices lost more ground yesterday in light trading on the American Stock Exchange.
Formal plans for a six-story office building in Harlem have been filed with the city's Buildings Department more than two years after the project was announced by Mayor Lindsay.
CAIRO, May 20 -- The United Arab Republic and Israel waged a war of words today over whether Israeli commandos attempted to cross the Suez Canal before dawn last Wednesday.
HOUSTON, May 20 -- The National Aeronautics and Space Administration took Senator Edward M. Kennedy to task today for his call for a slowdown in the space program.
CANNES, France, May 20 -- As the 22d International Film Festival at Cannes approaches its close Friday night, it becomes increasingly difficult to distinguish fantasy from fact.

ULAN BATOR, Mongolia, May 19 -- Premier Yumzhagiin Tsedenbal has expressed deep concern over the maintenance of peace in Asia, particularly in view of the continuance of the war in Vietnam, tensions over Korea and the Soviet-Chinese conflict.
ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L. I., May 20 -- After it was all over, the consensus was that Carlo Bergonzi, Guarneri del Gesu and Antonio Stradivari know what they were doing.

Peter Paul, Inc., announced yesterday it had agreed to acquire Helme Products, Inc., for approximately $61-million in stock, and the National General Corporation said it was no longer interested in acquiring the Parvin-Dohrmann Company.
Following are highlights of the remainder of the Apollo 10 flight plan. The schedule is subject to change at any time during the mission. Times are Eastern Daylight.

MASON, Mich., May 20 -- A small pistol, similar to the one it has been admitted was fired in the Algiers Motel during the Detroit riots in 1967, was loaded with a blank cartridge today and fired in the high-ceilinged chamber where a Detroit policeman is being tried for the murder of a Negro.

The Duke and Duchess of Windsor are honorary patrons of an exhibition of 18th-century Doccia Porcelain of Ginori and a dinner at the Parke-Bernet Galleries on Monday to benefit the Arciconfraternita di Misericordia di San Miniato.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., May 20 (AP) -- A jury of four women and eight men decided today that an Illinois manufacturer of birth control pills was free of any guilt in the death of a South Bend woman.
Critics of advertising, more numerous, it seems, than the birds of the air, tend to forget how the craft helps to enrich the language.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 20 -- The chalk-player -- the punter who looks with favor on favorites -- will cheer today's announcement that he will be able to wager on Rum Customer in Friday night's Realization Pace at Roosevelt Raceway.
HOUSTON, May 20 -- Man may not live by bread alone, but to an astronaut on his way to the moon a simple slice of rye can stir enough joy to feed his psyche as well as his stomach.

Under heavy pressure from the City Council, Mayor Lindsay has suddenly found $79.7 million to ameliorate the harshest cuts in the $6.6-billion city budget he proposed last month. The relief New Yorkers will feel at the discovery will be mixed with bewilderment at this sudden revelation.
In a normal year, David Washer would much rather be working on his employer's horse farm in Southern Pines, N. C., than riding jumpers here.

The Plumstead Playhouse, a nonprofit producing organization that began last season at the Mineola (L. I.) Theater, will try to make it to Broadway in the autumn. Stars lined up so far include Henry Fonda in "The Time of Your Life," Robert Ryan in " J. B." and possibly Robert Preston and Lauren Bacall in "Idiot's Delight."
Short interest on the New York and American Stock Exchanges declined in the month ended May 15. The decline occurred during a time when the stock market was in a strong rising phase.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The Democrats took their first step today toward framing a party political position with which to confront the Nixon Administration.

HOUSTON, Wednesday, May 21 -- Apollo 10 homed in on the moon early today, passing the point where lunar gravity began pulling the spaceship in for its planned orbit of the cratered earth satellite this afternoon.

Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn pressed an investigation yesterday to learn all details before making a decision regarding stock purchases by Charles Finley and three Atlanta Braves' owners involving Las Vegas gambling casinos.
The Nixon Administration endorsed in principle yesterday a plan to form a multibillion company to finance "big ticket" export items such as jet aircraft, computers and the like.

President Nixon's scheduled meeting with President Thieu on June 8 at Midway will put to the test the "close working relationship with Saigon" to which Mr. Nixon referred in his Vietnam address last week. The results of their discussion will have a crucial bearing on the Paris peace talks.

FLORENCE, S. C., May 20 -- Witnesses for the Federal Government testified today that they could recall no provocation for shots fired by state troopers into a group of Negro college students in February, 1968.

BERKELEY, Calif., May 20 -- A National Guard helicopter swooped over the University of California today and dropped a white, skin-stinging powder on several hundred students, faculty members and "people's park" demonstrators.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., May 20 -- Three teams, one of them helped by a hole-in-one, tied for first place today in the final round of the 17th annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Asssociation better-ball championship at the Crestmont Country Club.
There's a ship arriving here today loaded with 8,500 tons of Columbian sugar that may influence the spot price. So far, the dealer who owns the cargo has not found a home for it with a refiner.

SINGAPORE, May 20 -- The Communist-owned Bank of China has been ordered to increase its reserves and to obey other sections of the banking laws by tomorrow night or face the loss of its links to other banks through the clearing house here.

Governor Rockefeller's first round of talks in Latin America has illustrated both the advantages and the liabilities inherent in the kind of mission he has undertaken for President Nixon. It is doubtful that in visiting seven countries in nine days either Mr. Rockefeller or any of the twenty specialists accompanying him discovered anything very new about Latin problems or Latin attitudes toward the United States.
Dr. Joseph J. Copeland, acting president of City College, scheduled the resumption of classes today. They were called off Monday and yesterday in the continuing dispute with minority-group students.

CHICAGO, May 20 (UPI) -- The University of Chicago, once a football power and a charter member of the Big Ten, but without a football squad since 1939, will again field a team for the 1969-70 season, officials announced today.
Roy Wilkins of the N.A.A.C.P. said recently that the war in Nigeria is an example of the propensity of the dominant black man to be as bloody, cruel and stupid as the dominant white man.

Assistant Secretary of the Interior Carl T. Klein says he wants to expedite the clean-up of the nation's filthy waterways. So he's going to abandon the Federal Government's most effective existing weapon against the polluters -- public water pollution abatement hearings.

Cook United, Inc., formerly the Cook Coffee Company, said yesterday that it did not agree with a Justice Department position that the company should dispose of some of its stores as a condition to a proposed merger with Gray Drug Stores, Inc.
Now that his brief career as an intermediate hurdler has ended, Bob Seagren can concentrate on the two most important issues in his life, an 18-foot pole vault and a syndicated television show.

As if the titles executive vice president and creative director weren't enough, Jerry Birn, of Tatham-Laird Kudner, has now been raised to chief executive officer of the New York office. The 45-year-old Mr. Birn succeeds C. R. (Chuck) Stan-den, 52, board chairman of the agency.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, May 20 (AP) -- West Germany's gold and convertible currency reserves soared to a record $9.84-billion in the week ended May 14 during speculation on revaluation of the mark, the Bundesbank reported today. The figure reflects an increase of nearly $2.87-billion over reserves of $6.97-billion a week earlier.
TANGIER, Morocco -- When a young New York woman has been used to supermarkets, refrigerators and hot and cold running water, how does she cope without such conveniences?
Two members of a Cuban nationalist group were arrested by the Federal Bureau of Investigation in New Jersey early yesterday for allegedly plotting to bomb several buildings and ships in Montreal.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, May 20 (Reuters) -- Deputy Prime Minister Abdul Razak assumed responsibility today for the Malaysian economy, adding to his task of restoring law and order to a nation wracked by a week of racial violence between Chinese and Malays.

More than 100 aviation leaders paid tribute yesterday to Igor I. Sikorsky, aeronautical pioneer and founder of Sikorsky Aircraft, at a testimonial luncheon held by the Wings Club in the Biltmore Hotel.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The head of the National Coal Association acknowledged today that he and other mining industry executives "suggested" to Senator Jennings Randolph many of the key provisions in a controvereial mine safety bill that the West Virginia Democrat introduced last week.
CAN it be that back-office woes are plaguing one of the nation's most successful fund operations? Norman Dacey thinks so.
HOUSTON, May 20 -- The space agency said today that, contrary to some newspaper and television reports, no crew had been selected for the Apollo 13 flight next year.

TRENTON, May 20 -- The president of the New Jersey state conference of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People announced today that the conference had "strongly condemned" Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr., a leading candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor, on charges of racial discrimination.
As faculty members and administrators at Queensborough Community College, we cannot permit to go unanswered the inaccurate and irresponsible letter which apeared in The Times of May 14.
HONG KONG, May 20 (Agence France-Presse) -- China today accused Malaysia's leaders of causing large-scale bloodshed and of directing attacks on the Malaysian citizens of Chinese descent.

MOSCOW, May 20 -- The 14th game of the world chess championship between the titleholder, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, and his Soviet challenger, Boris Spassky, was drawn today. The challenger offered a draw 13 moves after adjournment on move 56 and it was accepted.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., May 20 -- The Apollo 11 space vehicle that is to land two Americans on the moon in July was eased today out of the 52-story-tall building where it had been assembled and gingerly trundled three and a half miles to its launching pad.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The charming lady who welcomes newcomers to the community with gifts from local merchants may have hidden motives -- notably the collection of information for a credit bureau.
JACKSON, Miss., May 20 -- All eight Negroes seeking aldermanic posts in today's municipal Democratic runoffs in Mississippi appear to have been defeated on the basis of nearly complete returns.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 20 -- This could be the year that Indonesia proves itself the hottest oil reservoir east of the Persian Gulf. Optimistic forecasts are coming in daily from surveys throughout the archipelago. Both onshore and offshore work have yielded significant discoveries in oil, which already accounts for 40 per cent of Indonesia's foreign exchange.

State Senator John J. Marchi asked the Board of Elections yesterday to remove former Police Chief Inspector Sanford D. Garelik, a Democrat, from Mayor Lindsay's ticket for City Council President in the Republican primary.

Frank De Paula, the 29-year-old light-heavyweight boxer from Jersey City, was arrested yesterday with his manager and three other men by the Federal Bureau of Investigation on charges of stealing $80,000 worth of electrolytic copper bars from a Port Newark pier.

With a member of the National Mediation Board here to give assistance, negotiations continued yesterday in an effort to avert a possible strike after midnight tonight by 1,600 members of the United Transportation Union against the Long Island Rail Road.
Interest rates, pushed up by a large supply of new issues and also by more talk about a prime rate increase, moved sharply higher yesterday. Tax-exempt bond yields topped 6 per cent.

Milton Friedman startled Europe recently. What he said was not exactly new. For almost two decades, he had been calling for floating exchange rates. But most people, in the United States as well as in Europe, looked upon the matter as a Rubicon yet to be crossed. He said we were already there.

A $79.7-million increase in next year's city budget -- enough to provide full operation of libraries and museums and to restore some projected cuts in hospitals, schools and colleges -- was assured yesterday.

Eight young leaders of the Students for a Democratic Society at Columbia University went on trial in State Supreme Court yesterday, charged with having violated a court order three weeks ago banning any disruptive demonstrations on the Morningside campus. Justice Charles Marks is presiding.

About three-fourths of the two-hour annual meeting yesterday of the American Broadcasting Companies, Inc. was usurped by two regular meeting-goers. They were among a handful of stockholders who addressed Leonard H. Goldenson, president of the diversified entertainment company.
NATIONAL Director, since 1960, of the Migration Division of the Puerto Rico Department of Labor, an office maintained here to help Puerto Ricans adjust to the communities in which they live and work.
Three members of the new interim Board of Education were appointed yesterday by the Borough Presidents of the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens.

GBODJOME, Togo, May 18 -- Gbodjome is a village of 1,800 people, dozens of mud huts, an indeterminate number of sheep, chickens and ducks, a little yellow schoolhouse, a great deal of sand and two broad, leafy asiti trees.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Attorney General John N. Mitchell strongly advised Congress today not to pass new laws to handle campus disorders.

PARIS, May 20 -- Alain Poher, the front runner in the race for the French presidency, called today for a re-examination of France's relations with the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and declared himself opposed to a unilateral arms embargo in the Middle East.

NEWARK, May 20 -- A massive effort was undertaken in Newark today to head off a repetition of the violence and looting that erupted last night following the fatal shooting of a 17-year-old youth by a policeman.

A 21-year-old patrolman facing a departmental trial tomorrow because a prisoner escaped from him last week, recaptured the subject yesterday near Brooklyn Police Headquarters after an eight-day search.
The London stock market resumed a downward drift yesterday as share prices dipped on a broad front.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, May 21 -- The battle for Apbia Mountain, which is designated Hill 937, was part of a 10-day-old operation south of the Ashau Valley. A United States Army spokesman explained today that the operation was intended to clear the Vietnamese infiltration routes.

ABOUT three weeks before the season ended last year, Danny Cater of Oakland and Carl Yastrzemski of Boston were the batting leaders in the American League at .289. It was the first time that the Athletics' batsman began to get the fancy idea that he might win the hitting title, even at such reduced figures.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 20 -- The Saigon Government closed three more daily newspapers today on charges of undermining the national war effort.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- Spokesmen for independent oil producers testified today that a higher price for domestic crude oil is necessary if output and reserves are to keep pace with rising demand.

GENEVA, May 20 -- The United States has suggested an agreement to the Soviet Union under which Japan and seven other countries would be admitted to the Geneva Disarmament Conference when it begins its summer session July 3.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- The chairman of the House Appropriations Committee added his voice today to Congressional criticism of the Pentagon by protesting that the military was impairing public confidence by its "many mistakes."
When Miss Marion Thiesen left the city's public school system after more than 30 years as a teacher and principal, the first item on her agenda was a summer vacation in Denmark.

Second-quarter results of Deere Co. continued to lag behind those of a year ago, but in the six months ended April 30 earnings more than doubled those of the 1968 period, William A. Hewitt, chairman, reported yesterday from Moline, Ill., headquarters.

Governor Rockefeller, who returned Monday night from the first of his four fact-finding trips to Latin America, said yesterday that his purpose was to develop an inter-American program that the United States Congress would support.
THE Passion Play seen through the eyes of hippie philosophy is what Aldo Giunta has in mind. The Christ figure is cheapened and only the spirit of hippiedom emerges as beautiful -- although insane.

BALTIMORE, May 20 (AP) -- Carroll Rosenbloom, owner of the Baltimore Colts, threatened today to build his own stadium and meanwhile play home games in other cities next season unless Baltimore commits itself to improve Memorial Stadium.
WASHINGTON, May 20 (AP) -- The White House said today that it was not unusual for a nonprofit, private foundation to raise funds for a Presidential library while a President was still in office.

The president of the Greyhound Corporation, Gerald H. Trautmam, told the annual meeting in Detroit yesterday that he still held hopes for controlling Armour Co. At present, Greyhound owns about 33 per cent of Armour's stock and the other suitor, the General Host Corporation, has about 57 per cent.
Two years ago, at the age slim, philosophical student of 24, Ray Burrows, a who chooses his words carefully, read a book and realized he had "an identity crisis."
Shabuoth, the Jewish commemoration of the giving of the Ten Commandments, will start at sundown tomorrow with observances in temples and synagogues.

WASHINGTON, May 20 -- There was Gen. William C. Westmoreland in full uniform on the sidelines, with 10 rows of ribbons, 4 stars on either shoulder and scrambled eggs on his visor, facing jut-jawed into the setting sun.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 20 -- Robert Porter, Minister of Home Affairs, announced in Parliament today that local government elections, planned for next year, had been postponed until 1971. Then they will be held on the basis of universal franchise -- one man, one vote.

THE American Dance Season at the City Center Went into the homestretch last night when the Talley Beatty Dance Company opened the season's last and mixed week. The next days are to be shared between the Talley Beatty Company, the Pearl Lang Dance Company and the Donald McKayle Dance Company.
WASHINGTON, May 20 -- Judge Irving R. Kaufman of the United States Court of Appeals for the second circuit was installed today as president of the Institute of Judicial Administration.

John H. Shaffer, Federal Aviation Administrator, forecast yesterday that, despite Federal restrictions that would limit flights at five major airports beginning June 1, air travelers might have another summer of frustrating delays.
Patrick J. Cunningham, a 41-year-old lawyer who has been serving as treasurer of the Bronx County Democratic organization, was elected county leader by the executive committee yesterday.

HONG KONG, May 20 -- Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China was officially ranked third in the hierarchy today for the first time since the shuffle in top positions that accompanied the Communist party congress last month.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 20 -- The United Presbyterian Church will be asked in 1970 at its annual General Assembly in Chicago to approve a campaign to raise at least $50-million to be used "in depressed areas and among deprived people."

FREEHOLD, N. J., May 20 -- This rural town of 10,500 people was placed under a curfew tonight following hours of destructive violence last night that left scores of downtown plate glass windows shattered and two black youths wounded.

WASHINGTON -- American Negro soldiers in Vietnam used to consider the war and the civil rights movement as separate things but the past three years have had an exacerbating effect. For the first time black G.I.'s ask: "Why should I defend someone else's freedom if no one defends mine?"

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., May 20 -- The state police and the National Guard clamped a 9:15 P.M. curfew on the campus of Lincoln University tonight after a series of fires last night and this morning that half destroyed the student union building.

THERE are about 700 pieces in the exhibition of Nelson A. Rockefeller's collection of Mexican folk art opening today at the Museum of Primitive Art, 15 West 54th Street. The oldest and rarest and probably most valuable is a mask, possibly 18th century and certainly no later than the early 19th, that was used in Easter-Week ceremonies in Guerrero.

Investor disappointment over the lack of progress towards peace in Vietnam combined yesterday with worry over a possible rise in the prime lending rate to send stock prices thudding lower for the second straight day.

ALLEN KLEIN is regarded by some people in the pop music industry as a man of mystery. But all agree that the brash 37-year-old accountant is a man of great success. "Nobody is able to get answers from him," one industry observer said yesterday, but Mr. Klein apparently has the right answers for his clients.

Price reductions averaging 12 per cent were announced yesterday by E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., on Nomex nylon paper used for electrical insulation. Prices of Nomex yarn and staple sold for other applications are unchanged.
TEHERAN, Iran, May 17 -- Iran, still wary, is growing increasingly relaxed about her developing relationships with the Soviet Union and Soviet-bloc states of Eastern Europe.

NEWARK, May 20 -- Detective George Thomas Jr., paunchy and graying at his temples, pointed to the street through the second-story squad and apartment buildings seen room window of Newark's Fourth Precinct station and said: "I've been on the force 14 years and it's a bitch out there."

BALTIMORE, May 20 (AP) -- Counsel for Howard (Buddy) Jacobson obtained an injunction today enjoining the Maryland Racing Commission from suspending the owner-trainer's license pending a May 27 court hearing.

George A. Spater, president of American Airlines, Inc., informed stockholders at their annual meeting in Wilmington, Del., yesterday that in addition to the $19.8-million of strike benefits paid to it by other airlines during February and March, the company had received another $700,000 in April.
A New York City fireman was shot to death early yesterday in a freakish accident growing out of a routine response to a minor fire.

Four cadets of the United States Military Academy, including the grandson of a World War II general, are being disciplined for using a telephone credit card number that they were told belonged to the radical Students for a Democratic Society.
LONDON, May 21 -- Britain tonight won agreement from Robert Bradshaw, Prime Minister of the Associated State of St. Kitts-Nevis-Anguilla, to have a commission consider the status of Anguilla.

A man described as a "high lieutenant in the Genovese Mafia family" was indicted yesterday with three other men on charges of conspiring to pay a bribe to a customs agent to pass pornographic literature into the United States.

The Lindsay administration has overruled community leaders in the Harlem-East Harlem and South Bronx Model Cities programs who drafted plans that would have given local residents, and not the city, ultimate control over millions of dollars in Federal funds.

To the Editor: United States evenhandedness in the Middle East seems totally unrealistic in the face of the vigorous Soviet-Arab alliance and Arab shiftiness. Since Arab mentality feeds itself on many distorted concepts, including tile image of the U.S., what can the U.S. ever expect from Arab countries?

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, May 21 (Reuters) -- Malaysia is rapidly returning to normal after racial strife, Government officials said tonight. But although curfew restrictions were relaxed, the authorities announced new censorship measures.

In another dazzling display of technological virtuosity, Apollo 10 went into orbit around the moon precisely on schedule yesterday afternoon. For the second time in history, human beings are journeying about earth's cratered satellite, reconnoitering the lunar surface to gain information essential for the landing that is planned barely eight weeks away.
JERSEY CITY, May 21 (AP) -- About 50 students staged another sit-in today at St. Peter's College despite the court-ordered arrests of 44 sit-ins, including three priests, earlier in the day.
" I feel so helpless after seeing this kind of film," the young black girl said. "My only answer is to go out and buy a gun."

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits, continuing to goad the Nixon Administration, urged the President today to reorder national priorities away from building what he called "limitless" military power and toward restoring "domestic tranquility."

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Radical changes in the anti-trust laws that would permit the Government to break up large companies that dominate an industry have been recommended by a group of noted lawyers and economists.
HOUSTON, May 21 -- The Apollo 10 astronauts swung into an orbit of the moon today and were set for tomorrow's critical maneuvers taking men to within nine miles of the lunar surface.

WASHINGTON, May 22 -- Western diplomats say they have detected signs that the Soviet Union may be preparing to press Arab countries to be more flexible on the issue of direct talks with Israel as part of a Mideast settlement.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Dr. Herbert L. Ley Jr., Federal Commissioner of Food and Drugs, insisted today that the Government lacked sufficient evidence to ban the sale of Chemical Mace and similar sprays to the public as dangerous.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- The Justice Department filed suit today seeking to prevent the acquisition of the B. F. Goodrich Company by Northwest Industries, Inc. Goodrich has, itself, been fighting the takeover.
Leopold Stokowski, the conductor and founder of the American Symphony Orchestra, was given an award last night by the New York University's Washington Square College Alumni Association.

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that although Mayor Lindsay was his personal choice for re-election he would not actively support him in the primary and would support his Republican-Conservative opponent if he won the primary election.

The Federation of International Archives began its first meeting in this country since 1938 at the Museum of Modern Art yesterday. But the chances are that it may never convene here again.
The United States Olympic Committee broadened its base yesterday by selecting for the first time five at-large members, two of them Negro, to the board of directors.
LONDON, MAY 21 -- The state-owned British Steel Corporation will be permitted to raise its prices by an average of 5 per cent, the Government announced today.

A 42-year-old confidence man was convicted yesterday in Federal Court here of defrauding colleges and high schools of more than $50,000 by falsely representing he could provide entertainment by well-known show-business personalities.

BERKELEY, Calif., May 21 -- Aroused members of the University of California faculty, protesting yesterday's aerial tear-gas attack on hundreds of students, began a boycott of classes today on the Berkeley campus.

IF they ever get around to giving an award for the dirtiest play of the season (perhaps they could be called "The Smelly Awards") I should imagine "Philosophy in the Boudoir," which opened at the Gramercy Arts Theater last night, would stand a fair chance of winning.
NEWCASTLE - UPON - TYNE, England, May 21 (AP) -- Twenty-two persons were injured in fights on the field that interrupted a semi-final soccer match in the Inter Cities Fair Cup tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- Officials in Washington were heartened by reports that President Eduardo Frei Montalva of Chile had forecast a negotiated settlement of his Government's dispute with American copper companies over renegotiation of contracts.
WASHINGTON, May 21 -- New orders for durable goods rose $1.2-billion in April to a record of $30.9-billion, the Department of Commerce reported today.
MORRISTOWN, N. J., May 21--Miss Barbara Blossom Wells and James P. Kenney will be married Aug. 23.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP) -- Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court has been receiving fees of $500 a day when he participates in seminars at a second foundation that he heads.
It may look like a hamburger, absorb catchup like a hamburger and even taste like a hamburger, but what's being sold in some city restaurants may not be a hamburger at all.

FLORENCE, S. C., May 21 -- Government witnesses testified today that state troopers fired without warning and without being fired upon into a group of Negro students last year, killing three and wounding at least 30 others.
MOSCOW, May 21 -- The Soviet Union today demonstrated publicly for the first time the TU-144, its supersonic airliner.

The New York chapter of the American Jewish Committee charged yesterday that Jews were being excluded from more than 100 cooperative apartment houses in Manhattan, mostly on the fashionable upper East Side.

SAIGON, South Vietnam -- Ho Nhan Hieu is a thirty-year-old Vietnamese who has spent much of the last fifteen years either agitating against various South Vietnamese governments or in jail for political action. Small and wiry, quick to smile, capable of halting English, Hieu has hard brown eyes and a stubborn determination to keep on struggling for the kind of Vietnam he believes in.
LONDON, May 21 -- United States Senator George S. McGovern today warned an international conference on racism that time was fast running out for the white privileged nations and churches.

Mayor Lindsay offered an invitation yesterday for the powerful State Urban Development Corporation to work in eight renewal areas here. The Mayor, who had fought the urban agency bitterly a year ago, made it clear that he favored the operation of the Development Corporation in the city only with severely limited authority.

Some people send religious medals to Bill Robinson and other people boo him. The Yankee outfielder gave credit to both sides last night after he hit a pair of triples and the Yankees defeated Oakland, 6-5, in the 11th inning to run their winning streak to seven games.
LONDON, May 21 -- Prime Minister Wilson told leaders of the Trades Union Congress today that his Government's fate could depend on passage of his proposed bill to curb wildcat strikes.

HOUSTON, May 21 -- "I guess there is something about physics we don't understand," said Col. Thomas P. Stafford, commander of the Apollo mission to the moon, as he discussed with flight controllers on the distant earth efforts to rid the spacecraft's drinking water of gas bubbles.

About $223-million was siphoned out of the Central Harlem, South Bronx and Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant districts of the city last year by policy bankers and heroin peddlers, it was estimated yesterday by State Senator John H. Hughes of Syracuse, chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Crime.

CHICAGO, May 21 -- Mayor Richard J. Daley met today with members of the school board and representatives of the Chicago teachers union in an eleventh-hour effort to avert what would be Chicago's first teachers strike against the public school system. A strike is set for 6 A.M. tomorrow.
Mayor Lindsay and Bronx Borough President Herman Badillo will hold the top positions on the June 17 primary ballot for the Republican and Democratic nominations for Mayor.
The New York State Athletic Commission has reserved decision on Frank De Paula's status until today.

A nonsectarian Institute for Advanced Studies in the Humanities has been established to bring the vast untranslated texts of the Talmud, the Commentaries on it and the works of the great post-Biblical Jewish philosophers into the main-stream of modern scholarship.

The theme was upbeat at the annual meeting of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation yesterday in Beverly Hills, Calif., as the company reported on dividends, sales, earnings, foreign oil concessions and the prospects for a new free-trade zone.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 21 -- President Eduardo Frei Montalva indicated today that the Chilean Government intended to obtain at least part ownership of the huge copper mines of the Anaconda Company in this country.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -- More people than the crossworders were puzzling tonight whether Warren Earl Burger would be the reverse of Earl Warren and whether his tenure as Chief Justice would see a reversal of the Warren Court's landmark libertarianism.

PHILADELPHIA, May 21 -The outcome of a proxy fight for control of the Curtis Publishing Company, which was supposed to have been resolved here today, will not be known until Friday afternoon, when the annual stockholders meeting of Curtis will be reconvened.
A gentle appeal for artists to use their creative insights to save man from emotional decay marked a gathering here yesterday of hundreds of members of the art and literary world.

Trading volume perked up yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, and prices edged ahead.

ATHENS, May 21 (AP) -Nancy Richey polished off her opponent in 20 minutes today as the United States women's tennis team began a challenge for the Federation Cup with a three-match sweep of Yugoslavia.

The chances are that Chicago will never have an other Berwanger, who won the first Heisman Trophy as 1935's outstanding player.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 21 (AP) -- The battalion of United States paratroops that seized Apbia Mountain yesterday was pulled out for a rest today, and another battalion was flown in to meet any North Vietnamese counterattack from Laos.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, May 22 -- The United States command said this morning that the fight for Apbia Mountain in the northwest part of South Vietnam "may well have been another battle of Hue," the old imperial capital, some 30 miles to the east.

Scotti still obliged to complain that law enforcement agencies get scant cooperation from either industry or labor in their efforts to eradicate criminal infiltration.

DETROIT, May 21 (AP) -- "I've always liked the underdog and I think I'm going to enjoy it here," Bill van Breda Kolff said today as he switched National Basketball Association coaching jobs -- from the successful Los Angeles Lakers to a perennial loser, the Detroit Pistons.

WASHINGTON, May 21 -The Federal Reserve Board has decided against exempting export credits from the program limiting bank loans to foreigners, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTO,N May 21 (UPI) -- Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the nation's new Education Commissioner, said today the Federal Government "must do more than simply give grants" to improve the educational system in the United States.

Representative George H. Mahon of Texas charged the other day that the United States military is under-mining public confidence by its many mistakes. The chairman of the House Appropriations Committee expressed concern about mistakes that cost money. Most Americans are even more concerned about mistakes that cost lives.

MADISON, Wis., May 21 (UPI) -- Bill Russell, player-coach of the Boston Celtics, said yesterday he thought Wilt Chamberlain "copped out in the last series, in the last game" of the National Basketball Association championship playoff between the Celtics and Los Angeles Lakers.

ATLANTA, May 21 -- The New York Mets, behind superlative Torn Seaver, got even tonight. They shut out the Atlanta Braves, the team with the best record in major league baseball, 5-0, and evened their season's won-lost record at 18-18.

The New York Life Insurance Company elected as its chairman and chief executive officer yesterday Charles W. V. Meares, a native of Britain who joined the giant insurer in 1923 as a $75-a-month clerk in the actuarial department.

Willie Mays, who observed his 38th birthday two weeks ago, gave this country's aging population a touch of splendor yesterday while his San Francisco Giants were defeating the St. Louis Cardinals, 4-3.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Seven of 11 microwave ovens puchased recently by the City of New York failled to meet radiation emission safety standards, according to Hanson latz, director of the City Office of Radiation Control.

The first settlement in critical bargaining involving 23 building trades in the city has been negotiated by the Glaziers Union and the plate glass dealers, providing a package of increases totaling $2.50 an hour over three years.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- The White House insisted today that increased American casualties in Vietnam -- including those of the 10-day battle for Apbia Mountain -- stemmed not from any changes in allied military tactics but from unusually intense enemy activity.

The New York and American Stock Exchanges issued this week their latest reports on changes in ownership by leading stockholders, directors and officers of listed companies. The lists include the following:

WEST SPRINGFIELD, Mass., May 23 -- Exactly one year after he won the title, Bob Foster of Silver Springs, Md., will defend his world light-heavyweight boxing championship tomorrow against Andy Kendall of Portland, Ore.

A producer of heating ducts, a phonograph record tape distributor and an operator of testing laboratories saw their shares score the best gains -- as much as 8 1/2 points -- among the companies that sold their shares publicly for the first time this week.

There is a heading on the first page of the April 29 Times, which invites correction. It reads: "President Adds to Mayors' Power in Urban Aid Plan." It relates to a "special" by John Herbers, in which he writes:
In a day-long distribution yesterday the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor handed out 424 applications to men who want to become checkers throughout the port.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, May 23 (AP) -- Prince Philip told a heckling student at Edinburgh University Friday night to "shut up and grow up."

MOSCOW, May 23 -- The 16th game of the world championship chess match between Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, the titleholder, and his Soviet challenger, Boris Spassky, ended in a draw after 32 moves today at Moscow's Variety Theater, according to Tass, the Soviet press agency.
Prices on the London stock market again sagged to new lows for the year yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, May 23 -- The threat of student demonstrations at the University of California at Los Angeles caused the curtailment of inauguration ceremonies today for the school's new chancellor. The curtailment canceled a speech by Robert H. Finch, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 22 -- The biting air of late autumn, laden with desperately needed rain, has tipped the stately poplars with gold and enlivened the shoppers, politicians, opera singers and even rioters in this slightly threadbare capital.

CAPETOWN, South Africa, May 23 (AP) -- Dr. Christiaan Barnard's wife, Aletta, sued for divorce today. She told the Capetown Supreme Court that the heart-transplant surgeon had left on a foreign trip in March and had said that he would never return to her.

BERKELEY, Calif., May 23 -- The Academic Senate at the University of California, Berkeley, agreed today to ask the Justice Department to investigate what it called "police and military lawlessness" during recent disorders on the Berkeley campus.
Oil stocks and oil-related issues provided the chief luster yesterday to a relatively drab stock market.

The Downtown-Lower Manhattan Association yesterday urged a southward extension of the projected Second Avenue subway to loop around the tip of Manhattan and terminate near the future Battery Park City on the West Side.

SALEM, N. J., May 23 -- Two Republican leaders warned today that racial charges against Representative Charles W. Sandman Jr. could cost their party the election for Governor if Mr. Sandman won in the Republican primary on June 3.

" ART," according to the admirable essay on that subject in the great 11th Edition of the Encyclopaedia Britannica, is "a word in its most extended and most popular sense meaning everything which we distinguish from Nature."

Two housing developments, a rehabilitation center for former narcotics addicts and a building for nocturnal animals in the Bronx Zoo were cited yesterday in the City Club of New York's annual Bard Awards for Excellence in Civic Architecture and Urban Design.
Trans World Airlines has appointed Melvin L. Milligan, its counsel since 1963, as the comsel since 1963, as the company's senior resident executive with Saudi Arabian Airlines.

ATLANTA, May 23 (UPI) -- Pete Brown, a 34-year-old journeyman golfer who is one of only a handful of Negro players on the pro tour, shot a six-under-par 66 today for a total of 135 and gained the second-round lead in the Atlanta Golf Classic by one stroke over Bob Shaw of Australia.
Four men were arraigned in Federal Court here yesterday on charges of possessing four million counterfeit 6 - cent stamps with a face value of $240,000.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -Congressional leaders moved today toward legislation that would require full public disclosure of personal financial interests for Federal public officials, including the judiciary.

WHEN Northwest Industries began trying to take over B. F. Goodrich, the railroad, steel and chemical holding company may not have reckoned with the ability of this pillar of the Establishment to react quickly by drawing on top public relations and legal talent to help its case.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Ralph K. Huitt has been appointed executive director of the National Association of State Universities and Land Grant Colleges, effective Jan. 1, 1970.
Another major corporation announced yesterday that it would deposit a substantial amount in Negro - owned banks to provide more money for black businesses.

Justice William O. Douglas has now belatedly resigned the presidency of the Albert Parvin Foundation which since 1962 has paid him approximately $12,000 annually in lieu of expenses. The Parvin Foundation's assets consisted initially of a first mortgage on the Hotel Flamingo in Las Vegas and subsequently, until a few months ago, of shares of stock in the Parvin-Dohrmann Company which owns three Las Vegas casinos.
MOSCOW, May 23 -- Representatives from nearly 60 Communist parties began making final plans today for the world Communist summit meeting due to open here on June 5.

" All my life," Mickey Lolich said after he had won three games in the World Series last year, "somebody else has been the big star and Lolich has been No. 2. I figured my day would come, and this is it."
Ellen Brooke often feels these days like a voice crying in the wilderness. Her complaint: Fashion designers are hurrying down a primrose path strewn with tinsel.
THE exhibition of Connecticut pewter at the New Haven Colony Historical Society offers a fresh view that proves 19th-century design is not all bad.
HOUSTON, May 23 -- Apollo 10 observations of the geology of the lunar surface appear to have raised new questions about the moon's origins.
DEVON, Pa., May 23 -- Lady Post never had any trouble getting a horse to jump.

WHITEHOUSE, N. J., May 23 -- Ch. Sarchell's Virginian, a golden red owned by Mr. and Mrs. William Dodd of Clifton, N. J., was best of variety and best of breed at the Cocker Spaniel Club of New Jersey's 32d specialty show tonight at Ryland Inn.
WASHINGTON, May 23 -- In the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals the following proceedings were held Thursday, May 22, 1969:

WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI) -- A Bronxville, N. Y., woman protesting United States involvement in the Vietnam war returned to the South Vietnamese Government today two medals awarded posthumously to her son.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (AP) -- Charles A. Lindbergh, "The Lone Eagle" of pioneer aviation, says that Robert H. Goddard, the rocket pioneer, told him in 1929 that a moon voyage was theoretically possible but economically improbable.
LONDON, May 23 -- A 23-year-old sergeant in the United States Air Force stole an American transport plane from a British air base early this morning and presumably crashed at sea.

HOUSTON, May 23 -- Tom Griffin, a 21-year-old fast-balling rookie right-hander, shackled the New York Mets' bats tonight and drove in three runs as the Astros, one of the hottest teams in major league baseball, completely mastered New York, 7-0, before 10,825 at the Astrodome.
The top management of a prominent insurance group showed dismay yesterday after its own lawyers threatened to join a truck drivers' union.

Rothmans of Pall Mall Canada, Ltd., said yesterday that directors had voted unanimously not to accept a bid from Philip Morris, Inc., for its holdings in Canadian Breweries, Ltd. "Further action will be determined by the turn of events," a statement issued by R. H. Hawkes, vice president and secretary of Rothmans said.
YONKERS, May 23 -- A yellow and white striped tent big enough to hold 300 persons will be set up on the grounds of the Leake Watts Children's Home here for a dinner dance Wednesday.

ATHENS, May 23 (Reuters) -- The United States scored two decisive singles victories and a close doubles triumph over Italy today and moved into the semi-final round of the women's Federation Cup team tennis competition.

LOS ANGELES, May 23 -- Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas has resigned his $12,000 a year post as president and director of the Albert Parvin Foundation.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 23 -- United States infantrymen killed 11 more North Vietnamese yesterday in scattered encounters around the base of Apbia Mountain overlooking the Ashau Valley.

PARIS, May 23 -- Interim President Alain Poher today remained the favorite to win the French presidential election, but the race looked closer than ever.

WASHINGTON, May 23 (UPI) -- The Nixon Administration, reacting to criticism that its approval of a Negroes-only black studies institute at Antioch College did "a serious disservice to the cause of racial integration,'' defended the action today as appropriate.

IT CERTAINLY was a rather down-in-the-mouth way to start a gala ballet evening at the Metropolitan Opera House with an audacious repeat of Roland Petit's totally meretricious "Pelleas and Melisande." At least I presume it was a down-in-the-mouth opening, for to be frank I arrived late and missed it.
The trial of eight leaders of the Students for a Democratic Society at Columbia University for criminal contempt of court ended yesterday.

RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, May 21 -- This nation remains calm as Gen. Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan, Commander in Chief of the armed forces and martial-law President, continues to move cautiously and almost silently in his efforts to stabilize conditions.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- A projected global communication system, outlined in a patent issued this week to the Raytheon Company, would send signals through a "whispering gallery" in the ionosphere.
ATHENS, May 23 -- Opponents of the Greek regime appeared today to be trying to undermine the country's prosperous tourist trade, now in full swing.

HOUSTON, May 23 -- The Apollo 10 astronauts took repeated bearings today on six carefully chosen lunar landmarks in an effort to minimize the extent to which the lunar module of Apollo 11 might miss its target in attempting to land on the moon next July.

A stockbroker, who formerly was manager of Bache Co.'s Fifth Avenue office, was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of perjury and making false statements to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

Concern over the rising cost of medical care, and advice that physicians avoid preoccupation with fees was expressed by the Undersecretary of Health, Education and Welfare, John G. Veneman, on a visit here yesterday.
ROME, May 23 -- A modern home for the permanent representative collection of Giacomo Manzu, noted Italian sculptor and close friend of the late Pope John XXIII, was inaugurated here yesterday.

Spreading glee among their supporters and confusion of a sort among their enemies, the New York Yankees won their eighth game in a row last night by beating the Minnesota Twins, 3-1, before 18,729 at Yankee Stadium.
The Decency Rally scheduled to take place at Shea Stadium on June 15 has been postponed for lack of funds.

CAPE KENNEDY, May 23 (UPI) -- The Air Force launched two advanced Vela radiation detection satellites into orbit today to watch for violations of the nuclear test ban and to report on any Communist Chinese nuclear explosions.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Mortgage interest rates rose to a record in April, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today. The average "effective" interest rate on conventional loans for new homes was 7.62 per cent in April, up from 7.47 per cent in March.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- President Nixon suddenly acquired today a 2,400-foot-long, one-piece painting that he does not have to fit into the White House. Instead, he can just look out the front window onto Pennsylvania Avenue and enjoy it from the premises.
LIMA, Peru, May 23 -- Peru decided today to expel the United States Army, Navy and Air Force missions and to reject the visit of President Nixon's special envoy, Governor Rockefeller.

CLINTON, N.Y., May 24 -- Kirkland College, newest of American nonsectarian women's colleges, will end its first school year on Tuesday with no problems except for the mud.

THE job pays only $10,000 a year, plus $5,000 for contingent expenses, and besides, it's on the bottom of the legislative totem pole. But three Manhattan residents are grappling for the Democratic nomination for councilman from New York City's Fourth District in the June 17 primary.

THE midnight cowboys squint in the afternoon light. A crowd of toughs shoves an old lady toward the window of a bookstore displaying the usual pictures of naked women. "Shocking! Lustful! Unusually excellent! -- Variety," blasts a movie marquee as the smell of custard and cheap perfume and onions fried in stale grease permeates the air.

PROSPECT, Ky., May 24 (AP) -- Mickey Wright of Dallas took a one-shot lead today over last year's tournament winner, Carol Mann of Buffalo, after 36 holes in the $15,000 Bluegrass invitation golf tournament.

Despite all of the various governmental and private programs for training the increasing number of black workers being hired by American business and industry, relatively little is being done to train the supervisors who have to deal with the special problems created by this new approach.

JACKSON, Miss., May 24 -- Democratic loyalists from Mississippi have called on a national Democratic reform committee to enforce party discipline on the state's Democratic delegation in Congress, which benefits from party seniority but refuses to ally with the national party.

LAGOS, Nigeria, May 24 -- Biafran aircraft flew over the federal Nigerian airfield at Benin just after dawn this morning, dropping bombs that are reported to have killed six persons and wounded eight.

CASSIS, France -- This little French fishing village, once a port of the Romans, is tucked into the first bay east of Marseilles. Blessed with the luminous light of Provence and surrounded by the spectacular cliffs and furrows, white beaches and blue waters of the Riviera coast, Cassis lives a serene existence.

One of the questions raised by the Fortas affair was whether Associate Justice William O. Douglas had acted just as improperly as Justice Abe Fortas in accepting $12,000 a year for his outside work as president and board member of the Parvin Foundation, an organization with interests in several Las Vegas gambling casinos. Last week, with Mr. Fortas gone from the Supreme Court, conservatives in Congress turned their guns on Justice Douglas.
TOO pretty to eat, flowering cabbage and flowering kale deserve space in summer flower beds. Their huge leafy heads look like gigantic full-blown roses.

NAHA, Okinawa -- Poor Okinawa! Torn between their powerful emotional desire for reversion to Japan and the remorseless forces of world confrontation, its people -- long the playthings of history -- may now be caught in a dilemma that some of its politicians refer to bitterly as "sweet potatoes or war."
THERE is no character named The.
A HOSPITAL is a big, scary place -- especially if you're little and away from Mummy and Daddy for the first time. But two little puppets can sometimes help change all that.

HONG KONG, May 24 -- Unity has become a dominant theme of press commentaries throughout Communist China, signaling a major effort by the Maoist victors of the Cultural Revolution to heal the wounds inflicted in three years of factional turmoil.

CLAY CITY, Ky. It is 6:45 P.M. on an unseasonably cold Saturday evening and 71 men sit impatiently in farm trucks, pickup trucks or automobiles pulling trailers, lined up on a lane just off the Hardwick Creek Road. Many of the men, already tired from working all day or driving hundreds of miles, turn to their families or girl friends and shake their heads.

MANY a glorious spring garden goes through a summer slump about mid-July which lasts well into August. Gardeners can remedy this no-color season by planting flowers that reach their peak after June blooms fade and before annuals really hit their stride.
TORONTO. "There is nothing economically or socially inevitable about the decay of cities." -- Jane Jacobs.

THE television season of 1968-69 is not likely to qualify as the electronic Renaissance; the level of staple and special programing provided only intermittent therapy for the drooping eyelid. Yet, within the semester just passed, there was a modicum of accomplishment and some developments were a credit to the running record of the home screen.

WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- For the first time in history, three University of Maryland seniors were designated as recipients tonight of the Sylvester Watch, an award given to the top athlete in the Terrapins' graduating class.

The impact of social and economic changes over the last 30 years on voluntary agencies serving disadvantaged Americans are assessed by Frederick M. Lewis, executive director of the Fresh Air Fund, in the 92-year-old charity's annual report.

FLORENCE, S. C., May 24 (UPI) -- An F. B. I. agent testified today that the campus police turned over to him Molotov cocktails and highly explosive phosphorus bombs after a confrontation between highway patrolmen and students at South Carolina State College last year.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 24 (AP) -- Desert Law, owned by William Haggin Perry, outdistanced the field in the $33,250 Milady Handicap at Hollywood Park today to win by three lengths.

LOS ANGELES, May 24 -- Thomas Bradley is now considered a slight favorite to be elected this city's first Negro Mayor on Tuesday, but his opponent, Mayor Samuel W. Yorty, has been swiftly closing the gap between them.

LOS ANGELES -- A group of professors from the University of California at Berkeley met with Gov. Ronald Reagan last Wednesday to protest the use of National Guardsmen against student demonstrators. Clearly agitated, the professors charged that Governor Reagan's hard-line tactics had precipitated the violence at Berkeley, which grew out of student attempts to build a "People's Park" on university-owned land.
WASHINGTON, May 24 (AP) -- President Nixon returned to the White House from Camp David, Md., this afternoon, then an hour later left for a cruise aboard the 104-foot yacht, U.S.S. Sequoia.

GRAND CANYON, Ariz. -- Running the big rapids of the Colorado River through the Grand Canyon is unlikely ever to become humdrum, no matter how often one does it. Yet, after a week on the river, we were all whitewater veterans and, if any of us felt timid about running Lava Falls rapids, none would admit it, even though Lava Falls was the biggest, loudest and most exciting of 100-odd cataracts we encountered.

A new miniature air-cushion runabout that can travel fast over land or water has been brought to the United States from Britain for the first time. Called the Hoverhawk, it will tour Florida and New Orleans, and then on Saturday, June 7, it will be demonstrated at Mamaroneck from 10 A.M. to noon and at Sands Point seaplane base, 15 Orchard Beach Boulevard, Port Washington, L.I. from 2:30 P.M. to 4:30 P.M.

CHICAGO, May 24 -- An effort is under way to get city councils in several major cities to take a strong stand for a quick end of the Vietnam war.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- W. Averell Harriman has proposed that the United States take the lead in stepping down the combat in Vietnam and bringing 50,000 soldiers home at once. He predicted that the enemy would follow the American examples.

Archbishop Stepinac, scoring in 14 of the 18 events, captured the team title for the second straight year yesterday in the track and field championship of the New York section of the Catholic High School Athletic Association.

THE alert, and lucky, Manhattan resident who hears an unfamiliar and melodious warble on his block this spring, has just been introduced to his new and sprightly avifauna neighbors, the house finches. The spread of these friendly and attractive birds into several parks, and even into some of the city's residential strets, is one of the nicer things happening in our city this year.

NUMEROUS proposals have been made in Washington to honor the late President Dwight David Eisenhower by the issuance of paper currency, a coin, or a medal bearing his portrait. When a person of such stature in Government life dies it has been customary to commemorate his achievements numismatically.

NEW DELHI, May 24 -- Secretary Rogers gave Indian leaders broad assurances today that the United States would step up its support of programs of economic development and regional cooperation in Asia after the Vietnam war.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 24 -- A. J. Foyt of Houston, the tough-talking three-time winner of the Indianapolis 500, got a good start toward a fourth victory today by winning the pole position for the 53d running of the race next Friday. Driving a Ford-powered Coyote of his own design, Foyt turned four laps of the 2 1/2-mile Indianapolis Motor Speedway oval at an average speed of 170.568 miles an hour.

HOUSTON -- Several times in recent days the medium of television has carried the residents of earth across 230,000 miles of space to the vicinity of the moon. Gene Marine, a reporter for The Nation and Ramparts, has written a lively account of a muckraker's voyage through the deteriorating landscape of modern America. SANTIAGO, Chile, May 21 -- Chile's Christian Democratic party, which won its mandate to govern in 1964, is being strained severely by dissident elements on the right and the extreme left.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association of New York has reported spending almost half a million dollars for promotion, advertising, lobbying and the expenses of its officers during the fiscal year ending June 30, 1968.

Arm trouble had forced him onto the disabled list late the previous season and so persisted into the winter that he even had difficulty in raising his arm to comb his hair. Was he washed up as a big league pitcher at the age of 26? He wondered as doubt gnawed deeply within him.

WEST POINT, N. Y., May 24 -- Age caught up with the Long Island Athletic Club's lacrosse team here today, as the defending club champions fell before Army, 10-9, in overtime. It was a rugged slashing battle that kept the more than 3,000 fans in their seats until the final gun.

HOUSTON, May 24 (AP) -- Eight years ago President Kennedy spoke the words that led to the nation's goal of landing men on the moon by 1970. There now appears to be little doubt that his hopes can be achieved -- with five months to spare.

Marian Rumsey has obviously seen a pond and a beaver at work and at play. She has glimpsed an otter and a mink, heard a scratch-scratch of a turtle, recoiled from a slithering garter snake. She also knows country dusk and darkness. It is her ability to convey the realism of nature which gives strength to this tale of a contest between a compassionate boy and a determined beaver in Oregon east of the Cascades.

PROBABLY because of their relationship to the odiferous chives, leeks, garlic, shallots and onions, alliums have been out of favor for some years. But the plants are beginning to be "discovered" and for good reasons. They are astonishingly beautiful in bloom.
