PRINCETON, N. J., May 24 -- Nearly one of every three college men and one of every four college women -- an over-all total of 28 per cent -- said they had "participated in a demonstration of some kind," according to a nationwide survey of 55 college campuses. The survey included interviews with 1,030 students.

Marya Mannes's "Manual for Survival" (Speaking of Books, April 27), addressed to the "dwindling" profession euphemistically called literary criticism, should be taken more seriously than her scathing wit implies.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 24 -- As the price of everything from a head of lettuce to a night's lodging continues to climb at a startling rate, a friendly but sharp debate rages among economists seeking the theoretical basis of the problem.

Don Rowe, a 20-year-old St. John's University junior, ran a 4:04 mile yesterday to qualify for the National Collegiate Athletic Association championships, and led the Redmen to victory in the 10th Crock o' Cheese track meet. St. John's, the home team, scored 74 points, while N.Y.U. and Fordham tied for second with 59 each.

BALTIMORE, May 24 (UPI) -- Elrod Hendricks's sacrifice fly with one out in the seventh inning tonight drove in Boog Powell with the run that gave the Baltimore Orioles a 2-1 victory over the Oakland Athletics.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 24 -- Howard Hughes, the industrialist, has expanded his buying spree here by buying the 10-year-old Paradise Valley golf course and country club for $2.25-million.

In a matchup presumably involving the American Football League's most spectacular players, Joe Namath and O.J. Simpson, the world champion New York Jets will open their 1969 season in Buffalo on Sept. 14. The league schedule was released yesterday by Milt Woodard, the A.F.L. president.

"Going Places" reveals Leonard Michaels as the abundant proprietor of what is commonly tossed around in academic circles as "awareness." He is aware, for instance, that too many people languish on the brink of oblivion -- but for him this is only the beginning.

GREAT FALLS, Mont. -- Although the proposed Safeguard antiballistic missile system is creating a national controversy, voters in this district where a site would be located are virtually ignoring the issue in favor of another one -- inflation.

WASHINGTON, May 24 -- Aristotle Socrates Onassis, the multimillionaire Greek businessman, strode into the office of a little-known Justice Department lawyer here 15 years ago after getting word that the Government might bring criminal charges against him.

ALBANY, May 24 -- Republican legislative leaders have announced the chairmen of the joint legislative committees for 1969-70. The number of committees has been reduced to 22 from 27, with appropriations reduced from $2.5-million to $2-million.

The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association, parent member of six other such organizations, held a two-day better-ball of partners championship last week at the Crestmont Country Club in West Orange, N. J.

The 43-year-old sculptor Ernst Neizvestny is probably the best known of the many "unofficial" artists who in recent years have challenged the official policies of the Soviet Government on matters of esthetic doctrine. Neizvestny's work has been widely reported on in the West.

ATHENS, May 24 (AP) -- The United States and Australia reached the final of the women's Federation Cup tennis competition today with 3-0 victories.

Since the Russian-born Mr. Kounovsky started standing women on their heads back in 1940, Kounovsky-ing has become a household word.
GREAT YARMOUTH, England -- The last of the herring boats has left Great Yarmouth, but the North Sea waters off this old Norfolk fishing port still teem with activity.

Mrs. Florence May Rice resigned last night as a member of Mayor Lindsay's Consumers Advisory Council in protest against the city's selection of experts to help fight the New York Telephone Company's bid for a $175-million rate rise.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 25 -- A yacht named The Hawk, with eight owners who did everything and no one was the boss, had everything done well enough for her to become the winner of the Larchmont Yacht Club's Edlu Trophy race today.
HUNTINGTON, L. I., May 25 -- In what a worried police detective said has "suddenly become a fad," vandals here have burned 37 parked automobiles in the last two weeks.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UPI) -- The Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield, said today that he would support legislation requiring all ranking government officials -- in the judicial, executive and legislative branches -- to disclose outside sources of income.

CAIRO, May 25 -- A group of middle-ranking military officers overthrew the shaky coalition Government in the Sudan this morning and designated a leftist, former Chief Justice Abubakr Awadallah, as Premier and Foreign Minister.

CAIRO, May 25 (Reuters) -- The Sudan's new Premier, 53-year-old Abubakr Awadallah has been involved in the stormy politics of the nation since 1954, when he was appointed Speaker of the Sudan's first National Parliament.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., May 25 -- Jim Bostwick put his golf game together well today and shot four under par for 30 holes to win easily the 37th annual Walter J. Travis invitation tournament, defeating Jim Maver, 5 and 4, in the final round at the Garden City Golf Club.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- So many extra people came to a Dejeuner sur l'Herbe today that the pates were eaten up and the committee running the party had to send out for pizza.

Representative Henry Helstoski of Bergen County, a liberal candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor of New Jersey, proposed a state educational opportunity tax yesterday during a televised debate with the five other Democratic candidates.

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, May 25 (Reuters) -- Policemen and snipers exchanged fire today and several stores and homes were burned as violence flared briefly in this capital where at least 167 persons have died in recent racial clashes.
ULAN BATOR, Mongolia, May 19 -- Tensions along Mongolia's frontier with Communist China have risen sharply in recent months, bringing a number of small flare-ups of violence.

Svetlana Beriosova, partnered by Donald MacLeary, danced her only Odette-Odile of the season in the Royal Ballet's "Swan Lake" at the Metropolitan Opera House Saturday evening. It was an occasion worth waiting for.
CHICAGO, May 25 -- A small band of antiwar demonstrators invaded Chicago's largest draft board office early this morning, burning Selective Service records and dumping tar and paint on files.

Two hundred Long Island Railroad passengers were delayed more than an hour last night after a train struck a garbage can.

THE biggest success in the world championship in Rio de Janeiro earlier this month was not the victory of the Italians, which was predictable, but the second place earned by the Nationalist Chinese team.

THE 11th game of the 24-game world title chess match between the champion, Tigran Petrosian of the Soviet Union, and his compatriot and challenger, Boris Spassky, was won by Petrosian after 56 moves of a Queen's Indian Defense.
WASHINGTON, May 25 -- Virginia H. Knauer, who says she is an activist, has been doing her best to prove it during her seven weeks as President Nixon's special assistant for Consumer Affairs.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., May 25 -- Limitations on the size and weight of highway trucks would be raised under legislation being prepared for introduction in Congress, a trucking official told an industry convention here yesterday.

THIS year's season of the American modem dance at the New York City Center ended last night. ATLANTA, May 25 (AP) -- Bert Yancey, steady under pressure, sank his third straight birdie putt on the second extra hole of a sudden-death playoff with Bruce Devlin to win the Atlanta golf tournament today.

VIENNA, May 25 -- The Vienna State Opera, the pride of this music-loving city where almost every other adult thinks of himself as a critic, celebrated today the centennial of the ornate building under whose roof Enrico Caruso and Maria Jeritza once sang, and Gustav Mahler and Herbert von Karajan conducted.

ROME, May 25 (AP) -- The beat of African drums boomed through St. Peter's Basilica today as Pope Paul VI and 24 newly ordained priests from different countries concelebrated mass for Pentecost.

KINGS POINT, L. I., May 25 -- The United States Merchant Marine Academy wound up its week's observance of World Trade Week yesterday by winning the annual national lifeboat race. This means that a Kings Point crew will represent the United States in the international whaleboat race at Sag Harbor during the three-day whaling festival in June.

The Edward Warner Award of the International Civil Aviation Organization has been presented to Henri Bouche, a French aviation economist, historian and author. He was cited for his contribution to international aviation.

PARIS, May 25 -- Tran Buu Kiem, the chief National Liberation Front delegate at the Paris peace talks, maintains that the Front looks forward to an era of normal and friendly relations with the United States once the Vietnam conflict is ended.

Barry Martyn's Ragtime Band, a British group, made its New York debut late yesterday afternoon at the Half Note Cafe to an audience that included a number of American jazzmen -- Eddie Condon, Zutty Singelton, J. C. Higginbotham, Claude Hopkins and others.

The proposed City College settlement chooses the wrong road to a desirable goal. It is imperative that the induction of disadvantaged youths into higher education, and thereby into the mainstream of employment and the professions, be vigorously stepped up. After many years of neglect, this necessity has been adopted as the underlying rationale of the City University's master plan which is being implemented both at the senior and the community colleges.
Six persons in a Harlem bar suffered minor pellet wounds last night when a man with a 16-gauge shotgun walked in, fired one round without warning and fled, the police reported.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 25 -- With the completion of the time trials for the Indianapolis 500 today, a tabulation showed that Jigger Sirois of Hammond, Ind., would have won the pole position if his car owner, Myron Caves, had not waved the yellow flag on May 17.

WASHINGTON, May 23 -- Whatever the Nixon Administration may ultimately make of Model Cities -- the Johnson Administration's innovation for attacking urban blight -- the man who now runs the program sees it as a step toward revitalizing the cities under local control.

THE Children's Ballet Theater, under the choreographic guidance of Christine Neubert, offered a modest dance interpretation last night of episodes from Louisa Mae Alcott's "Little Women." The first large-scale experiment in selecting judges for the Civil Court with the help of impartial screening panels -- the method favored by the American Bar Association -- will be on trial in next month's primary. Three candidates chosen in that fashion and a fourth in one resembling it are waging primary fights for nominations.
MARSEILLES, France, May 25 -- France's largest provincial center is likely to give first place to the Communist candidate, Jacques Duclos, in the presidential election Sunday.

ATHENS, May 25 (Reuters) -- Nancy Richey and Peaches Bartkowicz upset the Australian pair of Mrs. Margaret Court and Judy Tegart, 6-4, 6-4, today to regain the women's Federation Cup team tennis championship for the United States.

The Sine Nomine Singers gave another of their engaging concerts at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. There is something about the group that captivates: Its members (19 of them), are young and fresh-looking, and they sing as if doing so were the rarest pleasure in life.
Gertz Long Island, a store division of Allied Stores Corporation, today opens its newest branch, a complex of old Colonial buildings at East Hampton, L. I.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., May 25 (AP) -- Lee Roy Yarbrough, taking complete charge after mechanical troubles struck down his challengers, registered an easy victory today in the World 600 stock car race before a crowd of 75,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 25 (AP) -- Carl Taylor's first major league home run, a two-run blast in the fifth inning, gave the Pittsburgh Pirates a 6-2 victory to complete a sweep of their double-header with the San Francisco Giants today.

HOUSTON, May 25 -- Even the usually reliable Tom Seaver, who seemed tired in his third start in eight days, could not save the New York Mets today as their current losing streak grew to four games with a 6-3 victory by the Houston Astros before 22,716 at the Astrodome.

Four-year-old Lucy Miller sat on her father's shoulders and cheered the puppet show, Joseph Pormigiano 7, played with giant plastic building blocks, 4 year-old Timmy Gilmartin rode in the pony cart and Karen Cohen, 6, painted her own banner to carry in the children's parade.
ATLANTA, May 26 (AP) -- Clete Boyer cracked a two-run homer in the sixth inning tonight, leading the Atlanta Braves to a 3-0 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

Advertising copywriters honored their own last night at the last of the season's award ceremonies. (Did you hear a sigh of relief?) And if there were one thing that was proved last night at the Copy Club of New York's 1969 Gold Key Awards Banquet in the Rainbow Room, it was that creative people must think alike.
The New York Urban League's Association of Black Athletes announced yesterday the establishment of a counseling service to guide black basketball players to the colleges best suited for them.

Hoping to brush aside all memories of last weekend, the New York Mets and New York Yankees turned their attention to new opponents yesterday as the Mets prepared for a stand at Shea Stadium and the Yankees got ready to embark on a tour of the Midwest.

ALBANY, May 26 (UPI) -- All reference to sex education is to be eliminated from the state's two-year-old law requiring health courses in public schools, under legislation approved today by Governor Rockefeller.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Dr. William H. Stewart, Surgeon General of the Public Health Service, has drawn a barrage of criticism from the tobacco industry in an intensified battle over smoking and health.
The efforts of the Piper Aircraft Corporation to avoid a take-over by Chris-Craft Industries, Inc., and merge in-stead with the Bangor Punta Corporation produced a new legal action yesterday.

TRENTON, May 26 -- Former State Senator Ned J. Parsekian, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor of New Jersey, charged today that former Gov. Robert B. Meyner had four "serious" conflicts of interest.
It was all fair weather and clear sailing yesterday for the South Street Seaport restoration in Lower Manhattan as it came before the City Planning Commission for approval.

Dick Tiger, who gave Nino Benvenuti of Italy, the middleweight boxing champion of the world, a convincing lesson in the harsh sport last night in Madison Square Garden, has moved back into the most prominent spot in the 160pound division.
The money market was under extreme pressure yesterday, amid warnings that a "credit crunch" might be in the offing.

THOSE who believe that rubber bridge is a game with a substantial element of luck and that duplicate is a game from which the luck element has been eliminated are right up to a point. The luck element in duplicate is considerably reduced but is far from negligible, as the diagramed deal shows.
WASHINGTON, May 26 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board rejected late today a new bid by Continental Airlines for the South Pacific-Australia route denied it by President Nixon.
Two high-ranking administrative appointments were announced yesterday by the Board of Higher Education, governing body for the City University.

DURBAN, South Africa, May 26 -- Internally troubled, with its sweeping plans for a federation of racially separate states still remote, the Nationalist party nevertheless celebrated today its 21st year in control with its over-all power intact.
Carl J. Schiff, the city's Director of Horticulture, said yesterday he would no longer permit the use of DDT spraying in city parks because it was "dangerous."

HOUSTON, Tex., May 26 -- Space agency leaders said today that the success of Apollo 10 had pointed the way toward the "true goal" of space flight -- the distant planets beyond the moon, with Mars the first.
President Nixon telephoned his congratulations to the Apollo 10 astronauts yesterday as tributes hailing their historic voyage to the moon and back poured in from around the world.
A film biography of Sarah Bernhardt will be produced next year by Ray Stark, who with Columbia Pictures made the film version of "Funny Girl."

Samuel (Big Sam) Cavalieri, a reputed Mafia "soldier," was arraigned yesterday in State Supreme Court in the Bronx on a charge of criminal contempt for having refused to tell a grand jury whether he knew that Carmine (Mr. Gribs) Tramunti had succeeded the late Thomas (Three-Finger Brown) Luchese as boss of one of the major organized crime families.
WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The House tentatively imposed a $20,000 limit today on the amount of Federal subsidy paid any farmer for holding down production.

YONKERS, May 26 -- Most of the 22,756 persons who appeared tonight for the opening of Yonkers Raceway's second of three seasonal meetings paid strict attention to the trotters and pacers. The betting was as brisk as the competition on this first of 52 nights of action here, with the mutuel handle topping $2-million.

MIAMI, May 26 (UPI) -- A Northeast Airlines jet returned here after having been hijacked by three armed men earlier today and diverted from its New York destination to Havana.

Mrs. Rose Shapiro, former president of the Board of Education, accused the Lindsay administration yesterday of having helped thwart educational progress while exercising undue influence in the city's schools.
A suit instituted against the Veterans Administration by the Consumers Union of America, Inc., went to trial in Federal District Court here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Supreme Court refused today to disqualify Justice William J. Brennan Jr. from a case that is being appealed from a lower court that includes two judges who are partners with Justice Brennan in a real estate venture.

Poland's resistance to such rapprochement has been one of the major factors in bringing that policy -- and the Grand Coalition itself -- into doubt as West Germany heads toward parliamentary elections in September.

Federated Department Stores, Inc., and the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, two leading department store chains, registered record sales and earnings in the first fiscal quarter ended May 3, according to their reports yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that states may collect sales and use taxes from servicemen, even if they are permanent residents of other states.

Fifty-eight years after a man who signed himself A. Shub became the first person to borrow a book at the New York Public Library at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street, the massive building guarded by two stone lions looks the same on the outside.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- The Senate, with little debate and by voice vote, passed legislation today aimed at reducing the fees and charges that must be paid by those who invest in mutual funds.

WASHINGTON, May 26 -- Electoral reform took the first step along a slow uncertain route through the Senate today as a plan, favored by Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen but hardly anyone else, moved out of subcommittee.

MOSCOW, May 26 -- The 17th game of the world championship chess match between Tigram Petrosiam of the Soviet Union, the titleholder, and his Soviet challenger, Boris Spassky, was postponed today because Spassky was indisposed. The score stands at 8 to 8 in this 24-game series.
SONTHOFEN, West Germany, May 25 -- West German space adventurers took a giant stride backward this weekend to explore the heavens in man's first airship -- the balloon.

SOME of the wherewithal for summer living is what the American Indian Arts Center is showing in its latest exhibition of informal handicrafts made mostly by Indians from South America.
ALBANY, May 28 -- All new employes of a member or affiliate of any national security exchange will have to submit to fingerprinting, beginning Sept. 2, before they can work in New York State.

Brokers talked of an abundance of rain in Ghana yesterday -- 8.4 inches so tar in May compared with 2.4 a year earlier. Rain washes insecticides off the cocoa plants and makes them more susceptible to disease.

NEWARK, May 29 -- D. Louis Tonti, a candidate for the Democratic nomination for Governor of New Jersey, bought $5 worth of heroin in midtown Manhattan last night, and today he complained that New York City had become "a front for filth and worse, much of which finds its way to New Jersey."

Eighteen young men were indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on draft-evasion charges, and a 19th was charged with illegally Wearing a military uniform during a draft card-burning demonstration.
SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, May 30 -- President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam said today that he would never agree to a coalition government in his country with the National Liberation Front.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, May 29 (AP) -- Some of the hot money flowed back out of Germany last week, while France saw the first weekly gains in its reserves in nearly four months, statistics released by central banks revealed today.

Theodore C. Sorensen, speaking at Queensborough Community College, said [news story May 19] that student unrest can best be settled "on campuses without the advice or intervention of outsiders who may not know all the facts." He included among the outsiders the Congress, the courts and the police.

Standing on the steps of City Hall yesterday morning, State Senator John J. Marchi accused Mayor Lindsay of "an almost incredibly brazen and cynical misuse of the powers of his office" in accepting $6,000 in campaign contributions obtained by the president of the City Tax Commission.
OLD WESTBURY, L. I., May 29 -- Rachel Mayrock, a teen-age sister of Bruce Mayrock, said in a brief interview at her home today that her brother was "very strong on Biafra."
WASHINGTON, May 29 (Reuters) -- Hamer H. Budge, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has outlined the range of his agency's study of institutional investors.

Scores of close-up pictures of the moon taken by Apollo 10, showing craters so steep-sided their walls are streaked with landslides, as well as a dramatic sequence of "earthrise" over the lunar horizon were made public yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 29 -- Following is the text of a speech made today by Mike Mansfield of Montana, the Senate majority leader:

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The six-day riot on Cleveland's East Side last summer may have "marked the beginning of a new pattern" of racial violence in the United States, according to a report to the National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence.

Denny McLain pitched his eighth victory of the season yesterday as the Detroit Tigers defeated the Oakland Athletics, 8-4. And he is now winning games at the same rate that produced 31 victories last season.

DANCE events at Lincoln Center were brightened last night by the premiere of a ballet that didn't take place but should have, and a ETE cast change that shouldn't have taken place but did. Well, that's life. I suppose even a critic doesn't deserve everything.

OAKLAND, Calif., May 29 -- Sheriff Frank I. Madigan announced to a news conference today that he would arm his deputies with shotguns loaded with buckshot for use if needed against demonstrators in Berkeley tomorrow.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 29 -- On the top floor of the steel tower that overlooks the Speedway during the 500-mile auto race, Dr. Andrew Offut will be peering through binoculars tomorrow as the cars whine down the straight-aways and zoom through the turns.
After meeting with Mayor Lindsay for 45 minutes yesterday, the five members of the new interim Board of Education left by a rear door of City Hall to avoid a group of pickets.
TOKYO, May 29 -- The Japanese Government has rebuffed a Soviet request for soft bank loans from Japan to finance Japanese imports, a Finance Ministry official confirmed today.

JERUSALEM, May 29 -- A Syrian MIG-21 was shot down today by an Israeli jet in a brief air battle over the Golan Heights, the southwestern part of Syria that has been occupied by Israel since the war of June, 1967.

O. Edmund Clubb [letter May 23] could not have made a bigger mistake about the Vietnam war when he said "The hard fact is that the United States has assumed a highly vulnerable and untenable political position by undertaking to impose its will upon a small Asian nation by the illegitimate exercise of military force . . . . "
TRENTON, May 29 -- New Jersey Blue Cross officials asked the state today to approve increases in subscriber rates averaging 44 per cent.

PARIS, May 29 (AP) -- Dennis Ralston, the Bakersfield, Calif., professional, and Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., the third-ranked United States amateur, swept into the third round and Americans took four of the 16 remaining women's berths today in the French open tennis championships.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Friday, May 30 -- A youth set himself afire on the lawn of the United Nations yesterday before hundreds of onlookers. According to a sign he left on the grass, he was protesting "genocide" in Biafra.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 29 -- With a new generation of Bohemia joining in, San Francisco celebrated a $1.7-million addition to the San Francisco Art Institute at a party that was still blasting away with electronic music at 3 o'clock this morning.
Court actions dominated yesterday the acquisition battles over the Piper Aircraft Corporation, the Pan American Sulphur Company and the B. F. Goodrich Company.
RABAT, Morocco May 28 -- Despite an official policy of tolerance, the tiny Jewish community in this Arab country lives in an atmosphere of tense caution tinged with occasional crisis.
For a state with New Jersey's staggering problems -- economic, social, cultural -- the general prognosis for the gubernatorial primary election next Tuesday is dismaying.
New Yorkers sweltered yesterday in a record high temperature for a May 29 of 97 degrees as they prepared to commemorate today the nation's 102d Memorial Day.

CHICAGO -- The political aspect of Revolutionary Warfare is at least as important as its military aspect and the two are hitched in tandem. In this strategy, propaganda is of maximum importance and it often uses lies to accomplish its ends.

The election of Frank J. Graziano as president and chief executive officer of the Crompton Knowles Corporation, manufacturers of textiles, machinery and chemicals, was announced yesterday. He succeeds Frederic W. Howe Jr., who was elected to the new post of chairman of the board.
IN a parklike setting, a girl in her early teens seems so utterly engrossed in a bouquet of wild flowers that the approach of a boy means nothing and she dreamily nibbles on a few petals.
The nation's civil liberties movement, many of its leaders suggested this week, may be headed toward an impasse.
Trading perked up and so did prices yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

PRAGUE, May 29 -- The short, muscular Communist party chief of Bohemia-Moravia, Lubomir Strougal, had a reputation for toughness even as a 19-year-old law student at the end of the World War II when he went into the streets of Prague to cheer the Soviet liberators.

COLLINGWOOD, Ontario, May 29 (Canadian Press) -- Two men were reported dead, 11 missing and 45 injured today when a 730-foot cargo vessel slid down the ways prematurely, 15 minutes before its scheduled launching at Coiling-wood Shipyards.

LYONS, France, May 29 -- Former Premier Georges Pompidou, who is seeking to continue the Gaullist regime, and Alain Krivine, the young Trotskyite who did his best to overthrow it last year, both sought votes in Lyons today in their campaigns for the French presidency.
Nino Benvenuti, the world middleweight champion, testified again yesterday before a Manhattan grand jury investigating possible underworld influence in boxing.
The news of May 22 presents a dual triumph of good sense over short-sighted compassion.

CHERRY HILL, N. J., May 29 -- When nominations for the Jersey Derby closed on Feb. 3, Calumet Farm's Best Turn hadn't even made his racing debut. He was gawking out of his stall at Hialeah Park in Miami, a rangy but untested son of Turn-to who might or might not be something special.
The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of St. Paul-Minneapolis denied yesterday a report that one of its bishops had resigned from the hierarchy.

The need for reform of this state's abortion law was again strikingly illustrated a few days ago when four persons were arrested in the Bronx and seven women, including several college students, were held as material witnesses.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 29 -- Iraq has cased restrictions on her small Jewish community.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., May 29 (UPI) -- A $250,000 lawsuit on behalf of the Bavarian Motor Works, Ltd., of Germany has been filed here in Middlesex County superior court against William Manchester, over a passage in his book "The Arms of Krupp."
NEW CANAAN, Conn., May 29 (UPI) -- "If anyone knows our Mary is safe, please communicate this fact to us in any manner you see fit."

GENEVA, May 29 -- David A. Morse, Director General of the International Labor Organization, said today that the continued prosperity of South Africa, "will directly depend on an increasing participation of the nonwhite labor force in all sectors of the economy."

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- The Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield, in a brief but emotional address, called today for the renewal of a mature and open dialogue between the Administration and the critics of its Vietnam policy.

PARIS, May 29 -- The United States said at the Vietnam peace conference today that a political settlement in South Vietnam would be impossible without "the full participation and agreement" of President Nguyen Van Thieu's Government.

BUCHAREST, May 29 -- The easing of restraints on creative freedom is continuing here, despite the mood of ideological firmness in the rest of the Soviet alliance since the invasion by Warsaw Pact forces stalled the liberalization in Czechoslovakia. At present, Rumania is the only country in the Soviet bloc that offers much for intellectuals and artists to cheer about.
R. VERNON (Gadabout) GADDIS, the canny, 73-year-old wandering fisherman whose pursuit of the sport has made him a wealthy man, has ventured into motion pictures.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 29 -- At an impasse in contract negotiations because of a difference of $400,000, O. J. Simpson said today he had asked the Buffalo Bills to trade his negotiation rights to another American Football League team.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., May 29 -- A faint sigh of relief seemed to rise from a steaming runway at the Stewart Air Force Base today as 800 airmen of the 904th Military Airlift Group marched back into civilian life.

Alarmed by rising costs and mounting deficits, the country's five best orchestras -- the New York Philharmonic Symphony, Philadelphia, Boston, Cleveland and Chicago -- have joined forces to study mutual problems and to coordinate action toward their solution.

Sir Arthur Edwin Young, Commissioner of Police of the City of London, discovered yesterday that the "light suit" he had brought here in case of hot weather was really a "heavy suit" when the temperature soared toward 100 degrees.
BROOKLINE, Mass., May 29 -- The world was in turmoil 52 years ago today. The United States had just plunged into war against Germany, revolution had swept Russia and the suffragettes were marching.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 29 -- A Harvard committee set up to renegotiate Reserve Officers Training Corps contracts in the wake of student protests against the program this year will recommend to the Faculty of Arts and Sciences that it end all R.O.T.C. contracts by June, 1971, the committee announced today.
Philip E. Albrecht, a vice president of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., has been elected president of the New York Society of Security Analysts.
MOSCOW, May 29 -- A Communist party newspaper today assailed Soviet intellectuals for their inclination to think on their own and not follow party discipline.

PARIS, May 29 (Reuters) -- Transport Minister Jean Chamant of France and Economics Minister Karl Schiller of West Germany climbed into a model of the European airbus today and signed an agreement for joint development of the short-haul air liner.

DETROIT, May 29 -- Detroit will elect a Mayor in November, and it appears that Jerome P. Cavanagh, the 40-year-old incumbent, will be in trouble if he runs against any strong challenger. The Mayor says he is undecided on running again.

Norman Mailer, the only candidate for Mayor who has endorsed the projected dual-admissions policy at City College, said yesterday he reluctantly supported the concept because "it may be the price we have to pay for our complacency through the years."

THE widely advertised packaged travel tour was betrayed last night as a good deal less than a bargain on "Your Dollar's Worth," the consumer's program on National Educational Television (Channel 13). For the adult who feels lost away from home without a baby sitter the therapy of moving in a herd was recommended. But if the purpose of travel is to see and experience something a little different, says N.E.T., beware the escorted service.

WASHINGTON, May 29 -- A simmering revolt within the United Mine Workers of America burst into the open today with the surprise announcement by Joseph A. Yablonski, a long-time officer and executive board member of the union, that he would oppose the reelection late this year of the union's president, W. A. Boyle.
DECATUR, Ga., May 29 (AP) -- Ruth Eisemann-Schier pleaded guilty today of kidnapping and drew a seven-year prison term for her role in the $500,000 ransom abduction of Barbara Jane Mackle.

United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau announced yesterday that a major ring of securities thieves who had plagued Wall Street brokerage houses for the last seven months had been broken up with the arrest of four men.
NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., May 29 (AP) -- A rocket belt that propelled man through the air for seconds eight years ago gave way today to a jet belt that can keep him aloft for minutes and miles.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP) -- The armed services are putting into effect a Defense Department policy providing that reservists or National Guardsmen who do not perform satisfactorily can be called to active duty for up to two years.

Two hundred longshoremen returned to work yesterday in Jersey City after a one-day wildcat strike over alleged efforts of the union local to force a stevedore company to hire a man it did not need or want.
PRAGUE, May 29 -- Dr. Gustav Husak, the Czechoslovak Communist leader, advocated "the restoration of the leading role of the party" at the opening of a Central Committee meeting here today.

Mayor Lindsay told Sanitation Department officers yesterday that they would be instrumental in a new crackdown beginning next Wednesday on violators of alternate-side-of- the-street parking regulations.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 30 -- United Nations authorities have yielded to pressure from the Czechoslovak delegation and have not renewed the contract of a Czechoslovak staff member out of favor with the Prague regime.
DETROIT, May 29 (AP) -- Production in United States auto plants declined this week, largely as a result of the Memorial Day holiday weekend.
The Food of Love, four young musicians specializing in medieval and Renaissance music, will give free concerts on Saturday and Sunday afternoons at the Cloisters during June.

MIAMI, May 29 -- President Nixon set up a Cabinet-level advisory group today to work against what he called increasing threats to "the availability of good air and good water, of open space and even quiet neighborhoods."
KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., May 29 (AP) -- President Nixon announced today plans to nominate Stephen Horn to be vice chairman of the Civil Rights Commission.
Stock prices held steady yesterday in the face of extremely tight money conditions and the approach of a three-day weekend. Oil issues gave the market its glamour.

Theodore W. Kheel, the lawyer labor mediator, called on Democratic voters yesterday to nominate Robert F. Wagner for Mayor in the, June 17 primary "because he is the only candidate who can stop a Yorty-type campaign in its tracks."

PARIS, May 29 -- The United States and West Germany are locked in a monetary dispute over the amount of a new international reserve asset to be put into action later this year, according to qualified European monetary sources.
QUITO, Ecuador, May 29 -- Student violence erupted here today as Governor Rockefeller arrived and met with Ecuadorian officials behind heavy, security guards.
The .American Stock Exchange has issued its laest in-: iders' report, including changes in stock ownership by large shareholders, directors and officers of listed companies.

LONDON, May 30 -- A high United States official said today that the Nixon Administration would not recommend to Congress a reduction of United States forces in Europe even if other Atlantic allies followed Canada's example and reduced their forces.

SINCE the Chifferobe opened recently at 45-47 West 57th Street, Gene Alperin has been fascinated by what he calls "the clockwork of this neighborhood." Mr. Alperin and his colleague, Bernard Pachter, operate the store, and the timing he was referring to was the methodical ebb and flow of customers in the area. Between 11:15 A.M. and 3 P.M. they're out shop ping, he said, "then they rest for an hour and it starts again."

The acknowledgement by the president of the City Tax Commission that he solicited campaign contributions for Mayor Lindsay from lawyers, including some who may have practiced before the commission, demonstrates how hard it is to put an end to an old and thoroughly discreditable practice.

THEODORON is an anonymous foundation "committed to the promotion of young and relatively unknown creative talent," in the words of a release from the Guggenheim Museum, where an exhibition of 30 works by nine of these young artists has opened.

THE broad survey of art nouveau at the Finch College Museum of Art makes this a good time to investigate sources of the turn-of-the-century decorative style, and particularly the neglected contribution of Italy.

OAKLAND, Calif., May 30 -Francis Ignatius Madigan is a tall, powerful, muscular man with sharp blue eyes, a quietly confident manner and the outspoken conviction that the people who are causing trouble at Berkeley are not his policemen, but street rabble, for whom he feels contempt.
ATHENS, May 30 -- Four Greek journalists were arrested by the security police in Athens today. No official reason was given.
The parish council concept, which permits the laity and the clergy of Roman Catholic congregations to share in decision-making, is making significant advances in the Archdiocese of New York.

Bernard Botein, chairman of the Mayor's Criminal Justice Coordinating Council -- and until recently a presiding justice of the Appellate Division of State Supreme court -- has criticized the quality of legal advice given to poor New Yorkers.

Manuel Oquendo supported his wife and two sons last summer with his salary as a lifeguard at the Park Department's St. Mary's Recreation Center, at St. Ann's Avenue and East 145th Street, the Bronx, his 10th summer lifeguard job.
BUENOS AIRES, May 30 -- Argentine workers struck throughout the nation today as the military Government appeared to be faced with widening defiance.
The help-wanted advertising index declined in April, the National Industrial Conference Board announced yesterday.

In a May 22 news story, Malcolm W. Browne states that President Frei of Chile in his annual state of the nation speech, which he qualifies as "unexpectedly moderate," avoided the "denunciation of foreign interests employed in recent months by the military government of Peru."
LONDON, May 30 -- A four-man British expedition touched land yesterday for the first time in nearly 16 months, having achieved the first recorded trek across the frozen Arctic Ocean.
An unusual approach to the problems of corporate relations is being taken by one large corporation through the appointment of a rabbi as its community affairs head.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, May 31 -- Clashes between allied and enemy forces flared yesterday despite cease-fires proclaimed by both sides to mark Buddha's birthday. This morning the United States command reported at least 79 significant clashes, but refrained from describing them as violations of the cease-fire.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -The Department of Transportation has received detailed proposals for the construction of a high-speed air-cushioned vehicle guided by a track, or guideway.
PRAGUE, May 30 -- The Communist party's Central Committee tonight proclaimed Czechoslovakia "a firm part of the socialist community."
DEVON, Pa., May 30 -- Rod Jenkins piloted High Chapparal to the intermediate jumper championship at the Devon Horse Show tonight but the triumph was almost anticlimactic.

City Health Commissioner Joseph V. Terenzio ordered the medical staff at the Bronx Medical Center yesterday not to go through with its threat to curtail services, but the doctors said the cutbacks would start tomorrow.
The star performer in the new issues market this week was Hycel, Inc., a Houston manufacturer of chemicals for blood testing.

A nation shaken by the death toll of the war in Vietnam yesterday honored the 35,000 men who had given their lives on that Asian battlefield and the hundreds of thousands who had made similar sacrifices in earlier wars.

If President Nixon is going to lecture the nation about the Supreme Court, should he not get some elementary points clear in his mind? In his press conference of May 22 he said in succeeding sentences that he wanted to appoint a judge (a) who would be a "strict constructionist" and (b) who would grant Congress "great leeway" in writing laws and be "very conservative in overthrowing a law passed by the elected representatives."

TRENTON, May 30 -- Representative William T. Cahill, a candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor, denied any knowledge today of a racially restrictive covenant once placed upon property he now owns in Brant Beach, on Long Beach Island.
An 18-year-old Harlem girl will become today the first Negro graduate of the Oldfields School in Glencoe, Md., but she will not take part in the graduation exercises.

BERKELEY, Calif., May 30--National Guard troops behind barbed wire barricades and sheriff's deputies with shotguns protected the University of California's vacant lot today from thousands of demonstrators who wanted to make it into a "people's park."

NEW VERNON, N. J., May 30 -- The north embankment of the overpass where Sand Spring Road crosses Interstate Highway 287 is a huge wall of dirt and gravel. It stands 70 feet from Eugene Long's living room.

WASHINGTON, May 30 (AP) An analysis by a Bureau of the Budget study group estimates an adequate diet for the poor would require a tripling of Federal spending. This is far more than has been asked by President Nixon.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -The outgoing director of one of the most successful integrated educational programs in the antipoverty drive says he would like to see a "great experiment" in this country: a college broken along racial lines instead of academic disciplines.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 30 -- Proving that nothing succeeds like the perfect psyche, Dick Drescher made the first throw in the discus today the finest in I.C. an 4-A track championship.

Norman Mailer, the author and candidate for the Democratic mayoral nomination, stood with his back to Aqueduct race track yesterday, all prepared to shake hands with a throng surging down a ramp from the elevated train. Many of them were running toward him.

LONDON, May 30 -- The British Government said today that it would not sell the AngloFrench Jaguar jet fighter to South Africa and reminded France that the aircraft came within the scope of Britain's embargo on the sale of arms to South Africa.
VIENNA, May 30 -- Premier Jeno Fock of Hungary said here today that the Warsaw Pact countries hoped that the European security conference that they had proposed might be held in 1971.

Arts and Letters had a most remunerative workout yesterday. The Rokeby Stable's 3year-old opposed 10 older horses in the $116,750 Metropolitan Mile at Aqueduct, won the important handicap by 2 1/2 lengths, picked up a purse of $75,725 and established himself as a strong possibility to overthrow Majestic Prince in the Belmont Stakes next Saturday.
Dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.
A 4-year-old Queens girl was killed and her 6-year-old brother and their mother were injured yesterday when they were struck by a car at 208th Street and Murdock Avenue, St. Albans, Queens.

LONDON, May 30 (Reuters) -- The Government today put further pressure on banks to reduce personal loans by halving the interest paid on money that banks deposit with the state-controlled Bank of England.

OWERRI, Biafra (Nigeria), May 26 -- Before the war, this was a quiet industrial and educational center of about 20,000. Its population more than doubled with refugees as the federal Nigerian troops advanced and finally overran the city in September.

MEMPHIS, May 30 (AP) -- Lee Elder, one of the few Negroes on the pro golf tour, today shook off the effect of what he called "the first incident I've had on the tour" and moved into a tie with Bert Yancey for the second-round lead in the Memphis Open with a 36-hole total of 131.

Leon E. Panetta's assertion (letter May 24) that the position of the Office of Civil Rights, Department of Health, Education and Welfare, on Antioch College's Afro-American Studies Institute "was discussed with and has the concurrence of the . . . N.A.A.C.P" is incorrect.
Montreal's losing streak stretched to 14 games, Houston's winning streak ended at 10 and Pittsburgh made a triple play yesterday.

Down to his last right-handed pinch-hitter, Manager Gil Hodges of the New York Mets turned to his No. 3 catcher (who sported an average of .333) and sent Duffy Dyer to bat against the San Francisco Giants in the eighth inning last night.
The Lindsay administration was criticized yesterday by the Automobile Club of New York for causing massive traffic jams on major highways by failing to remove disabled vehicles.
LUGANO, Switzerland -- In this sunny Swiss lake retreat in the mountains near the Italian border, banks pop up nearly everywhere you turn.

Robert Moses yesterday vigorously defended the "aristocracy of service and achievement" by "talented individuals" at a memorial service at the Hall of Fame for Great Americans on the New York University campus in the Bronx.

TOKYO, May 30 -- A youthful opposition member of South Vietnam's House of Representatives called here today for immediate withdrawal of American support of the "military regime of Nguyen Van Thieu and Nguyen Cao Ky."
TOKYO, May 30, (Reuters) -The Government's Fair Trade Commission withdrew today its application to the Tokyo High Court for an injunction to suspend the merger of Japan's two largest steel mills.
KANSAS CITY, May 30 -- The good people of Kansas City used to enjoy watching the Yankees destroy the home team, but that was when the Yankees were the Yankees.
Negotiations between representatives of the Long Island Rail Road and the United Transportation Union at the Barclay Hotel were adjourned at 2:30 A.M. yesterday, with no further meeting scheduled.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, May 22 -- "Things change," said Jimmy McGuffie, the owner of McGuffie's Tavern and the restaurant upstairs. "But we still know what a Scottish gentleman is. He's a man who opens a bottle of whisky and throws away the cork." Things do change in this
PARIS, May 30 -- The campaign for the first round of the French presidential election came to an end tonight in a final burst of oratory.

STRAVINSKY'S career, like Gaul, is surely divided into three parts -- the Russian Stravinsky, the Parisian Stravinsky and the American Stravinsky. His friend and compatriot George Balanchine has traveled the same journey as Stravinsky, and it would be easy to parcel out his life into the same neat divisions.

COPLAY, Pa., May 30 -- Colgate University, faced with elimination in the National Collegiate District 2 baseball championships, averted that fate tonight by beating New York University, 7-1, at Memorial Stadium.
JERUSALEM, May 30 -- Israeli military analysts are focusing their attention these days on the Suez Canal area, where a relative calm has descended, rather than along the more active Jordanian front.

MOSCOW, May 30 -- Representatives of 70 Communist parties today ended their preparatory meeting for the world conference of Communist leaders without reaching accord on the main document to be discussed at the conference next week.

Although you have printed reaction to your [April 7] editorial "Will the Real C.B.S. Stand Up?" I should like to add the comment that the editorial was inaccurate and damaging in its reference to N.B.C.
EDISON, N.J., May 30 (UPI) -- Camp Kilmer, which has trained more than 5,000 urban youths in the Federal Job Corps program, was officially closed today as a result of recent fund cuts.

WASHINGTON, May 30 -- By holography, 1,000 standard-sized book pages of information can be stored in a crystal two inches square and a quarter inch thick. Whole libraries can be recorded in very little space.

Recent French polls project Alain Poher as one of the favorites in the run-off election for the presidency of France. Since little is known about Poher, I should like to refer to my notes of a one-hour interview with him in 1954.

O. J. SIMPSON and his wife, Marquerite, are lounging by the side of a new Chevrolet on what seems to be a tiled patio bordered by hedges in a current full-page advertisement in national magazines. Simpson is identified as a Heisman Trophy winner since he has yet to play professional football; he and the owner of the Buffalo Bills are more than 100 Chevrolets apart in salary negotiations.
BONN, May 30 -- West Germany's governing coalition veered toward a break-up today, but reportedly arrived at a truce after seven hours of tense deliberations.
MIAMI, May 30 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers flew to Florida today to present a first-hand report to President Nixon on his 18-day trip around the world.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- What is it like to be a Democratic liberal in Congress during this first year of the Nixon Administration?

OMAHA, Neb., May 30 (AP) -- The Bronx High School of Science in New York City ranked first among 7,000 schools that participated in the 20th annual High School Mathematics Contest, according to Dr. James M. Earl of the University of Nebraska at Omaha, the contest chairman.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 30 -- Like an America's Cup contender that she twice has been, American Eagle, with a near-perfect start, took the lead over 129 other yachts at the start of the Storm Trysail Club's 24th annual Block Island race today in relatively light northwesterly air of about 8 to 10 knots.
WASHINGTON, May 30 -- The Department of Health, Education and Welfare is studying a plan that it says will desegregate schools more efficiently and smoothly in both the North and the South.
LONDON, May 30 -- Britain's hungry student nurses won a food allowance of $115 a year from the Government today.

LAGOS, Nigeria, May 30 (Reuters) -- Biafra celebrated the second anniversary of its secession today and announced that it was prepared to meet an expected offensive by the Nigerian Federal Government. A radio broadcast from Biafra said that Gen. Odumegwu Ojukwu, the leader of the rebel state, had proclaimed a national holiday.

AMITYVILLE, L.I. -- One family in this quiet, suburban town has become acutely aware of the high cost of loving. Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gillies and their three children are giving up their pair of miniature Palominos so that the ponies can continue leading the good life.
SAN JUAN, P. R., May 30 -- As a cellist Pablo Casals personifies stylistic freedom; at the podium, however, that freedom ends and Casals becomes the unchallenged authority.

CHERRY HILL, N. J., May 30 -- On a sizzling day of bubbling tar in the parking lots and heat-prostration cases in the stands, Al Hattab seared the Garden State Park track this afternoon with a record-tying victory in the $137,100 Jersey Derby.
PASSAIC, N. J., May 30 -- Lawyers for the American Civil Liberties Union challenged in court here this week a curfew ordinance adopted by the seven-man City Council.

MOSCOW, May 30 -- The 18th game of the world chess championship match between the titleholder, Tigran Petrosian, and the challenger, Boris Spassky, both of the Soviet Union, was postponed today because the champion was indisposed.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 -Inside his red blazer, perspiration was soaking his maroon - and - white striped shirt and wrinkling his purple-and-black striped tie. Andy Granatelli had been entering racing cars in the 500mile race here since 1946 without winning, but now his driver, Mario Andretti, was an apparent victor.

TOKYO, May 30 -- An unprecedented surge of foreign interest is pushing prices on the Tokyo stock market to great heights. The 225-stock index, used is a yardstick for the Tokyo Stock Exchange, is closing in on the 2,000-yen mark as the long boom continues.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 30 -- Stock market speculators cashed in here today on the rumor that television is to be introduced to South Africa at long last.

Prices on the Toronto Stock Exchange registered sharp advances yesterday in active trading. The industrial index rose 1.26 to 197.23, while the western-oil index closed at a record 308.37, after adding 3.75. The gold and base-metal indicators eased.

In an East 125th Street building with wooden staircases and tilting floors, 200 Harlem ministers are running a homegrown set of programs that attend to community needs they believe are generally overlooked.

A key figure in the City College faculty senate accused all the city's mayoral candidates yesterday of having failed to ask the faculty group for information before making statements about plans for a new admissions policy at the college.
Most of the candidates for nominations in the June 17 primary were kept busy yesterday reviewing or marching in Memorial Day parades, or shaking the hands of voters relaxing in the sun.

Woody Herman made his debut at Fillmore East last night, leading a mod, retread verson of his band. His musicians wore colorful serapes and Mr. Herman was dressed in a mustard yellow shirt and bright blue trousers that showed that his hips still have the trimness to compete with Miles Davis's.

DENVER -- Two years ago, Mrs. and Mrs. James V. Wright sold their house in suburban Arvada for $16,500 and became part of a new way of life springing up in small places on the edges of America's cities.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 30 -At last! Four happy men hysterically embraced and kissed one another Italian style today in celebrating the end of years of frustration in the Indianapolis 500. Mario Andretti of Nazareth, Pa., won his first Indianapolis race after four years of futility (in 1968 he finished last).
A group of Biafrans and their supporters picketed at the United Nations then paraded through midtown yesterday in observance of the second anniversary of Biafra's secession from Nigeria.
FLEMINGTON, N. J., May 30 (UPI) -- A squad of policemen staged a narcotics raid in western New Jersey today and arrested seven pajama-clad young men in their homes.

RYE, N. Y., May 31 -- Fickle breezes and a strong ebb tide on Long Island Sound spoiled the American Yacht Club regatta today. Only 49 boats, in only four of the 12 classes, finished, out of a starting fleet of 120 in the season's fourth Yacht Racing Association championship event.
BERKELEY, Calif. May 31 (AP) -- Chuck La Benz paced four runners to a sub-four-minute mile today winning in 3:58.4 at the first Kennedy Games invitation track meet.

AN ancient castle, an antique cross and a portrait of a young man of today provide the designs for five British stamps and an air letter sheet that will be issued July 1 to commemorate the investiture of Prince Charles, the heir apparent, as the Prince of Wales.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 31 (AP) -- Tell, who inherited his grass running talents from his illustrious sire. Round Table, won the $33,450 Argonaut Stakes today at Hollywood Park.

The O. Henry Awards are an old established American institution, and the writers who win them are generally old established writers. They went this year to Bernard Malamud, Joyce Carol Oates (her sixth O. Henry) and John Barth. The 14 other writers in the collection are all similarly established in varying degree.
CHESTERTOWN, Md., May 31 -- Ruth E. Worrest's Ch. Major Gregory of High Farms topped an entry of 208 dogs at the Eastern Regional golden retriever specialty show today.

HOUSTON, May 31 (UPI) -- Rodney Milburn of Opelousas (La.) High School beat the best college hurdlers in the Southwest last night by winning the 120-yard high hurdles in the 12th Meet of Champions. His time was 13.7 seconds.
DALLAS, May 31 (AP) -- Financially speaking, it's fourth down with a yard to go every football season at Southern Methodist University.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 31 -- The Government that seized control of the Sudan last weekend is preparing to send a mission to Moscow in search of long-term credit, according to diplomatic informants.
WASHINGTON -- Not all people who smite Goliaths are called David.

THERE are just two reasons why Jerome Robbins's new "Dances at a Gathering" is so meaningful and delightful a ballet. The first is the happy brilliance and diversity of its invention. For rather more than an hour Robbins offers us dances, to Chopin piano music, that are gorgeous. The second reason is the work's humanity. Robbins is looking at people and showing them to us through the dance.
CHICAGO, May 31 -- If you've been yearning for a bottle of Rauenthaler Langenstiick Riesling Trockenbeerenauslese Cabinet, vintage 1953, Chicago would have been a good place to be one recent morning.

Despite one rape, three murders, a train derailment, a bank embezzlement, assorted sweaty chases, a mob tearing down a jail, snarling German shepherd dogs and the accidental destruction of a houseboat by dynamite, "Fools' Parade" is an upbeat novel. It tends to demonstrate Robert Browning's proposition that God's in His heaven, all's right with the world. Honesty, courage and the Good Guys win out. Cunning, greed and the Bad Guys lose.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 31 -- Delegates to the first constitutional convention in Arkansas in 51 years assembled here this week amid a precarious optimism that the effort would end with a modern constitution.

As I neared the end of Professor Konvitz's explanation as to why he changed his vote at Cornell, a chill ran through me. I thought I was reading a professor's rationalization and prayers in the Germany of 1931-32.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The demonstrations here in the week of the Presidential inauguration last January never turned into serious violence because of the close working relationship that developed between protest leaders and the Government officials, and because of the measured restraint of the local police, according to a report prepared for the National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence.

PARIS -- Adding speed to its trains has been one method used by France's national railroad system to meet airplane competition. Now, train passengers are being lured and comforted by a thoroughly rebuilt Gare Montparnasse, a Left Bank rail hub for more than a century.

Making its cumbersome way across the Atlantic is a strange craft -- perhaps as strange as any that ocean has ever seen. Riding it are seven venturesome men whose leader, Thor Heyerdahl, is again trying by a dramatic voyage to win support for a theory.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 31 -- A 28-year-old Australian exchange student who has led campus demonstrations at Florida State University is in the process of being deported.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 31 -- A bitter public employe strike that has pitted West Virginia's new Governor against organized labor is nearing the end of its third month with little prospect of an early settlement.
A leisurely look toward retailing in the year 2001 was taken last week at a time when major retail chains were busy with the business of the present.

SHELLEY WINTERS, who has played everything from a prostitute with a heart of granite to the mother of the President of the United States, is set to play a brand new part -- this time in real life. Miss Winters, on her way to Florida where she will act a beatnik poetess opposite Jackie Gleason in "How Do I Love Thee?," stopped off long enough to say that she will soon become a movie producer.
Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, will undertake a comprehensive program to help combat hunger and poverty and to assist deprived children in their school work.

NORWALK, Conn., May 31 -- David Timothy Wayne, 21-year-old son of David Wayne the actor, was arrested Friday night at Gallaher City Park here on charges of possessing narcotics. Four 18-year-olds were arrested at the same time.

SAYVILLE, L. I., May 31 -- A three-way battle for Raven Class honors will not be decided until tomorrow's final race of the Sayville Yacht Club's annual Memorial Day weekend regatta. The leader in the Raven series is Bill Pagels's Der Seadler with a first and a second today.

A reporter convicted of criminal trespass and fined $1 has filed an affidavit of error in an attempt to reverse the decision in a case with "far-reaching implications."

MANITOU SPRINGS, Colo. -- The temperature at the Pikes Peak Manitou Springs Cog Railway depot was 80 degrees one recent day. Along the tracks, lilacs bloomed against thickets of wild plum and chokcherry, but only 8.9 miles up the track, 15 feet of snow blanketed Pikes Peak and the temperature there stood at 20 degrees.

LANTANAS, those lovely summer bedding plants, are just right for penthouse terraces, and thrive in pots or planters and in window boxes. Even a half-dozen of these showy plants gives a cheerful lift to the summer landscape.

WASHINGTON, May 31 -- The Soviet Union is retaining its overwhelming lead over China in the competition for the loyalties of Communist parties throughout the world, but a new State Department survey illustrates the extent of deep divisions among the pro-Soviet group.

WASHINGTON, May 31 (AP) -- Paul Casanova, who drove in five runs, hit a two-run single in the eighth inning today to give the Washington Senators a 17-5 victory over the Chicago White Sox.

WASHINGTON -- The semantics of modern economics has a new phrase -- "disinflation without deflation." It is the invention of William McChesney Martin Jr., the perennial chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and Mr. Martin said the other day that the nation is "making some headway" in achieving it.

CHICAGO -- The Negro rights movement, nowhere more fragmented than on Chicago's South Side, is showing signs of coalescence under Operation Breadbasket, an economic and spiritual phenomenon that embraces everything from black power to conventional politics.

Scheuer on the mood of the country (in a radio interview) -- The swing to the right in the last six months doesn't augur well for candidates who are trying to represent a thoughtful middle ground. PRAGUE, June 1 -- Czechoslovakia's leadership today opposed the plan of some foreign Communist parties to raise the issue of Soviet troops in Czechoslovakia during the world Communist conference in Moscow this week.

WASHINGTON, June 1 -- The average recruit for the Central Intelligence Agency these days is likely to be around 26 years old, with an M.A. -- and probably a Ph.D. -- degree, command of at least one foreign language and "motivation.''

CHICAGO, June 1 -- Laszlo Moholy-Nagy, who died here in 1946 at the age of 51, was one of the most gifted and versatile artists of the 20th century. Besides being an abstract painter and sculptor of some consequence, he was a designer of genius, and he was also a very original photographer and filmmaker.

TORONTO, June 1 -- Philip Morris and Merrill Lynch, which are among the best-known names, respectively, in the American tobacco and securities industries, have set Canadians to wondering anew whether their country is destined to become the 51st state.
PARIS, June 1 -- Georges Pompidou and Alain Poher carry into their runoff contest for the French presidency two vastly different republican traditions in France.

The inability of Gaullist ex-Premier Georges Pompidou to win an absolute majority in the presidential election yesterday forces him, as expected, into a run-off with Interim President Alain Poher, the center candidate. Apparently Mr. Pompidou gained and Mr. Poher lost some ground in the past week, if earlier straw polls were accurate. Mr. Pompidou would now appear to be the favorite, but much depends on the campaigning of the next two weeks.

Dr. Lee A. DuBridge, the President's science adviser, has placed the problem of DDT high on the agenda of the new Environmental Quality Council of which he has been named executive secretary. This country's first association of practicing clergymen has been formed with the goal of increasing the competence of the ministry by a program of continuing education.

KHARTOUM, Sudan, June 1 -- Maj. Gen. Jaafar Muhammed al-Nimeiry, president of the new Revolutionary Council in Sudan, said tonight that the three southern provinces of the country -- remote and impoverished by a long civil war -would never be aIlowed to secede.

The City College faculty senate is expected to formally reject today the controversial dual-admissions proposal and to substitute a plan that would increase the number of minority students at the school on a more limited basis.

No talks took place yesterday in a labor dispute that threatens to close down the Long Island Rail Road. Trains were running on a normal Sunday schedule.

THE proposal of the powerful lobbies of the organized broadcasters and the cable TV operators to live in compromise rather than conflict introduces the concept of a cartel as the solution to the baffling complexities of the technological evolution of television.

HENRY ITKIN of Silver Spring, Md., and Ken Rhodes of Beltsville, Md., led the field into the two final sessions of the Goldman Open Pair Championship here yesterday afternoon. SANTA BARBARA, Calif. -The undersea oil gusher that erupted in January to plague miles of California beaches seems to have exposed the weaknesses in the structure of governmental processes available to deal with such emergences.

Phyllis Triolo, a native of Minneapolis and a graduate of the Juilliard School, played a concert at Town Hall last night in which the outstanding features were her forceful musicianship and rich, full tone.

PARIS, June 1 -- Times change and theaters change with them. Last night the French edition of "Hair" opened at the Theatre de la Porte Saint-Martin, where Sarah Bernhardt and Coquelin once stormed the boards, and where "Cyrano de Bergerac" had its premiere.

HAVANA, June 1 (Reuters) -- Several hundred Vietnamese students in national dress were in a crowd that turned out today to welcome Tran Buu Kiem, chief Vietcong negotiator at the Paris peace talks, who is here for a brief visit.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 1 -- The South Vietnamese armed forces appear to be doing a better job in battle now than ever before, but the day when they will be able to stand alone does not seem to be in sight.

TOKYO, June 1 -- The Foreign Minister of Japan recently recalled his first meeting with Albert Einstein. NEW DELHI -- A foreign woman walked into one of the leading fruit stalls here the other day and ordered six good mangoes. The fruit seller winced.

Barcelona of Ecuador beat the Millonarios of Colombia, 1-0, in a tight soccer match at Randalls Island Stadium yesterday before a noisy crowd of about 12,000. There was fighting in the stands and good soccer on the field.

KANSAS CITY, June 1 -When the New York Yankees came North to open the season, Jim Lyttle, John Ellis and Al Downing were left behind in Florida to train at the minor-league camp. There is no guarantee that any of them will not be back with a farm club in a week or a month.

PITTSBURGH, June 1 -- Automobile companies have begun cutting their purchases of steel.

RYE, N.Y., June 1 -- Close finishes were the highlight of the fifth championship regatta of the Yacht Racing Association season on Long Island Sound today as a fleet of 94 sailed in heavy weather off the American Yacht Club.

The Bangor Punta Corporation countersued Chris-Craft Industries, Inc., yesterday in the continuing battle for control of the Piper Aircraft Corporation.

WASHINGTON, June 2 -- "The Court is the Court, and it always will be." So said a Queens lawyer, Lee H. Bostic, who was admitted to the bar of the Supreme Court with about 200 other lawyers this morning.
