WASHINGTON, June 2 -- The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee voted unanimously at its March 4 meeting to keep the restrictive monetary policy unchanged, it was disclosed today.

In the credit markets yesterday, it was both the lull after the storm that partially disrupted securities trading in the morning and the lull before the potential storm that seems certain to challenge the nation's money managers in the weeks ahead.

There was special delight last night for Orlando Cepeda and Hank Aaron, and it transcended the usual glee these old pros feel when they have delivered. For Aaron, who has been doing this sort of thing since 1954, hit the 522d home run of his smooth career in the Atlanta Braves' 6-3 victory over the Cards at St. Louis.

New Yorkers were awakened by the crack and roll of thunder in the hours before dawn yesterday as a quick, violent storm materialized over the city and dumped 2.35 inches of rain in two and a half hours.
SALT LAKE CITY, June 2 -- A trusted employe with a record of embezzlement has been accused of helping to steal $604,199.65 from the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.
Prices moved down in late trading on the American Stock Exchange yesterday in a session marked by weather-induced delays.
MOSCOW, June 2 -- The Soviet teen-ager, pampered by his parents but often more worldly-wise than his teachers, was pointed out today as a major problem for Soviet society.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 3 (Reuters) -- President Nguyen Van Thieu returned home tonight after state visits to Taiwan and South Korea and again said he rejected any coalition government with the Vietcong.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -Tired of being pushed around by Southern opponents, the commission that is trying to modernize the Democratic party has decided to confront rather than avoid its critics.

Former Gov. Robert B. Meyner, a Democrat with a conservative record, and Representative William T. Cahill, a Camden County moderate Republican, won their respective party nominations yesterday for Governor of New Jersey.

SEATTLE -- United States policy seeks to "Vietnamize" the Indochina war as quickly as possible by turning over to the Saigon Government responsibility for defending itself. Apart from political convenience suitable to the frazzled American mood, the object is to disengage from what has become a basic commitment.
There were two awards for Joe Namath last night and one apiece for Weeb Ewbank, Earl Morrall and Art Rooney at the annual dinner of the New York Chapter, Pro Football Writers Association.

PARIS, June 3 -- The Boeing 747 jumbo jet airliner, the largest plane in the world designed for passenger service, made its maiden Atlantic crossing today, arriving here on a nonstop flight 9 hours 8 minutes after takeoff from Seattle-Tacoma airport.

Some commodity analysts have talked for months about the possibilities in silver futures, stressing that sooner or later prices had to rise sharply when supplies ran short. But sooner has become later, and silver futures prices run about $1 an ounce below the levels of a year ago.

The governing board of the League of New York Theaters, the group of theater owners, operators and producers, has voted unanimously to raise the evening curtains for all Broadway shows at 7:30, an hour earlier than usual.
The formation of the Organization of Legitimate Theaters, which will promote the live theater "in all its forms", was announced yesterday.

PARIS, June 3 -- In a match that became a blur of magnificent passing shots, service aces and seemingly impossible retrieves, Tom Okker of the Netherlands defeated John Newcombe of Australia today and gained the semi-finals of the French open tennis tournament.

IN the carefully documented view of Erlend A. Kennan and Edmund H. Harvey Jr. -- two science writer-editors who have been carefully poring over the public records of the American space program during the last few years, the fire at Pad 34 that killed Astronauts Virgil I. Grissom, Edward H. White 2d, and Roger B. Chaffee on Jan. 27, 1967, was not the isolated misfortune that most of us still regard it.

Curt Walters, a tall, blond, handsome singer who also plays electric bass, may be the only entertainer who has been willing to accept billing as an ampersand. Or it may be that his cousin, Spence Moorer, a short, black-haired, handsome singer is the ampersand.

Most supermarket chains in New York use computers to determine what the prices should be on the thousands of items they sell daily to women shoppers. The women use 10 fingers and their own brand of arithmetic to determine which items to buy.

The director of the Moscow publishing company that controls the rights to the memoirs of Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov, Soviet military commander during World War II, has attacked Harper Row for publishing sections of the memoirs here.

Neither Senator Kennedy nor Senator Dirksen comes off with glory in their continuing replay of the Battle of "Hamburger Hill." The Senator from Massachusetts shot from the hip in describing the attack in which 45 Americans were killed and 260 wounded as "senseless and irresponsible." As we suggested at the time, no civilian is competent to hand down so dogmatic a judgment on battlefield tactics, especially when the battlefield is 12,000 miles away.

The Franklin National Bank, which last year abandoned plans to form a multi-bank holding company to expand into upstate New York, announced yesterday that it had decided to join the trend to one-bank holding companies.
A militant Negro leader is quoted in a news article in The Times (May 26) as saying, "Power comes from the barrel of a gun. . . . You put a .38 on your hip and you get respect."
Mrs. Kendall Stebbins Bryant, whose nom de plume is Perigrine Pace, isn't really Laura Beekman Moore, the heroine of her new novel.

Rakhel Kafri's dance concert at Judson Church last night had avant-garde trappings in everything save originality. The first half of the program consisted of two esoteric duets with John Wilson, titled "Monitor" and "Archaean."
The market declined for the second consecutive day yesterday with most of the major groups finishing lower in active trading.

In skirts and wigs, in false beards and the black garb of Hasidic rabbis, in doorman's uniforms or hippie rags or any of the costumes worn by inhabitants of the city, 300 tough Tactical Patrol Force policemen are intensifying the nighttime fight against crime.
Interest rates made another substantial leap upward yesterday, disrupting several municipal bond sales, but also causing investors to pay increased attention to the new issues that did sell.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The traditionalists in Congress took a few swipes at rebellion today with homely homily and indolent investigation. But they had a tough time evoking the good old days.

CAN-AM is in a flap over foils. The function of the rear-mounted airfoil that resembles an airplane wing is to deflect airstream downward. This downward thrust, combined with today's super-wide tires, plants the car firmly on the ground and thus helps use more of the horsepower that the engine is putting out.
Off Broadway, home of the new and the brave, is in the process of repeating ancient history as producers seek control of their own playhouses, a practice prevalent years ago on Broadway.
" I don't owe any county chairman anything," says Representative William T. Cahill, emphasizing his independence.

WASHINGTON, June 3 (UPI) -- The Humane Society of the United States, contending it is not right to ask Majestic Prince to run the grueling 1 1/2-mile Belmont Stakes Saturday, suggested today that the horse's trainer resign as a protest.

Dr. John R. Everett, president of the New School for Social Research, yesterday advised graduates going into the field of education to "become evangelists not just professionals" in an attempt to teach rationality and reason to students.

PRAGUE, June 3 -- The Communist party's ruling Presidium today filled high posts in the apparatus with pro-Soviet conservatives, and appointed one of them, Dr. Lubomir Strougal, as deputy to the party leader, Dr. Gustav Husak.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Not even the relaxation of a steam bath can get Representative Richard Howard Ichord's mind off what he views as the dangers of Communist infiltration in this country. "There he was in the House gym steam room, sitting stark naked, sweat pour ing off him by the bucketsful, and he was preaching the dangers of Communism," a fellow House Demo crat recalls.

MONTPELIER, Vt., June 3 (AP) -- In a special referendum, Vermont voters rejected today by a decisive margin a proposal to call a convention for the first time in a century to revise the state's Constitution.

LONDON, June 3 (AP) -Ribofilio, an American-owned horse, turned in a good final training gallop today for tomorrow's English Derby. The bookmakers have installed the colt as the favorite in the field of 26, all 3-year-olds, slated to go for the first prize of $151,459 in the 1 1/2-mile race over Epsom's turf course.

College students in New York State are beginning to discover that the days when they could borrow money for their education and repay it after graduation at 3 per cent annual interest are apparently gone forever.
A strike threatened for today on the Long Island Rail Road was averted early this morning when the line and the trainmen reached agreement on a new contract.
Two major film companies announced yesterday the selection of new presidents.
McKEESPORT, Pa., June 3 -The crowd began arriving at 5:30 in the morning with stars in their eyes as well as in the skies.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -Owners of copyrights on television material indicated today their strong opposition to the private peace treaty outlined last week by television broadcasters and cable TV operators.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Officils of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio) and of the British Petroleum Company, Ltd., presented to the Justice Department today their case for being permitted to go through with their planned merger, without challenge on antitrust grounds.
Four hospitals and four neighborhood health-care centers will be built at a cost of $400-million for the city with funds advanced by the state under a revised program announced yesterday.

A COUPLE of weeks ago, stockholders of the General Time Corporation and Talley Industries voted at their meetings to merge the two corporations. Did this mark the end of a long battle for control of the Greenwich, Conn., timepiece maker?

SAN AGUSTIN, the Philippines, June 3 (AP) -- Six Hukbalahap guerrillas were killed and one was captured during a three-hour clash yesterday with Philippine Army troops near the United States Clark Air Force Base. Two soldiers were wounded.
DETROIT, June 3 -- The Detroit Building Trades Council said today that it would negotiate industrial-type labor contracts with producers of factory-built housing in this area.

One of the anomalies of the present inflation is that business appears much more willing to accept controls than Government is to impose them. At last month's meeting of the Business Council -- a Government advisory group made up of the heads of 100 of the nation's largest corporations -- David M. Kennedy, the Secretary of the Treasury, said he was "not willing to buy" direct controls over wages and prices.

Last year the April in Paris Ball changed its name to Le Bal de l'Amitie on the suggestion of several committee members who felt "the name's never been quite right since we moved the date from April to the fall."
General Mills, Inc., achieved record sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended May 25, James P. McFarland, president, reported yesterday from Minneapolis headquarters.
Three young modern-dance choreographers -- Kathryn Posin, Michael Ebbin and Ze'eva Cohen -- presented works from their repertory last night at the Cubiculo, 414 West 51st Street.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -Congress moved on two fronts today to assert some measure of control over military spending.
A financial report by the health and welfare fund of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association is being reviewed by the United States Department of Labor, a lawyer with that agency said yesterday
DETROIT, June 3 -- New-car sales in the final third of May and for the full month trailed those of the comparable 1968 periods, the automobile companies reported today.
Mayor Lindsay told reporters yesterday that a statement by former Mayor Robert F. Wagner that he had offered to help Mr. Lindsay work out a settlement of the 1966 transit strike was "flatly untrue."

Marcel Phillippe of Mater Christi High School in Long Island City won a special 880-yard Amateur Athletic Union race yesterday at St. John's University in Jamaica, Queens, in 1 minute 49.4 seconds, the fastest time ever recorded by an Eastern schoolboy.
Queens College held its 45th commencement yesterday with 4,000 students, faculty members and parents attending the traditional ceremony in the campus quadrangle. A total of 4,245 degrees was awarded.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 3 -- North Vietnam has made its first official overture to the United Nations by inviting a representative of the United Nations Children's Fund to Hanoi to discuss a possible UNICEF aid program.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Judge Warren E. Burger's nomination to succeed Earl Warren as Chief Justice won the quick and unanimous approval today of the Senate Judiciary Committee.

The Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which regulates the $156-billion savings and loan industry, announced yesterday the adoption of new regulations that will allow for the first time Federally chartered savings associations to accept "deposits" and offer a guaranteed rate of return for up to five years.
MOSCOW, June 3 -- Ten Soviet citizens have addressed an appeal to the world conference of Communist parties, which opens here Thursday, to consider "the rebirth of Stalinist methods in our country."
LONDON, June 3 (AP) -- Britain's reserves of gold and foreign currencies fell by $79.2-million during May, the first monthly decline this year, the Treasury announced today.

Bicycling in Central Park is fun for many people, but closing the park roads four days of the week [news article May 18] has very serious consequences. While some regulations are supposed to speed up traffic conditions become impossible the moment the park roads are closed.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 3 -- President James A. Perkins of Cornell was praised today by one university trustee and a number of scientist faculty members, while some professors started a move to urge the trustees to refuse "his implied resignation."
BUENOS AIRES, June 3 -The Argentine Government announced today that President Juan Carlos Ongania would deliver a major speech to the nation tomorrow.

It is inconceivable that the convenience of the military should be allowed to imperil Japanese-American relations in the matter of Okinawan reversion. America has no Asian interests more important than the continued political stability of Japan.

The long-discussed double-decker East River tunnel at 63d Street, for both subway and Long Island Rail Road trains, won final approval yesterday from the Board of Estimate.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- United States officials said today that preparations were being made for a joint announcement at Midway by President Nixon and the South Vietnamese President, Nguyen Van Thieu, of the first unilateral reductions in American forces in Vietnam.
OTTAWA, June 3 -- The Government presented a budget tonight directed mainly at Canada's battle against inflation.
Transportation Secretary John A. Volpe said yesterday that the Nixon Administration was prepared to "get tough" with auto makers if they did not accelerate efforts to make cars safer.

Dr. Bernard Sohmer, a 39-year-old mathematician, was appointed dean of students at City College yesterday to succeed Dr. G. Nicholas Paster, who resigned last week because of his fear that a repressive trend was starting on America's campuses.

CARACAS, June 3 -- The student violence dogging Governor Rockefeller's mission to Latin America has been more potent politically than was foreseen, but Mr. Rockefeller has indicated that this may be a blessing in disguise.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The question was raised during a Congressional hearing today whether states building airports, highways and other developments should lose Federal aid for the projects if they fail to protect natural resources and the environment adequately.

Switchboard operators at the National Broadcasting Company reported a flood of calls last night from television viewers complaining that the program "Star Trek" was interrupted for about 10 minutes for a report on the New Jersey primary elections.
WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Consumer installment credit increased strongly again in April, construction activity declined fractionally and manufcturers' new orders, sales and inventories all increased.
MONTREAL, June 3 -- The back-bench members of Parliament have not yet begun sniping at the Prime Minister, and the Prime Minister has not yet forsaken his occasional fling at the frug.

MADISON, S. D., June 3 -- President Nixon said today that student revolutionaries -- propelled by a "self-righteous moral arrogance" and abetted by "permissive" faculties -- were subjecting fundamental democratic values to perhaps their sharpest challenge in the life of the nation.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 3 -William (Lefty) Dunbar, a former policeman who instituted a grand jury investigation last fall into vote-fraud charges in Atlantic County, won the Democratic nomination for Atlantic County Sheriff tonight.

STONY POINT, N. Y., June 30 -- Orange and Rockland Utilities, Inc., and the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., will be partners in construction of a 623,000-kilowatt generating plant to be operating in Rockland County in 1972.

William DeKoning Jr., a prominent Long Island labor leader, was indicted by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday for allegedly demanding -- and receiving -- about $7,000 worth of services from the head of a construction concern.

Prices on the London stock market maintained a firmer trend yesterday, but eased near the close on news of a decline in British gold and currency reserves.
As Jo-Ann Gill walked down a red-carpeted flight of stairs with her fellow graduates at the start of commencement exercises at Marymount Manhattan College yesterday she cried.

We, the undersigned members of the Department of Economics, College of Arts and Sciences, Cornell University, pledge our support to the university administration, and particularly to President James A. Perkins.

BONN, June 3 -- An all-night struggle between the conservative Chancellor, Kurt Georg Kiesinger, and his minority Social Democratic partners over how to respond to Cambodia's recognition of East Germany last month ended early today on a note of compromise.
WILLEMSTAD, Curacao, June 3 -- The Government of Premier Ciro de Kroon gave in to the island's labor leaders today by agreeing to dissolve Parliament and call for new elections in a few days.

Representative James H. Scheuer suggested yesterday that the city give a 10-year 100 per cent property tax abatement for all low-income and middle-income housing begun within the next three years to alleviate "the worst housing crisis in its history."

SAN FRANCISCO, June 3 -Hopes for the financial salvation of the hard-pressed American Conservatory Theater have been buoyed by a matching fund offer designed to produce $150,000 to meet the year's goal.

LONDON, June 3 -- On Thursday morning it will be a year since Robert Kennedy was shot. Time has not diminished the sense that life without him is incomplete.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 3 -- The Representatives of the Big Four powers were privately reported to have moved ahead today on their proposed peace plan for the Middle East, but they kept their proceedings secret.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, June 3 -- The Soviet Union has adopted a new policy of trying to improve relations with Yugoslavia, according to authoritative Communist sources.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The House Internal Security Committee, no stranger to disruption on its own grounds, opened its investigation today into whether Students for a Democratic Society posed a "serious threat" to the nation.

Governor Rockefeller has wisely backed off from earlier assertions that the demonstrations against his mission in Latin America were due to a coordinated effort by militant forces from "inside and outside the hemisphere." He now warns against blaming outsiders and says there is "strong evidence" of some popular support for the anti-American manifestations.
MONTREAL, June 3 -- Maury Wills ended his 18-year career in baseball tonight by retiring suddenly just before the Montreal Expos took the field against the San Francisco Giants.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- Following is the text of speech made by President Nixon today at the dedication of the Karl E. Mundt Library at General Beadle State College in Madison, S.D. Copies of the speech were made available here.

Reacting to a sharp rise in construction costs, the City Council Finance Committee approved yesterday the addition of $49.1-million to this year's capital budget -- including $19.3-million more for a new police headquarters.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The National Commission on the Causes and Prevention of Violence has concluded that the United States, to avoid anarchy or repression, must find a way to strike a balance between the use of police power and the toleration of agitation for change.

NIOBRARA, Neb., June 3 (AP) -- Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Sage of rural Niobrara were notified today that three of their sons were missing as a result of the collision of the American destroyer Evans and the Australian aircraft carrier Melbourne.

" Disruptive tactics" were assailed yesterday by Dr. Andrew W. Cordier, acting president of Columbia, in a commencement day address that praised the student body and faculty members for having produced a plan for university operation that "may well become a pattern for universities in the future."
Robert Baumle Meyner, who has won the Democratic primary for Governor of New Jersey, plans to run his own campaign in his bid for a third term as chief executive of the state.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- A former Defense Department official said today a secret Pentagon chart demonstrated that the proposed Safeguard anti-ballistic missile system would provide a "very poor defense" of the Minuteman missile force.

JACKSON, Miss., June 3 -Negroes were defeated in mayoral campaigns in four Mississippi towns but picked up aldermanic seats in two small communities in municipal general elections around the state today.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -Theodore C. Sorensen, who was special counsel to President Kennedy, warned an audience of booksellers today that freedom of expression in America was under attack.

Three seagoing unions and shipping employers representing substantial segment of the country's merchant marine have reached agreements on a new three-year contract calling for 33 per cent increases in employment costs.

MASON, Mich., June 3 -- Ronald August, testifying today in his own defense conceded he had lied on two occasions in reporting what happened in the Algiers Motel Annex during the Detroit riots in 1967.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -Some Latin-American diplomats said privately here today that the violence that has plagued most stops of Governor Rockefeller's first two trips to Central and South America might serve to call United States attention to frustrated expectations of economic and social development in Latin America.
Two leading discount-retail chains gave optimistic reports to their shareholders yesterday at annual meetings, but a third announced a decline in sales and earnings for the first quarter.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 2 -- High level American officers here are at work on plans for the withdrawal of United States troops from South Vietnam if President Nixon decides to give the signal.
VIENTIANE, Laos, June 3 -The Laotian National Assembly voted today to support the efforts of Prince Souvanna Phouma, the Premier, to end the civil war in Laos.

Scaling new heights again, the New York Mets climbed past the break-even point and into second place in National League East by beating the Los Angeles Dodgers, 5-2, at Shea Stadium last night.

The pro football owners of the 13 teams designated as the National Conference for the 1970 season failed again yesterday to divide their franchises into three divisions, two of four teams each and one of five, following an all-day meeting here.

THE Reisinger Knockout Team Championship, the prestige event in the Eastern Regionals being played this week at the New York Hilton, began Monday night with an entry of 80 teams. After the first round of play 40 teams survived, 24 of which had a bye round last night.

WASHINGTON, June 3 -- The Japanese Government told the United States today it was willing to permit American military bases on Okinawa after the island reverts to Japanese rule, but wanted to restrict their use to the same standard as other American bases in Japan.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 4 (AP) -- Eight Columbus policemen and an alleged numbers operator were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges involving gambling payoffs.

The relationship between broker and customer is not so happy as it used to be some years ago. Many investors report serious errors on their monthly statements. Others complain of waiting months -- even a year -- for stock certificates to arrive. Some talk cynically of discrimination when they cannot obtain a few shares of a newly underwritten issue.

In a dull trading day marked by many price declines, wheat futures bucked the trend yesterday. Prices gained more than a cent a bushel, partly on talk that the winter wheat harvest might be delayed by wet fields. In addition, there were higher cast wheat quotations at Kansas City.
OCEAN CITY, N. J., June 4 -- The police still had no clues today in the stabbing deaths of two coeds whose bodies were found in a pine woods beside the state parkway near here early Monday.

MONTERREY, Mexico, June 4 -- A Mexican Airways jetliner crashed and burned in bad weather on a 6,000-foot mountain near here today, killing the 79 persons aboard. The dead included the Mexican tennis star Rafael Osuna and Carlos Madrazo, a long-time leader of the ruling Institutional Revolutionary party.

Cary Grant, Paul Newman and Lauren Bacall will make novel use of their acting talents on Tuesday when they become auctioneers-for-a-night at a private art sale sponsored by the Actors Youth Fund and the Police Athletic League.
THE Reisinger Knockout Team Championship, the premier event in the Eastern Regionals, continued last night at the New York Hilton with the original entry of 80 teams cut to 32.
The Federal Reserve Board warned its member banks yesterday not to use their foreign branches to evade regulations governing the payment of interest on deposits and the maintenance of reserves.

COLORADO SPRINGS, June 4 -- President Nixon delivered today a strong counter-attack against critics of his military and foreign policy. He derided them as "new isolationists" and pledged that under his leadership the United States would not "turn its back on the world."

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., N. Y., June 4 (AP) -- The Board of Education in this Westchester County community today announced elimination of interscholastic sports, hot lunches and other services because voters turned down a $2.6-million school budget.
The New York Chamber of Commerce called yesterday for a four-point program to reduce the rate of inflation to a tolerable level.
PERSISTENCE is nearly as valuable as skill to an angler, and he usually does not have the latter without the former.
The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday price increases for products that make up some 16 per cent of total industry shipments.

MANCHESTER, England, June 4 (AP) -- Clark Graebner, the top-seeded player from New York; Tom Gorman of Seattle and six American women gained the quarter-finals of the Northern tennis championships today.
That "the heart in service is more important than words" is the philosophy of Tikihiro Ueno, a 21-year-old student from Tokyo's Chuo University.

The retirement of the Most Rev. Robert E. Lucey, 78-year-old Roman Catholic Archbishop of San Antonio, was announced yesterday in Washington by the church's Apostolic Delegate to this country, the Most Rev. Luigi Raimondi.

MONTAUK, L. I., June 4 -- Nine colleges and universities leased space here today for an oceanographic research center that will concentrate on solutions to pollution problems in waters surrounding Long Island.

John F. White, installed as the new president of Cooper Union last night, predicted that "a new sense of responsibility" and "a better climate in which to teach and to learn" would result ultimately from the turbulence on the nation's campuses.

LONDON, June 4 -- London's world theater season ends with its only star show -- Franco Zeffirelli's production of "La Lupa" in Italian at the Aldwych Theater, in which Anna Magnani returns to the stage after a 15year absence.

TRUMBULL, Conn. -- When John Palmer, the Superintendent of schools of this beautiful, sun-dappled and quiet community, gives a party, it frequently involves 150 pounds of Swedish meat balls, eight gallons of specially made herring and 200 pounds of potatoes.
The stock market made a feeble attempt to halt this week's slide yesterday, but it ran out of steam in the afternoon and finished lower for the third session in a row. Trading volume declined.

The Collins Aikman Corporation, producer of textiles and yarns, will show records in sales and earnings in the first fiscal quarter, which ended May 31, Donald F. McCullough, president, told shareholders at yesterday's annual meeting in Wilmington, Del.

A 20-year-old private guard assigned to security duty at City College was arrested late yesterday on a charge of setting six minor fires yesterday morning and last Thursday in buildings he had been detailed to protect.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Albert Sydney McLemore, who has devoted half his life to the Navy, will observe his 40th birthday tomorrow at sea. It will be a very dreary occasion for the commander.

YONKERS, June 4 -- Mrs. Helen R. Buck's Overcall, who turned in a 1:59 mile last week, is considered one of the fastest free-for-all pacers in the United States. This 6-year-old son of Capetown-Overbid and a half-brother to the retired Overtrick will get a chance to prove his speed over 1 1/2 miles tomorrow night in the $50,00 International Pace at Yonkers Raceway.

Two years ago today Israel lashed out at menacing Arab forces, launching a six-day blitz that shattered Arab armies and advanced Israeli troops to new lines on the Golan Heights, the Jordan River and the Suez Canal.
The state of housing in New York City seems as hopeless as an abandoned tenement whose broken windows stare blankly out on a slum.

One of the oldest events on the thoroughbred calendar was won by a youngster bearing the colors of one of the sport's oldest names yesterday when C. V. (Sonny) Whitney's favored Prize Silver easily won the $35,275 Juvenile Stakes at Belmont Park.
MOSCOW, June 4 -- Boris Spassky, challenger for the world chess championship defeated the titleholder, Tigran Petrosian, in the 19th game of their match today at Moscow's Variety Theater.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- The Army reaffirmed today its decision to send Sgt. Michael Sanders to Vietnam despite his contention that the assignment is punishment for speaking against the war.
BUENOS AIRES, June 4 -- Argentina's military Government promulgated new provisions today for its so-called anti-Communist law under which labor organizers could be jailed for up to six years.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Congress was told today that Students for a Democratic Society might have won an "indirect victory" through campus disruptions by forcing "hundreds'' of university deans and presidents to leave their jobs.

Mrs. Janet Pomeroy Avery Dulles, widow of John Foster Dulles, the former Secretary of State, has left the bulk of her "more than $1-million" estate to a son and daughter. Mrs. Dulles died May 14 in Washington, at the age of 77.

STANTON, Del., June 4 (AP) -- Diane Crump, who won with her first Delaware Park mount at long odds on Memorial Day, made her record read 2 for 2 at the Stanton track today with a front-running triumph aboard Fathom in the sixth race.
The Phoenix Theater, which dissolved its three-year partnership with the Association of Producing Artists recently, is keeping its vow to return to Broadway next season.
PARIS, June 4 -- Thousands of Parisians climbed two flights of stairs today for the first public glimpse of the interior of tomorrow's flying movie house, the Boeing 747 jet airliner.

" God would roll over in His grave," a man told the Rev. John W. Moody of Trinity Church, yesterday, when Mr. Moody confirmed that a modern-dance concert would take place in the Episcopal Church, a landmark of the Wall Street area.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Litton Industries, Inc., formally challenged today the right of a committee of Congress to inquire into its merger policy when one of its mergers is already under legal attack by the Federal Government.
ATLANTA, June 4 (AP) -- The International Cup soccer competition, which failed to attract many American fans this spring, will be abandoned next year, the North American Soccer League said today.
A ballet inspired by the film "Romeo and Juliet" will be presented next Wednesday at the Ballo Bellissimo in the Pierre's Grand Ballroom.
The Continental Can Company plans to offer its 42 per cent interest in the Brockway Glass Company to Continental shareholders in exchange for common stock of Continental.

LONDON, June 4 -- "How do you like Britain?" Mrs. Walter H. Annenberg said to a guest at the one-and-a-half hour reception she and her husband -- the new Ambassador to the Court of St. James's -- gave tonight to meet the American press corps here.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 4 -- (UPI) -- Chile asked the United States today to call off the visit Governor Rockefeller had planned to make later this month as President Nixon's envoy. The Chilean Government bowed to the threat of strikes and street violence by leftist students and labor groups.
What is a Wernher von Braun worth?

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 4 (AP) -- Navy Secretary John A. Chafee told the 860 members of the graduating class at the United States Naval Academy today that they must be prepared to defend themselves in combat against primitive weapons as well as the latest nuclear-tipped missiles.

LEYLAND, England, June 3 -- The British workingman, widely blamed for disrupting the economy through wildcat strikes, rejects such criticism as exaggerated and bitterly resents the Labor Government's proposed antistrike legislation.

The settlement early yesterday of the Long Island Rail Road's dispute with its trainmen and conductors will sharply increase labor costs, but is not expected to result in any immediate increase in fares.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- President Nixon's attack on military critics today appeared to have abbreviated, if not terminated, the Administration's period of good feelings on Capitol Hill. Since the Administration took office, probably no Nixon speech or statement has stirred up such an adverse reaction as the President's national defense speech at the Air Force Academy in Colorado.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Here is a story that is going the rounds of the convention of the American Booksellers Association which is being held here this week:

The city's interim Board of Education said yesterday that it would meet with the Great Neck, L. I., school board to discuss a Great Neck proposal to have 40 Negro children from Queens attend schools in the suburban community next fall.

American aerospace experts questioned yesterday were at a loss to explain how Mr. Socarras could have survived. Dr. Charles Glasgow, chief engineer of the Douglas Aircraft Company, makers of the DC-8 in which the Cuban stowed away, called the survival a miracle.
The City College faculty senate decided last night to put off until next fall any final recommendations on a black and Puerto Rican studies program for the 20,000-student school.
OCEANPORT, N. J., June 4 (AP) -- Gee Sparkler held off a rush of Double The Bet to win the $8,500 Tosmah Purse by a neck at Monmouth Park today.
NICE, France, June 4 -- In an area where they showed considerable strength, the opponents of Georges Pompidou are virtually conceding his election June 15 as President of France.

Louis Nizer, counsel to 85 per cent of the producers and distributors of copyrighted film programs used on television, formally criticized yesterday the proposed accord between individual television broadcasters and cable TV system operators.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Urban lawmakers failed today in their bid for a larger share of Federal funds for hospital construction and modernization.

Institutional Investors Systems, Inc., publisher of the Institutional Investor magazine and other publications, filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday covering the public offering of 260,000 shares of stock.
An official at the Bronx Municipal Hospital Center said yesterday that patients were dying unnecessarily because of cuts in the city's hospital budget.

GREAT NECK, L. I., June 4 -- Antonio Palafox, the former Mexican Davis Cup player, was extended today in defeating Bob Kahn of New York, 4-6, 6-4, 6-3, and reaching the quarter-finals of the Long Island tennis championship.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 4 -- There are few observers and officials here and in other Arab countries who seriously believe that a peaceful settlement between Israel and the Arabs is in sight, and those are dismissed as dreamers or wishful thinkers by people who consider themselves realists.

As they say around the track, the field is firming up for the Belmont Stakes on Saturday. It looks as if five will compete in the mile-and-a-half "Test of the Champion," with Frank McMahon's undefeated Majestic Prince the popular, if not statistical, choice to complete the sweep of the Triple Crown for 5-year-olds.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (UPI) -- Herbert L. Ley Jr., Food and Drug Commissioner, said today that he was powerless to keep manufacturers from adding hidden costs to many products by reducing the contents of packages without lowering the price.
Prices in the London stock market drifted lower yesterday in the traditional Derby Day slackening of trading.

Connecticut is the latest state to breach the wall of separation between church and state by providing financial assistance to religiously affiliated schools. Although it seeks to disguise the unconstitutionality of its new statute by limiting the payments to teachers of secular subjects, there can be no doubt that in many cases the payments will keep such schools from closing.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Spokesmen for major foundations told Congress today that proposed legislation prohibiting major Federal, state or local government officials from receiving any payments from tax- exempt foundations went too far.

CARACAS, Venezuela, June 4 -- The Latin American Foreign Ministers have adopted a "common position" proposing "new bases" for inter-American economic and social cooperation that go beyond the Alliance for Progress.
DETROIT, June 4 -- Richard Austin, a 56-year-old county auditor, announced today that he would run for Mayor of Detroit, the first major Negro candidate for the post in the city's history.

HANOI, North Vietnam, June 4 (Agence France-Presse) -- The formation of a provisional coalition government in South Vietnam and the withdrawal of American forces appeared more clearly than ever today to be the chief North Vietnamese aims in Paris.
Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner charged yesterday that the Lindsay administration had lagged badly in the construction of schools, housing and hospitals.

The State Assembly Insurance Committee intends to recommend that the State Insurance Commissioner turn down a Blue Cross application for rate increases as "excessive," Alfred D. Lerner, its chairman, said yesterday.
MONTREAL, June 4 -- Maury Wills said today that he had quit his $80,000 a year job in baseball because his performance had slipped and his fans and teammates "expected better of me."

JERUSALEM, June 4 -- Two years after the war of June 5 to 10 in 1967, Israelis seem in a buoyant mood, aware that their confrontation with the Arabs will continue but confident that they are in no danger.
As a C.C.N.Y. alumna, I have been reading with great distress about the proposals to admit Negro and Puerto Rican students to C.C.N.Y. on the basis of race. I am totally opposed to the plans.

PRINCETON, N J. June 4 -- New Jersey's Democratic and Republican leaders moved quickly today to unify dissident forces for what some of them predicted would be one of the closest elections for Governor in many years.

GENEVA, June 4 -- Russell L. Schweickart, who piloted the lunar module on the Apollo 9 flight, said today that an earth - orbiting space station would probably be the next move by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration after completion of the moon program.
WASHINGTON, June 4 -- A sale of $76-million of gold to Italy was the largest United States gold transaction in the first quarter of this year, the Treasury disclosed today.

Local filming went into high gear this week as three major features simultaneously began shooting here. Six other productions already are being filmed here. The nine films constitute "an all-time high for production here since 1966," according to a spokesman for Mayor Lindsay's office.

TOWSON, Md., June 4 (AP) -Nine Roman Catholics who .plundered draft board records m nearby Catonsville and burned them with homemade napalm rested their defense against state charges today on the record of the Federal trial in which they were convicted.

HONG KONG, Thursday, June 5 (AP) -- The First National City Bank of New York announced agreement in principle today to buy 76 per cent of Hong Kong's Far East Bank and its 13 branches in the British Crown Colony.
ON Feb. 7, 1968, the Mates Investment Fund wrote shareholders that a number of mutual funds had taken positions in "investment letter" stock.

SYDNEY, Australia, June 4 -- An official Australian account of the collision between the Melbourne and the Frank E. Evans, made public in Canberra tonight, described the opening minutes of the diaster as "a scene of tragedy and heroism."
The credit markets strengthened yesterday morning, but the modest rise in bond prices didn't last long. In the afternoon, most prices fell back.

GENEVA, June 4 -- The annual conference of the International Labor Organization, a United Nations specialized agency, disregarded tradition today by electing a trade-union official rather than a government delegate as president of its 50th anniversary session.

ONCE when Maxwell Riddle of Ravenna, Ohio, was judging a dog show in Havana, he placed a German shepherd fourth. He is one of the few persons eligible to judge all 116 American Kennel Club breeds. He is also a newspaper reporter in Cleveland.

The 1969 Schaefer Music Festival at Wollman Rink in Central Park will begin on Thursday, June 26, with a pair of concerts by Benny Goodman and Lionel Hampton. It will run through Aug. 23, ending with performances by the Sam Dave Revue and Patti Labelle and the Blue Bells.
Robert C. Currey in his letter published May 24 tells us what "an effective" ABM system will do. He fails, however, to tell us what an ineffective ABM system will do.

HOUSTON, June 4 -- An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified today that the F.B.I. kept a telephone surveillance on the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. for several years before his murder.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 4 (AP) -- Numerous captured documents show that the enemy's high command in Vietnam is acknowledging grave battlefield reverses, but insisting its forces still occupy "the most advantageous position."

MADRID, June 4 -- A 22-year-old man fled from Cuba to Spain today in the wheel pod of a jet airliner, surviving an acute shortage of oxygen and temperatures of 40 degrees below zero during the nine-hour flight. A companion fell to his death.

EPSOM, England, June 4 (Reuters) -- Blakeney, a colt whose owner sold haft his interest in the horse recently, stormed to a one-length victory in the 191st English Derby today at Epsom Downs. Blakeney, who went off at 15-2 odds, was ridden by 21-year-old Ernie Johnson, who was making his first ride in the Derby.
Kennedy International Airport officials unveiled yesterday an array of innovations designed to unclog the airport's cramped passenger facilities this summer.
The City Planning Commission will hold a hearing June 18 on an amended plan for the 25-block Washington Street renewal area on the Lower West Side.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 4 -- Representative Shirley Chisholm, the first Negro woman elected to Congress, told Douglass College graduates here today that there was "no room in the United States of America for white extremists or black extremists."

SANTIAGO, June 4 (Reuters) -- More than 1,000 university students battled police riot squads today for more than three hours near downtown Santiago as they attempted to storm the United States Consulate and the Argentine Embassy.

In nominating Representative William T. Cahill for Governor, New Jersey Republicans have made a responsible choice while striking an important blow at a widespread mood of reaction and negation. They have also preserved a fair chance to recapture the governorship in November after sixteen years of Democratic rule. The Democrats in the primary opted for the familiar by naming Robert B. Meyner, a popular and efficient Governor from 1954 to 1962.

ITHACA, N. Y., June 4 -- Cornell University "obviously has trouble," and one very large need is improved and two-way communications for students, faculty members and the administration, according to its provost, Dr. Dale R. Corson.
PARIS, June 4 -- Hear Mrs Billie Jean King comment on how she lost to Mrs. Leslie Bowrey today in the quarter-finals of the French Open tennis tournament:
History proved to be a demanding, but rewarding, subject last night for the New York Mets.

MOSCOW, June 4 -- A Jewish radio engineer, whose petition to emigrate to Israel was denied a year ago, has been sentenced to three years in a prison camp on charges of slander against the Soviet state and social system.
The proposed "direct" route of the future Second Avenue subway south of 34th Street was attacked yesterday as a line that would bypass a great mass of Lower East Side residents.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, June 4 (UPI) -- A four-engined plane with a Haitian flag painted on its side carried out a raid on Port-au-Prince today. Damage was light and there were no casualties.

WASHINGTON, June 4 -- Cambodia has agreed for the first time to admit American specialists to check her charge that American military defoliating missions in South Vietnam have destroyed millions of dollars worth of Cambodian crops.

BAT YAM, Israel -- Israel's best publicized export beyond Jaffa oranges is probably Habitat, the dramatic complex of box-like housing units by the architect Moshe Safdie that was the centerpiece of Montreal's Expo 67.

WEST POINT, N. Y., June 4 -- Gen. William C. Westmoreland, the Army Chief of Staff, today deplored attacks on the military establishment, which he called "the shield behind which this country has lived in prosperity," at graduation ceremonies at the United States Military Academy.

SYDNEY, Australia, June 4 -- The people of West Irian, the part of New Guinea under Indonesian control, are increasingly unhappy as the scheduled "act of free choice" approaches, according to Australian reports.

RYE, N. Y., June 4 -- William Scott Jr. of San Francisco, competing in the tournament for the fourth time, won the 65th annual United States Seniors Golf Association championship today with a 36-hole total of 143.
Following areexcerpts from a transcript of President Nixon's commencement address yesterday at the Air Force Academy in Colorado Springs, as recorded byThe New York Times:

Mary Hopkin's long, blond hair cascades down her porcelain cheeks, framing a delicate, heart-shaped face. She is a Welsh girl, just turned 19. She speaks quietly, a bit shyly and with a charming lilt. She is concerned that the audiences who come to hear her sing at the Royal Box of the Americana Hotel will expect too much of her.

The nation's top maritime official warned maritime unions yesterday that the shipping industry "cannot afford another strike" and urged settlement of outstanding bargaining before the June 15 deadline. Most sea labor contracts expire on that day.

BONN, June 4 -- West Germany announced today that it was closing its embassy in Cambodia in retaliation for that country's recognition of East Germany.
LISBON, June 4 -- Biafra has decided to free, as "a measure of clemency," 18 foreign oil workers captured in May by Biafran troops and sentenced to death, it was officially announced here tonight.

The Most Rev. James P. Shannon, one of the most liberal prelates in the Roman Catholic hierarchy of America, confirmed yesterday that he had resigned as auxiliary bishop of the Archdiocese of St. Paul-Minneapolis.

LOS ANGELES, June 4 -- Nationwide moves against the pesticide DDT gained impetus today as 60 West Coast marine scientists appealed to Gov. Ronald Reagan to back a measure to ban the use of the compound in California.
PARIS, June 4 -- About two dozen Congressmen are in Paris for the air show, and they do not want publicity.
WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) -- Lee Elder, one of the few Negroes on the professional golf tour, says he will begin skipping tournaments next year because of racial baiting by the galleries.
ALBANY, June 4 (UPI) -- A person who breaks his leg while dancing in the company elevator during his lunch hour may collect workmen's compensation, the Court of Appeals ruled today.
The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation has arranged with 24 major banks a $400-million line of credit, one of the biggest ever negotiated by an industrial company, it was announced here yesterday.
CAIRO, June 4 -- Abie J. Nathan of Tel Aviv, a would-be peacemaker, flew to Cairo from Rome last night by airliner to seek talks with Egyptian leaders.

The Revitalization Corps, a private organization that was inspired by the memory of the late President Kennedy when it was formed five years ago, announced yesterday the opening of its summer program, "Operation Suburbia."

NEWARK, June 5 -- David M. Satz Jr., the United States Attorney for New Jersey since 1961, announced his resignation today and said he would join a Newark law firm on July 7. His resignation will take effect that day.

The rich, resonant singing of massed gongs, chimes, cymbals, bells and tympani was explored in fascinating fashion by Christopher Tree last night at Muse, Bedford Avenue and Lincoln Place in Brooklyn.

Dr. Eugene S. Callender, the city's deputy housing and development administrator, issued a statement yesterday criticizing "the politically motivated prophets of doom" who have attacked the Lindsay administration's rate of housing production.

The key to a settlement of the agonizing strike of ill-paid Negro hospital workers in Charleston, S. C., could be provided by a Federal investigation now under way into charges that the struck State Medical Hospital has violated antibias rules.

Two alleged members of the Carlos Gambino Cosa Nostra family and a reputed narcotics peddler said to have been marked for death because he reportedly owed them $14,500 were arrested in Queens yesterday and held in $50,000 bail each.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., June 5 (AP) -- Fire raged through a large barn at Saratoga Raceway early today, destroying 43 harness racing horses.

VANCOUVER, British Columbia, June 5 (AP) -- Maury Wills, Montreal Expos' record-holding shortstop who asked for voluntary retirement Tuesday, will rejoin the National League club in Los Angeles tomorrow night, General Manager Jim Fanning said today.
NICE, France, June 5 -- This sun-splashed Mediterranean resort is trying to establish itself as a book publishing center, but the results so far have been uncertain.

PHILADELPHIA, June 5 (AP) -- Former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey, stressing that a peace settlement in Vietnam must be acceptable to all the people, urged today "an immediate standstill cease-fire" followed by "free elections open to all political groups."
WASHINGTON, June 5 -- The United States is expected to sign an agreement with Spain within the next few days providing for continuation of United States use of military bases there for two years.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 5 -- The South Korean and American defense ministries held their second annual ministerial-level meeting here this week in an atmosphere of Korean uneasiness that, as one source put it, "the American tide will recede" from post-Vietnam Asia under the Nixon Administration.
FLINT, Mich., June 5 -- A new commuter airline serving seven Michigan and Ohio cities has found an answer to the low ceilings of its planes. It is the ministewardess.

FORT DIX, N. J., June 5 -- Prisoners in the Fort Dix stockade set mattress fires, smashed windows and hurled footlockers, beds and other equipment tonight in what an Army spokesman characterized as a "disturbance."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 5 -- The Security Council was called today to meet on Monday in a new effort to end the five-year-old civil strife in Cyprus before there is a new outbreak of violence.
Consumers continued on a spending spree last month, lifting sales of the nation's major merchandise chains to their highest levels in history.

SINGAPORE, June 5 (AP) -- There was no panic, "just cool detached courage," aboard the destroyer Frank E. Evans in the moments after the United States ship and the Australian carrier Melbourne collided in the South China Sea Monday.
If Henry Higginc tried to teach a chimp to talk and failed, it would not be for lack of talent on the part of the professor or the chimp.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, June 6. Enemy rockets and mortar round struck more than 70 allied installations and populated areas in South Vietnam last night in the most concentrated series of bombardments in more than three weeks.

The Herbert H. Lehman College of City University, which was known as the Bronx branch of Hunter College until last year, held its first commencement yesterday on the campus at Bedford Park Boulevard West and Paul Avenue. There were more than 1,000 graduates.

HOUSTON, June 5 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation monitored the telephoned calls of the leader of the Black Muslim religious sect from 1960 through at least 1966, agents testified in court today. Several of the monitoned conversations related to the former heavyweight champion, Cassius Clay, himself a Black Muslim.

AREA A -Barnegat Bay has had few striped bass this year, according to Cap Colvin of Seaside Park, N. J., a long-time salt-water fly fisherman. Stripers are bE/ing taken in Barnegat Inlet, most with live shrimp, and bluefish from I to 9 pounds have been caught by surf fishermen.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- There is "some discontent" in Latin America over United States policies, Secretary of State William P. Rogers conceded today. He pledged that the Nixon Administration would do "all we can" to improve the situation.

WASHINGTON, June 5 -- Two Democratic Senators challenged today as "superficial and casual" the recommendation of a special Presidential panel that oil drilling and production be resumed off the Santa Barbara coast to prevent a recurrence of the massive leak that killed waterfowl and polluted beaches.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 5 -- Led by Mrs. Albert B. Bower of Pelham, the captain, Westchester won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's 44th annual team match today and the Golf Illustrated Trophy.

The National Football League, an organization founded in 1920, yesterday recognized that not everyone who has played this game wound up being a wealthy man. The N.F.L. owners announced the formation of the Pro Football Players Alumni Foundation, a tax-exempt organization that will provide funds to old-time players in need.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 5 -- "I'm heartbroken," said Mayor Maynard E. Sensenbrenner, bending over his plate of creamed chicken at a civic luncheon this afternoon.

Armour Co. made a small gain in earnings from operations but registered a sharp turnaround in net income in the 26 weeks ended May 3, compared with the similar period in 1968, Charles R. Orem, president, said in his semiannual report at the company's Chicago headquarters yesterday.

Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay exchanged praises and banter last night at the 21st annual dinner of the State Republican Committee at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

MANCHESTER, England, June 5 (AP) -- An American finalist in men's and women's play was assured today when Clark Graebner, Tom Gorman and three women from the United States reached the semi-finals of the Northern lawn tennis championships.

FORT LAUDERDALE, June 5 -- Donna de Varona and Mrs. Vicki Manolo Draves, Olympic champions from California, and 10 others were elected today to the International Swimming Hall of Fame. They were chosen in an international poll of 1,700 coaches.

YONKERS, June 5 -- Overcall paced the fastest mile and a half over any sized oval in 163 years of recorded harness racing history tonight en route to an easy victory in the $50,000 International Pace at Yonkers Raceway.

NAHA, Okinawa, June 5 -- Scuffling broke out here today between striking Okinawan employes of United States bases and American military policemen. At one point, military policemen with fixed bayonets moved forward to push back demonstrators.

ON his 45th birthday yesterday, Donald Edward Johnson received a fitting present from President Nixon: nomination as director of the Veterans Administration. The aptness of the appointment of the towering Iowan from the tiny town of West Branch is rooted in the 24 years he has devoted to the cause of veterans. He has been affiliated with the American Legion since his discharge from the Army in 1946 as a decorated combat hero.

VIENNA, June 6 -- Maria Magdalena Van Der Spuy, 16 years old, the daughter of the South African Ambassador to Austria, Johannes Petrus Van Der Spuy, has been missing from her home here since Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruled today that draft boards had no right to reclassify registrants because of antiwar or antidraft activities, as Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey, Director of Selective Service, suggested they do.

A 14-month-old private postal system that expects to show a profit of a million dollars on its operations to date will open three outlets in New York City by September, its president announced yesterday.

Photo Expo 69, which will open at the Coliseum at 10 o'clock this morning when a laser beam cuts through a strip of 25-mm. film, is fundamentally a trade show at which 350 manufacturers will show their wares.
WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Representative Otis G. Pike asked fellow Representatives yesterday to turn down a $2,456,000 project to improve Port Jefferson Harbor in his home county of Suffolk, L. I.

Joe Namath of the New York Jets, widely accepted as the nation's most flamboyant athlete, announced his retirement from pro football yesterday. His action followed a threatened suspension by Pete Rozelle, the sport's commissioner, for alleged gambling activities by the customers of the quarterback's East Side restaurant.

CHICAGO, June 6 -- George B. Crowley, a defense attorney, said in an opening statement in defense of three policemen today that a newsman had been "restrained' 'but had not been wilfully deprived of his civil liberties after he allegedly shouted an obscenity and "threw a punch" at an unidentified policeman.
BONN, June 6 -- The German waiter appears to be a vanishing breed and figures made public today by the West German Labor Office explain why.

Verdi's "Il Trovatore" was given the kind of lusty performance at the Metropolitan Opera last night that provides the audience with a good time. There is nothing wrong with this, and undoubtedly the work has been treated this way most often in its 116 years.

The International Business Machines Corporation won the first skirmish yesterday in its five-front antitrust battle.

While I sympathize with the idealism of the 35 students who were given a jail sentence for their sit-in at Brooklyn College, I applaud Judge Albert R. Murray for his address to them.

PARIS, June 6 -- It looked odds-on for Nancy Richey today day to reach the final of the French open tennis tourney she won a year ago. The little Texan, familiar in floppy white hat and shorts, was leading Mrs. Margaret Smith Court, 5-2, in the third set and then succumbed to such a superb run of shotmaking and smashing that it defied the possible. Mrs. Court won, 6-3, 4-6, 7-5.

The meeting of the pro football owners concluded yesterday without the accomplishment of their No. 1 goal -- the realignment of the present National Football League for the 1970 season. New Zealand meat producers, recently put under restraint on the amount of beef they could export to the United States, are perturbed over trade reactions to their efforts to increase sales of lamb in the American market.

NAHA, Okinawa, June 6 -- Tsuneo Oshiro has worked for the United States Navy on Okinawa for 14 years and his monthly salary has tripled during that period to $154. From a clerk he has risen to a supervisor with five Okinawan clerks under him. Yet he feels he stands at a dead end.
Columbia University's provost, Paul D. Carter, has resigned after three months and will become vice president and provost at Hamilton College in Clinton, N. Y., in the fall.

WASHINGTON, June 6 -- A year after he succumbed to an assassin's bullet in a Los Angeles hospital, Robert F. Kennedy is best remembered as an apostle of involvement as against alienation, that rare politician who could talk with the people who feel left out.

MASON, Mich., June 6 -- Lawyers for Ronald August, the suspended Detroit policeman accused of murdering a young Negro during the 1967 Detroit riot, contended today ,that the prosecution had failed to show premeditation or malice in the killing.

The Allied Chemical Corporation and the Union Carbide Corporation announced yesterday price increases for major phthalate plasticizers. "AN old juke box makes great lighting fixture." said Dominic Sicilia, the 31-year-old owner of Mr. Nickels' Juke Box Ship, which opened recently at 1105 First Avenue near 60th Street. WASHINGTON, June 6 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers was given a quick course by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today on the intricacies of nuclear disarmament. He emerged with the conclusion that continued testing of multiple warheads could complicate strategic arms control.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- Legislation that would create a Federal Broker-Dealer Insurance Corporation similar to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation was introduced today by Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Democrat of Maine.

Valerie Solanas, who pleaded guilty to assault in the shooting of Andy Warhol, the pop artist and underground film maker, was sentenced to up to three years yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Gerald P. Culkin in Manhattan Criminal Court.

HOYLAKE, England, June 9 (UPI) -- Richard Davies of Pasadena, Calif., opened his bid for a second British Amateur golf championship today by gaining a 5-and-4 triumph over Les Walker of England on the course where the Californian won the title in 1962.

LONDON, June 9 -- Enoch Powell, prominent Conservative Member of Parliament, said tonight that Britain faced a situation "fraught with danger and disaster" unless large numbers of colored immigrants were sent home.

Prices on the London stock market dipped near the close yesterday, after holding steady through most of a quiet trading session.

John E. Leslie, chairman of Bache Co., Inc., the nation's second largest brokerage firm, said yesterday he favored a return to normal trading hours by the exchanges "as soon as possible."

WARWICK, R. I., June 3 -- Jouncing in three-foot waves in six feet of water off Prudence Island in Narragansett Bay, Art Lavallee's outboard launch performed ably as we flung our plugs down the moaning wind.

CHICAGO, June 9 (UPI) -- Bobby Tolan doubled twice and scored each time today to spark the Cincinnati Reds to a 4-1 victory over Chicago that snapped the league-leading Cubs' seven-game winning streak.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) -- Daniel Jackson Oliver Wendel Holmes Morgan, who once posed as a Washington lawyer for six years though he had dropped out of school at the age of 14, lost a fight with the Government today in the Supreme Court.

HONOLULU. June 9 -- President Nixon led a cautiously optimistic team of senior official back across the Pacific today after a conference on, Vietnam that they hoped had eased the political pressures on them at home while preserving their negotiating flexibility in Paris.

Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, who resigned last month from the post of City College president, will receive the college's first Martin Luther King Medal for his "life-long dedication to humanitarian ideals," it was announced yesterday by Dr. Joseph Copeland, acting president.

BASEL, Switzerland, June 9 -- The Bank for International Settlements, which has evolved as a key forum for central bank cooperation, warned today that the monetary system will continue to operate under "uncertain and unstable" conditions because of the intractable payments problems of four major countries -- the United States, West Germany, Britain and France.

WASHINGTON, June 9 -- The House Ways and Means Committee, meeting without its ailing chairman, Wilbur D. Mills of Arkansas, appeared today to be on its way to defeating attempts to write major exemptions into the proposed repeal of the 7 per cent tax credit on business investment for plant and equipment.

Practically every school in the City of New York has been forced to cut back its services due to a lack of personnel and funds. The recent budget cuts have forced all schools to reduce their teaching and administrative staffs.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y, June 10 -- The Security Council voted unanimously today to extend the United Nations peace-keeping force in Cyprus for six more months, until Dec. 15.

MINEOLA, L. I., June 10 -A "neighborhood security watch" to involve community residents in crime prevention was started by Nassau County today in what was believed to be the first program of its kind in the nation.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 10 (UPI) -- The latest of six girls slain in this university area in less than two years was identified tonight by her father.

WASHINGTON, June 10--The Defense Department, after spending $1.3-billion on the project, canceled today the Air Force's manned orbiting laboratory program as "a major step" toward reducing the military budget.

WORCESTER, Mass., June 10 (AP) -- Acting in opposition to the use of napalm in the Vietnam war, the Massachusetts Conference of the United Church of Christ today divested itself of Dow Chemical Company stock.

WHEN Pierre Boulez stops conducting long enough to go home to Baden-Baden, the town in West Germany where he has lived for the last decade, he relaxes in an apartment that occupies two floors of a Victorian mansion.

A Southern television station that had been accused of discrimination against Negroes on the air has reached a private agreement with Negroes and church groups to assure balanced representation of the opinions and interests of all set owners within its viewing area.

PHILADELPHIA, June 10 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies, who have troubles enough with an eight-game losing streak, received an additional setback today when they lost Chris Short, their best pitcher, for the season.
UPTON, L. I., June 10 -- A mongrel dog named Brunhilde has become the first recipient of a nuclear-powered heart pacemaker, it was announced here today.

The new interim Board of Education, asserting that it "will not take even one step backward," refused yesterday to cut back services in the next school year because of the reduction in its requested operating budget.

NAHA, Okinawa, June 10 -- The All-Okinawa Military Employes Trade Union led 5,000 Okinawans this evening in a demonstration to protest the use of bayonets by United States military police and troops during the union's strike against American military installations last Thursday.
WARSAW, June 10 -- The Polish Government moved today to curtail the emigration of Jews.

PARKERSBURG, W. Va., June 10 (UPI) -- A teen-aged brother and sister admitted today that they doused their six-room frame house with gasoline and set a fire that killed their parents and 10 brothers and sisters. Both were charged with murder.
The sloth is energetic and the aardvark is restless. Bats swoop low over water, clawing for fish prey and owls peer into dim light from limb and cliff. Foxes scampser, porcupines hustle, skunks dart.

A $1.5-million finder's fee and a 10-year consulting arrangement with Milton A. Rudin, a Hollywood lawyer, were criticized yesterday at a special meeting of stockholders of Kinney National Service, Inc.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI) -- The House Commerce Committee, after hearing a charge that the National Association of Broadcasters sought to mislead Congress, decided today to go ahead with legislation to give cigarette advertisers a six-year exemption from Government regulation.

SAN FRANCISCO -- What this century needs is a substitute for war. The kind of holocaust to which man lent himself until 1945 is appallingly brutal and evil and has now also become totally impractical if humanity is to survive.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -- Factions in the Nixon Administration are debating a possible extension of the Voting Rights Act of 1965, the key provisions of which are due to expire next year.
GENEVA, June 10 -- The visit by Pope Paul VI to Geneva today went off, as might have been expected, like a bit of Swiss clockwork, with only one flurry of unscheduled excitement.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -Secretary of the Treasury David M. Kennedy warned today that "this is not the time to reduce taxes," when the nation is still beset by "strong inflationary pressures."

In the current debate regarding the establishment of an antiballistic missile (ABM) system it seems that a basic principle is being ignored. In today's technological age the missile has replaced the aircraft I flew in World War II.

Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner Smith, Inc., took a giant step into the domestic mutual fund business yesterday with the announcement that it intended to actively offer mutual funds to its more than 1 million customers.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, June 11 (AP) -- The air war over South Vietnam was intensified yesterday as United States B-52 bombers struck at enemy positions in the Central Highlands and northwest of Saigon.

GENEVA, June 10 -- Pope Paul VI visited this city -- the home of the Swiss Reformation and of the World Council of Churches -- and appealed today for increased efforts to heal the divisions among men caused by poverty and religious conflict.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 10 -- With his institution emerging from a year of bitter student turmoil, the president of Harvard University urged his graduating seniors today to avoid a simplistic approach to the evils they are so impatient to correct.
HONG KONG, June 10 (Agence France-Presse) -- Hanoi today reaffirmed its stand that American pilots held in North Vietnam were war criminals.

PRAGUE, June 10 -- The Czechoslovak Ambassador in Moscow, Vladimir Koucky, asserted today that the Soviet leadership had withheld information on anti-Soviet feeling in Czechoslovakia from the Russian people to prevent "an atmosphere unfavorable to our friendship."

The subpoenas served on university administrators by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations which call for disclosure of the names of leaders and members of campus organizations such as the Students for a Democratic Society are an intolerable intrusion into freedom of association and opinion.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 10 -- Mrs. Eric Ridder spent most of this morning puffing away furiously on a mentholated pacifier and sidestepping women in various stages of undress. It was hard to recognize her own house.
The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court issued a ruling yesterday that threw into confusion the judicial contests that are part of next Tuesday's primary election.
A sprightly great-grandmother recalled her first subway ride 54 years ago as she received a pass yesterday that will permit her to travel on subways and city buses at half fare.

The "whole fabric" of the collective-bargaining process is being challenged by disadvantaged workers who seek entry and permanent status in industry, according to a Washington labor relations consultant.
The price increase for structural steel products initiated last week by the United States Steel Corporation appeared yesterday to be taking hold throughout the industry.
WASHINGTON, June 10--The Judicial Conference of the United States laid down stiff new rules today that forbid all Federal judges except members of the Supreme Court to accept outside fees.
Metromedia, Inc., and the Transamerica Corporation announced in a joint statement last night that the merger plans of the two companies had been called off by mutual consent.
Prices fell sharply on the London stock market yesterday on selling spurred by expectations of a rise in the British bank rate and a further tightening of credit.

IBADAN, Nigeria, June 4 -- Student activists in the United States, Europe and Asia may be committed to pacifism, but most students in Nigeria are hawks, dissatisfied with the relatively restrained conduct of the war against the Biafran rebels.
The Bendix Corporation has instituted a major restructuring that in effect creates three autonomous operating companies and also realigns its top management.

Mario A. Procaccino called on the four other contenders for the Democratic mayoral nomination yesterday to "stop trying to snow the people with daily attacks on the Lindsay administration" and tell the voters, instead, their own positions on the major issues in the campaign.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- The jury began deliberations late today after a two-week trial of three policemen charged with violating a newsman's civil rights by beating him. The violation allegedly took place during the week of the Democratic National Convention.

NEWARK, June 10 -- Some of the inner secrets of organized crime came to light today in the form of transcripts of conversations among reputed members of the Mafia and with other persons, including the man who is now the Mayor of Elizabeth, N. J.
BASEL, Switzerland, June 10 -- Central bankers from the richest countries, trying to figure out what can be done about soaring interest rates, have come to this conclusion -- very little.

In the course of its "Promenades" last night, the New York Philharmonic "saluted" nature and the American Museum of Natural History, which is celebrating its centennial. As nature has often been one of the finest inspirations for composers, so last night's salute turned into one of the most successful programs that Andre Kostelanetz has devised for his series.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 10 (AP) -- Second Lieut. Charles L. (Chuck) Richards of Tacoma, Wash., clipped two seconds from his modern pentathlon world swim record today to move into first place in the sixth modern pentathlon world championships.
WASHINGTON, June 10 -President Nixon arrived home tonight and declared that his trip to Midway had "opened wide the door to peace." He invited North Vietnam to "walk with us through that door."
PARIS, June 10 -- The National Liberation Front announced today the establishment of a "provisional revolutionary government" to rule South Vietnam.
The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York made public a financial statement for the first time yesterday and reported that it operated last year with a deficit of $1.2-million.
Prospects for continued operation of a major segment of the American-flag merchant fleet after midnight Sunday appeared dim yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department estimated today that this year's winter wheat crop would be 1,161,458,000 bushels, com- pared with the 1,127,426,000 predicted a month earlier and 5 per cent less than last year's record production.

A skilled, professional and profound observer of the New York banking scene (having absorbed a maximum dosage of credit card advertising) observed: "Never have I seen such an intensified competitive situation and the strange thing is that they all have the same services."

The Perfect Film and Chemical Corporation has a new president and chief executive officer to succeed Martin S. Ackerman, its controversial executive who headed the Curtis Publishing Company until last March.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) -- Hilary Sandoval Jr. told a Senate hearing today that his agency, the Small Business Administration, was doing well despite problems that he said he had inherited.
Corn futures prices lost about a cent a bushel yesterday in quite active trading. There was talk that most of the new corn crop had been planted and growing conditions appear favorable.

The reported decision of Senators Jacob K. Javits and Charles E. Goodell to join with the Republican State Committee in recommending that Paul Curran, chairman of the State Investigation Committee, succeed Robert M. Morgenthau as United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York is an ill-advised mixing of politics with law enforcement.
Nat Lefkowitz, executive vice president and treasurer of the William Morris Agency, Inc., has been elected president of the agency, which represents every phase of activity in the amusement world.

State Senator John J. Marchi seems more wistful than aggressive as he leaves his handsomely paneled, breeze-swept home on Staten Island's Ward Hill for another day of trying to undo Mayor Lindsay in the Republican primary.

BASEL, Switzerland, June 10 -- The International Monetary Fund will sell $50-million of gold to creditor countries -West Germany, Italy and Japan -- to raise a portion of the money for a new standby credit to Britain, sources reported here today.
MONTREAL, June 10 -- Harry Howell's days with the Rangers ended today after 1,160 games as the New Yorkers sold the quiet defenseman to the Oakland Seals.

CHICAGO, June 10 -- Fourteeen men and two women, members of the Illinois Black Panther party, were indicted yesterday by the Cook County grand jury on charges of kidnapping and conspiracy to commit kidnapping.
