Eight leaders of the Columbia University branch of Students for a Democratic Society were found guilty of criminal contempt of court yesterday and jailed for maximum terms of 30 days for defying a court order banning disruptions on the Morningside campus this spring.

GENEVA, June 10 -- Following are excerpts from Pope Paul VI's address to the International Labor Organization today, from a speech of welcome by Dr. Eugene Carson Blake, general secretary of the World Council of Churches, and from the Pope's reply. The English translations of the Pope's speeches, which were in French, were supplied by the Vatican press office.

The Citizens Union announced yesterday its preference for Representative James H. Scheuer and former Mayor Robert F. Wagner in the five-way Democratic mayoralty primary and for Mayor Lindsay in the two-way Republican primary.

Ken Holtzman again failed to finish what he started last night but, as usual, his Chicago Cub teammates bailed him out. The Cubs scored a 3-1 victory over the Braves at Atlanta and made Holtzman the major leagues' first 10-game winner this season.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., June 10 -- A 23-year-old high school physics teacher who was arrested at a public hearing last night was suspended from the school system today.

WASHINGTON, June 10 -Governor Rockefeller of New York appeared today before a House subcommittee to express his support for legislation that would give state and local governments greater flexibility in utilizing Federal grants.

NEWARK, June 10 (UPI) -The State Public Utilities Commission said today that it had started an investigation of possible safety hazards of the new high-speed Metroliner train.

TORONTO, June 11 -- Seven of Canada's nine chartered banks increased their prime rates today to a record 8 per cent from 7 1/2 per cent. One is expected to decide tomorrow.

More than $2-million has been repaid to the city by 12 voluntary hospitals as a result of new audits of affiliation contracts with the city, Controller Mario A. Procaccino announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 11 -- The White House ordered the cancellation of the manned orbiting laboratory program -- the military's most ambitious space project -- over the objections of the Defense Department and the Air Force, Congressional sources reported today.

Borough President Herman Badillo of the Bronx offered a five-point program yesterday for improving the city's efforts to curb air pollution, and attacked both the Wagner and Lindsay administrations for what he called their "indifference and inaction."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., June 12 -- The Rev. Ralph David Abernathy told a graduating class here today that only "aggressive, nonviolent action" was effective in creating a "world without racism, without poverty and without war."
LONDON, June 12 -- Britain's see-saw trade position showed marked improvement in May.

TOKYO, June 12 (AP) -- The Communist-led Pathet Lao announced a "program of action" today to form a new coalition government in Laos and force the withdrawal of all military personnel from the Southeast Asian kingdom. Presumably the reference was to foreign troops.

MOSCOW, June 12 (UPI) -- The Swedish Communist party joined others from the West today in defying the Soviet Union at the world conference of Communist parties. The Swedes denounced the Soviet-led invasion of Czechoslovakia and dissociated themselves from attacks on China.

The Federal Government's disclosure in Newark on Tuesday of recorded conversations of Mafia members revealed treachery and intrigues within the underworld directed against the top bosses of the secret organization.

HONG KONG, June 12 -- The composition of the new Provisional Revolutionary Government of the Republic of South Vietnam represents no significant change in the realities of the Vietcong political structure, but it does serve to underline the old realities.
Eight policemen were indicted yesterday on charges of having taken payoffs from racketeers to protect gambling operations in the Negro slums of Brooklyn.

Gerald O'Brien, In a May 27 letter, wrote that The Times May 9 news article dealing with the plight of the textile workers in Inman, S. C., did not note the fact that the textile industry is not being damaged by imports, although they have increased -- his premise being that the employes had, until recently, worked 48 hours a week.
PARIS, June 12 -- French financial authorities reported today a larger foreign trade deficit for May and a further loss of gold and foreign exchange reserves in the first week of June.
Prices plunged yesterday in moderately active trading on the American Stock Exchange.

The latest list of primary candidates for City Council, made available late Wednesday night, shows that the incumbent Lester Baum, Republican Councilman at Large for Manhattan, will not be opposed in the primary election.

BILLINGS, Mont., June 12 -- In the deep green valleys between the rumpled rows of mountains that blanket the Appalachian coal fields, a rank and file rebellion is threatening the legacy of John L. Lewis, who died yesterday in Washington at the age of 89.

Atlantic Richfield, the country's eighth largest oil company, has invited its three ad agencies and four others to compete for its future advertising business, which could be worth $20-million a year in billings.

JERUSALEM, June 12 -- One of the most dramatic encounters in the two-year struggle between Israeli patrols and infiltrating Arab commandos on the west bank of the Jordan River ended yesterday in a mountaintop battle with 11 men reported dead.
State Senator John J. Marchi said yesterday that he would not wait for an invitation from a college president before moving the police onto a campus to quiet disorders.

THEY are young and single. The skirts they swing are very often short and the eyelashes they flutter are very often false. Meeting men is never a problem, but it usually engenders stereotyped reactions.
BONN, June 12 -- Controversy is developing in West Germany over two disturbances that erupted this week during university appearances by the Israeli Ambassador, Asher Ben-Natan.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today a settlement of its case against Frederic S. Mates and the mutual fund and investment-advisory and management service that bear his name.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 12 -- New York bankers began a strong counterattack here today against critics who charge that banks are responsible for soaring interest rates.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Robert P. Mayo, the Director of the Bureau of the Budget, told Congress today that President Nixon had changed past procedures to give the Budget Bureau as much opportunity to challenge defense spending as the spending of any of the civilian agencies.
WASHINGTON, June 12 -- This afternoon at 2:30 o'clock a dark, unmarked car paused in front of Walker-Jones Elementary, a neatly kept school in one of Washington's poorer black sections.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration opened its broadest attack yet on combination drugs today. It ordered off the market 49 commonly used antibiotics that it said were ineffective or dangerous.

HOYLAKE, England, June 12 (UPI) -- Dale Morey and Bill Hyndman 3d of the United States and the defending champion, Mike Bonallack of England, gained the quarter-finals of the British Amateur golf championship today.

AS a sports novel, Brian Glanville's "The Olympian" takes a median position, equidistant from the mythic, fantasy-serving character of Bernard Malamud's "The Natural" and from the hard-line naturalism of Budd Schulberg's "The Harder They Fall." Mr. Glanville has used the very real world of the champion miler to trace an imaginary quest, an errand into the maze done time and again under four minutes.

GENEVA, June 12 -- President Nixon applauded the International Labor Organization today on its "half-century of dedicated service to humanity."

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- President Nixon greeted with marked warmth today President Carlos Lleras Restrepo of Colombia, the first Latin-American chief of state to be invited here as a state guest by the Administration.

The momentum built up in the past few months by the sensationally successful flights of Apollos 8, 9 and 10 made almost inevitable yesterday's decision to "go" with Apollo 11 on the scheduled date, July 16, for the first lunar landing mission.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.
The president of the Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn, Dr. Ernst Weber, who will retire June 30, called on students yesterday to realize that all people do not deserve equal educations.
A 26-year-old Queens mother was charged with first-degree manslaughter yesterday in the death of her 9-month-old daughter, whom authorities described as "a battered and abused child."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 12 -- Harvard University conferred 3,907 degrees today at a ceremony marred somewhat by the walkout of about 100 students. A more disruptive demonstration was averted by an unexpected, last -minute decision by Harvard's president, Nathan M. Pusey, to allow a representative of the Students for a Democratic Society to address the convocation. rump session nearby.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- Resentment is being expressed by some Federal judges over the stiff new restrictions on their outside activities, which critics say were rammed through by Chief Justice Earl Warren without adequate notice to the judiciary.

The Everglades National Park faces a decisive threat to its existence. On a site at the northern edge of the park, Miami proposes to build the world's biggest airport, covering 39 square miles. The airport planners envisage jets, jumbo jets, and supersonic transports arriving and departing every 30 seconds.

WASHINGTON, June 12 -- United States officials said today that the efforts of the major powers to achieve a Middle East settlement had reached a critical stage with the current visit of Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister, to Cairo.

TOKYO, June 12 -- Japan's two largest automobile makers, the Toyota and Nissan motor companies, have disclosed that 19 models of their products, in addition to Toyota Corona and Nissan's Datsun Bluebird models, have structural or mechanical defects.

LANSING, Mich., June 12 (UPI) -- Michigan's only woman state Senator stood brushing tears from her face today while her male colleagues applauded after she told of her own abortion in a dramatic but futile attempt to win passage of legislation liberalizing the state's 100-year-old abortion statute.

The New York Philharmonic headed into the home stretch of its 1969 season of "Promenades" at Philharmonic Hall last night with the introduction of its final program of the current season. This was a "Promenade de Paris," and the entire second half was devoted to music by Jacques Offenbach, who was born 150 years ago this month.
Billy Graham visited Madison Square Garden yesterday for a final check on arrangements for the 10-day crusade that he will open here this evening.

The Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company realized its first profit increase in a year and a half with a 21.5 per cent rise in the first fiscal quarter ended May 24, according to the results issued yesterday by Melvin W. Alldredge, chairman.
ROME, June 12 -- Near the outset of his address to the World Council of Churches in Geneva two days ago, Pope Paul VI said, "Our name is Peter."

Barnett Newman, the abstract expressionist who has often been a critic of the Museum of Modern Art, came yesterday to the defense of the museum, which had been charged of exercising "a subtle form of blackmail" by soliciting the donations of works from artists for a forthcoming exhibit.

The Federal Reserve's clamp on credit, which on Monday forced the prime lending rate of the banks up to a record 8 1/2 per cent, is becoming progressively tighter, banking figures published yesterday showed.

BUENOS AIRES, June 12 -- Argentina's military Government today virtually completed the naming of a new cabinet in response to widespread rioting and strikes two weeks ago.

TRENTON, June 12 -- Organized crime and political corruption emerged today as the hottest issue in New Jersey's gubernatorial election, with the Democratic and Republican candidates pledging themselves to all-out campaigns against the mob.

Stock prices sagged yesterday to their 1969 low under the weight of tight money conditions and uncertainty over Washington's next moves to combat inflation. There was no panic selling, but popular market averages kept grinding progressively lower without any attempt at a rally. The Dow-Jones industrial average dropped 12.02 points to 892.58. This brought the blue-chip average to its poorest reading since the close of 892.34 on Aug. 23, 1968.

VIENNA, June 12 -- Pierre Boulez, newly appointed conductor of the New York Philharmonic, said today that he intended to have as many guest conductors as possible to take care of those parts of the repertory that were contrary to his personal taste and musical personality.
Cocoa futures rallied a little yesterday under the influence of what brokers called "heavy buying" from Europe, mainly Switzerland.

Four years ago, when private banks and other money-lending agencies were being asked to assume major responsibility for student loans, it was emphasized that the shift from government to private lending would not increase the students' financial burden as the government would still meet the differential between high-interest commercial loans and low-cost Federal ones.

The Museum of Modern Art announced two appointments yesterday in its department of painting and sculpture. William S. Lieberman, formerly a curator in the department, has been named its director and William S. Rubin, also a curator, has been named chief curator of the painting and sculpture collection, with primary responsibility for acquisitions and research on the collection.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Congress took the first tentative step today to prepare for a possible constitutional convention, the first since the Federal charter was drafted in 1787.
Prospects for labor peace instead of a strike for the bulk of the privately owned American merchant marine brightened last night.

The National Timber Supply Act, which I had the honor to sponsor in April, has been the subject of almost daily news stories and widespread favorable editorial support. It reflects the findings of the March 19-21 Senate Banking and Currency Committee hearings and investigation of softwood lumber and plywood prices and availability.
Stock prices recovered slightly yesterday in a technical rally after falling on Thursday to their 1969 low.

The Atlanta Braves, feeling the pinch from poor pitching, used their top starter, Phil Niekro, in relief last night for the second time since last Sunday. He gave a single to Manny Sanguillen in the 10th inning that scored Jose Martinez from third and gave the Pirates a 2-1 victory at Pittsburgh.

CAIRO, June 13 -- The Soviet Union and the United Arab Republic, after four days of consultations here by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, declared today that a settlement of the Arab-Israeli conflict would require adherence to "all parts and provisions" of the resolution of the United Nations of Nov. 22, 1967, on the crisis.
HOUSTON, June 13 -- On the practice tee today, Jack Nicklaus discovered what he had been searching for during the past several weeks.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The Justice Department contended today that it had the legal power of eavesdrop without court approval on members of organizations that it believes to be seeking to "attack and subvert the Government by unlawful means."
Tom Paxton probably writes more good songs on more worthy subjects than any other folk singer popular today.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (UPI) -- Mayor James N. Corbett Jr. of Tucson, Ariz., charged today that the publisher of two Tucson newspapers had acquired a dictatorial monopoly on public opinion in the city.
In John Lindsay we have a Mayor who is working to break the cycle of spiraling welfare costs through education, job training and the establishment of Federal standards of assistance.

NEW LONDON, Conn., June 13 -- Tom Bolles, Harvard's athletic director emeritus and the varsity crew coach at Cambridge from 1937 to 1951, is going to be among the missing tomorrow when the Crimson meets Yale in intercollegiate rowing's oldest rivalry.

BRISTOL, England, June 13 (UPI) -- Pierre Barthes, a French professional, scored his third upset in as many days, when he defeated Clark Graebner of New York, 10-8, 6-4, today to advance with Ken Rosewall of Australia into the final of the Wills open tennis tournament.

THE Columbia University student protest that brought police to the campus was the basis for an unusual experiment in filmmaking last night. The sequence of events at Morningside Heights was re-enacted in the form of a simulated documentary designed to personalize the convictions of the participants and illustrate decisionmaking ordeals of the parties in conflict.

Rockefeller University conferred 27 doctor of philosophy degrees in the sciences and mathematics yesterday in a commencement exercise free of some of the features -- planned and unplanned -- that have been marking the graduation ceremonies of many universities.
WHAT is being billed as the first "self-propelled vacuum cleaner" whizzed across the carpeted floor at the Plaza yesterday during a press preview of the Hoover Company's new upright cleaner.

OMAHA, June 13 -- It has been 16 years since a team from the northeastern section of the United States won the National Collegiate Athletic Association's baseball championship. Holy Cross accomplished the feat in 1952 as a representative of District I. No District II team has ever done it.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., June 13 -- Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, put the blame for inflation, which he termed the nation's first domestic problem, on the Government today, declaring that Continued on Page 52, Column 1 its responsibility for soaring prices was "almost complete."

Lawyers for 14 Black Panthers accused of plotting to bomb department stores and a police station demanded yesterday that District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of Manhattan be replaced by a temporary district attorney to handle their case.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 13 -- The Massachusetts Institute of Technology awarded degrees today to 1,139 men and women, about 90 of whom wore red armbands on their black academic robes.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed lower on balance yesterday, for the 10th consecutive session. But the market showed some signs of stiffening against the downward pressure.

THE second week of fur showings ended on a cheerful note. Laurence Kaye of Christian Dior furs matched yesterday's sunny morning with an array of minks dyed in mouth-watering pastels. But at the commencement ceremonies yesterday, the nation's oldest and most prestigious intellectual community showed, if not the thickness of its armor, the real toughness of its sinews.
LOS ANGELES, June 13 (AP) -- Development of a simple blood test for melanoma that may hold promise of mass screening for some other forms of cancer was reported today by an immunologist.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -United States officials generally believe that the Vietcong's proclamation of a Provisional Revolutionary Government for South Vietnam has dimmed hopes for progress at the Paris peace talks in the near future.

HOLMDEL, N. J., June 13 -- When the Garden State Arts Center was inaugurated a year and a day ago, it was "baptized by a great downpour," as one official put it. Last night, as the center opened its second season, the weather could be described as a benediction.
BALTIMORE, June 13 -- The South all-star lacrosse team broke a two-game North winning streak tonight with a 12-11 victory before more than 5,000 fans at Johns Hopkins University.
Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner yesterday assailed what he called "indirect appeals to bigotry" by Controller Mario A. Procaccino.
City Councilman Robert A. Low called yesterday on three labor experts who have helped solve a variety of city crises to help bring Joe Namath back to the New York Jets.

Judge Edward C. McLean of the United States District Court in New York ruled yesterday that Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., should be able to sell its 33,215-share interest in the Mercantile National Bank of Chicago to the Gleaco Corporation for $3,321,500, or $100 a share.

In its tentative proposals for the tax treatment of foundations, the House Ways and Means Committee would emulate the farmer who burned down a perfectly sound barn in order to rid it of a few pests. Instead of pinpointing its fire on the culprits -- those foundations which are operated as blinds for tax dodgers -- the committee proposes a blunderbuss attack on all foundations.

LOS ANGELES, June 13 -- The last time the New York Mets and Los Angeles Dodgers faced each other, they played a 15-inning 1-0 game decided by an outfielder's error. Tonight they managed to do the same thing in only nine innings, but it was the Dodgers who won it.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., June 13 -- The inhabitants of Martha's Vineyard, who have probably not been so collectively upset about anything since the British Marines sacked their serene island in 1778, are feuding over whether to try to repel a new invasion from the mainland -- by jet airliners.

BALTIMORE, June 13 (AP) -Doctors at Johns Hopkins Hospital, using some techniques for the first time, have taken a major stride toward rebuilding the face of a 13-year-old Tennessee girl in a 13-hour operation.

THE cool, wet growing season thus far has encouraged that nemesis on the premises, annual bluegrass. Many gardeners are fooled into thinking that their lawn is vigorous and velvety only to find it fade out quickly as soon as hot weather arrives. Nothing more drastic has happened than the cyclic fading out of annual bluegrass, the pesky look-alike weed grass that makes gardeners believe their lawn is the real thing, perennial Kentucky bluegrass.

LE MANS, France June 15 -- For the first 21 hours, the 24 Hours of Le Mans was an endurance contest, a slowly evolving test of gear boxes and fuel injection pumps. But when the field was left with only 14 of the 45 starters, the endurance contest became a real race, a race for three hours between men as well as between screws and bolts.

PITTSBURGH, June 13 -- The nation's big-city Mayors are trying to mount a campaign that would persuade the Nixon Administration to put more Federal money into urban programs. But so far they have been unable to agree among themselves on how, or whether, to attack a prime target -- the military budget.
The stage was set yesterday for a tennis match that local fans had been anticipating when George Seewagen Jr. and Pete Fishbach reached the final of the New York State men's championship.

MIAMI, June 15 (UPI) -- John William DiGiovanni, a reputed frequenter of Joe Namath's Bachelor III restaurant, was arrested by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents today on charges of jumping bail bond and bank burglary.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- The Soviet Union is working hard to "neutralize or destroy" the United States' fleet of 41 Polaris missile submarines, in the view of Vice Adm. Hyman G. Rickover.

BANGUI, Central African Republic, June 13 -- Gen. Jean Bedel Bokassa, President of this landlocked state in the heart of Africa, decided recently to close a bank whose manager he suspected of unsavory methods.

WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Cyrus R. Vance, former United States representative at the peace talks in Paris, broke his self-imposed silence on President Nixon's negotiating strategy today and called for a "standstill cease-fire" by all sides in Vietnam.

SEGOVIA, Spain, June 15 (AP) -- A three-day-old restaurant jammed with 500 supermarket employes at a celebration collapsed today in Los Angeles de San Rafael, a mountain housing development, killing 51 persons and injuring 175.
HARTSDALE, N. Y. -- Perched on a little knoll on the edge of town, the white frame house looks, on the outside, straight out of New England; a variation of a Cape Cod cottage, perhaps.
A volcanic dynamo called La Lupe shook up Carnegie Hall Saturday night.

Mayor Lindsay and State Senator John J. Marchi took advantage yesterday of their last joint appearance before tomorrow's Republican mayoral primary to debate which of the two was telling the truth about problems of finance and crime in the city.
WASHINGTON, June 15 -- Dr. Harold Mohamed, a white college administrator in a dark business suit, set his jaw and threw back his shoulders.

HANOVER, N. H., June 15 -- A midmorning downpour disrupted the 199th Dartmouth College commencement more than protesters did today, forcing the participants to reassemble in soggy dignity in a field house half a mile from the campus.

BOGOTA, Colombia, June 14 -- For a decade, Colombia has been the main testing ground for the proposition that democracy and development can be advanced together in Latin America by self-help and United States aid and investment.

UTICA, N. Y., June 15 -- A crowd of 200 rampaged through a predominantly Negro section of Utica for several hours early today, breaking windows, looting half a dozen stores and hurling stones and bottles at the police.

They come, dropping the tensions and fears of their city jungle, to take in the mood of relaxation and gaiety beside the fountain and the pool, and beneath the trees of the new little park of Lincoln Center.

HOUSTON, June 15 -- Walking through the pine woods to the 18th tee at the Champions Golf Club today, a husky 35-year-old man in a beige cap, orange shirt and gray slacks was stopped by a blue-shirted marshall.

It was with some interest that I read your front page article on "The Changing City: A Medical Challenge" of June 2, and some of the comments about the inadequacy of nursing care in New York's hospitals.

PARIS, Monday, June 16 -- France yesterday elected Georges Pompidou, a Gaullist, to succeed Charles de Gaulle as President of the Republic for the next seven years. Mr. Pompidou defeated Alain Poher, the Interim President, after a short and bitter campaign. He won nearly 58 per cent of the vote.
Mitchell I. Ginsberg, the city's Human Resources Administrator, said yesterday that the latest figures indicated a "dramatic and drastic decline" in the rate of increase on the city's welfare rolls.

MONT TREMBLANT, Quebec, June 15 -- The only way Bruce McLaren and Denis Hulme can be expected to lose a Can-Am race is for them to collide while show boating for the crowd and thus eliminate themselves from the race. Well, that didn't happen today in the Labatt Can-Am, second of this year's schedule, and the London-based New Zealanders as usual placed one, two, the one in today's case being Hulme.
JERSEY CITY, June 15 -- John V. Kenny's monolithic rule over the old-line Hudson County Democratic organization is expected to easily repel a challenge in Tuesday's mayoral election here.

THE rather obvious idea that love is as constant as the Seine despite the competition of the glamorous worlds of modeling and TV is presented with a good deal of charm and tenderness in "You Only Love Once," the French import that had its premiere yesterday at the Fine Arts Theater.

HANOI, North Vietnam, June 15 (Agence France-Presse) -- President Ho Chi Minh made a rare public appearance last night when he attended a rally here to mark the Vietcong's setting up of a provisional revolutionary government for South Vietnam.

"Strange Paradise," a Monday - through - Friday dramatic series, the first to be produced for television syndication, will have its premiere in the fall as the joint production of four broadcasting organizations.
PARIS, Monday, June 16 -- The French created a seeming paradox yesterday by voting into the presidency the protege of the man they sent into retirement less than two months ago.

The New York Athletic Club retained its team title yesterday in the Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union track and field championship meet at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx. The Winged Foot scored 69 points as the Grand Street Boys finished a distant second with 28, followed by Long Island A.C. with 27 and the Pioneer Club with 26.

FOUR-YEAR-OLD Princess Stephanie of Monaco has been seen in ermine. Her 12-year-old sister, Princess Caroline, reportedly has a rabbit coat. America's Caroline has never evidenced a penchant for fur, but now that her mother is married to a Greek shipping sovereign, who knows?

Fred Benjamin is a dancer who was nurtured in the bright-lights school of "show" choreography, which has left an unmistakable mark on all of his work. With his company, he presented a concert of five dances yesterday evening at Clark Center.

LONDON -- The collective bargaining between Prime Minister Wilson and the British Trades Union Congress on legislation to curb wildcat strikes has provided depressing reinforcement for those who fear that democratic institutions all over the world are so trapped in outmoded slogans that they will eventually cut their own throats.

The halfway mark was reached last week on the conversion of the 18-year-old Delaware Memorial Bridge to four-lane, one-way traffic. The last section of concrete deck on the southern half of the roadway was poured on schedule Thursday by the contractors for the Delaware River and Bay Authority.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 15 (AP) -- North Vietnamese troops struck at a United States artillery base in the Ashau Valley today but were hurled back with heavy losses before they could break into the camp itself.

The country's maritime industry, which only recently got over the longest strike in its history, was hit by another one at midnight last night. The strike, affecting ships operating out of Atlantic and Gulf Coast ports, began after talks broke down between the union representing East and Gulf Coast masters, mates and pilots and the major shipping groups.
The razor's edge that corporations have been treading in the area of timely disclosure has become even finer as a result of a recent court case won by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
If 1966 was the year of the credit crunch, 1969 will be the year of the super crunch.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 15 -- Alexander Calder heaved his bulk out of an Oldsmobile 98 marked "Mayor's Welcoming Committee," shielded his eyes with a thick workman's hand, and stared intently at the great, swooping, orange-red, 42-ton mass of metal.
BUENOS AIRES, June 15 -- Radio listeners in Lima have been hearing a stream of commercials for Peruvian-built Ford automobiles read by an announcer with an exaggerated Japanese accent.
Joe Namath hired James J. Lynch, a former Federal Bureau of Investigation agent, yesterday to police his restaurant.
DALLAS, June 15 (AP) -- In a spectacular collision, one race driver was killed and a second was seriously injured today in the finals of the National Hot Rod Association's Spring-nationals.

At the end of an academic year shaken by disruption and violence, there is evidence of growing determination among concerned faculty, administrators and students to uphold campus government under law. The unhappy responsibility of isolating the destroyers and, if necessary, removing them from the campus is now generally acknowledged and was carried out last week at Harvard.
When Kyutaro Isomura leaves New York for Japan sometime this summer he will leave behind a good size corporate monument to the skills of the Japanese businessman.

TO BE honest, I never actually expected to see "A Teaspoon Every Four Hours," which, with a kind of Virginia-like trust in Santa Claus, was bold enough to open at the ANTA Theater on Saturday night, merely 193 days before Christmas.

The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation announced yesterday that one of its subsidiaries had purchased 35 per cent of the common stock of Tadiran Israel Electronics Industries, Ltd., Israel's largest electronics manufacturer.
BONN, June 15 -- The combined effect of economic boom conditions and Bonn's refusal to revalue the West German mark has been the biggest run on West German securities since 1960.
Top-level executive changes have been announced in various segments of the maritime industry.
Lumber and plywood prices, which went through the roof last winter, are back in the cellar again.

PHILADELPHIA, June 15 -- The road back to Christian unity leads through "a true and real service to the world,' which can be accomplished only by a church ready to serve rather than rule, a high Vatican prelate said tonight.

The United Fruit Company took first place in the National Safety Council's 1968 safety contest for ship lines operating oceangoing and coastwise dry cargo and passenger vessels. The awards were announced last week.

Several recent contributors to your columns have asserted that the Chinese Communist Government can be relied on to conduct its affairs in a rational manner (Fairbank et al., Lewis, Bernstein). To students of the economy of the China mainland, this view appears optimistic.

SUBIC BAY, the Philippines, June 16 -- The bridge watch officer aboard the Australian carrier Melbourne when she cut the United States destroyer Frank E. Evans in half on June 3 testified today under questioning that if the carrier had maintained a different course and reduced her speed, "the collision would still have occurred but maybe not at a right angle."

Although Adam Clayton Powell is not our favorite Congressman, a great deal more than the fortunes of one Representative and one election district are involved in the United States Supreme Court decision that he was wrongfully excluded by his colleagues in the House of Representatives two years ago.

EASTBOURNE, England, June 16 (AP) -- Prime Minister Wilson offered today to work with President-elect Georges Pompidou of France for a united Europe, starting with Britain's entry into an enlarged Common Market.
" Crunch Day" came and went yesterday, leaving Wall Street none the worse for wear.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Food and Drug Administration has told manufacturers to put much sharper limits on their claims for a widely used class of sulfa drugs.
A major redevelopment project on the Brooklyn waterfront calling for the creation of a 70-acre container and general cargo facility between 33d and 39th Streets was announced yesterday.
LONDON, June 16 -- Clark Graebner had a frantic few minutes before reaching the third round of the London open grass - court tennis championships today.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Tuesday, June 17 (Reuters) -- The Police High Commissioner said today that Indonesian authorities in West Irian had smashed a plot to assassinate the United Nations special representative for the territory, Ferdinand Ortiz Sanz, head of the West Irian office in Jakarta.

PRAGUE, June 16 -- The Czechoslovak Communist party showed concern today over the letter-writing campaign that is going on as a way of registering opposition to the new conservative pro-Moscow regime.

HOUSTON, June 16 -- The head of American Reform Judaism's rabbinic body called on his fellow clergymen today to assign a lower priority to theological discussions with Christian spiritual leaders because of their "neurtal" if not "antagonistic" attitude toward Israel.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- A New York law that restricted voting in some school district elections to parents of schoolchildren and property owners or lessors was voided by the Supreme Court today.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The Administration was urged today by a House Republican leader and a group of moderate Republican Senators to halt the testing of multiple missile warheads while it seeks an agreement on arms control with the Soviet Union.

NEWPORT, R. I., June 16 -- While Huey Long's 76-foot ketch Ondine and Ted Turner's converted 12-Meter sloop American Eagle continued at the top of the fleet, the number of yachts reported as disabled today grew to seven from among the 84 that started to race here from Annapolis on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The prospect of a direct confrontation between Congress and the Supreme Court was raised today by the Court's decision that the House had improperly excluded Representative Adam Clayton Powell.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that a large number of savings and loan associations had shown interest in proposals for long-term lending to them by the home-loan banks.
Mayor Lindsay signed local laws yesterday to enlarge and strengthen community planning boards and to give 50,000 elderly homeowners, starting next year, a 50 per cent cut in their real-estate taxes.

The "Automatic" Sprinkler Corporation, which made 22 acquisitions between 1965 and 1968, announced yesterday that it was planning a new acquisition -- its own stock.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Industrial production resumed its robust growth in May after a one-month slowdown in April, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- The author of the controversial Air Force contract for the C-5A cargo plane told Congress today that the cost of the jumbo carrier was running "hundreds of millions of dollars" below what it would have been under conventional contract procedures.

Denny McLain, the enfant terrible of Detroit, defeated the New York Yankees on six hits last night and became the first pitcher in the American League to win 10 games.

Igor Stravinsky will observe his 87th birthday today in New York Hospital, which he entered seven weeks ago for a blood-clot operation on his right leg. The composer, who has had two more operations since, is feeling well enough to be planning to leave the hospital very shortly, according to Lillian Libman, his personal representative.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to consider the Federal Government's contention that the 13 Atlantic Coast states have no jurisdiction over offshore lands beyond the three-mile limit.

In an effort to expand its campaign against drugging show horses, the American Horse Shows Association yesterday decided to announce publicly when its veterinarians arrive at a show to test horses.

Flight departures of Pan American Airways were delayed up to three hours at Kennedy International Airport last night by a slowdown of baggage handlers and mechanics and a work stoppage by ticket agents.

Prices on the London Stock Exchange drifted down after a firm opening yesterday as domestic economic uncertainties dampened trading activity.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Facing a doubling of air traffic by 1975, President Nixon asked Congress today to levy new and higher user charges to pay for a 10-year, $5-billion airport and airways improvement program.

The people on the street are backing Joe Namath, 5-1, in his dispute with Pete Rozelle, the Commissioner of Pro Football.
The bond market staged another cautious advance yesterday, nudging several interest rates down some more.

WASHINGTON, June 16 (UPI) -- The Defense Department today identified 100 men killed in Vietnam. They included the following:
CAIRO, Ill., June 16 -- Chief of Police William Peterson received a baptism of fire this morning in his first day on the job.
Rod Carew, the leading hitter in the major leagues, used his fleet feet instead of his talented bat to tie an American League record last night.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Several sponsors of a bill dealing with campus disorders reversed their stand today, signaling almost certain death of the measure in House committee. However, key backers of the bill vowed they would carry the fight to the House floor by seeking to add the measure as a rider to some future appropriations bill.

The American Stock Exchange extended its current decline into the 11th successive session yesterday. There were brief signs of a recovery at the opening, and the list showed gains until noon. Thereafter, however, bearishness asserted itself again, and the list closed near its low for the day.

Twelve women climbed onto the back of a truck yesterday to announce in crowded Herald Square that a citywide coalition of women had been formed to urge Congress to reverse the nation's priorities and appropriate money for social concerns rather than military defense.
ALBANY June 16 (UPI) -- Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea, Jr., announced today the formation of a temporary state commission to study violence and unrest on campus.
Waterfront thefts and pilferage costs United States industry $59-million a year and the figure is rising, according to the American Institute of Marine Underwriters.

BRASILIA, June 16 -- Governor Rockefeller arrived today in Brazil, where hundreds of political dissidents were under arrest to prevent demonstrations against the Governor, President Nixon's special envoy to Latin America.

Three insurance companies joined forces with the Agency for International Development (A.I.D.) yesterday to finance 700 houses in Tegucigalpa, Honduras. The deal is typical of others sponsored by the agency which generated $197million in housing loans in Latin America last year.

Twentieth Century-Fox has spent almost $15,000 for two full-page newspaper ads to defend its $20-million production of "Tora! Tora! The International Paper Company announced yesterday an increase of $5 a ton in the price of unbleached kraft linerboard and semichemical corrugating material, effective Aug. 1 for all shipments east of the Rocky Mountains.

MINOTOLA, N. J., June 16 -- Two schools were closed in this small South Jersey community today because of racial tensions resulting from an alleged beating of a black student by a white teacher at Cleary Junior High School last Thursday.

YONKERS, June 16 -- Overcall would have been the favorite in any case, but the 6-year-old stallion owned by Mrs. Helen Buck of Far Hills, N. J., received the advantage of the rail position in today's draw for the $50,000 National Championship Pace on Thursday night at Yonkers Raceway.

WHEN Colombia negotiated a $15-million loan with the World Bank recently to finance a program to build public high schools, there was none of the usual uproar by left-wing students over "foreign domination."

The candidates for the Democratic nominations for citywide offices have been playing a numbers game during their hard-fought battles for voter support and they hope the voters will play it their way in tomorrow's primary.
The city has ordered 50 prefabricated bus shelters, all to be erected by Sept. 30, the Mayor's office announced yesterday.

Wrangling between Pennsylvania and New Jersey Mafia "families" over jurisdictions in recruiting members and in gambling rackets, mutual mistrust between partners in a numbers game and name-dropping of national political figures are disclosed in Federal Bureau of Investigation recordings of eavesdropped talks.
A change in Customs rules to speed air cargo imports through Kennedy International Airport will be announced today in Washington, two Congressmen said here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 16 -- President Nixon named four more ambassadors today -- two businessmen and two career diplomats.

OMAHA, June 16 -- New York University backed Tom Collins's eight-hit pitching with a 12-hit attack and errorless fielding tonight and the big right-hander pitched his teammates to a 9-2 victory over the University of Massachusetts before 8,260 fans.

SEGOVIA, Spain, June 16 (UPI) -- Thousands of mourners crowded into a vast 15th-century cathedral and its square today to pay last respects to 53 persons killed in the collapse of a new restaurant during lunch yesterday.
BOSTON, June 16 (AP) -Nicol Williamson made an unscheduled exit during the opening of "Hamlet" at the Colonial Theatre tonight.
CHICAGO, June 16 ((UPI) -- The Great Lakes head of the Seafarers International Union and a top aide were sentenced to prison today for plotting bombings during a 1963 labor dispute.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- The Supreme Court declined today to take up an anti-trust suit by three St. Louis dairies against a supermarket chain they claimed was trying to monopolize the market.

PARIS, June 16 -- In choosing a political leader, the French tend to feel that the kind of woman the candidate married is his affair, not theirs. Wives do not campaign, and, in fact, the more they are out of the limelight, the better for their husbands.
PARIS, June 16 -- There was only temporary relief for the French franc today following the election victory of Georges Pompidou.

The Supreme Court's ruling yesterday that the House of Representatives had acted unconstitutionally two years ago when it excluded Adam Clayton Powell, still leaves unresolved one of the chief causes for the Harlem Representative's exclusion by his colleagues.

LONDON, June 16 -- Earl Alexander of Tunis, architect of Allied victories in the Middle East, North Africa and Italy in World War II. died this morning in the hospital at Slough. Buckinghamshire, 20 miles west of London. His age was 77.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 16 -The House of Representatives sent a message to President Nguyen Van Thieu today urging him to dismiss the one-year-old Government of Premier Tran Van Huong.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- The Justice Department filed suit today challenging a North Carolina law on the ground that it set up a special school system that perpetuates segregation.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, June 17 (AP) -- A 500-man Vietcong force, attacking a Thai base 20 miles east of Saigon, was mauled yesterday in a six-hour battle that brought United States warplanes, helicopters and artillery into play.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- Trade unions can force companies to bargain in some cases where certification elections have not been held, the Supreme Court ruled today.

The director of the city's Medicaid program yesterday estimated that "a minimum of 5 per cent" of the bills from private practitioners contained instances of fraud and other abuses, and that this would worsen "substantially" because of budget reductions ordered by the state in the city's auditing of the program.

WASHINGTON, June 16 -- Mortgage prices plummeted and offers to sell mortgages to the Federal National Mortgage Association soared in the wake of the increase in the commercial-bank prime rate, it was disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) -- Trade unions can force companies to bargain in some cases where certification elections have not been held, the Supreme Court ruled today.

The director of the city's Medicaid program yesterday estimated that "a minimum of 5 per cent" of the bills from private practitioners contained instances of fraud and other abuses, and that this would worsen "substantially" because of budget reductions ordered by the state in the city's auditing of the program.
DETROIT, June 16 -- The "air bag" may be the most painful automobile safety device ever developed -- and it fights dirty, too, punching car riders well below the belt.
A convicted narcotics conspirator's sorrowful assertion that he was "repentant" failed yesterday to impress Judge Morris E. Lasker, who sentenced him in Federal Court to seven years in prison.
There will be no Debutante Ball of the Greenwich Junior League this year. The annual September event was not canceled; it never really got started.

The former manager of a Long Island savings organization. who pleaded guilty to emembezzlement last January, walked out of court a free man yesterday after the judge had criticized the bank for making a profit in the case.
The election of F. Perry Wilson as president and chief operating officer of the Union Carbide Corporation was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON June 16 -- Joe Namath, late of the New York Jets, may seem to have little to do with national security, although it is true that professional football is widely considered to be as American as cherry pie.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 16 -- It seems so simple when Jim Ryun lifts his long, lean legs and pumps his arms several times and passes a rival runner in the stretch en route to another victory. But as John Updike, the brilliant novelist, has observed: "Funny, how what makes you move is so simple and the field you must move in is so crowded."
WHITE PLAINS, June 17 -- The Westchester County Republican organization lost five or six primary contests for county legislator today.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 17 -- Despite an influx into West Germany last month of more than $4-billion, the German economy is now short of liquid funds and interest rates are moving up sharply, German bankers said today.
The City Planning Commission will hold a hearing on July 16 on a zoning amendment that would allow swimming pools in the back yards of all one-family and two-family homes.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 17 -- Robert E. (Ted) Turner 3d of Atlanta, who owns American Eagle, could not have been more ebullient today had his converted 12-Meter yacht won the America's Cup, the shimmering international sailing prize for which she was built, but which she never succeeded in defending.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Seeking to break a Congressional impasse, the Nixon Administration proposed today that universities and colleges be given authority to seek Federal court injunctions to quell campus disorders.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The contrasting opinions of Chief Justice Earl Warren and his successor, Judge Warren E. Burger, in the case of Representative Adam Clayton Powell have provided an insight into the "activist" style of Justice Warren and the more conservative approach of Judge Burger.
Controller Mario A. Procaccino was the beneficiary of a major split in the liberal vote in the Democratic mayoral primary yesterday, but he may be hurt by a divided party in November.

ITHACA, N. Y., June 17 (AP) -- Henry Thiesen, Ithaca City Prosecutor, argued today that 10 members of the Students for a Democratic Society should be brought to trial for an anti-R.O.T.C. demonstration at Barton Hall on the Cornell University campus.
A Stanford University astronomer believes he has recorded the motion of the earth through the "glow" of radio waves left from the primordial flash in which it is thought the universe was born.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The House Democratic leadership proposed today a cooling-off period on the Adam Clayton Powell case as its leading figure indicated he might be open to compromise.

GENEVA, June 17 (Reuters) -- George Meany and the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions apparently reached an agreement today to stop the withdrawal of the A.F.I.-C.I.O. from the international group.

About 50 teen-agers from the city's ghettos will sing for their suppers when they reach Rome today in their first trip abroad. For some it will be a first trip outside the city. They'll dance, too, and make music: set up art shows, make films and tape recordings.

SUBIC BAY, the Philippines, June 17 -- The 24-year-old American naval officer who was senior bridge officer aboard the United States destroyer Frank E. Evans when it collided with the Australian carrier Melbourne on June 3 declined today to give testimony before the joint United States-Australian board of inquiry.

ONE day four decades ago, Walter Hagen, then golf's most flamboyant performer, arrived in Augusta, Ga., for an exhibition match. When he discovered that his partner would be Maureen Orcutt, he snorted, "I would get a lady golfer!" not realizing that his blond partner had overheard his remark.
Seventeen will soon be 25 -- impossible in math but possible in publishing.

Everett A. Whorl, a certified public accountant, was indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on perjury charges in connection with a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation of the Crescent Corporation and of Pakco Companies.
The State Department of Social Services announced yesterday that the size of the welfare cutbacks scheduled for July 1 would be reduced everywhere but in New York City.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 17 -- Prof. Richard J. Wurtman flew to Italy the other day to attend a scientific congress. After four days there, he rushed back across the Atlantic to Cambridge, where he is an associate professor at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, to attend sessions of a special committee studying the role of military research at the institute.

Although a registered New York City voter, I am unable to cast a ballot on Primary Day. Within the past six months, due to exorbitantly rising rents, I was forced to move -- and so change voting districts, like thousands of city residents.

ASCOT, England, June 17 -- Princess Anne held up a big, black umbrella all by herself as she and a group of close friends at Royal Ascot Races today strolled from the Royal Enclosure to the paddock despite a mean little drizzle.
UTICA, N. Y., June 17 (AP) -- A police official was suspended for alleged wiretapping during an investigation of a case with Mafia connections, a lawyer said in State Supreme Court here today.

David Schwartz, chairman of Jonathan Logan, Inc., said yesterday that he had purchased the building at 33 West 52d Street containing the Toots Shor restaurant, but had not bought the restaurant itself.

MOSCOW, June 17 -- Since 1953, when he became the first 16-year-old Soviet chess player to earn the title of International Master, tall sandy-haired Boris Spassky has lived a life of chess studded with sparkling victories, but marred by dismal failures in several key matches.
OTTAWA, June 17 -- The city government of Ottawa shows little inclination to make the capital of Canada a model of English-French bilingualism, an official report stated today.

NEW DELHI, June 17 -- Diplomatic activity is quickening among South Asian nations in line with the Soviet Union's new but so far unspecific plan for a collective security system in this part of the world.

The Rhode Island truck driver who was named Driver of the Year by the American Trucking Associations will receive his trophy today from Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe in the department's auditorium in Washington.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -Offices in big-city business districts will receive, mail only twice a day beginning this summer or fall, the Post Office announced today.

Faced with increasing reports of crime -- and a decrease in the percentage of crimes that are solved -- the Police Department is about to test the first major change in the organization and operation of its detectives in the last 50 years.
BOSTON, June 17 -- In a surprise move reflecting changes in administrative procedures, Dr. Mary Daly has been granted tenure and promotion to associate professor of theology at Boston College.
YONKERS, June 17 -- There will be no show betting in Friday night's $25,000 Volomite one-mile free-for-all trot at Yonkers Raceway.

JEKYLL ISLAND, Ga., June 17 (AP) -- Gov. Lester G. Maddox said today that either he or his wife would be a candidate for Governor next year if his program was not approved by the Legislature during this administration.

THE New York Double Knockout Team Championship, in which most of the experts in the metropolitan area were entered when it began in October, ended last week in a victory for Michael Engel, Barclay Cooke, Jay Mechutan and Marcel Friedmann, all of New York.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 17 -- The Security Council President announced today in a meeting on Rhodesia that the Council's 15 members agreed in condemning the white-supremacy Rhodesian Government's plan for a constitutional referendum but had been unable to reach a formal consensus.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- Two small but significant steps toward meeting manpower needs for the mass production of housing were taken today when the carpenters' union entered into a pair of agreements with a housing manufacturer.
A major segment of the nation's merchant marine settled its two-day-old strike last night after two and a half hours of bargaining with the International Organization of Masters, Mates and Pilots.
JESSUP, Md., June 17 -- Two Maryland Circuit Court judges allowed themselves to be handcuffed, thrown in jail and made to mingle with 1,520 felons today, just to see what it was like.

THE Museum of Modern Art's summer exhibition, "The New American Painting and Sculpture: The First Generation," which opens to the public today, bears no serious battle scars in spite of all the ruckus it has created.
Democrats chose nominees for the Civil Court in 10 primary contests yesterday, with organization and insurgent candidates roughly splitting the victories.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 17 -- Although official statements from Cairo assert that full agreement was achieved between the Soviet Union and the United Arab Republic during the recent visit of Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko, Western diplomatic analysts here see signs of a fundamental and growing disagreement between the Russians and the Arabs.

LIONEL TIGER, a young Canadian anthropologist now teaching at Rutgers, begins his tortuous but explosive study with the innocent observation that men enjoy the company of other men -- without the presence of women -- which will seem like a crashing cliche to anyone with eyes in his head to observe the per sistence in American culture of the Saturday-night poker game, Maggie and Jiggs, and the sign of crossed arms brandishing rolling pin.

BUFFALO, June 17 -- Mrs. Alfreda W. Slominski, a conservative Republican, won her party's nomination for Mayor today in an easy victory over Richard E. Moot, who is considered a moderate-to-liberal Republican.

SOME visitors to Belmont Park pay their $2 to enter the track and never see a horse race.
Stock prices sagged to new 1969 lows yesterday, reflecting the uncertain fate of the surtax and fears of another increase in the prime lending rate.

Tom Tresh spent his last 7 1/2 seasons with the Yankees and Ike Brown spent his last 7 1/2 seasons in the minor leagues. Last night they were both playing for the Detroit Tigers and helping to beat the Yankees.

The House Committee on Ways and Means unveiled on May 27 an astonishing plan to discourage independent scholarship on matters of public concern. [Editorial June 14.]

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 17 -- Governor Rockefeller sidestepped a military decoration ceremony today and spent an hour walking with a few Senators and Deputies through the silent chambers of the inactivated Brazilian Congress.
SWEDESBORO, N. J., June 17 (AP) -- A kiss in the park, stolen or not, is going to cost lovers dearly in this South Jersey town.

Dr. Paul F. Chenea has been named executive in charge of the research laboratories of General Motors Corporation and George R. Elges has been appointed general manager of the Cadillac motor car division. Mack W. Worden has been named executive in charge of the marketing staff of the car producer. All three appointments are effective July 1.

SAIGON, June 17 -- Military spokesmen reported today that 21 American soldiers had been killed and 130 wounded thus far in a combined United States-South Vietnamese offensive operation in and around the Ashau Valley, 28 miles southwest of Hue.
LONDON, June 17 -- It has a fairy-tale ring that 18-yearold Denise Carter of Los Altos, Calif., has achieved a giantkilling feat almost unprecedented in women's tennis.
Imogene Coca, who has been absent from the stage here for 10 years, will begin rehearsals on Monday for a Broadway-bound comedy, "Why I Went Home."

State Senator John J. Marchi who already had the Conservative party nomination for Mayor, defeated Mayor Lindsay last night in a close Republican mayoral primary, and Controller Mario A. Procaccino won the Democratic nomination.

State Senator John J. Marchi's victory in the Republican primary last night was greeted ecstatically by members of the Conservative party, who prepared to take an important role in the affairs of the city's Republican party.
PRAGUE, June 17 -- The rising leader of conservatives in the Czechoslovak Communist apparatus, Dr. Lubomir Strougal, announced today a campaign of further purges of liberals.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- About 100 demonstrators representing various antiwar organizations were peacefully removed from the Penatgon this afternoon after they had spent about half an hour in the building reading a list of servicemen killed in Vietnam.

Jimmy Hinchcliffe, pitching for the Mets/Yankees against the Baltimore/Tigers, was delighted when the umpire called, "Strike!"

BONN, June 17 -- The coalition Government of Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger marked today the 16th anniversary of the East German workers' uprising with a parliamentary session aimed at defining the "state of the nation" in this divided country.

BIMINI, Bahamas, June 17 -- An unusually restrained Adam Clayton Powell declared today that he was "particularly happy and overwhelmed" by the Supreme Court's ruling that the House of Representatives violated the Constitution when it excluded him two years ago.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 17 -- Scores of arrest are reported to have been made in Jidda and among oil workers in the northeastern province of Saudi Arabia since Tapline, the pipeline that transports Saudi oil to the Mediterranean, was blown up two weeks ago.
GENEVA, June 17 -- The top executives of the International Committee of the Red Cross said tonight that the Nigerian Air Force had made it impossible to resume night relieff flights to Biafra.

BRIELLE, N. J., June 17 -- Lean George Haines Jr. of Somerset Hills, who believes that a golfer who keeps in condition keeps his scores low, got off to an impressive start in defense of his New Jersey amateur crown today.
WASHINGTON, June 17 -- President Nixon has ordered a sweeping review of the Government's controversial chemical and biological warfare policies.

Mayor Lindsay met yesterday with Joseph Monserrat, the president of the Board of Education, and Albert Shanker, the head of the United Federation of Teachers, to discuss the current school contract talks.

PARIS, June 17 -- The French Communist party, which demonstrated its political strength Sunday by persuading millions of voters to stay away from the polls, warned President-elect Georges Pompidou in a tough statement today that it will press for fulfillment of its social demands.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 17 -- The Mayor of Sacramento walked through the bullet-riddled offices of the Black Panther party today and said that he was "shocked and horrified" at the evidence of police misconduct.
PARIS, June 17 -- Britain said today that she wanted negotiations on her long-delayed entry into the European Economic Community to open "at the earliest possible moment."

PORTLAND, Ore., June 17 -- "Thanks for coming, Pat," said a raspberry-colored sign that a woman poked above the crowd today at the town of Forest Grove, where Mrs. Richard M. Nixon visited another volunteer project.

Your June 9 editorial "Help for the Commuter" overlooks my basic reason for disapproving, on fiscal grounds, the proposal by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to convert the construction of 31 coach cars into bar cars for the Long Island Rail Road.
OAKLAND, Calif., June 17 (UPI) -- A Trans World Airlines jet on the way to New York carrying 87 persons was seized in flight and taken to Havana today in the longest United States hijacking.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- A majority of the Justices of the Supreme Court have rejected Chief Justice Warren's suggestion that the Court immediately adopt the strict restrictions on outside activities that were recently applied to the lower Federal judiciary.

WILTON, Conn., June 17 -- The body of a young girl, matching the description of 10-year-old Mary Mount, who disappeared in New Canaan three weeks ago, was found by two teen-aged fishermen in a woods here this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The Nixon Administration has drawn up tentative plans for two additional troop withdrawals from Vietnam this year -- one in August, the other in October -- according to authoritative sources. The withdrawals would total 45,000 to 75,000 men.

WASHINGTON, June 17 -- The House Ways and Means Committee agreed today to extend the income tax surcharge precisely as President Nixon had proposed -- at the 10 per cent rate through the end of this calendar year and at a rate of 5 per cent through June 30, 1970.

HOUSTON, June 17 -- Leaders of Reform Judaism in the United States called on the Nixon Administration today to give primacy to the needs of "millions of Americans" rather than to the development of new military arms by the defense industry which they charge seeks "new profits."

MOSCOW, June 17 -The meeting of most of the world's Communist parties, convened among much discord, ended today with a communique hailing it as "an important stage on the road of strengthening the cohesion of the Communist movement."

HORSEHEADS, N. Y., June 17 -- The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company played under canvas here today to a capacity audience, with more than 500 good-natured participants booing the villain and cheering the hero.

Robert W. Haack, president of the New York Stock Exchange, disclosed yesterday that the exchange was drawing up new standards for listing bonds and new policies on longterm warrants in a drive to protect investors from "funny money."

NEWARK, June 17 (AP) -- The attempted extortion trial of three labor union representatives was declared a mistrial today, partly because of last week's disclosure of F.B.I. transcripts.

Trading volume picked up slightly yesterday but prices failed to follow suit on the American Stock Exchange. As a result, the market registered its twelfth straight decline.

The shareholders of Allied Stores Corporation had their day yesterday on the closing of Allied's Stern Brothers store in Manhattan but apparently left more impressed with the parent company's progress in other directions.

Wall Street is worried. The broad retreat in common stock prices in the last few weeks, while far from panicky, seems to reflect not only the cumulative effects of tight money but also a deep-seated concern that the Government's efforts to control inflation may not work.

MINEOLA, L. I., June 17 -- In Democratic primary contests in Nassau County, James A. Rousmaniere was the victor in the contest for Supervisor in Oyster Bay, and George B. Costigan, the incumbent supervisor in Long Beach also won.
YAPHANK, L. I., June 17 -- In the only countywide contest in Suffolk, for county judge an insurgent defeated one of the regular candidates endorsed by the Republican and Conservative parties.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The House of Representatives voted today to bar any mandatory health warning in cigarette advertising for the next six years.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday new highs in revenues and earnings for the three and 12 months ended May 3.

HOUSTON, June 18 -- The rabbinic body of American Reform Judaism ended today its requirement that newly ordained rabbis serve as military chaplains for two years. In its place a voluntary system of chaplaincy was adopted.

The upper West Side has its only little summer music festival in a park. Last night members of the community gathered on the grassy slope facing the Hudson River at the foot of 103d Street to hear the opening concert of the season.
Eastern Gas and Fuel Associ ates apparently has abandoned its long fight with the DWG Corporation for control of the Southeastern Public Service Company.
KARACHI, Pakistan, (Reuters) June 18 -- Three men threw grenades at an Ethiopian jetliner here tonight and sprayed it with submachine-gun fire, setting it aflame.
Bond prices extended their recent gains in early trading yesterday but gave most of them up in the afternoon.
WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Soviet Union has submitted a detailed reply to United States suggestions for a peace settlement in the Middle East, State Department officials said today.

GENEVA, June 18 (Reuters) -- Biafra announced here today that a new airstrip was being built exclusively for relief flights and said it had reached agreement with the United States on ground relief shipments.
TEL AVIV, June 18 -- Israeli jets bombed, strafed, fired rockets and dropped napalm over a few hundred square miles of Jordanian territory for five hours today.
IN the first official statement since his transformation from a state legislator to a political figure of national prominence, John Joseph Marchi promised yesterday:
" For whosoever shall call upon the name of the Lord shall be saved."
CHICAGO, June 18 -- Students for a Democratic Society today barred the "capitalist press" from its annual convention.

HAMBURG, West Germany, June 18 (Reuters) -- The flagship of West Germany's small passenger fleet, the 25,000-ton Hamburg, slipped out of her home port today almost unnoticed on her maiden voyage to the United States.

Evidently nothing can prevent Rhodesia's white minority from taking another lunge toward utter disaster in tomorrow's referendum. Despite somber warnings of responsible Rhodesians, black and white, a decisive "yes" vote is anticipated for Prime Minister Ian Douglas Smith's new Constitution.

Some indications yesterday of inaccurate vote tallies in Francis X. Smith's home borough of Queens kept alive his hopes of winning the Democratic nomination for President of the City Council. He was the loser by 172 votes in the unofficial count.
Short interest on the New York Stock Exchange has declined to a 21-month low, according to figures released by the exchange yesterday.
A "Weekend in Waterford," a benefit for the Eugene O'Neill Memorial Theater Foundation, will take place June 28-29 on the foundation grounds, the Hammond family's former estate in Waterford, Conn.
A total of 18,000 commuters on the Penn Central and the Long Island railroads were delayed yesterday by equipment failures or a shortage of equipment.
A hundred and twenty American Indians are in town to talk business.

SUNRISE, Wash. June 18 (UPI) -- Two survivors of a Mount Rainier climbing expedition that ended with the death of one man told today of how they dangled from a ridge, ducking falling rocks and roped to the dead man.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 18 -- Students at the University of Michigan chose music over rioting tonight and ended -- temporarily at least -- an attempt to take over three blocks of a campus street as a Peoples' Pedestrian Mall.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 18 -- A charge that the courts administer a double standard of justice that is harsh on the poor and benign toward the rich was denied with some heat today by judges attending a crime conference with convicts from three Maryland institutions.
DUBLIN, June 18 (AP) -- Ireland's Parliamentary election today produced a heavy turnout at the pools, a chorus of cries of "foul" and a general expectation that nobody can win.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Clark M. Clifford, the former Secretary of Defense, has publicly called on President Nixon to scale down military operations in Vietnam and to schedule the withdrawal of all American ground combat forces from that country by the end of next year.

WILTON, Conn., June 18 -- The body of a young girl, found in a deserted woods near a reservoir here yesterday, was identified by authorities today as that of 10-year-old Mary Mount, who disappeared in New Canaan three weeks ago.

The surtax package survived its first crucial test when the House Ways and Means Committee voted to approve all of the Administration's proposals. But another hurdle will have to be surmounted next week when the measure faces strong opposition on the floor of the House. The fire will come from conservatives who are generally antipathetic to higher taxes and liberals who are rightfully outraged by the committee's failure to recommend significant tax reforms.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission imposed penalties today on Hayden, Stone, Inc., a major New York Stock Exchange member firm, for allegedly extensive misrepresentations by a former salesman in its White Plains office.
ROME, June 18 -- The Vatican is selling part of its holdings in an Italian real estate and investment company and will reinvest the money abroad, unofficial Vatican sources asserted today.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A Senate subcommittee voted by 8 to 2 today to override President Nixon's recommendations and approve a liberalization of controls on United States exports to the Soviet Union and other Communist countries of Europe.
The choices made in both Republican and Democratic primaries for the two principal subsidiary offices were far more acceptable than those selected for the top of the ticket.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- A group of young Republican House members advised President Nixon in a report today that many of the nation's most respected institutions of higher learning were in danger of destruction unless there was an end to campus violence.
Mayor Lindsay took to the streets yesterday to begin "a hard-working campaign" for re-election in November, with only the Liberal party nomination in hand.
OMAHA, June 18 -- New York University beat Texas tonight, 3-2, to remain alive in the 23d National Collegiate baseball championship at Rosenblatt Stadium.
BUENOS AIRES, June 18 (Reuters) -- President Juan Carlos Ongania completed his Cabinet today by naming a wealthy landowner, Jose Rafael Caceres Monie, now Ambassador to Paraguay, as Defense Minister.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- The Federal Communications Commission today canceled its recent renewal of the broadcasting license of WPIX-TV, (Channel 11) in New York, pending further investigation of charges that the station has distorted its news shows with doctored film.

THE most heart-warming sight on Third Avenue yesterday morning was a long line of children and parents waiting to see "Ring of Bright Water." Inside the 68th Street Playhouse the view was even better.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N. Y., June 18 -- Joe Frazier was in the ring, ready to spar, when Howard Cosell called to him.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Senator Charles E. Goodell of New York renewed his feud with Senator Everett McKinley Dirksen today by accusing the Senate Republican leader of blocking the nomination of Dr. John H. Knowles to be Assistant Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare.
WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- Two former members of the Black Panther party testified today that the party had spurned its original purpose of self-defense and now exploited the people of the slums.
The Delegate Assembly of the United Federation of Teachers voted yesterday to authorize strike action if an acceptable new contract with the Board of Education is not ready by Tuesday.

The city's political alignments have been torn apart by the mayoral primary election victories of State Senator John J. Marchi and Controller Mario A. Procaccino, according to leaders of the Republican and Democratic parties.

MIGUEL COLON, a 51-year-old master, won the recent 1969 Puerto Rico Chess Championship, scoring 8-2 in the 11-man round robin. The event, held at the Club de Ajedrez Capablanca in San Juan, was limited to 11 local masters, including last year's champion, Arturo Colon, Miguel's 41-year-old brother.

WEST DENNIS, Cape Cod, Mass. -- Not everyone spends the summer here swimming, boating, fishing, reading and just plain lazing. From June through August, when Cape Cod's population is multiplied by the school's-out influx of vacationers, this peninsula enjoys an abundance of New England fairs and festivals, bake sales and clambakes, luncheons and suppers -- all for good causes and all promising the best that dedicated cooks can do.

WASHINGTON'S CROSSING, N. J. -- When Mrs. Helen Boehm was told recently that she was the greatest public relations representative her late husband could have had, she smiled warmly and answered, "I had a mission."
SAIGON, June 18 (Reuters) -- President Thieu pledged today that he would never allow South Vietnam to fall to Communism.

The official spokesman for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York warned yesterday that losses in the financial markets would not deter the central bank in its drive to control inflation.

THE great shirtwaist dress tide that swept Georgia Bullock to fashion fame and fortune 20 years ago has receded, but it has left its mark. The California designer still believes that clothes should be comfortable to wear, relaxing to the eye and, belted or not, constructed as simply as possible.
The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that it planned to implement a substantial increase in listing fees -- the charges that corporations pay to have their shares listed on the exchange.

Three employes of the Department of Motor Vehicles were arrested in the department's Brooklyn office yesterday and charged with selling learner's permits to applicants who could not pass the eye examination and written tests.

KANSAS CITY, June 18 (UPI) -- Reggie Jackson of the Oakland A's, whose hitting spree in the last week has given him a major league leading total of 24 homers, received a telegram of admiration today from President Nixon.

CAPE KENNEDY, June 18 (UPI) -- Neil A. Armstrong, a civilian, and Col. Edwin E. Aldrin of the Air Force, successfully rehearsed man's first walk on the moon in a step-by-step simulation today and jokingly reported finding diamonds and rubies there.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- As tourists swarmed today through the Smithsonian Institution and on the Mall, which extends from the Capitol to the Lincoln Memorial, the future of one of their favorite foods -- the hot dog -- was debated at a sparsely attended hearing nearby.

SUBIC BAY, the Philippines, June 18 -- After protracted consultation, the two-nation board of inquiry investigating the Melbourne-Evans collision in the South China Sea on June 3 agreed today to excuse a key American witness from testifying.
FORT DIX, N. J., June 18 (AP) -- The Army announced today that 38 prisoners at the post stockade have been charged with participating in a riot in connection with an outbreak June 2.
New York City's basic real state tax rate will rise about 30 cents. to a record $5.52 for each $100 of assessed valuation. the Citizens Budget Commission predicted yesterday.
