The African-American Teachers Association said yesterday that five of its members, including Leslie Campbell and Albert Vann, had been dismissed from their positions in Intermediate School 271 by officials of the Ocean Hill-Brownsville demonstration district.
PARIS, June 18 -- The election of Georges Pompidou as President has provoked a grave debate among experts on the French language, who in this country alone number 50 million.

A controversial plan to bus Negro children from a poor section of Queens to the affluent school district of Great Neck, L. P., was vetoed yesterday by Dr. Bernard E. Donovan, Superintendent of Schools, with the approval of New York City's Board of Education.
For most commodity futures yesterday was a dull trading day with few trends to be discerned. On the Chicago Board of Trade, corn received some attention, gaining a cent and more a bushel.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- In a gesture to Latin America, President Nixon has decided to eliminate from foreign-aid programs a much-criticized regulation requiring recipients to spend most of their aid funds in the United States, diplomatic informants report.

John J. Cassese resigned yesterday as the president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association and announced he would devote his "full efforts" to the campaign of Mario A. Procaccino, the Democratic candidate for Mayor. He also said he was going to leave the police force.

Following a United States Supreme Court directive, a three-judge Federal Court here yesterday ordered the New York State Legislature to enact a new apportionment law for the 1970 Congressional elections.

The stock market opened yesterday with a burst of strength and then declined steadily to close with a mixed pattern in its leading indicators.
COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 18 -- Opposing views over the management of gold in monetary affairs were aired today in unusually frank exchanges at a top level meeting of bankers here.

PHILADELPHIA, June 18 -- The New York Mets defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 2-0, tonight and Jerry Koosman pitched such a strong game that they did not even have to resort to their famous four-man outfield.

PARIS, June 18 -- The assembly of the Western European Union appealed unanimously today for a carefully prepared European security conference in which the United States and the Soviet Union would participate.

BRIELLE, N. J., June 18 -- George E. Haines Jr. of Somerset Hills and Bud Zachary of North Jersey, titleholders in 1968 and 1967, respectively, reached the semi-final round of the New Jersey amateur golf championship today.

PORT JEFFERSON, L. I., June 18 -- Supporters of open-housing ordinances were defeated last night in the elections of North Shore villages of Belle Terre and Port Jefferson.

Two off-duty firemen climbed a staircase engulfed in flames yesterday to rescue a woman and two children trapped on the upper floor of a two-story building at 206th Street and White Plains Road, the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, June 18 -- Vice President Agnew and the Republican National Chairman expressed support today for State Senator John J. Marchi, the winner of the New York City Republican mayoral primary. But the White House remained silent.

LONDON, June 18 -- The Government gave way to labor-union opposition today and abandoned its plan to legislate against wildcat strikes.

ASCOT, England, June 18 (AP) -- Lester Piggott, Britain's foremost jockey, who faces a seven-day suspension starting Friday, rode the British-owned Kamundu to a half-length victory in the one-mile Royal Hunt Cup today at the Royal Ascot course.

"His intention," says Sartre, "is to harm, and his work aims at being an evil action."

William E. Chambers Jr., who joined Norman, Craig and Kummel as president last fall, is leaving the agency, according to industry sources. Leaving with him will be George G. Milliken, executive vice president.

COLUMBIA, S.C., June 18 -- In major city elections in South Carolina yesterday, Greenville elected a Republican Mayor for the first time, and voters in North Charleston voted for incorporation as the state's largest city, after Columbia.
PORTLAND, Ore., June 18 -- A series of fires across the city's predominently Negro Albina district caused damage estimated at $500,000 early today.

Three railroads that have been protesting the merger plans of the Norfolk Western and Chesapeake Ohio railroads withdrew their opposition yesterday.

TRENTON, June 18 (AP) -- Governor Richard J. Hughes said today that unless more blacks were put to work on the construction site of the New Jersey College of Medicine and Dentistry in Newark, the state would take the union and the contractors involved to court.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 18 -- Jim Ryun will attempt a difficult one-mile, three-mile double in the 48th annual National Collegiate outdoor track and field championships tomorrow through Saturday at the University of Tennessee.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 18 -- Saigon has been enveloped by pessimism since the Midway conference between President Nixon and President Nguyen Van Thieu and the Vietcong's announcement of the formation of their Provisional Revolutionary Government for South Vietnam.
A drug designed to curb a few of the viruses that cause the common cold has shown some promise in initial, small-scale tests in man, it was reported here yesterday.

CAPETOWN, June 18 (AP) -- South Africa's Finance Minister, Nicholaas Diederichs, said today that sales of the country's newly mined gold this year had improved so much that foreign-exchange controls would be further relaxed.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June 18 -- Prime Minister Ian D. Smith declared today that the voters of Rhodesia had basically only one question to consider in the referendum on Friday -- whether to hand over the Government to the country's black African majority.

UNIONDALE, L. I., June 18 -- The Rev. Francis J. Haggerty, whose transfer to another parish sparked two demonstrations last week on his behalf, said today that he would take a temporary leave of absence from his clerical duties.

VINELAND, N. J., June 18 -- Four persons were killed and six others injured, two critically, today in a truck-car collision here.

WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation attacked as "scurrilous" today a report that its director, J. Edgar Hoover, had acted on his own in wiretapping the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

At the cocktail hour in the 21 Club yesterday, the Remington Electric Shaver Division of Sperry Rand introduced the "biggest advance in shaving since the introduction of the electric shaver." It is the Lektro Blade shavers line -- replacing the Selektro line -- and is the electric shaver with the replaceable blade.

THOMAS J. HOLT is bearish on the market. In his latest market letter -- the Holt Investment Advisory published June 6 -- he urged investors to limit commitments in common stocks to 25 per cent of their capital.

The Chicago White Sox gave an exemplary demonstration of the conservation of resources yesterday afternoon on their way to a 13-10 triumph over the Seattle Pilots. The Sox scored three runs without swinging a bat in a four-run seventh-inning rally that overcame a 10-9 Seattle lead.

In seeking ways and means to reduce the threat to the New York City public schools and to upgrade the quality of instruction on all levels, your editorial of June 12 urges quite properly that "efforts to improve the productivity of available funds are imperative."

NEWARK, N. J., June 19 -- Two men were indicted today and a third man was being sought on charges of having tampered with the Essex County jury that convicted Ruggiero (Ritchie the Boot) Boiardo and 18 other defendants of conspiracy to run a numbers racket here.

DUBLIN, June 19 -- With more than half the results of yesterday's election results counted, it was clear tonight that Prime Minister John Lynch's party. Fianna Fail, would form the Government when the 19th Dail Eireann, or parliament, convenes on July 2.

BEAUMONT-LE-ROGER, France -- The first thing to remember about Georges Pompidou, who takes office today as France's new President, is that he is decidedly a man of the West. Although he hopes, like de Gaulle, to underscore France's economic and political independence, he is far less likely than the general to try and play the superpowers off against each other and walk a tightrope in between.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 19 -- Running relaxed and without pain for the first time in more than a month, Erv Hall tied the world record in the 120-yard high hurdles during a trial heat today of the National Collegiate outdoor track and field championships.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- President Nixon said tonight that the United States might suspend tests on MIRV's -- multiple independently targetable re-entry vehicles -- if the Soviet Union would suspend testing on its own multiple-warhead missiles.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 19 -- Diminutive Mike Estep, who played in the shadow of Zan Guerry, a fellow sophomore at Rice all season, registered a 5-7, 6-4, 8-6 upset of Bob Lutz, Southern California's top-seeded player, in the quarter-finals of the National Collegiate tennis championships today.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 19 -- A prominent Congressional monetary expert, Representative Henry S. Reuss, called on the Federal Reserve System today to issue guidelines immediately for a voluntary freeze on bank credit at present levels.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- President Nixon said tonight that he would endorse State Senator John J. Marchi, the Republican candidate, for Mayor of New York City but that he would not campaign for him.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, June 19 -- Reports of incendiary bombings and street disorders in Montevideo, capital of Uruguay, the last stop of Governor Rockefeller's current Latin-American trip, caused a change today in the program for the visit there.

NEWTON, N. J., June 19 (AP) -- The suspended Hopatcong police chief, Hubertus Jacobi, was found innocent of extortion and a related charge but guilty of malfeasance today in connection with an $80,000 fire last year.
No one in the ship brokerage business believed their lists would ever again contain an $3,000-ton liner for bidding and disposal. But they were wrong.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Some officials in the Nixon Administration are searching for a new approach to school desegregation and the search is making civil rights leaders nervous.

A deadly game of espionage and counterespionage between the Mafia and the Federal Bureau of Investigation was disclosed in the bugged conversations of members of the underworld that were made public last week in Federal Court in Newark.

MINEOLA, L. I., June 19 -- Declaring that "no person will be allowed to go hungry in Nassau County," County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson announced today that special stores would be opened, starting next month, in 30 neighborhoods to provide free food daily to 15,000 needy families.

GROSSINGER, N. Y., June 19 -- It had been raining when Jerry Quarry awoke today and he had been excused from road work. His "heavy work," as boxers say, is over, anyway, and he had slept until midmorning.

Although the two mayoral candidates with nearly the lowest campaign expenditures ended up with the highest number of votes in the primary, political professionals generally remain unshaken in their belief that money is important in campaigns.

A cable television company operating outside New York City plans to make separate charges for four TV program services, including motion pictures. Cable TV subscribers already pay an average of $5 a month for the relaying over wires of programs televised by regular stations.
The International Business Machines Corporation announced three executive promotions yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI) -- Mr. Hoover's statement was disputed by Ramsey Clark, the Democratic Attorney General who succeeded Robert F. Kennedy and Nicholas Deb. Katzenbach.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- President Nixon confirmed today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation's wiretapping of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., was done with the approval of the Attorney General.

PRAGUE, June 19 -- Interior minister Jan Pelnar of Czechoslovakia denounced today what he described as a network of "hostile centers" in the United States and Western Europe that were maintaining illegal contacts with persons in Czechoslovakia.

NEWPORT, R. I., June 19 -- While American Eagle, the star of what had turned into a protracted, tedious production, was being made ready for another, harder and longer test, prizes for what she and others had accomplished in the immediate past were being distributed at a cocktail party today.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 19 -- A Regents' committee of the University of California overrode campus administrators today and recommended development of student housing "as expeditiously as possible" on the site of the controversial "People's Park" in Berkeley.

AS this month began the A.D.S. (Athletes for Democratic Society) suspected they had the chancellor of Pro Football University, Pete Rozelle, on the run. Joe Namath, the A.D.S. instrument of rebellion, had told smutty stories at the big faculty dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria right out there with Justice Whizzer White, a tool of the Establishment, and a pride of priests, the representatives of another Establishment.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Some Baltimore youngsters may still think of Dr. William David McElroy as the firefly man. A few years ago he recruited teams to capture insects on summer nights so that he could study the process by which some creatures convert chemical energy into light.

West 42d Street, not famed for its high-level cultural attainments, blossomed with poetry yesterday, some in voice -- by Mayor Lindsay in Bryant Park -- some in writing -- a display of verse from concept to print opened at the New York Public Library next door.
HOUSTON, June 19 -- Leaders of American Reform Judaism described the synagogue today as "archaic" and unable to meet the religious needs of the Jew or to aid him in resolving social problems.

A permanent injunction was issued yesterday against the sale or distribution of one issue of Kiss, an underground periodical. The injunction had the effect of giving notice that city officials are keeping an eye on the proliferation of weeklies that put heavy emphasis on sex.
John L. Edmonds, the city's Model Cities neighborhood director, yesterday announced live projects for the HarlemiEast Harlern area totaling $4million. The projects are:

Lawyers for the Interchurch Center agreed yesterday to postpone a court hearing on a restraining order they obtained Monday against disruptions in the building at 475 Riverside Drive by James Forman and others supporting "reparations" from the churches to black Americans.
The Humble Oil and Refining Company is seeking, through court action, a larger share in the vast oil discovery on Alaska's North Slope.

A vigil marking the 16th anniversary of the execution in Sing Sing Prison of Julius and Ethel Rosenberg as spies was held from noon until 1:30 P.M. yesterday in Foley Square in front of the United States Court House.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- President Nixon said tonight that he had developed a better approach to ending the war in Vietnam than had his critics from the Johnson Administration and that he hoped to bring American troops home even faster than they had suggested.
Prices on the London stock market eased yesterday after opening slightly higher.
Evangelist Billy Graham last night compared the dedication of campus radicals with that of the early Christians.
An inspection of election records has turned up enough votes to give Francis X. Smith the Democratic nomination for City Council President, aides of Mr. Smith said yesterday.

The election of Stephen M. Peck, senior partner of S. M. Peck Co., as a governor of the New York Stock Exchange to serve until the annual election in May, 1970, was announced yesterday. He will fill the vacancy created by the election of Bernard J. Lasker as chairman of the board on May 12.
The Queens County grand jury that returned an arson indictment last week in connection with an A. P. warehouse fire will continue to look into an alleged campaign of terror against the food chain.

I was disturbed by the implications of your news article of June 14 detailing unsupervised wiretapping by the Justice Department. Such action represents a serious affront to our right of privacy, as protected by the Fourth Amendment.
About 6,000 riders on the Penn Central's Hudson division were delayed for 45 minutes to two and a half hours yesterday by a freight train derailment in Yonkers.
Higher sales and profits for the fourth quarter and the year ended April 30 were reported yesterday by the H. J. Heinz Company.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- President Nixon's special assistant for consumer affairs came out forcefully today for less fat in hot dogs than the Department of Agriculture would permit.

WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The Atlanta Braves and Oakland Athletics, faced with a crackdown by Bowie Kuhn, the commissioner of baseball, are cutting the ties between their owners and Las Vegas gambling casinos.

In two separate court actions, four faculty members and 32 men students were sentenced to jail yesterday for their part in demonstrations this spring at Queens College and Queensborough Community College.
The resources of New York's young and relatively unknown jazz community were illustrated last night at Muse, Bedford Avenue and Lincoln Place, Brooklyn, by Pete Pearson and his Afro Jazz Lab.

BRIELLE, N. J., June 19 -- If a matchmaker had arranged a contest between two top state amateurs it couldn't have worked out better than it did today as the New Jersey amateur golf championship tournament reached the final round.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 19 -- The enemy made six attacks on Tayninh and its surrounding villages today. A 300-man enemy force broke through in one sector and fought allied troops in village streets.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday that three of nine defendants in a civil suit had consented to a permanent injunction preventing them from further alleged violations of the securities laws in connection with the shares of the Photo Mark Computer Corporation. Action against the other six was unresolved.

The lawyer who got the United States Supreme Court to agree to rule on the constitutionality of exempting church property from taxes is the landlord of a 22-by-29-foot parcel on Staten Island that is taxed $5.24 a year.

LONDON, June 19 (AP) -- Her horse's carrots are presented on a tray in a starched linen napkin. Her servants brew tea for 9,000 guests at a time. She has so many jewels she cannot remember which ones she has worn.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The United States and Spanish Governments are expected to sign an agreement here tomorrow providing for the United States' use of American-built military bases in Spain for 15 months more.
VIENNA, June 19 -- The tastes of Viennese critics and dance-lovers clashed sharply last night over the performance of "Astarte" by New York's City Center Joffrey Ballet.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Economy-minded Congressmen slashed funds today for low-income housing and the Model Cities program and trimmed all but $10-million from a proposed $55-million increase in funds for summer jobs for disadvantaged youths.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Unqualified confidence that an extension of the income tax surcharge will be passed by Congress was expressed tonight by President Nixon.
Following is a transcript of President Nixon's news conference in Washington last night, as recorded by The New York Times:
As a lawyer who spent most of Primary Day in the polling places of East Harlem, I am writing to confirm the systematic disfranchisement of New York's Spanish-speaking voters on June 17.

GENEVA, June 19 -- Dr. Auguste R. Lindt, the Red Cross relief coordinator for Nigeria and Biafra, stepped down today as a result of friction with the Nigerian Government, which declared him persona non grata last week.

ROME, June 19 -- Eugene Cardinal Tisserant, 85-year-old dean of the Roman Catholic College of Cardinals, has written a letter to Leo Cardinal Suenens, primate of Belgium, that is reported to dispute Cardinal Suenens's recently published criticism of many aspects of church policy and organization.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The White House announced today a revision in the rules governing military courts-martial, which dispense justice to 3.4 million American servicemen.
TEL AVIV, June I9 -- Four Arabs, believed to have been on an intelligence mission for Syria, were killed last night by Israeli soldiers.
Leaders of the New Democratic Coalition, the city's largest organization of liberal Democrats, have begun moving toward an endorsement of Mayor Lindsay for re-election.

Air travel throughout much of the nation was turned into near chaos yesterday when about 240 Federal air traffic controllers -- most of them in the New York area -- reported they were sick and refused to work.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- There are increasing indications here that as Chief Justice, Warren E. Burger will remain active in off-the-bench activities that are related to the law. By his example, he is expected to counter the current pressures toward a cloistered judiciary.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Secretary of the Treasury David M. Kennedy testified today that he expected "toward" the end of summer we will see a change" in the booming economy, with the possibility of a move toward lower interest rates.
John A. Masiello Sr., a reputed Mafia loan shark, his wife and their 26-year-old son, John A. Masiello Jr., were accused here yesterday of a five-year conspiracy to help the son evade the draft.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- President Nixon expressed concern tonight that the Senate might unduly tie the hands of the President by its proposed resolution limiting the power of the executive branch to enter into foreign commitments.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed today President Nixon's nomination of Donald E. Johnson, former national commander of the American Legion, to head the Veterans Administration.

A former staff writer for WPIX-TV, whose letter to a friend was instrumental in the revocation Wednesday of WPIX's broadcasting license renewal, said yesterday that she was not alone in opposing what she called news film distortions by the station.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- The House ethics committee reported today that it had found no evidence of complicity in a series of roll-call errors disclosed last September.

Pechiney, S.A., of France, a major producer of aluminum, chemicals, copper and graphite, would obtain more than a 50 per cent interest in the Howmet Corporation under a tentative plan announced here yesterday.

CAIRO, June 19 -- The visit of the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Oromyko, to Cairo has spread disillusionment among Egyptians. They feel there has been a Soviet shift toward the American viewpoint on a Mideast peace settlement, at the expense of the Arabs.

LONDON, June 19 -- Ron Holmberg, the baldish but no longer portly New Yorker, dispatched Ken Rosewall from the London grass-court open tournament today with a burst of inspired tennis. But Holmberg had little time to savor the 1-6, 6-2, 6-2 triumph.
Frank Mulzoff, a standout defensive player at St. John's 20 years ago, was named yesterday head basketball coach of his alma mater, effective at the end of the 1969-70 season.

CANBERRA, Australia, June 19 -- Britain, Australia, New Zealand, Malaysia and Singapore outlined a joint program today for the defense of Malaysia and Singapore after the scheduled departure of British forces from the area at the end of 1971.

CHICAGO, June 19 -- The Students for a Democratic Society convention settled down to factional infighting, caucuses and heated debate today, with a strong bid for a takeover by members of the Progressive Labor party.

AN unusual feature of the Eastern Regional Championship here earlier this month was a short exhibition match between teams unofficially representing the American Contract Bridge League and the American Bridge Association.
AUSTIN, Tex., June 19 -- Oil buyers told the Texas Railroad Commission today that they had been too optimistic last month when they nominated June oil production figures.
A full-page advertisement in The Times of June 13 sponsored by the Citizens Committee for Peace With Security is headlined, "84 per cent of all Americans support the ABM system."

The Real Estate Industry Stabilization Association of New York, representing landlords affected by the city's new rent stabilization law, opened an office yesterday at 132 West 43d Street, between the Avenue of the Americas and Broadway.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- A resolution that would restore the seniority and back salary of Representative Adam Clayton Powell was introduced in the House today amid predictions that the leadership would not compromise with the Manhattan Democrat.
WASHINGTON, June 19 (UPI) -- The Senate Agriculture Commitee voted today to more than double food stamp spending next year.
Stocks declined for the 14th straight day yesterday on the American Stock Exchange. The slump was a sharp one and covered a broad front. Volume remained moderate.

Jerry Fishback had just entered the winner's circle aboard George H. (Pete) Bostwick's Duty Officer at Belmont Park yesterday, after having guided the 3-year-old gelding into first place by 15 lengths in the mile-and-a-half Annapolis Hurdle Handicap.
PHILADELPHIA, June 19 -- The New York Mets scored two runs in the ninth inning tonight, defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 6-5, and moved to within 5 1/2 games of the first-place Chicago Cubs.
Silver futures interrupted their recent long-term decline yesterday for what a broker called "a faint-hearted rally."

An exhibition gallery will be opened early in September in Houston for the display of the fine and decorative arts that are scheduled for auction at the Parke-Bernet Galleries in New York and at Sotheby Co. in London.

BONN, June 19 -- The Bundesbank, West Germany's central bank, sought to apply the brakes today on runaway economic expansion by raising its discount rate to 5 per cent from 4 per cent, effective tomorrow.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 19 -- Officials are looking into charges that the all-Russian staff of the United Nations information center in Moscow might have blocked the transmittal of a petition from Soviet citizens charging abuses of human rights.

"THE only cliches you will find here, hopefully, are on the labels," said Angelo Donghia, the decorator-owner of Vice Versa, a new show-Avenue (59th Street) offering fabrics, wallpaper and customorder carpets. The concern which opens today, will serve architects, decorators and their clients.
Three Federal Bureau of Investigation agents have been transferred from the New York office after giving the Government affidavits in the Roy M. Cohn bribe conspiracy case.

PROF. JULES BACKMAN is appalled by the mercurial tastes of investors. He watched incredulously as "speculative overenthusiasm" lifted the conglomerate stocks to unprecedented highs, and he has been equally shocked as their values have collapsed.

ATHENS, June 9 -- The Greek Government announced tonight that Premier George Papadopoulos had accepted the resignation of Theophylaktos Papaconstantinou from the post of Minister of Education and Religious Affairs.

Former Secretary of Defense Clark Clifford seems to be developing a reputation for rescuing American Presidents from disaster. He helped develop the strategy for saving President Truman from almost certain defeat in the Presidential campaign of 1948.
A 100-foot section of the ceiling of Immanuel Lutheran Church crashed to the floor yesterday morning, destroying pews and leaving a pall of dust over the sanctuary.

CHICAGO, June 19 (Reuters) -- A Cook County grand jury today returned indictments of murder, attempted murder, rape, aggravated battery and involuntary manslaughter against 10 patients, former patients and guards of two Chicago mental hospitals.
PITTSBURGH, June 19 (Reuters) -- A former Air Force enlisted man shot himself today after climbing to the top of a downtown bridge and shooting into the street. He slightly wounded one person.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 19 -- A forecast of still higher Eurodollar rates and a call for raising or eliminating interest-rate ceilings in the United States to ease some of the Eurodollar pressures were made today at the annual monetary conference of the American Bankers Association.
SAIGON, June 13 -- United States combat deaths in Vietnam rose by one-third last week as South Vietnamese losses increased by one-quarter.

Charles Evers, the first Negro Mayor-elect of Fayette, Miss., and 20 other Negro city and county officials newly elected to posts in surrounding Jefferson County will attend a crash course in local government this weekend.
Popular stock averages slid to new yearly lows yesterday under the pressures of tight money and investor concern.
D.D.B. Buys TV Studio. Norman, Craig Names Kaplan President. Zebra Associates, Integrated Agency, Opens Doors.
Film activities at Lincoln Center, which have been threatened because of acute financial problems, will be continued through the aid of a newly formed group, the Film Society of Lincoln Center, Inc.

THIELLS, N.Y., June 19 -- When night comes to Letchworth Village here on the western shore of the Hudson River, its 3,791 inmates retire to small stone cottages. There, in darkened dormitories, some holding teddy bears, they wait for sleep to come.

A beam of hope has abruptly pierced one of the blacker moments of Nigeria's civil war. Both sides have agreed to an American proposal to send emergency food and medicines into Biafra by ship, up the Cross River in eastern Nigeria.

A physical check by the city on 1,300 patients who received dental work under the Medicaid program has disclosed that 9 per cent of the cases showed evidence of fraud -- that is, of work not done for which private practitioners were paid.

HAUPPAUGE, L. I., June 19 -- A Suffolk grand jury is investigating a charity for crippled and retarded children that allegedly is used as a front by men connected with the Mafia to collect thousands of dollars from residents in the county.

SUBIC BAY, the Philippines, June 19 -- A British naval officer, who watched through binoculars the collision of the United States destroyer Frank E. Evans and the Australian aircraft carrier Melbourne on June 3, gave testimony today that cast doubt on the behavior of the carrier in the minutes proceeding the disaster.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 19 -- The police were on stand-by duty tonight to prevent further attempts to occupy a street next to the University of Michigan campus, the scene of three nights of disturbances by young people.

OMAHA, June 19 -- New York University's hopes for a National Collegiate baseball championship came to an abrupt end tonight in Rosenblatt Stadium, the victim of Lerrin LaGrow's right arm and potent bat.

Japan is showing "incomprehensible arrogance" in refusing to discuss voluntary quotas on wool and man-made fiber products with Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans, Robert S. Small, president of Dan River Mills, Inc., charged here yesterday.

LONDON, June 19 -- In London this week, Sheik Zayed bin Sultan al Nihayan, the ruler of Abu Dhabi, is talking about the British pullout east of Suez. In Canberra. Denis Healey, the British Minister of Defense, is attending a five-nation conference to discuss it.
PARIS, June 19 -- The United States pressed North Vietnam at the peace talks today for an agreement on mutual troop withdrawals.
NORWICH, Conn. -- There's a little bit of Seventh Avenue tucked into the pastoral countryside here, and Arlene and John Meyer reign over it.

For airline passengers who lived through last year's tribulations, the 1969 summer aviation season began officially yesterday. Once again they ran a chaotic gantlet consisting of canceled flights, exasperating waits on the ground before takeoff, and additional delays in the air as their "stacked" planes circled until they received permission to land.

New York State bar associations should maintain an Albany office to aid with salutary legislation and to oppose undesirable bills. On-the-spot appearance of their representative -- instead of the present bar committee letters -- would serve as a valuable asset to all lawyers and legislators.

The second concert of the Moravian Music Festival was given at Brick Presbyterian Church last night under the direction of Thos. Johnson. The program was made up chiefly of short vocal works -- anthems, hymns and solos -- with sacred texts, but it also included J. C. F. Bach's Sinfonia in D minor. A son of the famous Bach, he was a professional musician but not a Moravian.

TOKYO, June 18 -- The crux of the Okinawa problem, Premier Eisaku Sato said here today, is how to secure Japanese political control over the islands in a manner that "does not diminish the importance of American military bases" for the defense of Japan and the preservation of peace in east Asia.

BY now I suspect that I have seen "Mame" at the Winter Garden Theater more often than any other living soul with the possible exception of its conductor. I have not only seen "Mame," I have practically been "mame-d," and if they ever need a general understudy I fear that I am rapidly becoming an almost inevitable choice.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

This sympathetic and friendly survey of Cuba in transition may seem too much so by some. But Elizabeth Sutherland, an American journalist, has not scanted the hazards and complexities of Cuba's attempt to change her patterns in race relations, family mores and individual psychology.

GLEN COVE, L. I. June 19 -- Jim Stalarow, an 18-year-old who was graduated from North Shore High School three days ago, and Jim Tingley, who won his first golf tournament before Stalarow was born, shared the medal with two-under-par 68's today in the Long Island amateur tourney at the Nassau Country Club.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- President Nixon served notice on Congress today that he was opposed to any legislation that would cut off Federal funds to universities where campus disorders occurred.
EAST NORTHFIELD, Mass., June 19 -- Attempts to set up an all-inclusive New England power pool got off to a faltering start here today.

The appointment of Wilbur B. McLaren, an industrial relations executive for many years in private industry, as executive officer for labor relations and personnel of the New York City Transit Authority was announced yesterday by William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.
Joe Namath is ready to put his interest in the controversial Bachelors III restaurant in trust if the move will permit him to return to football.

AREA A -- Few kingfish and spotty catches reported off the surf. Very few blues being taken off Brielle. At Surf City, the bay was reported "paved with blowfish," but anything else is "few and far between."

The owners of eight liquor stores and a supermarket in Harlem filed a $1,775,000 damage suit yesterday in what is believed to be the first case specifically charging the city with negligence in guarding against looters.

PARIS, June 19 -- Latent bitterness between rival Gaullist factions broke into the open today, making it clear that the new French President, Georges Pompidou, has yet to assert his authority over the political movement he inherited from General de Gaulle.

"One bad pitch," that futile lament that echoes through the hundred years professional baseball is now commemorating, decided last night's game at Yankee Stadium, where the New York Yankees defeated the Detroit Tigers, 5-3.

THE fastest track in fashion these days is the middle ground where the prices are moderate and the clothes adventurous. The Coty American Fashion Critics Jury recognized this by giving its top awards, called "Winnies," for 1969 to Victor Joris of Cuddlecoat and Stanley Herman of Mr. Mort, both leaders in the moderate price field.

NEWARK, June 19 -- Representative William T. Cahill, the Republican candidate for Governor of New Jersey, tonight attacked the Democratic record on organized crime in the first campaign debate with former Gov. Robert B. Meyner, his Democratic opponent.

The ordeal experienced by many in Tuesday's primary only confirms what has long been known -- that New York's present election laws urgently need modernization and reform. The hours for primary voting -- from 3 P.M. to 10 P.M. -- are absurd and the schedules imposed on officials responsible for preparation are impossible.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- Mrs. Richard M. Nixon plans to go back to college in the fall, but not as a student.

WASHINGTON, June 19 -- United States officials are considering a direct bid to North Vietnam to state its terms for the release of American prisoners. Until now, both sides have shied away from giving any appearance of bargaining over the prisoners.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., June 19 (AP) -- Phil Rodgers, a long-time non-winner, fired a late, windblown 67 today and tied George Archer, the Masters champion for the first-round lead in the $150,000 Kemper open golf tournament.

Robert T. Stevens will step down as president and chief executive officer of J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., the nation's second largest publicly owned textile manufacturing company, on Aug. 1, one day after reaching the age of 70.

Bond prices backed and filled again yesterday, but by the close of trading most issues showed small declines. Purchasers of fixed-income securities, lured into the market to snap up issues at record yields earlier in the week, appeared to have returned to the sidelines.
The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange has approved a broad automation program that could have a profound impact on the methods of handling the securities trading of the future.

LUSAKA, Zambia, June 19 -- The Zambian Government announced today that voters in a national referendum had approved a proposal to remove from the Constitution a requirement that the Government hold a referendum each time it wants to change the Constitution.
The money market weathered massive payments of corporate taxes on June 16 without undue stress, banking figures published yesterday showed.
WASHINGTON, June 19 -- The Federal school lunch program for poor children was attacked again today in a new report, which called the program "America's most persistent food scandal."
WASHINGTON, June 19 (AP) -- A Nobel Prize-winning geneticist condemned today the secrecy of United States chemical and biological warfare activities and the stockpiling of germ agents.

The city's Department of Consumer Affairs announced yesterday that laboratory tests by the Department of Health had confirmed its "suspicions" of the widespread use of vegetable additives in hamburgers sold in restaurants and luncheonettes.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -White House aides and other Administration officials expressed concern today over the present interpretations and potential effects of President Nixon's nationally televised remarks on Vietnam last night.

The 300 delegates of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday gave their board of officers an overwhelming vote of confidence. The delegates, who are elected to represent units making up the P.B.A., acted at their first monthly meeting since the resignation of John J. Cassese as president, and Norman Frank as public relations adviser.

A union official accused of threats during an election campaign marked by allegations of racketeering and corruption against the union leadership surrendered yesterday on a coercion charge at the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of Manhattan.
PATERSON, N. J., June 20 (AP) -- Public school teachers approved a $720,000 contract by an overwhelming majority today, ending a four-day-old strike against the city's 28 schools.

Your May 10 editorial "Prizes for Torture" rightly protested the encouragement and award of prizes for painful animal experiments by high school students. A few examples will demonstrate the laxity of current standards.
With the artillery fire of the war against inflation sounding ominously in the background, the stock market sagged under ponderous worries yesterday to its 1969 low.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 20 -- Terrorists set fire to a General Motors building here today, causing damage estimated at $1-million.

GENEVA, June 20 -- A Red Cross mission has estimated that as many as 1.5 million Biafrans have died of hunger in the two years of Nigeria's civil war. The population of secessionist BiBafra is estimated between a million and 14 million.
MONTEVIDEO, June 20 (Reuters) -- The powerful National Workers Convention called several one-hour strikes and meetings today to protest the Rockefeller visit.
MOST of the mystery went out of fashion during the last few years with the nude look and the discovery that the haut couturiers were copying rather than inventing.

CHICAGO, June 20 -- The effects of the official policies of monetary and fiscal restraint are about to achieve softening in the economy and an end to the "greatest decline in bond prices," Henry Kaufman, partner and economist of Salomon Brothers Hutzler, said today.
CAIRO, June 20 -- An authoritative Cairo editor reported today that President Nasser held firm to a position of no compromise with Israel during his talks last week with Mr. Gromyko
A new numbering system for stocks and bonds designed to enable computers to "talk" to each other and thus speed up stock-market transactions was introduced here yesterday.

DANANG, South Vietnam, June 20 -- Official spokesmen have stressed that the American forces in the Ashau Valley are not fighting for territory, but to drive out the enemy forces. However, there are increasing signs that the United States command has decided to move into the valley, which has been uninhabited for the last year, on a permanent basis.

Kenneth Burke, the literary critic and Reed Whittemore, the poet, critic and editor, have each received an award of $7,000 for "lifelong contribution to American letters" from the National Council on the Arts.
BOSTON, June 20 -- Joe Pepitone lost a grand slam home run tonight and Hank Soar lost an afternoon with his family. Both of them were unhappy. Pepitone was a little bit louder.
JERUSALEM, June 20 -- Six persons were injured tonight when three bombs exploded in rapid succession on a street leading to the Wailing Wall in the Old City of Jerusalem.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- President Nixon announced today that he had chosen his first woman ambassador. He named Miss Eileen Roberta Donovan of Scituate, Mass., a career diplomat, to be Ambassador to Barbados.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 20 (Reuters) -- President Nguyen Van Thieu met with his top advisers tonight. Usually reliable sources said that Mr. Thieu presented programs for sweeping changes in the Saigon Administration in preparation for an offer for a political settlement with the Vietcong rebels.
LOS ANGELES, June 20 -Federal controls similar to those that regulate the food and drug industry were urged today as a means of curbing the sale of unsafe household products.

BOGOTA, Colombia, June 20 (AP) -- Three men and a woman hijacked a C-47 of the Colombian airline today and ordered it flown to Cuba. They permitted the Urraca airliner to land on the Colombian coast to discharge passengers and take on fuel before flying across the Caribbean.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 20 -- William McChesney Martin Jr., chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, warned United States bankers today that he might favor even sterner restraints such as voluntary credit controls, "forced savings'' and a higher surtax, if these should be needed to bring the severe United States inflation under control.
The Appellate Division ruled yesterday that the city must pay the $5-million annual maintenance cost of the three main Long Island Rail Road stations even though the rail line is owned by the state.

VIENNA, Ga., June 20 (UPI) -- A freight train slammed into a car packed with women and children this afternoon, killing nine of the youngsters and a mother. Two others -- a mother and a child -- were critically injured.

GLEN COVE, L. I., June 20 -The Federal Maritime Administrator declared today that the soon-to-be announced Administration maritime policy would contain features designed to allow the industry more flexibility in managerial, technical and productivity skills.
Ernie Banks, the grand old man of Chicago Cubs baseball, drove in the first run in a 2-0 triumph over the Montreal Expos yesterday at Wrigley Field.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 20 -Southern California's Joaquin Loyo-Mayo, who played second to the late Rafael Osuna on Mexico's Davis Cup team this spring, came from behind to beat Miami's second-seeded Pat Cramer, 5-7, 6-4, 6-2, 6-0, today and earned the right to face Mike Estep of Rice tomorrow in the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tennis championships.
A detailed study of the air pollution problem posed by vehicles that would use the controversial, long-delayed Lower Manhattan Expressway will be financed by the Federal Government.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, June 20 -- Prime Minister Ian D. Smith has won a solid mandate from Rhodesia's tiny whitedominated electorate to give Rhodesia a new Constitution that would clearly separate black voters from white in the country.

TRENTON, June 20 (AP) -Reluctant leaders of the Republicancontrolled Legislature agreed today to return for a special session July 2 to hear Gov. Richard J. Hughes's proposal for immediate action on bills ranging from urban aid and crime control to bus subsidies.

Mayor Lindsay yesterday attributed President Nixon's endorsement of State Senator John J. Marchi as the Republican nominee for Mayor to "the exigencies and needs of party politics on the national scene."
MOSCOW, June 20 -- The United States will have two representatives Eva Yevdokimova and Helgi Tomasson in the final round of the First International Ballet contest here this weekend.
MARKED American copper and brass costs little more than unidentified pieces so it make good sense for the collector to expend the extra effort locating it.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- A high United States official committed the Nixon Administration today to a joint program with the Latin-American nations to "revitalize" the hemisphere's economic, social and political development.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 20 -- Proving that his thirst for world records was as rich as his thirst for clothes, John Carlos ran consecutive races of 9.1 seconds and 9.2 today en route to a National Collegiate outdoor track and field title in the 100-yard dash.

TORONTO, June 20 -- The Canadian dollar slipped to its official value this week, after trading at higher rates in foreign exchange markets for more than 13 months. It closed tonight at the official level, 92.5 United States cents.

EXCEPT for Gustave Tassell, it was a walk down memory lane at several ready-to-wear showings this week. There were Hollywood's old polo coats and prom dresses of the nineteen-forties at George Halley and platform shoes and wedgies at Ken Scott.

A rented car carrying three young Bronx couples in formal attire to a high school prom ripped through a guard rail and a wire-mesh fence last night and plunged 25 feet onto the tracks of the Penn Central railroad cut on Park Avenue near 180th Street.

ST. LOUIS, June 20 (AP) -The St. Louis draft board of Joseph (Jo Jo) White has asked the Selective Service System to set aside the basketball star's Marine Corps reserve status as "fraudulent," the St. Louis GlobeDemocrat said today.
BRADBURY K. THURLOW is like a bull in a bear pen. Sharing the stage with almost nobody, he states rather emphatically that the current stock-market spiral is about over.

NEW ORLEANS, June 20 -A Federal grand jury indicted today Edward Grady Partin, Baton Rouge labor figure, on five counts of conspiracy and extortion. Partin was a key Government witness in the trial that sent James R. Hoffa, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, to prison.
JAMESTOWN, N. Y., June 20 -- A tornado and violent thunderstorms, with winds of up to 84 miles an hour, cut a 20-mile-wide swath through Chautauqua and Cattaraugus Counties today.

LOS ANGELES, June 20 -After almost four years of strikes and boycotts against California table grapes, a committee of grape growers sat down today to discuss a settlement with the union representing agricultural workers.

Herbert Hoover 3d, 41-yearold grandson of President Herbert Hoover, has resigned as president and director of the Sierracin Corporation, the company announced yesterday. He has been succeeded by Ramsey C. Armstrong, who will continue as chairman and chief executive officer.

LONDON, June 20 -- Rod Laver, the world's No. 1 player and the odds-on favorite to take the Wimbledon title for the fourth time, was soundly thrashed by John Newcombe today in the semi-finals of the London grass-court open tennis tournament.

TOKYO, June 20 (Reuters) -The Ministry of International Trade and Industry today ordered Japanese motorcycle manufacturers to speed up the recall of defective machines, including about 2,000 unsafe cycles in the United States.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Three top officials of the New York Stock Exchange will meet with President Nixon here on Monday afternoon, Ronald L. Zeigler, White House Press Secretary, announced today.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -The board of directors of the National Association of Broadcasters canceled today an agreement on the development of cable television that its staff had negotiated last month with representatives of the cable companies.

STANFORD, Calif. -- In "My Fair Lady," Prof. Henry Higgins taught a primitive Cockney named Eliza Doo-little to speak correctly. Prof. Kenneth L. Pike of the University of Michigan has taken the whole world of primitive tribes for his province, and he is trying to understand what they say.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- President Nixon presented Medals of Honor today to the next-of-kin of three Marine enlisted men killed in Vietnam combat.

Another chance to see a triple crown wrapped up, this one the triple crown for fillies, will be offered racing fans at Belmont Park today. The 1 1/4mile Coaching Club American Oaks, the third segment of the triad that includes the Acorn and the Mother Goose, will have its 53d running and its entrants include Mrs. Whitney Stone's Shuvee.
PARIS, June 20 -- The new Premier of France was born in Paris on March 7, 1915, a sunny day for the most part.

YONKERS, June 20 -- Lady B. Fast, a 5-year-old Speedster mare who only once before had moved so fast over a half-mile oval, recorded a major upset by winning the $25,000 Volomite one-mile trot in 2:00 4/5 tonight at Yonkers Raceway.
PARIS, June 20 -- An effort to make the living standards of all members of the Roman Catholic clergy, from priest to archbishop, more equal has been announced by the Paris Archdiocese.
Two months ago, 12-year-old Noreen thought that the letter's B-A-L-L spelled "doll." David, 10, could not read his name. And Sandra, at 11, stared at the word "look" and told her teacher:

BRIELLE, N. J., June 20 --- George E. Haines, a sixthgrade schoolmaster from the Westtown School in suburban Philadelphia, scored an eagle 3 on the Manasquan River Golf Club's 447-yard fifth hole today and seemed on his way to an easy victory in New Jersey amateur championship when he was detoured.

LOS ANGELES, June 20 (AP) -- Connie Hawkins has jumped from the American Basketball Association and signed with the Phoenix Suns of the rival National Basketball Association, dropping in the process his $6million lawsuit against the N.B.A.
WHAT makes men haze freshmen, join fraternities, form Kiwanis Clubs or have a night out with the boys while their wives climb the walls?

The nation's air transportation system returned to near normal operations yesterday after Federal air traffic controllers called off a "sickness" demonstration that caused monumental air traffic delays on Thursday.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 20 -An authoritative source disclosed tonight that Arab commandos were withdrawing from Lebanon.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 20 -- An enemy force estimated at 600 stormed a United States artillery support base and landing zone north of Tayninh early this morning, killing 7 Americans and wounding 18 in the second day of an upsurge in enemy assaults in and around the provincial capital.
WESTPORT, Conn., June 20 -- General C., ridden by Jim Hulick, won his fourth consecutive junior working hunter championship today at the Fairfield County Hunt Club Horse Show.

The recent furor about conflict of interest where judges in the Federal courts are concerned leads us to ask why similar inquiries have not been raised in the matter of the appointment or nomination of civil court judges.
Denny's Restaurants, Inc., which earlier this month declared itself a suitor of the Parvin-Dohrmann Company, announced yesterday it had contracted to buy another company with gambling interests.

WASHINGTON, June 20 (UPI) -- Lieut. Gen. Lewis B. Hershey said today that if a youth filed suit against his draft board he could postpone his military service for years and often avoid induction entirely.
ROME, June 20 -- The Vatican confirmed today that it was selling "some" of its shareholdings in the Societa General Immobiliare, a 107-year-old nationwide real estate and financial holding company.

CHARLESTON, S. C., June 20 (AP) -- About 400 supporters of striking hospital workers tried to march tonight without a parade permit, and threw bricks and bottles at the police and National Guard troops who tried to stop them.

Angry postal workers demonstrated at post offices here yesterday to protest what their leaders called an "insulting" and "unrealistic" 4.1 per cent pay increase granted by President Nixon in an Executive order.
Late selling forced the American Stock Exchange to its fifteenth straight decline yesterday in moderate trading.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -A panel of land resource experts recommended today that the wild horse -- a vanishing symbol of the Old West -be given better protection so he could continue to roam the open range.

The Rabbinical Council of America, representing nearly 1,000 Orthodox rabbis in this country and Canada, called on its members this week to give young people a greater voice in congregational affairs.

PRAGUE, June 20 -- The Government today dissolved the Student Union, which helped spearhead last year's short-lived liberalization and which, until recently, had defied the new pro-Moscow leadership of the Communist party.
THE Puritan tradition condemns playing-cards as the Devil's tickets and links card-games with gambling. But the link is not necessarily valid.
The world's largest and most powerful tug, the 17,500-horsepower, 284-foot West German Oceanic, underwent initial sea trials last week.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands -- The opera likely to make the biggest splash in Europe in a long time will have its premiere here during the Holland Festival.
The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday one-month suspensions of two members who formerly acted as specialists in the stock of the Westec Corporation.
CHICAGO, June 20 -- The Students for a Democratic Society convention was plunged into chaos tonight when the Black Panther party denounced the Progressive Labor faction as "contrarevolutionary."

WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Nicholas Johnson of the Federal Communications Commission said today that the commission should face up to the issue of whether a competing application should be considered for the broadcasting license held by WPIX-TV in New York.

The technical rally in silverfuture contracts earlier in the week ran into heavy selling by discouraged holders of long positions who wanted to liquidate. Their selling forced prices down twoards the low levels made previously.
MC5, the raucous rock band from Detroit, is playing through tomorrow night at Ungano's, a club at 210 West 70th Street.
The president of the Board of Education said yesterday that progress was being made in the contract talks with the United Federation of Teachers.
ATHENS, Tex., June 20--Clinton Williams Murchison Sr., the entrepreneur whose $500-million fortune ranked him as one of the world's wealthiest men, died here today at the age of 74.

WHEN Mr. and Mrs. Kermit Roosevelt Jr. named their baby daughter Corinne Avery a couple of months ago (the birth date was April 23), Mrs. Roosevelt said, "We thought of calling her just Avery, but it seemed sort of sexless."

TAIPEI, Taiwan -- Greater Taipei, rising on land dominated 20 years ago by rice paddies, is experiencing nearly all the growth problems of a Western city -housing, administration, traffic, industry and even smog.
Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner yesterday rejected suggestions that his defeat in the Democratic mayoral primary was his "last hurrah." But he ruled himself out as an independent candidate in November.
AUSTIN, Tex., June 19 -- A reader, perhaps typical of many in and out of Texas, addressed the following letter to the editor of The Dallas Morning News the other day:

Despite the substantial contributions its research findings have made to public health, the pharmaceutical industry has come in for much justified criticism of its policies regarding pricing, advertising and, at times, inadequate testing procedures.
Arthur, the East Side discotheque, whose psychedelic lighting, frenetic music and chic informality attracted the young and the restless, is closing after four years.

PARIS, June 20 -- Sources in the United States delegation said tonight that there could be no political negotiation on a Vietnam settlement at the peace talks here so long as the other side olung to its demand for the ouster of the present government of South Vietnam.

CANBERRA, Australia, June 20 -- While avoiding future military commitments in Southeast Asia after 1971, Britain will maintain an armed posture in the region which "really has meaning" as a deterrent to aggression, the British Defense Minister, Denis Healey said today.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., June 20 (UPI) -- The New Zealand lefthander, Bob Charles, broke out of a log jam with a six-underpar 138 today to gain the secondround lead in the $150,000 Kemper open by a stroke over eight runners-up.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- A spokesman for Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare Robert H. Finch said today that Dr. John H. Knowles was still the Secretary's choice for Assistant Secretary for Health and Scientific Affairs.

THE Stuttgart Ballet last night at the Metropolitan Opera House continued its remorseless and inevitable conquest of the New York dance world. The major factor in this conquest is undeniably John Cranko, the director and choreographer, backed up by his teaching and ballet staff led by Anne Woolliams and Alan Beale.
The new-issue market took its worst beating in six months this week as prices of most new offerings declined in active trading.

With a flourish fully worthy of the largest crowd at a National League game this season, the New York Mets extended their recent surge by polishing off the St. Louis Cardinals and Bob Gibson at Shea Stadium last night.

Stanley G. Mortimer Jr., the son-in-law of W. Averell Harriman, was in satisfactory condition yesterday in a hospital in Tuxedo, N. Y. after having attempted suicide Monday with a shotgun, the state police said.
A mild rally on the London stock market yesterday checked the steady downturn prevalent throughout the week. Trading remained light, however, and modest gains reflected technical situations.

A leading Negro job recruiter for business and industry warned yesterday that unless the Republican Administration gave solid support to new legislation to enforce equal employment opportunities President Nixon would "put the final nail in the coffin of his credibility in the black community."

VIENNA, June 20 -- A bitter feud between Friedrich Gulda, the pianist, and the venerable Vienna Musikakademie today threatened to overshadow the finale of the Vienna Music Festival, now drawing to a close.

It is distressingly obvious from the story of the imprisonment of the Soviet engineer, Boris Kochubiyevsky (news story June 5), that his only crime was that of being a Jew, wishing to adhere to his Jewish heritage and desirous of transmitting that cultural heritage to his children still unborn.
An unofficial recount gave Francis X. Smith the Democratic nomination for City Council President yesterday, after errors in the Election Night tabulation came to light.
Cigar smokers will soon have to pay more for their favorite brands.

Bowie Kuhn, the commissioner of baseball, denied yesterday that he had "ordered" club owners to divest themselves of stock holdings in Las Vegas hotels. He disclosed that his continuing investigation would eventually produce a set of guidelines to define what sort of connections were undesirable for baseball.

A jury that had deliberated three days reported yesterday that it was unable to agree on a verdict in the case of a man charged with murdering Vera Ann Coppola, a bank clerk killed in the Wall Street area.

NEWARK, June 20 -- A request by a lawyer for Simone Rizzo (Sam the Plumber) DeCavalcante to suppress any further dissemination of his recorded conversations with other reputed Mafiosi was denied here today in Federal District Court.
WASHINGTON, June 20 (AP) -- Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird reported to Congress today that the cost of nine weapons projects had risen $3.5-billion above earlier estimates.
ROME, June 20 -- Pope Paul VI will soon appoint a team of experts to study the "holy shroud" said to have been wrapped around the body of Jesus after he was removed from the cross.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Two leading New York bankers vigorously defended today last week's one per cent jump in the prime lending rate and indicated the move was already succeeding in relieving a dangerous situation in the banking system and financial markets.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -The chief of the Justice Department's antitrust division said today that the Nixon Administration was opposed to any special authorization for pricefixing and profit-pooling by "competing" newspapers.

GLEN COVE, L. I., June 20 -- John Humm, a 50-year-old golfer who won the title in 1948 and 1952, added to the woes of the generation gap today as he eliminated two young golfers to reach the quarter-final round of the 46th annual Long Island amateur championship at the Nassau Country Club.

Arnold Toynbee has said that the most dangerous nations are those that have never been defeated. With the exception of the United States all the great powers past and present have had their national purpose thwarted to a greater or lesser extent and suffered humiliation.

Dental societies in the five boroughs of the city accused the City Health Department yesterday of being unfair in a recent Medicaid inquiry that found that 9 per cent of 1,300 dental cases studied showed evidence of fraud by private practitioners.

The latest argument for an ABM system is that it is required to prevent the destruction of our deterrent forces by a massive first-strike of Russian SS-9 missiles carrying thousands of multiple warheads.
OMAHA, June 20 -- Arizona State's baseball team was supremely confident about the outcome of its National Collegiate title game against Tulsa University tonight in Rosenblatt Stadium.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -The chief of the Justice Department's antitrust division said today that the Nixon Administration was opposed to any special authorization for pricefixing and profit-pooling by "competing" newspapers.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- A Federal judge today ordered the United Mine Workers and its president, W. A. (Tony) Boyle, to stop denying fair and equal distribution of publicity among the membership to Joseph A. Yablonski, an opponent of Mr. Boyle in the union presidential race.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Administration officials conceded "disappointment" today at the Soviet response to the principles for a Middle East settlement presented by the United States late last month. But they indicated that the two-power conversations and the four-power talks at the United Nations would continue.

A discussion by three doctors, a lawyer, an official of the Federal Bureau of Narcotics and a student representative yesterday produced the dominant view that marijuana laws might be eased but should not be erased.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Police departments, courts and correctional agencies in New York State will share a $1,853,391 Federal grant aimed at improving their ability to deal with crime, Attorney General John N. Mitchell announced today.

Terry Sawchuk, who admits that "my body is getting a little sore after all these years," became a Ranger yesterday in a deal in which the New Yorkers traded Larry Jeffrey to the Detroit Red Wings for the 39year-old goalie and a 22-yearold forward, Sandy Snow.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -The stresses and frustrations of being a Negro in the city are driving some young black men and women to suicide, a study by a psychiatrist of Columbia University suggests.

PARIS, June 20 -- Georges Pompidou took office as President of France today for a seven-year term. A few hours later he named Jacques ChabanDelmas, the President of the National Assembly, as Premier, succeeding Maurice Couve de Murville.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- New orders for durable goods dropped sharply in May, after a large increase in April that is believed to have been caused by attempts of some businesses to place their orders before the expected termination date of the 7 per cent investment-tax credit.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 20 -The University of California Regents gave a resounding "no" today to renewed appeals of campus administrators to permit a user-created "people's park" on university-owned land in Berkeley.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -- The International Monetary Fund announced today the long-expected $1-billion standby credit for Britain.

The city's top housing official, Jason R. Nathan, said yesterday that Congress was undermining its own Housing Act of 1968 by "slashing funds for the city's urban renewal, Model Cities and fair housing programs."

Nearly thirty years ago, 350 feet beneath a West Virginia mountain, I stood paralyzed with fear when a greasy haulage motor caught fire. Having heard endless mine lore from my father and grandfather, I knew that fire in a mine was death, especially when the mine was not rockdusted to reduce the explosiveness of coal dust.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, June 20 -- Governor Rockefeller was virtually free of harassment by hostile demonstrators today during talks with Paraguayan leaders, in which he studied the problems of this small and impoverished nation.

Lou Rosini of the Easter Seal Paranauts of Philadelphia broke his own meet record in the heavyweight division of the weight-lifting competition yesterday at the 13th annual national wheelchair games got under way at Bulova School of Watchmaking in Queens.

WASHINGTON, June 20 -- Sue Fuller, a New York abstract artist, will be awarded a patent next week for her method of constructing three-dimensional compositions of colored thread that appear to be floating in space.
WASHINGTON, June 20 -Former Attorney General Ramsey Clark suggested today that J. Edgar Hoover retire as director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

The constitutional right of American citizens to be secure against "unreasonable searches and seizures" is gravely jeopardized by a Justice Department brief filed in the Federal District Court in Chicago.
HACKENSACK, N. J. June 21 -- Top-seeded Pete Fishbach of Great Neck, L. I., won two matches at the start of the annual Eastern clay-court tennis championship today at the Oritani Field Club.
The secretary of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Dudley T. Easby Jr., is resigning to become consultative chairman of the museum's new department of primitive art.

THE Bankers Trust "A" chess team, a quintet of experienced buffs, Lorie, Phillips, DeSimini, Leipa and Ganser, captured first place in the recent Bankers League Tournament by scoring 12-2 match points ahead of the field.

LONDON, June 21 -- In a 2-hour, 12-minute battle fought at tremendous speed and pace. Fred Stolle outgunned John Newcombe today, 6-3, 22-20, and won the London grass court tennis championship at the Queen's Club.
The only Negro member of the State Board of Regents charged yesterday that the police were unfairly blamed for crime problems arising from what he termed an inefficient and ineffective school system.

One of the gravest travesties of the Democratic spirit that exists today in the United States is the lack of Congressional representation for the residents of the District of Columbia.
DALLAS, June 21 -- The Dallas employment situation may be leveling out.

CHICAGO, Sunday, June 22 -- The national officers of Students for a Democratic Society read the Progressive Labor faction out of the organization early today, then walked out of the national convention.

THE race is on for the holidayer's monthly savings. He is being tempted with free cameras and half-price theater tickets, provided he signs up for pay-now, go-later plans under which he can buy annual overseas vacations by agreeing to make regular payments to a travel club over a period of one to three years.

CANON CITY, Colo. -- The Royal Gorge is a handy size: It is deep enough to be spectacular and yet narrow enough to be spanned. For 40 years, tourists have been crossing the gorge on a suspension bridge whose main span is 880 feet long, and for 38 years they have been descending 1,058 feet to the Arkansas River on an incline railway.
CLEVELAND, June 21 (UPI) -- Mike Cuellar limited the Cleveland Indians to four hits today as the Baltimore Orioles scored their ninth victory in their last 10 games, 3-1.

MINEOLA, L. I., June 21 -- The creation of a commuter commission to protect the interests of riders on the Long Island Rail Road was proposed this week by Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson to the Board of Supervisors.

PLUSCARDEN PRIORY, Scotland -- This 13th-century Benedictine priory, the most northern monastery in the world, unless there are any still going in Russia, is set in gorgeous countryside, but it is hardly the sort of place that one would expect to find booking up fast as a holiday center. But that is what is happening. Americans from New York, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Ohio and many other places have written to inquire about staying here.
VINCENT CANBY's piece on Nick Ray was a sensitive and very intelligently written statement on what's certainly the most tragic situation in the film world today.

The dust jacket of "The Fantasy Worlds of Peter Stone" says that in it Malcolm Boyd explores the "myths of American society" -- which might seem a bit pretentious in a 120-page volume, except that the author is something of a myth himself and thus speaks from firsthand experience.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, June 21 -- The United States agreed today to work through a special inter-American committee to establish "new bases and instruments of action" for economic cooperation with Latin America.

DAMASCUS, Syria, June 21 (AP) -- The Arab League today announced a ban on the Columbia Broadcasting System for "rendering consultative services and technical assistance" to Israel's television network.

Arthur Schlesinger Jr.'s latest book sets out to be a history of our times and a prescription for the future. An enormous task, true, but one for which Schlesinger would seem to have all the qualifications: academic leader, prizewinning author, intimate of Presidents and politicians.

NEWPORT, R. I., June 21 -- ''It would not be right, now would it, if a trans-Atlantic race to Ireland had no Irish boat sailing in it? No, it would not, and that is why we have entered the Helen of Howth, shipping her from Dublin to Newport for that purpose."

LONDON -- Anthony Trollope would have enjoyed this last political week in London. For in his novels he saw politics as posturing, motivated largely by the desire for power; he suggested that most great issues were invented and were as easily abandoned by their inventors.

THE exhibition entitled "The New American Painting and Sculpture: The First Generation," which opened this week at the Museum of Modern Art, offers us not a loan show but the museum's own permanent collection as it has not been augmented by a busy round of belated purchases and gifts. The irony that has necessitated these new purchases and gifts is as obvious as it is familiar.

HANOVER, N. H., June 21 -- The Dartmouth College Committee on Standing and Conduct, the college's disciplinary board, has adjourned for the summer, having disposed of the cases of 31 of the 40 students who were arrested May 7 for occupying Parkhurst Hall, the administration building, in violation of a court injunction.

PHILADELPHIA -- Listen to the Boston people, and you come away firmly convinced that Philadelphia did not really do much in the Revolutionary War, that it played merely a supportive role to the genius of Bostonians, who started, carried on and finished off America's fight for independence.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., June 21 -- Marty Liquori of Villanova, who was almost too sick to run, upset Jim Ryun of Kansas today in a thrilling one-mile run at the 48th annual National Collegiate outdoor track and field championships.

The latest phase of the $8.5-million Brooklyn Bridge ramp system -- a 1,500-foot-long ramp to carry Manhattan-bound traffic from the bridge to northbound lanes of the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive -- is in the final stages of construction.

DALLAS, June 21 (AP) -- The president of the John F. Kennedy Memorial Commission said Thursday that "an extremely fair price" had been negotiated for construction of the memorial and that the monument would be dedicated by Jan. 1.

Even when such a fence is not required by law, most home swimming pool owner's will prefer to put up some kind of tall fence in order to insure privacy, to keep out wandering children, unwanted strangers or roving pets -- and to act as a windscreen on breezy days.

JERUSALEM -- Israel will have a national election this fall, and the results are all but in. Mrs. Golda Meir, who was selected as Premier to replace the late Levi Eshkol earlier this year, will almost certainly succeed herself.

IF it is true that God helps those who help themselves, then the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra should be assured of a future -- an independent one, not shared as part of a merger with the Rochester Philharmonic. For the members of the orchestra, the people who play the violin, oboe, trombone and triangle, are literally out on the streets trying to raise a whopping $1.5-million for their own endowment fund.

Reviewing Lawrence Durrell's book of travel essays, "Spirit of Place" (June 8), Patrick Leigh Fermor boasts of his familiarity with "the Mediterranean diaspora." When it comes to the Central European watershed, alas, he's all wet.
In "Say, Isn't That Whats-isname?", doesn't Joan Walker slip on her own "Whats-isname" peel when she pairs Ralph Bellamy with Joan Bennett in the Geritol commercial?

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 21 -- After a singularly pessimistic monetary conference of the American Bankers Association here, bankers around the world have become well aware of the possibilities of a general economic slowdown.

PARIS, June 21 -- President Pompidou suffered a setback today when Antoine Pinay, on whom he had counted to lend prestige to the Government's financial policies, refused to become his Finance Minister.

PORTLAND, Me., June 21 -- Percival P. Baxter, the former Governor of Maine who died here on June 12, has left to the state of Maine trust property that will bring income that is valued at more than $5-million.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 21 -- Paul Mellon's Fort Marcy, a sort of equine Fort Knox, made another succesful flying foray into Hollywood Park today.
RED BANK, N. J., June 21 (AP) -- Trouble broke out in a small area of Red Bank for the second consecutive night tonight as Negro youths had a second rock-throwing encounter with the police.

The year's longest span of daylight is upon us, and the latest sunset. From now on, through the height and the heat of summer, the days will slowly shrink, a few minutes at a time, toward the balance of the equinox in September.

CHARLESTON, S. C., June 23 -- The wife of the Rev. Ralph David Abernathy accused Charleston officials today of arresting her husband on a phony charge and keeping him in jail under an exorbitant bond.

LOS ANGELES, June 23 (AP) -- Johnny Longden has disclosed that Majestic Prince probably would not race again until 1970 because of a condition that began to show even before the colt's victory in the Preakness and defeat in the Belmont Stakes.

The International Business Machines Corporation announced yesterday a new pricing formula for its computer equipment and services in a move that is expected to cause a major restructuring of the rapidly growing, multi-billion-dollar electronic data processing industry.
DUSSELDORF, West Germany, June 23 (UPI) -- West German authorities said today that the fish population of the Rhine River, numbering in the millions, had been poisoned by an unknown pollutant.
OTTAWA, June 23 (UPI) -- Defense Minister Leo Cadieux announced today that Canada would reduce her armed forces from 98,000 to 80,000-85,000 men during the next three years.
YONKERS, June 23 -- Miss Conna Adios has the distinction of being one of the most active pacers in the East judging from the working schedule that has been arranged for the 4-year-old mare.
CAIRO, June 23 -- Egyptian commando activity is increasing after a lull of nearly two months.

NIAGARA - ON-THE - LAKE, Ontario, June 23 -- It is always exciting to watch seeds grow into saplings and holding out the promise of trees. Niagara-on-the-Lake is an extraordinarily beautiful township just on Canada's side of the border.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Chief Justice Earl Warren was himself the author of some of the most important opinions that the Supreme Court handed down during the 16 years in which he presided over its deliberations.

LOS ANGELES, June 23 -- The cost of doing business has traditionally been greater in New York than anywhere else in the country, but the gap is narrowing. Corporations renting space in scores of cities from coast to coast are finding that rentals and the price of essential services are moving upward even faster outside of New York City than they are in the world's business capital.

THE 64-year-old Roman Catholic primate of Belgium, Leon-Joseph Cardinal Suenens, who has upset the Vatican with his criticism of the governng process of the church, is known as a modern bishop, an excellent theologian and a soccer enthusiast.

RIVERHEAD, L. I., June 23 -- Three men accused of being linked with organized crime were arrested today on charges of using innocent collectors, including Boy and Girl Scouts to raise thousands of dollars for a bogus charity.
