PARIS, June 23 -- An assembly of radical priests, some of them married, concelebrated mass in the crypt of a Roman Catholic church here over the weekend.
PORTSMOUTH, England, June 23 (AP) -- The first four men ever to walk across the polar ice cap returned to solid land today and said that polar bears were the biggest danger they had encountered.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- Proposed Government regulations to be published tomorrow would lower the standards for skilled nursing-home care under Medicaid.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The Justice Department announced today that it would file suit, in an attempt to block the proposed merger of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation and the Hartford Fire Insurance Company.

Laird said today that the Pentagon would continue to allow members of the same family to serve together on a ship despite the loss of three brothers aboard the destroyer Frank E. Evans when the Australian carrier Melbourne sliced her in half June 3.

BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., June 23 -- Two top helmsmen of the Riverside (Conn.) The 19th annual Berlin Film Festival, which starts tomorrow and will run through July 6, will eliminate the presentation of awards by categories of talent. VIENTIANE, Laos, June 25 -- Five battalions of North Vietnamese troops have launched a surprise attack on Muong Soui, an important Government base west of the Plaine des Jarres. Following 36 hours of intermittent fighting, some of it described as heavy, Government forces continue to held the town and its strategic airstrip, the longest in the hills of northeastern Laos.

The murder conviction of a 35-year-old derelict was reversed yesterday by the Appellate Division, despite the agreement of all five justices of the court that the defendant had "stabbed and killed" his victim.

President Nixon can claim he has fulfilled at least one campaign pledge and presumably Senator Dirksen will sleep better. The Senate has confirmed Otto F. Otepka -- living symbol of some of the worst days of the McCarthy-McCarran era -- to a $36,000-a-year job on the superfluous Subversive Activities Control Board.

BOSTON, June 25 (AP) -- A Chicago researcher has developed an easily administered test to locate tumors of the parathyroids -- small glands in the neck that regulate calcium and phosphate in the body.

A group of 50 delegates, including producers, executives, actors and writers, headed by Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, will attend the Sixth Moscow Film Festival, July 7 through July 22.

The Avco Corporation had lower sales and earnings in the second quarter, reflecting the high cost of money in its personal loan operations and the reduced volume of its government business, the company's report disclosed yesterday.

Representative Hugh L. Carey said yesterday that he had volunteered to run as an independent candidate for Mayor "to check the emotional, panicky stampede" of Democrats to Mayor Lindsay, touched off by the results of primary voting.

A 28-year-old construction worker, jailed since last November in the Brooklyn House of Detention, was set free yesterday after authorities searched in vain for the records in his case.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 25 -- There was moon, military and long-duration spaceflight testing going on here today.

Jerry Quarry, his right eye closing, was flat on his feet, sometimes actually rocking back on his heels, and his survival instinct was in command. He was protecting his right eye with his right glove and jabbing defensively with his left, instead of trying for a desperate punch that might stagger Joe Frazier or even knock him out.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -- Representative Richard L. Ottinger charged today that the Rockefeller family had improperly intervened in the Interior Department's approval of the Hudson River expressway.

BILLINGS, Mont., June 25 -- Eastern Montana's Second Congressional District for the first time since 1958 will send a Democrat to the United States House of Representatives following a close special election contest yesterday.
FORT-LAMY, Chad, June 22 -- Almost unnoticed by the outside world, a rebellion is slowly spreading across this parched Central African nation, pitting Arabs against black men.

LUSAKA, Zambia -- A little sardine, which Africans call the harlot because of vivid coloring of an area near its mouth resembling ruby-red lips, is to form the basis of a million-dollar fishing industry in landlocked Zambia, where protein-deficiency in human diets is a serious problem.
The Free Theater of New York, which performs for impromptu audiences on the city's streets in the summer, has been granted $10,000 by four foundations and the New York State Council on the Arts.
The Associated Dry Goods Corporation, whose department-store operations include Lord Taylor here, announced yesterday the election of three new directors.
STANFORD, Calif., June 25 (UPI) -- Householders were advised today to quit using DDT sprays, but by no means to throw the sprays away.

BONN, June 25 -- A poisonous wave of insecticide washed out of West German waters today after killing millions of Rhine River fish and some ducks during the last six days. It is still lingering in the Netherlands, where about 100 tons of dead fish have washed up.

BRUSSELS, June 25 -- Common Market officials said today delay by the Senate in confirming the appointment of Carl J. Gilbert as President Nixon's special trade negotiator had impeded progress in settling trade problems between the community and the United State.

CAIRO, Friday, June 27 (Reuters) -- A program for peace in the Middle East purportedly advocated by the United States was published today by the Cairo newspaper Al Ahram.
BONN, June 26 -- West Germany's Bundestag or lower house of Parliament decided today to give the judiciary 10 more years for the tracking down and prosecution of Nazi criminals.

The National Audubon Society announced yesterday the start of a campaign to ban the use of DDT anywhere in the United States.

STONY BROOK, L. I., June 26 -- Mrs. Thorne Dempsey of St. George's Golf and Country Club and Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Glen Oaks will meet tomorrow in the 36-hole final of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's 66th annual championship.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- President Nixon's decision to appoint Dr. John H. Knowles to the Government's top health post, a certainty Tuesday, was cast into doubt today -- but not necessarily reversed.

The student disorders that plagued the city's secondary schools in late April and early May, forcing some schools to close temporarily, have virtually disappeared during the last six weeks of the term that ends today.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 26 -- The man sought by California was identified as Richard Claude Scott, also known as Richard Syska. CAIRO, Ill., June 26 (AP) -- A missile-throwing incident flared up between groups of Negroes and whites gathered at Cairo's police station tonight. It was quickly brought under control, but increased state police patrols and an 8 P.M. to 6 A.M. curfew were ordered.
Editors and distributors of four mass - circulation periodicals with a heavy emphasis on sex were arrested yesterday afternoon after they voluntarily surrendered to police.

DETROIT, June 26 -- The Yankees and the Tigers both had their bags packed tonight, but it was the visitors who took away the victory in the finale of the four-game series.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 26 -- Bob Lutz defeated Ken Rosewall today in the first major upset in the Wimbledon tennis open. The 21-year-old University of Southern California senior, not good enough to reach the semi-finals of the National Collegiate championship last week, beat the 34-year-old Australian, 8-6, 7-9, 6-3, 6-2, and ended Ken's chance to win the only great championship that has escaped him.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The Nixon Administration, stepping up preparations for the start of missile talks with the Soviet Union, has named a five-man negotiating team and has scheduled briefings for members of the North Atlantic alliance, according to reliable sources.

BENNY GOODMAN and Lionel Hampton made embers of the Swing Era glow again last night when they made one of their infrequent appearances together at the first concert in this summer's Schaefer Music Festival at the Wollman Rink in Central Park.
MIAMI, June 26 -- Hardly anyone noticed Byron Dyce holding an extensive workout yesterday under a hot, south Florida sun. But then, hardly anyone seems to notice half-milers these days.

At a meeting disrupted by a student who served a court order on the chairman, the trustees of Long Island University yesterday selected Glenn W. Ferguson, former Ambassador to Kenya, as the university's new chancellor.
A recent diplomatic incident sheds some light on the disarray of American trade policy.
Prices on the London stock market closed lower yesterday as a four-day rally lost momentum.
A lawyer in practice here for 36 years was disbarred yesterday after admitting he had paid $35,000 to an associate of the former chairman of the State Liquor Authority to win favors for his clients.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) -- Secretary George Romney of the Department of Housing and Urban Development, announced today the approval of eight new model cities contracts totaling $66.5-million, including $38.1-million for Chicago.

The Metropolitan Opera Association plans to terminate the contracts of 50 individual artists and does not plan to begin rehearsals for 1969-70 until the new season is assured through agreements with its major labor unions.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The Federal Reserve Board moved today to moderate the enormous borrowings by large American banks of Eurodollars as an escape from the Reserve's restrictive money and credit policy.

RACINE, Wis., June 25 -- A three-day television conference opened here today on the perennial problem of noncommercial TV: What should public broadcasting do on the air? The answers range from not making educational TV "sour and dour" to closing a generation gap and choosing between arousing the activist elite or the apathetic mass. No solutions were expected by Saturday afternoon's adjournment.
Your June 18 editorial repeated an assertion that the Democratic mayoral nominee, Mario Procaccino, had conducted a "one-issue campaign." The facts are otherwise.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Without any public announcement the Air Force last week ordered the controversial multiple warheads for its Minuteman 3 intercontinental missiles.

On Wall Street, they might call it "a seasonal adjustment." But whatever it was, the New York Mets kept cooling off yesterday, and suffered a 2-0, four-hit setback at the hands of Grant Jackson and the Philadelphia Phillies at Shea Stadium.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Richard W. McLaren, the head of the Justice Department's antitrust division warned the securities industry today that it had the responsibility of proving that fixed minimum commissions on securities transactions "are necessary to make the Securities Exchange Act work."

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The American Civil Liberties Union started a constitutional challenge today against the Justice Department's new doctrine that wiretapping of certain domestic groups can be justified on grounds of "national security."

The promoters of a rock music festival planned for mid-August in Wallkill, N. Y., met here yesterday to plan security measures. They hope to prevent disorders such as those that marred similar activities in California last weekend. The promoters anticipate a crowd that could reach 150,000.

SANTIAGO, Chile, June 26 -- President Eduardo Frei Montalva announced tonight a gradual take-over of the Anaconda Company's two big copper mines at Chuquicamata and Salvador, and said that they would be nationalized fully in 1972.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) -- Former President Lyndon B. Johnson, breaking a selm-imposed silence that has lasted since he left office said tonight that the scars of divisions still existed in the Democratic party.

The Chicago Cubs maintained yesterday their strange mastery over the Pittsburgh Pirates in games played at Wrigley Field on Jim Hickman's two-run homer in the 10th inning. The hit -- the seventh home run of the game at the windy field -- enabled the Cubs to triumph, 7-5, for their 13th straight over the Pirates at home.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) -- The Board of Immigration Appeals ruled today that Susan B. Anthony, grandniece of the suffragette, had not lost her United States citizenship and could not be deported.

LOS ANGELES, June 26 -- Heavy industry is usually blamed as a prime contributor to pollution of the environment, but evidence is growing that the white-collar habitat of American commerce also must shoulder part of the blame for befouling the urban landscape.

PARIS -- The United States has never been so emotionally upset and generally befuddled by any issue as Vietnam. Even the Civil War with complex arguments over slavery, racial equality, states' rights and integration of the developing West seems to have been more easily understood.
DOVER, Del., June 26 -- The Delaware Senate passed today a resolution calling for a Federal constitutional convention, but action this year in the House was called unlikely.
Joe Louis, one of the greatest heavyweight champions in boxing history, collapsed at noon yesterday on a lower Manhattan street and was taken to Beekman-Downtown Hospital.

IN the eyes of some financial analysts, Litton Industries took a novel approach in stating its preliminary nine-months' earnings and thus showed a 40 per cent increase in per-share results rather than a decline.

Theodore C. Sorensen and Stanley H. Lowell, both actively identified with the liberal wing of the Democratic party, declared yesterday that they had not yet decided whom to support for Mayor of New York City.

SACRAMENTO Calif., June 26 -- Earl Warren says the most important Supreme Court rulings of his 16 years as Chief Justice of the United States were those declaring that one man's vote should mean as much as any other man's.

Eight members of a Muslim religious sect were convicted in Federal District Court in Brooklyn yesterday of assaulting F.B.I. agents and assisting in the escape of a Federal prisoner, according to John F. Malone, chief of the New York office of the F.B.I.
PRAGUE, June 27 -- In her first appearance here, Ella Fitzgerald was greeted tonight by rhythmic applause.

STONY BROOK, L. I., June 27 -- Mrs. Thorne Dempsey of the St. George's Golf and Country Club won the 66th women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship today in an exciting 36-hole final against Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Glen Oaks.

GROTON, Conn., June 27 -Oliver Buckland Ellsworth, a leading Connecticut banker, drowned today after he apparently suffered a heart attack on his boat in Mumford Cove. He was 71 years old and lived at 53 Neptune Drive.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP -- Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that he had asked for an immediate report on the use of armored vests in Vietnam after a member of Congress reported that some had serious defects.
TORONTO, June 27 -- Most Canadian banks raised their prime lending rates to 8 1/2 per cent today and the interest paid on non-checking savings accounts to 6 1/2 per cent. Both rates are records.

The Celanese Plastics Company, a division of the Celanese Corporation, said yesterday it was raising prices on its line of ophthalmic sheeting, effective July 1. The sheeting is used for eyeglass and sunglass frames, trophies and personal accessories.
A 22-year-old man was arrested yesterday on a charge of homicide in the death of a 15-month-old girl.

THE young American craftsmen's show that opened yesterday at the Museum of Contemporary Crafts is immensely pleasing. It will offend no one, but neither will it add much that is startlingly new to the apperception of those who follow the field.

CLEVELAND, June 27 -- Charles Coody, a slim Texan whose principal achievement on the gollf circuit was to win the Dallas Open in 1964 as a freshman professional, led the $110,000 Cleveland Open by four strokes today.

A vivid instance of instant image-changing is carried out each night this week at Plaza 9, where a young seven-man group of instrumentalists and singers called the Americana Brass is making its first New York appearance.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 27 -- While the Apollo 11 astronauts practiced a landing on the moon today, technicians at Launching Pad 39 started to simulate the full countdown preparations for the first lunar landing next month.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Pentagon said today the Army would burn 12,643 tons of poisonous mustard gas at United States military installations, as recommended by the National Academy of Sciences last week.

LONDON, June 27 -- A "lost" Tiepolo, discovered gracing one of the ceilings of the United Arab Republic Embassy in London in 1965, was bought today for 390,000 guineas ($982,800) at a sale of old master's paintings at Christie's.
MADRID, June 27 -- A Portuguese resistance leader who escaped from jail in Oporto last month was arrested here early Wednesday, two days after he slipped into Spain from hiding in Portugal.
Allow me a postscript to "Casual Death Is the Way of Life for Haitians," (H. J. Maidenberg news dispatch of June 13).
Delays were heavy at some airports here yesterday as weekend and early summer travelers took to the skies.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 27 -- Like a schoolmaster reprimanding a pupil, Pancho Gonzales spanked Tom Edlefsen, 6-4, 6-3, 6-2, this afternoon as six Americans reached the round of 16 in the Wimbledon tennis championships.

A refusal on the part of Bobby Ussery to let his mount loaf completely in the stretch enabled the Locust Hill Farm's Promise to win the $57,600 Carter Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. Favored with the crowd of 22,391.
PRAGUE, June 27 -- Every Saturday afternoon, a crowd gathers on the sidewalk outside an office building on Stepanska Street for a 40-hour vigil preparatory to a trip to West Germany.
The stock of the Anaconda Company reached a low for the year yesterday following the announcement Thursday of an agreement to nationalize the company's two large copper mines in Chile.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 26 -- California, which runs neck and neck with New York as the nation's biggest borrower in the tax-exempt bond market, has not been able to sell bonds since April 28 because of high interest rates, and it may not be able to sell any for another year.
BOSTON, June 27 -- On Joe Fan Day at Suffolk Downs, Bill Veeck gave away a 3-year-old filly named Buck's Delight to a startled customer under whose chair the prize-winning certificate was hidden.

CHARLESTON, S. C., June 27 -- Settlement of the three-month-old strike at the Medical College of South Carolina Hospital was announced here today, but the Rev. Ralph David Abernathy refused to leave jail until agreement also is reached at the Charleston County Hospital.
EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., June 27 -- Senate investigators have been told that although this city participates in all the major food programs, its efforts to feed the needy are a "drop in the bucket."

RACINE, Wis., June 27 -- The voice of youth dissatisfied with the status quo in television was heard in all its vigor here today. It was one of the first times youth has received an open hearing at a meeting of broadcasters, and a thorough and drastic shake-up, making TV more responsive to society's needs, was the recurring theme.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The House Banking Committee approved legislation today that would permit one-bank holding companies to enter any business that the Federal Reserve Board ruled to be "functionally related" to banking.

JERUSALEM, June 27 -- Dick Scott, an American immigrant and leader of a private-enterprise settlement here who was arrested yesterday on an extradition request by the United States Government, asserted today that he had fled California because he was being threatened by criminals for helping Federal authorities.

SPOLETO, Italy, June 27 -- The Festival of Two Worlds opened its 12th season here tonight with the warmly applauded debut of the American Ballet Company, a troupe of 15 young dancers headed by Eliot Feld, which will return this year to take up permanent residence at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
" It's a variation on Commodore Vanderbilt -- 'The public be damned!' " said one irate Connecticut commuter yesterday.
Prices on the London stock market drifted lower again yesterday, chiefly on continued profit taking.

In a slow, dreary session when investors and stockbrokers alike turned their thoughts to weekend pleasantries, the stock market distinguished itself yesterday by edging the Dow-Jones industrial average to a new 1969 low.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 27 (UPI) -- Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker of the United States signed two economic agreements With the South Vietnamese Government today.

BOSTON, June 27 -- Dr. John H. Knowles said today he would like to see an investigation of the American Medical Political Action Committee to determine if it acted ethically in what he described as a long effort to block his nomination to the nation's top health post.

Former Supreme Court Justice Arthur J. Goldberg requested in a letter last week to Gov. Ronald Reagan of California that the death sentence of Sirhan Bishara Sirhan, convicted of killing Robert F. Kennedy, be commuted.

Four reputed Mafia leaders who refused to testify before a Queens County grand jury lost a long court battle today to avoid being prosecuted for contempt. The four, who were arrested with nine others Sept. 22, 1966, at a meeting at a Queens restaurant are Thomas Eboli and Dominick Alongi, both of New Jersey, and Michael Miranda and Anthony Carillo, both of Queens.
Chain stores and catalogue houses showed substantial gains in sales volume last month, according to a compilation of a selected list of companies in the field.

YONKERS, June 27 -- If ever a horse looked like a sure winner, Laverne Hanover was it, as he moved toward the finish line, three or four lengths ahead of the field in the $35,000 Meadow Skipper Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

Trans Caribbean Airways is considering either spinning off or selling its subsidiary Diversified Media, which publishes the Newspaper El Diario-La Prensa, O. Roy Chalk, chairman and president, told the annual meeting yesterday in New York.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The American Medical Association wields its influence in Government through an elaborate system of organizational and personal contacts that extend from state doctors' committees for political action through Congressional lobbyists to the White House itself.

THE Turbine Ship Hamburg docked at West Houston Street, but its aim was Seventh Avenue. The cargo on the maiden voyage of the German Atlantic Line's flagship included a fashion collection by Werner Machnik of West Berlin, representing Germany's bid for international fashion recognition.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Senator Hugh Scott of Pennsylvania, the Republican whip in the Senate, took issue today with President Nixon's opposition to an extension of the existing voting rights legislation.
BREWSTER VILLAGE, N.Y. -- Send 2 1/2-year-old tots away to summer camp? It sounds a mite unmotherly -- until you see how much they enjoy it.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird will seek changes in military law to make one month's unauthorized absence by a serviceman evidence of intention to desert.

LONGBINH, South Vietnam, June 20 -- A chartered Boeing 707, flight W2B3, rolled to a stop at the Bienhoa air terminal at 12:10 P.M. the other day, and 165 passengers, all in fatigues and none of them smiling, stepped into their year of war.

Tiny Tim came to the Wollman Rink in Central Park last night, blowing kisses, exuding beneficence ("Thank you! God bless you!"), grimacing at the glare of the spotlight, strumming his ukelele and trilling his way through a variety of ancient songs. He was preceded on the program, which was part of the Schaefer Music Festival, by Sweetwater, a West Coast rock group.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 27 -- The enemy continued today to shell the Special Forces camp at Benhet, the small patch of territory in the Central Highlands that has been the target of nearly two months of gradually increasing attacks.

OAKLAND, Calif., June 27 -A national conference of college administrators suggested today that huge regional ethnic studies centers be established for nonwhite students instead of small, limited units on every campus.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -The International Monetary Fund disclosed today the currency composition of Britain's drawing of $500-million under its recently-negotiated $1-billion standby credit.

If the famous players of the past, gathered for the OldTimers celebration tonight, or anyone else in a crowd of 42,276 at Shea Stadium last night expected to see what had made the New York Mets so devastating lately -- they didn't.

While legions of her fans maintained an ardent vigil in the hot and humid streets, colleagues of Judy Garland bade her farewell yesterday in a swift, simple service at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home.

Narcotics addicts should be denied bail on the same basis as mental incompetents when they are accused of crimes, Bronx District Attorney Burton B. Roberts told a State Senate committee hearing here yesterday.

VIENTIANE, Laos, June 27 (Reuters) -- North Vietnamese troops occupied five hills surrounding the strategic northern town of Muong Soui today, forcing Government battalions to pull back their headquarters to the outskirts of the town.

Irked at the discovery that American businessmen act like businessmen and are quick to snap up an obvious bargain, trans-Atlantic airlines have determined quietly to deprive them -- and tourists as well -- of a favorite money saver.

LONDON, June 27 (AP) -- Britain and St. Vincent signed an agreement today giving the Caribbean island associate statehood effective Oct. 27. The agreement was signed by Lord Shepherd, minister of state at the Foreign and Commonwealth Office, and Milton Cato, Chief Minister of St. Vincent.
Mayor Lindsay, in seeking support of liberal Democrats in the November election, has promised to serve a full second term if he wins re-election.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Two Central American neighbors -- Salvador and Honduras -- have broken relations in a dispute brought to a head by recent rivalry over soccer.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The House of Representatives, without the formality of a roll-call vote, approved today a joint resolution that would continue withholding taxes under the 10 per cent income tax surcharge through the end of July.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Senate Armed Services Committee, by a 10-to-7 vote, today approved the deployment of the Administration's Safeguard missile defense system.
CLEVELAND, June 27 -- There have been many good strikeout pitchers in baseball but none of them has done his specialty with the frequency of Sam McDowell.

PACIFIC PALISADES, CALIF. Short of living on an ice floe in the Arctic, there is no way to avoid the summer visitor. Residing in the heartland of hedonism, Southern California, you are precisely on course for the July drop-in.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Federal Reserve Board moved today to close a potential loophole in its regulations involving the "Federal funds" market.
ALAMO, Calif., June 27 -- Winnie Ruth Judd, the "Tiger Woman" of the nineteen-thirties, was arrested this afternoon in a home in this rural Oakland suburb, where she had been working as a maid.
The market for new stock issues was subdued this week following a poor reception for a record of 29 new issues the week before.

The pennant winners in the American League have been unable to repeat their successes in each of the last four seasons. So far this year, the Detroit Tigers seem to be following the pattern perfectly.
BOSTON, June 27 -- Bishop James K. Mathews of the United Methodist Church predicted today a "drastic realignment" of American Protestantism within the next 10 years.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., June 27 -- Conrad Jones of Darien, Conn., a member of the New York and Beverly Yacht Clubs, owns the Storm Trysail Club so far as this season's sailing competition is concerned. Today his 35-foot Hickley Pilot Class sloop Ergo became the principal winner of Storm Trysail's older event, the annual 200-mile race around Block Island that originates and finishes in Long Island Sound.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Robert H. Finch, the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, has abandoned his five-month effort to persuade President Nixon to appoint Dr. John H. Knowles to the Government's top health post despite opposition from conservative Congressional Republicans and the American Medical Association.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Efforts to force Congress to call a national convention to amend the Constitution were promoted in some parts of the country today and attacked in others.
Paul O'Dwyer's recent strictures to liberal Democrats, as reported in The Times, not to stampede to the banner of Mayor Lindsay, but to seek first certain key objectives, deserve elaboration.
WHITE PLAINS, June 27 -As summer comes to the lush rolling hills and crowded slums of Westchester County, many of its black and white leaders see the racial situation here as filled with contrasts.

The Atomic Energy Commission announced yesterday that it would hold a public hearing Aug. 19 to consider an application by Columbia University to operate a controversial 250-kilowatt research reactor in the basement of the Engineering Building on the North Campus.

ATLANTA, June 27 (AP) -- The West will send its powerful running attack against the East's burly defenders tomorrow night in the ninth annual Coaches All-America football game, and the contest could produce more heat strokes than touchdowns.
We are in urgent need of volunteers to record textbooks for blind students. Both readers and monitors with a college education or the equivalent are needed.
Frozen pork bellies attracted some active trading and prices rose a little, enlivening yesterday's session in the commodity futures market.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 27 -- Frank Chapot, United States Equestrian Team star, didn't win a thing at the opening session of the three-day Middlesex County Show today, but he had no complaints.

THE healing virtue of poetry has been acknowledged as far back as Aristotle. In his famous definition of tragedy, he listed as one of its effects the cleansing of the spirit through the elimination of Pity and fear and, by extension, of anxiety.

Thousands of city teachers voted yesterday on whether to ratify the new school contract as the current school year ended with little fanfare, considerable relief and mounting -- though guarded -- optimism for the future.

THE strange, forbidding, last years of Frederick Delius, the British-born composer, were the subject of a compelling biographical drama last night on National Educational Television's "N.E.T. Playhouse."

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The nation's export surplus declined sharply in May from the April level, but the trade accounts for the year to date continued to show a small plus balance, the Commerce Department reported today.

The Kroger Company, the nation's third largest grocery chain, realized an increase of 25 per cent in earnings in the 24 weeks ended June 14 on a sales gain of 10.9 per cent, both setting new records, according to the results issued yesterday from the company's Cincinnati headquarters.

MIAMI, June 27 -- Weather, world records and an attractive European tour are the major concern and incentives for more than 500 top athletes entered in the 81st annual Amateur Athletic Union national track and field championships tomorrow and Sunday.

The Great Western Financial Corporation, one of the nation's largest savings-and-loan holding companies, announced yesterday that it had reached preliminary agreement to acquire the Belmont Savings and Loan Association, Long Beach, Calif., in an exchange of stock worth more than $37-million.
ALBANY, June 27 (AP) -- The third and fourth muggings of the week near the State Capitol were reported today.

The 22d American Dance Festival at Connecticut College in New London will present world premieres by six choreographers this summer. Seven concerts for the price of four will be offered under a new subscription plan for those subscribing before July 19.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- With help from school-children, a New York woman artist and author has invented a playground toy that resembles a large gravy boat and is named Skipsy Doodle.

SEOUL, South Korea, June 27 -- About 1,000 university students staged violent street demonstrations here today opposing moves to amend the Constitution to allow President Chung Hee Park to run in 1971 for a third consecutive term.

BOSTON, June 27 (UPI) -- The dean of the Harvard Medical School accused the American Medical Association today of blocking the appointment of Dr. John N. Knowles to the Government's top health job in a "betrayal of the democratic process."
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Governor Winthrop Rockefeller of Arkansas implored President Nixon today not to "break faith with the black community" by slowing the pace of school desegregation.

PEKING, June 27 -- A campaign to provide a direct radio link between Peking and the rural areas, where perhaps 600 million of China's more than 700 million people live, underlines the complexities of governing this vast country.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Soviet Union is urging the United States to transfer the current bilateral talks here on the Middle East permanently to Moscow, the State Department said today.
For the police of the 14th Precinct, yesterday was moving day.
Gasoline truck drivers have called for a strike beginning Monday against four major gasoline companies, it was announced today by a spokesman for the Petroleum Trades Employes Union.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 (UPI) -- The Labor Department, citing a "deplorably low rate of employment among minority group members in the building trades, announced plans today to compel major Federal construction contractors to hire such workers on a formula system.
BELEM, Brazil, June 19 -"Ah, Belem has come a long way in six years," Pedro Alves Batista said. "We have industry now, you know, and a lot of capital has come in from the south."
FLAT-WOVEN oriental rugs are attracting collectors who are finding it difficult to locate choice early examples with the usual thick pile.
BOSTON, June 27 -- A few days ago, a service station operator hailed a doctor who was walking by on his way to the Massachusetts General Hospital, almost next door.
DETROIT, June 27 -- A Federal grand jury apparently plans to investigate the National Black Economic Conference and its demand for money from churches.

Something extra had to be added to the fourth annual United States Cup of Champions four-team international soccer tournament at Yankee Stadium last night before Inter Milan of Italy was able to claim victory.

LONDON, June 26 -- The exhibition scene here is particularly rich at the moment in shows devoted to significant figures in modern European art. While none of these shows is definitive in the historical sense, at least four of them -- the exhibitions of Matisse, Bonnard, Kirchner and Severini -- lend a certain perspective to well-documented careers.
Stocks moved irregularly yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and wobbled to a mixed close in light trading.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- Republican campaign officials predicted today that the party had a good chance to gain control of the Senate but little opportunity to take the House in next year's Congressional elections.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -The Federal Trade Commission suspended today the July 1 effective date for its labeling regulations under the Fair Pack-aging and Labeling Act.

BUENOS AIRES, June 27 (Reuters) -- A demonstrator was killed tonight and a policeman seriously wounded in clashes between the police and protesters who attempted to organize an anti-United States rally.
Jones Laughlin Industries, Inc., a subsidiary of Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., declared a five-for-two split yesterday.

LIMA, Peru, June 27 -- Peru's military government was moving quickly today to implement its new land reform measures, but key leaders said they had no intention of going as far as Cuba did in expropriating property.

SUBIC BAY, the Philippines, June 27 (UPI) -- After three weeks of testimony from 78 witnesses, a United States-Australian naval board of inquiry completed its hearings today into the collision of the destroyer Frank E. Evans and the Australian carrier Melbourne.

ALBANY, June 27 (AP) -- The state's top education officials gave support today to a proposal under which pupils attending parochial schools in New York would be able to take some courses in public schools.
JERUSALEM, June 27 -- Defense Minister Moshe Dayan indicated today that Israel planned to retain considerable territory on the west bank of the Jordan River that she seized in the 1967 war.
THE analysis of some bridge hands recalls the Chinese wooden dolls which when taken apart reveal an apparently never-ending series of smaller dolls.

NEWARK, June 27 (AP) -- The former Council President of Woodbridge Township, Robert E. Jacka, was fined $30,000 and sentenced to five years' probation "without supervision today for conspiracy in connection with a $110,000 payoff.

The agent who sold a candid account of Mrs. Jacqueline Bouvier Kennedy Onassis' White House years written by her personal secretary said yesterday that when the book is published "it will contain a great many passages of high praise for Mrs. Kennedy . . . some things good and kind."

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- The United States Military Court of Appeals directed today that Air Force Capt. Dale E. Noyd be allowed freedom pending disposition by military courts of his appeal from a court-martial resulting from his refusal to train Air Force pilots.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- A former chief counsel of the Navy told Congress today that "sloppy" procurement methods by the military departments were costing the public "hundreds of millions of dollars" each year in needless expense.

PITTSBURGH, June 27 -- A national assembly of human relations specialists, setting guidelines for Jewish community action on race relations and the urban crisis, today opposed "compensatory racial or ethnic quotas."

MOSCOW, June 27 (Reuters) -- Ilya Glazunov, the artist whose last exhibition here in 1964 was closed after officials described his paintings as "vulgar decadence," opened a one-man show here today.
About 250 police detectives converged on a City Council hearing yesterday to take a stand against "flopping."

LUXEMBOURG, June 27 -- The six nations of the European Common Market decided today to spend $900-million to aid the 18 African States, most of them former French colonies, associated with the Common Market.

PENSACOLA, Fla., June 27 (UPI) -- JoAnn Prentice scored a 71 and sank four birdie putts on the broiling Scenic Hills Course today to take the halfway lead in the 17th United States women's open championship with a two-under-par total of 144.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- Aviation Daily, a trade publication, said today that the Civil Aeronautics Board had recommended by a 4-to-1 vote that Continental Airlines be granted a route from the East Coast and the Middle West through Hawaii and the South Pacific to Australia.
PARIS, June 27 -- The Federal Reserve Board's proposed restraints on American bank dollar borrowing in Europe led to widespread declines in Eurodollar rates today.

GENEVA, June 27 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Union, the United States and 26 other nations agreed in principle today that international, rather than national, law should be used to determine liability for damage caused by spacecraft.
OMAHA, June 27 (AP) -Reinforced police units patrolled the Negro section again tonight after a third consecutive night of violence that required action by officers and firemen until daybreak.
ARGUS RESEARCH, one of the most prestigious institutional advisory services in Wall Street, has turned cautiously bullish on auto stocks.

The Administration's voting rights proposal unveiled by Attorney General Mitchell reminds us that laws, like men, can smile and smile and be a villain all the while. Genuinely good features can mask impossibly bad ones and extended debate can be a cover for evil intentions.

ATHENS, June 27 -- Greece's army-backed Government today ousted Michael Stasinopoulos from the presidency of the nation's highest administrative tribunal, the Council of State. The regime accused the 25-judge tribunal, which was set up 40 years ago to protect citizens from abritrary government action, of challenging its revolutionary authority.

MONTREAL, June 27 -- In a brief but not totally successful escape from the controversies of the capital, President Nixon flew here today to help commemorate the 10th anniversary of the opening of the St. Lawrence Seaway and to salute the bonds between Canada and the United States.
Bond prices retreated a bit yesterday following word late Thursday that the Federal Reserve is seeking to require banks to set aside reserves against their borrowings abroad.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Democratic National Committee intends to avoid involvement in the New York City mayoral election.
MASSENA, N.Y., June 27 -- Governor Rockefeller made a blooper today, but President Nixon came to the rescue.

The president of the Student Government Association of Long Island University said yesterday that he would ask the association to call for the resignation of Glenn W. Ferguson, who was named chancellor or the university on Thursday minutes before the appointment was challenged by a court order.
President Nixon flew here yesterday to go to the dentist and to have dinner with friends and advisors.
The New York and American Stock Exchanges announced yesterday that they would expand daily trading sessions by 30 minutes, starting July 7, a week from Monday.

TRENTON, June 27 -- The New Jersey Supreme Court today ordered trial judges to take over almost all pretrial examination of prospective jurors because it said lawyers had been seeking favorable rather than impartial juries.

The Jehovah's Witnesses, close to 100,000 of whom will converge on Yankee Stadium for their week-long convention beginning July 7, have a housing problem that would make even seasoned New York apartment hunters wince.

LAGOS, Nigeria, June 30 -- The Government announced today that it had relieved the International Committee of the Red Cross, a Swiss organization, of responsibility for coordinating relief efforts on both sides of the lines in the two-year civil war.

Mark Massey of Shreveport, La., seeded first, and Robert Odasz of Puerto Rico, seeded second, won first-round matches, in the Eastern junior and boys' championships at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday.

Appointment of Willis C. Armstrong as president of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce has been announced by the council's chairman, James A. Linen, who is president of Time Inc.

CAERNARVON, Wales, Tuesday, July 1 -- Two men died in an explosion in a Welsh town early today, and a bomb hoax stopped the royal train carrying Prince Charles only hours before his investiture as Prince of Wales.
SACO, Me., June 23 -- Within the shadows of the river cities of Saco and Biddeford, we took striped bass on both the rising and the falling tides from mid-morning to mid-afternoon.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -A study group on railroad safety said today that the Federal Government should be given broad new regulatory powers over the nation's railroads to halt a soaring increase in train accidents, particularly derailments.
CAIRO, June 30 -- An Egyptian Government spokesman denied today the report that Israeli commandos had damaged a powerline at Sohag on the Upper Nile.

BALTIMORE, June 30 (AP) -A federal warrant was issued today charging a 56-year-old unemployed automobile salesman with hijacking an Eastern Air Lines plane with 103 persons aboard to Cuba last Saturday.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- William McChesney Martin Jr., chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today he was confident that "we can stop inflation, and bring down interest rates, without establishing programs -- voluntary, semi-voluntary or mandatory--designed to control the allocation of credit among types of borrowers."

WIMBLEDON, England, June 30 (Reuters) -- Tricia Nixon watched the Wimbledon tennis matches today from Queen Elizabeth's seat--but without the 1920-style hat that is usually worn by women in the center-court royal enclave.

MONTREAL, June 30 (AP) -George Archer, the Masters golf champion, has been forced to withdraw from the Canadian open, July 24 through 27, because his wife had committed him to the American Classic at Akron, Ohio, long before he won the Masters and without his knowledge.
The stock market defied its usual blue Monday jinx yesterday to produce a technical rally at a time when Wall Street's mood appeared to range from skeptical to gloomy.

HONG KONG, June 30 (AP) -- The Vietcong warned today that they are holding Americans as prisoners of war and threatened "certain and inescapable revenge" for what they termed the murder of more than 100 Vietcong prisoners by American and South Vietnamese in three different incidents.

The Columbia Broadcasting System announced yesterday the three original plays that it will present next season on the new "C.B.S. Children's Hour" and at the same time disclosed that a number of well-known writers who had been approached for the series had declined for various reasons.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Traditionally, in any representative form of government, it is not easy to get things done. But some Americans--particularly black, poor and hungry ones--may be wondering if their own representative Government hasn't made it harder than necessary.

The Republican County Committee in Manhattan heard conflicting views last night from two of its district leaders over whether Mayor Lindsay or State Senator John J. Marchi should be supported in the campaign for Mayor.
PARIS, June 30 (Reuters) -President Pompidou will hold his first news conference July 10, his office announced today. It will be his first since taking office.
The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York appointed Msgr. Thomas A. Gartland yesterday to coordinate the financial affairs of its ailing school system.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Senate Agriculture Committee turned down today a proposal to provide free food stamps to the very poor.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The House of Representatives, by the narrow margin of 210 to 205, approved today the Administration's bill continuing the income tax surcharge, repealing the 7 per cent investment credit and reducing or eliminating Federal income taxes for some 13 million low-income families.

BOSTON, June 30 -- The Rev. Dr. Robert V. Moss Jr., 47-year-old head of Lancaster Theological Seminary in Lancaster, Pa., was elected president today of the two million-member United Church of Christ.

None of the Long Island Rail Road's 94 new, stainless steel, air-conditioned cars is "completely serviceable," State Senator Edward J. Speno, the chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Transportation, said yesterday.
DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., June 30 (UPI) -- The nation's top stock car drivers battle tomorrow for the pole position in the $88,830 Firecracker 400 on Friday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 30 -- Jordan called today for a condemnation of Israel's occupation of the Arab sector of Jerusalem and urged a cutoff of arms and military equipment for Israel.
BERLIN, June 30 -- A 27-year-old Croatian made his way into the Yugoslav military mission in West Berlin today and fired three shots at the head of the mission, Dr. Anton Kolendic.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- The Senate confirmed the nomination of Gen. Earle G. Wheeler today for a second one-year extension of his term as chairman of the Joints Chiefs of Staff.

A 50-year-old insurance salesman who allegedly killed one man and wounded two others after being harassed for a week by young hoodlums moved out of his Brooklyn home yesterday and was given police protection.

BUENOS AIRES, June 30 -- The Argentine Government declared a nationwide state of siege tonight in an effort to halt anti-Government terrorism and labor unrest that has grown still more intense with the arrival of Governor Rockefeller.

A doctor whose relationship with President Nixon stirred speculation last year about the President's emotional stability has written: "During the entire period that I treated Mr. Nixon, I detected no sign of mental illness in him."

The Security Council debate on Jerusalem unfortunately is not likely to throw much light on the Arab-Israeli situation, but it may do some good if it puts pressure on the Big Four to speed their desultory search for a new peace formula, paying particular attention to the status of the disputed holy city.
JERUSALEM, June 30 -- Premier Golda Meir warned Israel's Arab neighbors today that their violations of the cease-fire agreements were deliberately being repaid "sevenfold."

SANTA FE, N. M., June 30 (AP) -- The Most Rev. James P. Shannon, a Roman Catholic prelate who resigned as auxiliary bishop of the St. Paul-Minneapolis archdiocese in disagreement with Pope Paul VI's encyclical against contraception was appointed today as vice president of a small secular college here.
FREEHOLD N. J., June 30 (UPI) -- A judge in County Court heard testimony today in the case of a former Police Chief demoted to patrolman on charges that he had had an affair with a Councilman's wife.

Martha Larrimore has replaced Rosetta LeNoire in the role of Bloody Mary in the Guy Lombardo production of "South Pacific," the Richard Rodgers-Oscar Hammerstein 2d musical that is to open Saturday at the Jones Beach (L. I.) Theater.
Col. Frank Borman, who commanded the Apollo 8 flight around the moon, took off for Moscow last night for a nine-day visit -- the first visit to Russia by an American astronaut.

AMAGANSETT, L. I. -- The principal conversation in the fishing and food world in the Hamptons in recent days has not been the considerable run of striped bass and bluefish from local waters but the processing of fresh caviar from sturgeon caught by haul seiners in the bathing waters off Amagansett beach.
At about 1 A.M. yesterday, James Hampton became a crime statistic.

The Beatrice Foods Company, which derives some 58 per cent of its sales from nondairy lines as a result of acquisitions over the years, continued to report record results for the first fiscal quarter ended May 31.
Two New York City lawyers said here yesterday that they had almost completed arrangements for the release of Moise Tshombe before his death.

MOSCOW, June 30 (Reuters) -- An Italian concern, Sirce, today signed a contract with the Russian Republic for the design and partial equipping of 14 Western-style Supermarkets, including four in Moscow and three in Leningrad.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Those primitive people who build their villages on the slope of the volcano amuse us. How stupid, we say. The volcano erupts, buries them and their homes, and the survivors return and build again on the slope. Only morons, we say, are unable to learn from experience.

When he set up the committee to plan today's investiture of the Prince of Wales, the Duke of Norfolk warned against any "monkeying about in the name of modernization," and so it will be, with one dramatic exception: Half a billion people around the world are expected to watch on television this ancient ceremony in 700-year-old Caernarvon Castle.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The Transportation Department has ordered the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization to stop soliciting money from airlines for corporate memberships and advertising.

BOSTON, June 30 -- When the Rev. Dr. Robert Verelle Moss Jr. takes over as president of the United Church of Christ next October, he hopes to inaugurate "eucharistic fasting" in the denomination's 7,000 local churches. The 47-year-old theologian was elected president of the church today.
WASHINGTON June 30 (AP) -- President Nixon has named Lieut. Gen. Seth J. McKee to be commander in chief of the North American Air Defense and Continental Air Defense Commands effective Aug. 1.

BUFFALO, June 30 (UPI) -Mrs. Edward H. Butler, president of The Buffalo Evening News, has named Elwood M. Wardlow managing editor for administration and Murray B. Light managing editor for news. The appointments followed the death last week of Paul E. Neville.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Following is the text of President Nixon's letter today to Gerald R. Ford, House minority leader, on tax reforms and the surtax:

LEXINGTON, Ky., June 30 (AP) -- T. L. Plain, an assistant basketball coach at the University of Louisville for two assistant to Coach Adolph Rupp years, has been named as an at the University of Kentucky.
GOSHEN, N.Y., June 30--It has been said and reiterated that nothing ever changes here at the Cradle of the Trotter, as this rustic township, founded in 1714, is referred to by the local citizenry.

HENLEY, England, June 30 (AP) -- Harvard's lightweight crew, favorite for the Thames Challenge Cup for eights at the Royal Henley Regatta, was hit by a mysterious virus today, just two days before racing is scheduled to start.
MADRID, June 30 (Reuters) -- Spain will join France, Italy and Belgium in building a new short-haul passenger jet, to be named Mercure, official sources said tonight.

Construction costs are already so high in this city that unsubsidized apartments can be built only for the rich. The community must underwrite new housing for hundreds of thousands of New Yorkers through low-rent projects or tax subsidies to middle-income units. The high price of building is one reason why low-income families seeking admission to municipal housing would have to wait a full half-century under current construction schedules.
JERUSALEM, June 30 -- Mayor Teddy Kollek today welcomed the "Jerusalem Committee," an advisory body for the rehabilitation of the city.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -The Nixon Administration asked Congress today to authorize special surveys of the voting participation of various racial, ethnic and economic groups.
New York City's private schools will open in September with the largest enrollment and the steepest tuition increases in their history.

IT seems like only yesterday that baseball players were among the world's worst dressed men. Remember when they used to show up in public in baggy sport jackets worn over polo shirts? Their feet, of course, were the ubiquitous brown loafer, worn with white socks.
Smith, Barney Co., Inc., announced yesterday the appointment of seven men-ranging in age from 27 to 40-to its board of directors, ex panding the board's membership to 42.

Edward J. Ennis, general counsel of the American Civil Liberties Union since 1955, has been elected chairman of the organization, succeeding Ernest Angell, who retired after 19 years' service. Mr. Ennis, a 61-year-old lawyer here, served with the Department of Justice for 14 years.
SALT LAKE CITY, June 30 (AP) -- Gov. Calvin L. Rampton asked the Army today not to use Utah as a dumping ground for surplus and obsolete poisonous gas.

Lowell M. Birrell, convicted stock swindler, was indicted here yesterday by a Federal grand jury on conspiracy and fraud charges involving the unauthorized use of blank stock certificates to secure a $5,000 bank loan.
MIAMI, June 30 -- The jet age caught up with Eastern Airlines' last two Convair 440's today.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- As a result of a train derailment in Maryland last Saturday, Senator Charles McCMathias, Republican of Maryland, called for a thorough check of the Penn Central tracks on the East Coast.
MIAMI, June 30 -- Discouraged by his mental collapse in the one-mile run yesterday, Jim Ryun said today he would cancel a European trip and all further track and field competition for this year.

MANAUS, Brazil, June 24 -- The rains come gently now, sometimes twice each day, to this city in the middle of the Amazon world of trees and waters. But the repetitive rains have not washed away the recurring worry of a boom town already once gone bust.
CHARLESTON, S.C., June 30 -- A hospital workers' strike that is half-settled stretched into its 103d day as negotiations were stalemated tonight and the Rev. Ralph David Abernathy remained in jail.

The American Management Association has named Alexander B. Trowbridge, president, as chief executive officer of the management - education organization. Mr. Trowbridge, a former Secretary of Commerce, succeeds Lawrence A. Appley, who remains as chairman.

BOSTON, June 30 (UPI) -- Dr. John H. Knowles, rejected as the nation's top health officer, said tonight that if Dr. Roger O. Egeberg had been chosen first he "would have been knocked off by the same forces."

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- A Defense Department spokesman said that Secretary Melvin R. Laird "continues to be concerned" about American prisoners held by the enemy and hopes they will be treated according to the provisions of the Geneva Conventions on prisoners.

MOSCOW, June 30 -- A team of Soviet researchers, in a report published today, said most Russians now had a "fetish" for automobiles, refrigerators and other items that once were completely unavailable or considered wrong for Soviet citizens to desire.

An incendiary device went off in a Brooklyn Woolworth's store yesterday morning causing slight damage to rugs stacked on the floor. The police said it was thought to have been placed in the store at 408 Fulton Street sometime after closing Saturday evening and before it opened yesterday morning. There were no injuries in the incident, which is being investigated.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Mortgage interest yields rose above 8 per cent for the first time at this week's "auction" of the Federal National Mortgage Association, the association disclosed today.

The movement of the new winter wheat crop to market sent wheat prices down yesterday under active liquidation by all facets of the trade. All five wheat contracts closed at new lows for the season on the Chicago Board of Trade.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 30 -- Mrs. Billie Jean King was two points from defeat by Judy Tegart; Rosy Casals was a set and 5-3 down to Mrs. Lesley Bowrey; Julie Heldman was a set up with the great Mrs. Margaret Court on the rack and, Mrs. Ann Jones was slaughtering Nancy Richey 6-2 and 5-love and then lost five games in a row.
Until an elaborate and unusual communications network was hooked up late yesterday, live TV coverage here of today's investiture of Prince Charles in Wales was threatened.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., June 30 (AP) -- Smog has reached this desert resort that long has described itself as "a refuge from smog." A. J. HaagenSmith, chairman of the California Air Resources Board, said today that unseasonable weather conditions had pushed the smog about 110 miles from the Los Angeles basin.
PARIS, June 30 -- Major Western nations gave the United States a vote of confidence today in the fiscal and monetary measures now in force to battle inflation.

A hearing on an effort by students of Long Island University to restrain the trustees from appointing a chancellor until student representatives had been consulted was postponed yesterday until July 10. State Supreme Court Justice J. Bertram Wegman delayed the hearing at the request of Francis A. McGrath, attorney for the trustees.

OKAYAMA, Japan, June 30 (AP)--Hiroyui Ebihara of Japan, the World Boxing Association's flyweight champion, knocked out Jose Garcia Lopez of Mexico at 2:23 of the first round of a 10-round nontitle bout tonight. Ebihara weighed 114 1/2 and Lopez 115.
Dean Witter Co., Inc., announced yesterday that Lawrence B. Morris Jr. had been named senior vice president in charge of the national buying department.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 30 -- South Africa's controversial "BOSS" bill--the measure that gives the ultrasecret Bureau of State Security virtually unlimited power over the admission of evidence in court and over news of its activities --became law today.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- The Federal Reserve System's open market committee voted 10 to 2 last April to continue unchanged its policy of firm monetary restraint, committee minutes showed today.

JACKSON, Miss., June 30 -- The chairman of the N.A.A.C.P. board of director today assailed black militants, persons demanding cash reparations from white churches and the Nixon Administration as impediments to Negro progress.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -Attacks on the rising cost of the federal Medicaid program were opened today by both the Senate and the Department of Health, Education and Welfare.
BETWEEN LIFE AND DEATH. By Richard Hammer. 305 pages. Macmillan. $6.95.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- A new student antiwar campaign, led by veterans of the McCarthy for President drive and supported by campus editors and student-body presidents around the country, will try to shut down all normal university activities for a day on Oct. 15.
Dismissal proceedings have been ordered against Criminal Court Judge Edward J. Caiazzo, who jailed four Long Island Rail Road riders who had refused to produce their tickets.
IT'S common knowledge that this has not been a vintage year for the go-go mutual funds, and even their best friends are telling them so.

Major commercial banks in New York--faced with the prospect that substantial additional loan demand may move into the banks from the commercial paper market -- are considering a new system of "penalty" interest rates on loans.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Following is the vote by which the House passed today a bill continuing the 10 per cent income surtax:

MIDDLETOWN, CONN., June 30 -- Four persons were arrested tonight in connection with the breaking and entering of stores amid minor disorders during the first night of a curfew set up to end scattered racial violence.
EXCELSIOR SPRINGS, Mo. -- Played for real, war leads to bloodshed. Played as a game, it leads to conferences such as the eighth symposium of the National Gaming Council.
BUCHAREST, June 30 (UPI) -- Officially, the news that President Nixon plans to visit Rumania early in August was just a minor item. Unofficially, it was the talk of Bucharest and hit like a bomb.

The Union Carbide Corporation said yesterday that it would double its investment in a previously announced project at the petrochemicals complex at Penuelas, P. R. Plans call for the investment of $300million, with approximately $225-million by the end of 1971. The remaining $75-million would be spent by 1975. Original plans called for the expenditure of $150-million.
SAIGON, Tuesday, July 1 (Reuters) -- A young Vietnamese man poured gasoline over his body and set himself ablaze at the corner of two busy Saigon streets this morning, the police said.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30 (UPI) -- Frank Massino, head football coach at Archbishop Kennedy High School in Conshohocken, Pa., has been named an assistant coach at Temple University. He will serve as head freshman coach, succeeding Tom Urbanick who was promoted to the varsity.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 30 (UPI) -- Lew Alcindor, who led the University of California, Los Angeles, to three straight National Collegiate basketball titles, has been chosen outstanding athlete of the year for 1969 by the Sportsmen's Club.
Prices improved slightly yesterday in light trading on the American Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Government wound up its fiscal year tonight with the budget almost certainly in surplus for the first time in nine years.

KONTUM, South Vietnam, June 30 -- The South Vietnamese commander in the battle to relieve the besieged Special Forces camp at Benhet said today that he had used the mountainous outpost as "bait" to draw the enemy into a trap.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange moved ahead strongly yesterday registering some of the biggest gains since the start of a recovery trend last week.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Senator Edward M. Kennedy is planning to take a quiet look at Europe this summer, avoiding meetings with heads of state who might want to talk with a potential Presidential candidate.
KIRKSVILLE, Mo., June 30 (AP) -- High winds and a tornado struck Kirksville early today, destroying 17 mobile homes and injuring at least eight people.

Amid a considerable amount of talk on consumerism and Government controls and the ever-present panel discussions on important phases of the business, delegates at the 1969 convention of the American Advertising Federation heard of two new campaigns. There was also a luncheon invocation that drew applause.
The rousing sound of sea chanteys rang out yesterday on the docks of the South Street Seaport Museum.
The Clark Equipment Company announced yesterday it had acquired the Delfield Company, Detroit, and the Melrose Company, Gwinner, N. D., for about 550,000 shares of Clark common stock.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- The Washington Senators signed today 18-year-old Jeffrey Burroughs, a highly regarded heavy-hitting outfielder from Long Beach, Calif., and the No. 1 choice in the major league's June draft.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, June 30 (AP)--The 53-foot United States yawl Lisa Lee from Annapolis, Md., arrived today after dropping out of the transAtlantic race from Newport, R. I., to Cork, Ireland.
DEAL, N. J., June 30 (UPI) -An Asbury Park lawyer is threatening to sue this seaside resort on the ground that a free swim for town officials is unfair to those who must pay.

The Edison Electric Institute announced yesterday that W. Donham Crawford has been made vice president and managing director of the Institute. Edwin Vennard, who served in that capacity for 13 years, retired yesterday. Mr. Crawford, 46, had been administrative vice president of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., prior to joining the institute as vice president last April.
SUNNINGDALE, England, June 30 (UPI) -- Billy Casper, preparing for next week's British Open, had a 71 in the first round of the Bowmaker amateurprofessional tournament today.
CINCINNATI, June 30 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Bengals of the American Football League traded a fullback. Tom Smiley, to the Denver Broncos today for Eric Crabtree, a wide receiver.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., June 30 (AP) -- Charles E. Morgan Jr., the sailboat designer and builder, said today he would construct the America's Cup 12-Meter yacht Heritage at his St. Petersburg plant.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30 -- More than 30,000 people swarmed to Robin Hood Dell tonight to hear Van Cliburn play Rachmaninoff's Piano Concerto No. 2. After playing four encores, Mr. Cliburn was besieged on the stage by many of the younger members of the audience.
JOHN DE CONEY thinks hair is sexy. The 23-year-old Australian, whose own brown hair skims his shoulders, isn't talking about the nudist musical, but his own trade--barbering.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 30 (AP) -- Two United States military policemen were shot and killed late today after they had been called to investigate a disturbance in a restaurant-night club near downtown Saigon.
The help-wanted advertising index of the National Industrial Conference Board dropped sharply in May, the board reported yesterday.

VIENTIANE, Laos, June 30 -- The United States charge d'affaires here met today with his Russian counterpart, apparently to express American concern over the North Vietnam military success at Muong Soui, which United States Embassy spokesman today termed an escalation of the Laotian war.

David E. Walbert, 60-year-old chairman of the Midland-Ross Corporation, a diversified manufacturing concern, said yesterday he would retire today for reasons for health. H. J. Bolwell, president, said the post would not be filled.
The Orioles are flying in from Baltimore and Stan Bahnsen is driving up from Fort Dix. But Joe Pepitone might be home in New Jersey tonight when the Yankees and Orioles begin a two-day series.
PITTSBURGH, June 30 (UPI) -- Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn said today he was not stepping into the Richie Allen case because "that is the Philadelphia club's problem and will remain its problem."

ALBANY, June 30 -- Acting Gov. Malcolm Wilson today announced the recess reappointment of Dr. Robert D. Helsby of Latham as chairman of the State Public Employment Relations Board. He will receive $35,000 annually for the new term to expire May 31, 1975.

BUENOS AIRES, June 30 -- Augusto Vandor, a former protege of Juan D. Peron, the exiled former dictator, had come under increasing criticism recently from leftist labor leaders for his friendliness to the military government of President Ongania.

GLENEAGLES, Scotland, June 30 (AP) -- Curtis Person of Memphis, who has won every major senior title in the United States, took the lead today after the first round of the fourth international senior golf tournament at Gleneagles.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- The Senate approved today and sent to the White House legislation to repeal restrictions scheduled to take effect tomorrow on Federal aid to dependent children. Without the repeal, legislation passed in 1967 but postponed twice since then would have imposed limitations on the number of dependent children under 18 who, because of a parent's absence, may receive aid with Federal financial participation.

ST. LOUIS, June 30 -- The New York Mets closed out the best month in their history tonight when they pounced on the St. Louis Cardinals with six runs in the first inning and bulled their way to a 10-2 victory.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The Interior Department said today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had found no support for allegations of brutality against students at the Indian School at Chilocco, Okla.

CAERNARVON, Wales, June 30 -- His face and his profile are everywhere: on ashtrays and on coasters, on postage stamps and on platters, on coffee pots and on vases. He smiles from pictures in store windows. He looks somber in portraits in women's magazines.
A formal hearing was started yesterday to determine the cause of a Long Island Rail Road accident in Pennsylvania Station June 23 in which 160 passengers claimed injuries.

The return of thoroughbred racing to Aqueduct yesterday was greeted by a crowd of 29,671 horseplayers. Most of them were very happy to be back at the Big A, but there was not too much joy among the favorite players after the feature race, the $34,775 Tremont stakes, was over, for the standout choice finished last in a field of seven.
The 15-day strike by deck officers against American-flag East and Gulf Coast tankers was near settlement last night.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- The Justice Department filed four civil suits today alleging discrimination against Negroes by three restaurants and a motion picture theater in the South.

SETAUKET, L. I., June 30 (AP) -- The subconscious desire by parents to limit the size of their families causes vast numbers of infant deaths in Latin America, according to Dr. Benjamin Viel, professor of preventive medicine at the University of Chile.

The Diamond Shamrock Chemical Company, subsidiary of the Diamond Shamrock Corporation, said yesterday that it was increasing the price of its DDT insecticide 1 cent a pound, to 18 cents, in truckload lots, effective today.
Astrology, the computer and retailing are a new, seemingly impossible combinnation. Yet, it may be the newest and one of the most profitable developments on the retail scene in some time.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -Virginia will begin operation tomorrow of a Medicaid program providing medical assistance for the needy, it was announced today. Virginia will be the 40th state to operate a Medicaid program.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 30 (UPI)--The Illinois House of Representatives, in one of its last acts of the session, passed and sent to the Governor today a bill calling for the first income tax in the state's history. Gov. Richard B. Ogilvie was expected to sign the bill tomorrow. The bill passed by a 91-to-73 vote.
The corporate bond market, which last week was described as showing more poise and confidence than it had for many months, lost some of its newfound composure yesterday.

Transactions in a 500,000share initial public offering of Der Wienerschnitzel International, Inc., are to be canceled and the issue is to be postponed indefinitely pending a report of the hot-dog franchising concern's fourth-quarter results, it was announced yesterday.

HANKOE, Norway, June 30 (AP) -- Pam, the Australian yacht, won the third race today and joined Nemesis of the United States and Norway's Fram IV in the 5.5-Meter yachting finals for the Scandinavian Gold Cup.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Clarence E Larson, 59-year-old president of the Nuclear Division of the Union Carbide Corporation, was named today by President Nixon for a five-year term as a member of the Atomic Energy Commission.

GENEVA, June 30 -- Willy Spuhler, the Swiss Foreign Minister, said today that Switzerland intended to develop her relations with the United Nations while continuing to remain outside the world organization for the time being.

Fifteen dogwood trees, 11 London planes, a number of wild-cherry trees and other greenery have been mysteriously cut down in a Queens park that local residents said had become a rendezvous for homosexuals.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 30 (AP) -- James J. Reed, a soccer and wrestling coach at Princeton for 40 years, and Judson A. Timm, who was football backfield coach for 15 years, retired today from the university's Department of Athletics and Physical Education.

Nine university and college presidents urged yesterday that their colleagues across the country refuse to negotiate with student protesters under duress and reject requests for amnesty in civil and criminal cases.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Nixon Administration announced today the formation of a blue-ribbon panel to make a 12-month study of the Defense Department's management, research, procurement and decision-making machinery with a view to recommending reforms.

The Norfolk Western Railway announced yesterday the election of John S. Shannon as vice president-law, effective today. Mr. Shannon, who has been general counsel, succeeds Robert B. Claytor who, as senior vice president, will now devote all his time to the executive department.
Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co., a leading broker and investment banker, has announced its intention to enter the commercial paper market as a dealer.
GENEVA, June 30 -- Member nations of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade agreed today to postpone for three months the general assembly that they were to have held in November.
SEATTLE, June 30 (AP) -- One hundred thousand Shriners swelled Seattle's population by almost a sixth today for the public opening of the 95th Imperial Council session.
Who needs Richie Allen? And, as a matter of fact, who needs Johnny Callison, Deron Johnson, Chris Short or Don Money?

LOS ANGELES, June 30 (AP) -- Joe Mullaney, basketball coach at Providence College for 14 years, was named today the coach of the Los Angeles Lakers of the National Basketball Association. The appointment was announced by Jack Kent Cooke, the owner of the Lakers.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 30 -- While Bonny the space monkey was drifting and dreaming in orbit, the Apollo 11 astronauts rehearsed their own launching here today in a computerized spacecraft simulator.

The New York division of the Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association charged yesterday a conflict of interest and widespread abuses of power in the conduct of thoroughbred racing in New York.
A group of 400 dentists who serve a large part of the city's Medicaid roll announced yesterday that they would accept no new patients under the program because of a series of fee reductions.

GENEVA, June 30 -- Jacques Freymond, acting president of the International Committee of the Red Cross, said tonight that the agency could not accept being barred by Nigeria from assuming its traditional humanitarian role.

VIENNA, June 30 -- Wilhelm Backhaus, the 85-year-old pianist, was in serious condition today after having suffered a heart attack during a concert Saturday. Mr. Backhaus, a leading interpreter of Beethoven, was stricken while performing in a church in Ossiach, Carinthia.

PITTSBURGH, June 30 -- A national coordinating body of Jewish human relations groups today condemned Jewish extremist groups that threaten "violent and coercive tactics" in defense of "Jewish security and Jewish interests."

Choreographers, like the rest of mankind, are divided into the tough and the tenderminded. Last night at the Cubiculo Theater, 415 West 51st Street, the apportionment was evident right down the middle in a program of solo dances by Gertrude Talcott and Leslie Martin. Miss Talcott was the harder-eyed of the two, while Miss Martin retained a somewhat misty-eyed view of the individual and her place in the general scheme.

The Haas Community Funds has made a matching grant of $75,000 to the Theater of the Living Arts in Philadelphia. The money will enable the theater, which is the only resident professional company in Pennsylvania, to implement plans for the 1969-70 season.
MADRID, June 30 (AP) -After 493 years of off-and-on rule, Spain formally turned over her African enclave of Ifni to Morocco today.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., June 30 (UPI) -- Joe Louis, enjoying the dry desert climate today said too much activity and the humidity in New York were the causes for his collapse there last Thursday.
THE tragedy of Oedipus was passed along, unmitigatedly, to the Jan Hus Theater, where "The Glorious Ruler," a new play, opened last night.

PRAGUE, June 30 -- The Communist party officially voiced its concern today over "penetration and influence of anti-Communist ideology and propaganda," and announced a change in the direction of its staff college.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- The Post Office Department and Western Union have begun a six-month experiment to test the "mailgram," a service to provide overnight delivery of written messages. The mailgram is transmitted over Western Union lines, then written out at the Post Office in the town for which it is destined. It is then delivered in the regular mail.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (Reuters) -- The Agriculture Department said today that world production of raw sugar in 1968-69 set another record and was the largest ever produced. It estimated the crop at 75,734,000 short tons, 4 per cent more than the 1967-68 crop of 72,848,000 tons.
CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., June 30 (AP) -- Vicente Zarazua, a star of the Mexican Davis Cup tennis team, suffered multiple injuries today when his automobile and a dump truck collided here.

The Board of Elections today reported final tabulations of the citywide voting in the June 17 primary that showed that Mayor Lindsay lost the Republican nomination to State Senator John J. Marchi by 6,332 votes.

The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation announced yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering the public offering of 282,828 of its common shares by the Hillman Land Company. The steel corporation will receive none of the proceeds.
