Robert G. Lindsay, Richmond County Democratic leader, who had supported former Mayor. Robert F. Wagner's losing bid for the Democratic mayoral nomination, swung over yesterday to endorse the victor, Controller Mario A. Procaccino.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 30 -- King Hussein I of Jordan today carried out major military and government changes that indicate a tightening of internal security and firmer control over the country's 50,000-man army.
LONDON, June 30 -- A time bomb blasted a three-foot hole in the wall of a Cardiff post office early today. No one was hurt, but one postal worker had a narrow escape.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 30 (AP) -- A Government spokesman said today that Truong Dinh Dzu, the imprisoned politician, was being treated well and was undergoing care for a heart ailment.
Loans and credits totaling $103.5 - million to Pakistan, Venezuela, Argentina and Mauritania were announced yesterday by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
The parking problem for temporary art exhibits in congested New York is being tackled by the Museum of Contemporary Crafts and the New York State Council of the Arts.
City residents 65 years old up older will be allowed to ride at half-fare on subways and buses during some non-rush hours beginning at 10 A.M. today.

BONN, June 30 -- The Government of Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger voiced annoyance today over what it took to be a snub by President Nixon, forcing the West German leader to postpone his summer visit to Washington for the third time.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- President and Mrs. Nixon entertained the Apollo 10 astronauts tonight at an intimate black tie dinner at the White House that included music by Henry Mancini. One of his selections, predictably, was "Moon River."
SONS OF DARKNESS, SONS OF LIGHT. By John A. Williams. 279 pages Little, Brown. $5.95.
Stockholders of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company and the New Jersey Natural Gas Company approved at separate meetings yesterday morning the merger of the Jersey utility into Brooklyn Union.

Yesterday the Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act of 1965--for which the tobacco industry can take more "credit" than Congress--expired. This law required a weak admonition against smoking to be printed on cigarette packages but not in advertising, where a strong warning might really count. Furthermore, it tied the hands of the Federal regulatory agencies against any additional limitations on cigarettes for four years.

The appointment of Rabbi Mark N. Goldman as assistant rabbi of Congregation EmanuEl of the City of New York was announced yesterday by Alvin E. Coleman, president of the congregation, and the Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Perilman, its spiritual leader.
Bruce G. McCauley, 48 years old, was named yesterday as general manager of The Daily News.
About 200 black demonstrators occupied the site of the proposed state office building in Harlem last night. Construction on the building is scheduled to begin today.

Major mutual savings banks in New York City sustained a heavy outflow of deposits on Thursday and Friday of last week, the Savings Banks Association of New York State reported yesterday. For most banks, Thursday and Friday were the first two days of the "grace period," when deposits may be withdrawn without loss of accumulated earnings.

Corporate merger activity rose to a record level in the first half of 1969, according to a survey by W. T. Grimm Co., a Chicago management consultant firm that specializes in mergers and acquisitions.
ALGIERS, June 30 -- The Algerian Government today issued a statement on the death of former Premier Moise Tshombe of the Congo describing the cause of his death heart failure.
BOSTON, June 30 (AP)--The preseason football game between the Atlanta Falcons and Boston Patriots here has been changed from Aug. 16 to Aug. 17.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- Senator Herman Talmadge, Democrat of Georgia, said today that if Japan did not lower textile exports to the United States, welfare and uemployment checks might well be labeled "Made in Japan."

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- The Defense Department today listed 74 men as having been killed in Vietnam. They included Specialist 4 Robert J. Robinson of the Army, whose home is in New Brunswick, N. J.

THE top-ranked players are unanimous in believing that head - to - head team matches are the most exciting and testing form of bridge competition, with the luck element reduced to a minimum. Nevertheless, the opportunities for playing such matches are limited, and many top teams meet high-caliber opposition only twice a year in the national championships.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) The prices farmers received for their products increased by 3/4 of 1 per cent in the month ended June 15, the Agriculture Department reported today.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (Reuters) -- President Nixon's tour to Asia and Rumania and his plans for a California vacation appeared today to have caused new complications in scheduling the Washington visit of the Israeli Premier Mrs. Golda Meir.

MONTICELLO, N. Y., June 30 -- "Those Russians are handling my golf carts like cowboys," Steve Downey Jr., golf professional at Kutsher's Country Club complained today. "Looks like my whole fleet will be wiped out."

MASSENA, N. Y. (AP) -Trustees of the State Power Authority have awarded a $64.7million contract to build a pump generating plant in Schoharie County to a Framingham, Mass., combine. The Perine Corporation and Gordon H. Ball, Inc., were given the contract for plant to be constructed at the Blenheim-Gilboa Pumped Storage Paulen Project.

Potential repayments to consumers of tetracycline and other broad-spectrum antibiotic drugs for overcharges from 1954 through 1966 may go as high as $37-million across the country. This is a tentative allocation being discussed among the lawyers involved.
It was a strange pairing that made up the bill for the Schaefer Music Festival at the Wollman Rink in Central Park last night: Flip Wilson and the Modern Jazz Quartet.
VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass.--Move over, Lillian Hellman the playwright. Lilliam Hellman, the author of memoirs, is taking over the center of your stage.
Bruno Sammartino of Abruzzi, Italy, defeated George (The Animal) Steele of Detroit last night before a crowd of 5,527 in the professional wrestling feature at Madison Square Garden.

AUBURN, Ala., June 30 -Auburn University has been awarded a $52,000 grant from the National Science Foundation to study the male reproductive organ, but the university's news officer said that the prejudice of male editors was keeping the project from getting much attention.

Having contributed his name and his efforts to an agency that has become one of the best known in the world over the last 20 years, Ned Doyle, approaching 67 years of age, has announced his plans to retire.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -The Senate passed and sent to the House today a bill to rename the GGlen Canyon Dam on the Colorado River after President Dwight D. Eisenhower.

SPOLETO, Italy, June 30 -- Never trust a gala! As might easily have been expected, Eliot Feld's newly formed American Ballet Company was markedly more successful on its second program given at the Teatro Nuovo here yesterday afternoon than at its grand gala opening two days previously.
The city's Social Services Commissioner charged yesterday that "capricious" state economizing threatened to eliminate a 22-month-old work-incentive program for welfare recipients.

WHEN you step out of the elevator onto the third floor of the Whitney Museum, where the Thomas Cole exhibition opens to the public today, you are faced with what may look to you like a tremendously enlarged old-fashioned color postcard (11 feet long) of Mount Aetna with the Roman ruins of Taormina in the foreground, or like a romantic masterpiece, depending on how you choose to respond to it.

Ingmar Bergman, Sweden's premier moviemaker, plans to write and direct a film version of Henrik Ibsen's "Peer Gynt." The movie, Mr. Bergman's second English-langauge project, is scheduled to be made next year, largely on location in the Norwegian mountains.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -Treasury bill rates moved in opposite directions at today's auction, the Government reported late this afternoon.
Production of steel by the nation's mills fell 2 per cent last week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 30 -- The announcement by Premier Jacques Chaban - Delmas of France last Saturday that his Government might reconsider the embargo on arms deliveries to Israel has evoked Arab concern.

MONTREAL, June 30 -- Col. Hubert Julian, known as the Black Eagle of Harlem, reported today that a $10-million ransom deal for the release of Moise Tshombe was all arranged at the time of the ex-Congolese leader's death.
CHICAGO, June 30 (UPI) -Chicago saluted two of the Apollo 10 astronauts today and was told that Americans were "going on to explore the universe."

Leonard R. Hutchinson has been appointed to the newly created post of vice president for finance of the American Stock Exchange, it was announced yesterday. Mr. Hutchinson, 48 years old, who joins the exchange today, has been financial vice president for the National Screw and Manufacturing Company.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- The newest, most sophisticated communications satellite has broken down, but service across the Atlantic Ocean is being restored by using the reactivated four-year-old Early Bird satellite.

GREENWICH, Conn., June 30 -- Lisa Orr, No. 1-ranked player in the 16-year-old-and-under category, won two matches today and advanced to the their round of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association championships at the Fairview Country Club. The remainder of the rated field played only one match.
" Whores, Wars Tin Pan Alley," the Kurt Weill revue co-starring Martha Schlamme and Alvin Epstein, will move to the Sheridan Square Playhouse, 99 Seventh Avenue, from the Bitter End on Thursday.

A 60-year-old registered male nurse, Frank L. Dulaney, of 5 West 63d Street, pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal Court to failing to file income tax returns for three years, when his income ranged from $22,000 to $31,000 a year. Mr. Dulaney, a nurse for 33 years, was indicted Jan. 16 by a Federal grand jury on five counts involving the years 1962 through 1966.

HOUSTON, June 30 -- The Southern director of the American Civil Liberties Union said in a brief filed in Federal Court here this weekend that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had "deliberately doctored" a summary of a monitored conversation between the late Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Cassius Clay, the former heavyweight boxing champion.
At least two groups of construction workers--steamfitters and sheet metal workers--were scheduled to stay away from their jobs today after rejecting contract offers.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- World trade declined seasonally in the first quarter of this year, but it still was almost 10 per cent above the corresponding 1968 period, the International Monetary Fund reported today.

On June 13 the Safeguard System Command at Huntsville, Ala., awarded a research and development (R D) contract for $28,224 to the Stanford Research Institute. On June 19 there were eight contract awards, as follows (all R D):
CENTRAL ISLIP, L. I., July 1 -- Three inmates, including a convicted murderer, escaped early today from the Central Islip State Hospital, but by evening two were back in custody.
Lowering himself over the side of a building, a Brooklyn fireman yesterday rescued a bricklayer who was dangling by one foot upside down seven stories above the ground.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- A proposed new policy statement on the controversial school desegregation guidelines -- this one containing no provision for giving Southern districts more time to comply with the law -- has gone to the White House, informed sources said today.
The Spence School, a private school for girls, announced yesterday the appointment of its first male head, Dr. Dustin Hull Heuston.

ROME, July 1 (AP) -- Premier Mariano Rumor and other Italian leaders warned feuding political factions today that the seven-month-old coalition Government was on the verge of collapse, and "chaos" was the only alternative to agreement.

The Lukens Steel Company, the first of the steel industry to issue half-year results, reported yesterday net earnings of $4,113,000, or $1.46 a share, for the 24 weeks ended June 14. This is 30 per cent more than the $3,158,000, or $1.10 a share, earned in the corresponding period last year. Sales, however, dipped 2 per cent to $67,075,000, from $68,471,000.

The heir apparent to the presidency of the nation's largest bank said yesterday that the economy appeared to be "topping out" and that he would be opposed to another increase in the prime lending rate of the banks, which is now at a record 8 1/2 per cent.
DALLAS, July 1 -- A Federal court held invalid today a commonly used method of reducing needy children's welfare payments to a level far below published state standards of need.
JERUSALEM, July 1 -- Israel's national police headquarters was moved today from Tel Aviv to East Jerusalem, the former Jordanian part of the city.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The Government moved today to settle a civil antitrust suit that accused the Bemis Company, Inc., of conspiring to bar competitors from marketing mesh-covered vegetable bags.

WATERBURY, Conn. July 1 -- Mayor George P. Harlamon today ordered and then canceled a citywide curfew that he had called for in an effort to control the unrest in the city's black community for the last three nights.
An elaborate scheme to enable a multimillionaire financier to take control of a $50-million conglomerate in 1965 resulted yesterday in the indictment of the financier and 10 others.

PARIS, July 1 -- The tide of motor traffic is washing away another stretch of ground long dedicated to the Parisian art of flanerie, which consists of strolling and watching strollers from cafe terraces.

Robert Odasz of Puerto Rico, seeded second in the junior division, won three matches yesterday to gain the semi-finals of the Eastern junior and boys' tennis championships at the West Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, Queens.
The London stock market exended the previous day's rally yesterday.

Sections of the city-owned Welfare Island were rented last week for a private party for writers, actors, models and their friends, but city officials said yesterday that the island was no longer for rent.

Under dusty heaps of rubble and in the dilapidated frames of sagging Brooklyn factory buildings and houses, volunteer archeologists are digging up clues to the existence of a long forgotten early 19th century colony of Negro free men in Bedford-Stuyvesant.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 1 -- With political storm signals flying, California sailed into a new fiscal year today without a budget.
HARRISON, N. Y., July 1 -- Tournament golf is entering a new era of multi-stars, according to Jack Nicklaus. "You won't find one or two dominating the game as in the past," he said today.

EVERYONE laughs, everyone pokes fun and no one approves. That's what they say. But somehow it keeps getting bigger and more widespread, and soon we may all smother in an avalanche of designer signatures and initials.
All but half a dozen of the 75 clerks and mailmen at the Kingsbridge Post Office in the Bronx called in sick yesterday in what postal authorities called an "illegal work stoppage."
Special "saturation" teams of city inspectors found no neighborhood pattern of consumer fraud in three months of investigations around the city, according to a report made public yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 1 -- Federal District Judge Richard B. Austin ordered the Chicago Housing Authority today to integrate public housing projects by scattering many of them in white neighborhoods and assigning a large proportion of Negroes to them.

Gifts of $1.25-million each by John D. Rockefeller 3d and Lawrence A. Wien yesterday enabled the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts to successfully end its 13-year campaign for capital funds of $184-million.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- A feud between two organizations representing the nation's air traffic controllers surfaced today over the "sick-out" that crippled much of the country's air transportation system June 19.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- American officials said today that enemy rockets had caused the casualties among enemy prisoners held in South Vietnam that brought Vietcong hints of reprisals against allied prisoners.

No matter what their failings have been in their first season, the Montreal Expos have not lacked the beau geste. They continued to respect history yesterday, trouncing the Chicago Cubs, 11-4, on Dominion Day, a national holiday marking the 102d anniversary of Canada's confederation.
Volume expanded somewhat and prices moved up again yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

PARIS -- It may surprise some American liberals who see President Nixon as typifying conservative political strains to know that he is highly regarded in such leftist lands as Indonesia and Rumania which he will now visit. This reputation was acquired by Nixon as an individual before he became President.
The New York State Health Planning Commission has approved the city's application for a $1.9-million Federal grant to organize the first comprehensive health planning agency here.

TRENTON, July 1 -- The State Legislature will return for a special session tomorrow, and Gov. Richard J. Hughes says it should stay until August, if necessary, to complete business dealing with urban aid and crime control.
Stock prices pushed ahead yesterday for the second successive session as oils, computers and nonferrous metals paced the advance.
LONDON, July 1 Reuters) -- England and the West Indies drew the second cricket test at Lord's today, after a thrilling final hour's play.
DETROIT, July 1 -- Automobile sales may be running near record levels, but production is trailing last year, and the industry profits are tied directly to output.
GENEVA, July 1 -- The new president of the International Committee of the Red Cross is known for his English sense of humor, Italian charm and a capacity for hard work that is 100 per cent Swiss.
Penn Central's explanation of its proposed new rate schedule announced on June 27 for New Haven line commuters, focused only on the proposed cut in monthly rates.
CLEVELAND, July 1 (UPI) -The Cleveland Browns' running back, Ernie Green, who underwent knee surgery earlier this year, retired today as an active player.
BUENOS AIRES, July 1 -- A nominal state of siege was in effect in Argentina today after the assassination of a leading labor organizer, but Buenos Aires and other major cities appeared calm.
The USM Corporation announced yesterday that it had acquired a majority stock interest in Ira Systems, Inc., a Waltham, Mass., computer equipment manufacturer.

IF the precise details have lost some of their sharpness over the years, the general idea remains crystal clear. It's the memory of an ancient vaudeville skit. One partner commits some petty offense that would have resulted in a $2 fine. But when the case is magnified to virtually death-chair proportions, the whimpering victim still keeps moaning, "Pay the $2, my boy."

SUBIC BAY, The Philippines, July 1 (UPI) -- The stars and Stripes came down today aboard the broken hull of the destroyer Frank E. Evans, marking the formal end of the ship's 24 years of service in the United States Navy.

"HURR-EE, hurr-ee, hurr- ee," cried the circus barker in the black top hat. And they did. Hundreds of children, little and big, swarming along a path in Central Park yesterday morning toward the mall where they were going to see the first performance of the summer season by the Robert F. Kennedy Theatre for Children.
BONN, July 1 -- The German Federal Republic's third President, Dr. Gustav Heinemann, took office today with an impassioned vow to "serve peace."

The Federal truth-in-lending law went into effect across the nation yesterday, and a consumer group here promptly filed a suit charging that a Harlem merchant had failed to tell a customer the annual interest rate on a purchase.
LONDON, July 1 -- An English intellectual, watching the Caernarvon spectacular on television today, remarked with a self-deprecating smile:
The interim Board of Education will begin discussing today the matter of selecting a chancellor for the city school system.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 1 -- The Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission has been bitten by a "safety bug" and will start a "Get Behind Your Seat Belt" campaign Thursday, when Fourth of July weekend motorists crowd the roads.

Just how much fun a ball game can be when batters send the ball flying to all corners of a spacious park was amply demonstrated for a crowd of 16,668 at Yankee Stadium last night when the New York Yankees beat the Baltimore Orioles 10-9.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Following are excerpts from the texts of statements on the Administration's voting rights bill made today by Attorney General John N. Mitchell and Representative William M. McCullough, Republican of Ohio, at a hearing of a House Judiciary subcommittee:
AT this point, one might expect reflective, soft-spoken Arnold Bernhard to be resting in a remote village or otherwise unavailable to reporters.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The National Transportation Saftey Board found today that the probable cause of the sinking of the freighter Panoceanic Faith on Oct. 9, 1967, was the master's failure to make prompt repairs when it was observed that the tarpaulins covering the forward hold were loose.

A group of prominent citizens interested in nuclear arms control has proposed that President Nixon initiate negotiations at the Geneva disarmament conference to extend the present partial ban on nuclear tests to include large underground explosions.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 1 -- The top delegates of the Big Four powers recessed their Middle East peace talks here today, leaving the next round of consultations to be undertaken by the United States and the Soviet Union.
PARIS, July 1 -- American officials told an international monetary gathering today to expect no sharp reduction in American interest rates this year.

GOSHEN, N. Y., July 1 -- Stanley Dancer, the squire of New Egypt, N. J., who could do little right yesterday (and was booed for it) did just about everything right today (and was cheered for it) as the 132d harness racing meeting at Historic Track completed its second of five matinees.

EXTRACTING the maximum penalty from a declarer who is clearly going down several tricks may be of great importance in a duplicate game. A common situation arises when a nonvulnerable player ventures a save against a game bid by a vulnerable opponent.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- A major Government-sponsored program to develop new birth control measures was announced today.

The first thing the Rumanians did after hearing that President Nixon had accepted an invitation to visit Bucharest was to tell the Soviet Government, and the second thing they did was to publish in their official press a long article on Rumanian-Soviet friendship.
DES MOINES, Iowa, July 1 (UPI) -- A law to redistrict the Iowa Legislature went into effect today and was immediately challenged in court by the state Democratic party.

GENEVA, July 1 -- Marcel A. Naville, new president of the International Committee of the Red Cross, denounced the Nigerian Government today for having relieved the organi zation of its Nigerian duties "in the same way that a faithless servant is shown the door."

BOSTON, July 1 -- The biennial General Synod of the United Church of Christ agreed tonight to fund its newly created Commission for Racial Justice with a minimum guarantee of $500,000 in 1970 and $600,000 in 1971.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Nixon Administration's five-day-old voting rights proposal ran into such uniform and intense opposition on Capitol Hill today that it was regarded as all but dead.
BETHANY, Conn., July 1 -- The police said today that they were investigating the possibility that the slaying of two young girls were connected.
CAERNARVON, Wales, July 1 -- For Maj. Francis Jones, the investiture of Prince Charles today at Caernarvon Castle was the climax of six years of work and a lifetime of personal interest.
The Human Resources Administrator, Mitchell I. Ginsberg, announced yesterday that his agency would dissolve its Office of Education Affairs, headed by Henry Saltzman.
Two young men were arrested in South Brooklyn early yesterday morning in an alleged attack when a tall, seemingly drunken woman pulled a gun and identified himself as a policeman.

LOS ANGELES, July 1 (UPI) -- Bob Seagren and John Pennel, the world record-holder, will get another chance to top 18 feet in the pole vault at the United States-British Commonwealth-Soviet Union track and field meet here July 18 and 19.
CAERNARVON, Wales, July 1 (AP) -- After Prince Charles was installed as Prince of Wales today, he entertained some young friends at dinner aboard the royal yacht Britannia.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- A Senate committee looking into the soaring costs of Government medical care programs heard charges today of widespread abuses, including fraudulent billings by doctors and administrative laxity.

ALBANY, July 1 -- The State Court of Appeals ruled today that New York City could not collect property taxes on Argentine consular property even though such property was not tax exempt under any treaty between the United States and Argentina.

MIDLAND PARK, N. J., July 1 (UPI) -- The Mayor of this mile-square Bergen County borough appealed to President Nixon yesterday to do something to spare it further Vietnam losses, contending that Midland Park had done its part.
LENINGRAD, July 1 -- Ambassador Jacob D. Beam today inaugurated a United States educational exhibition that will tour six Soviet cities over the next year.

HONG KONG, July 1 -- Peking, on the 48th anniversary of the founding of the Chinese Communist party, called today for the rebuilding of the party structure, which was shattered during the turmoil of the Cultural Revolution.
A midtown bookstore failed in Federal Court yesterday to curtail arrests and seizures of alleged pornographic material offered for commercial sale.

RICHMOND, July 1 -- A three-judge annexation court today added, pending possible appeals, about 44,000 people and 23 square miles to Richmond, Virginia's capital. The expansion would dilute an ever-growing Negro voting power in the onetime capital of the Confederacy.
Two of the nation's most profitable railroads reported yesterday slight gains in earnings for the quarter ended June 30.
An appeals court yesterday upset a lower court decision that had given Jackie Gleason, the comedian, the right to seek a divorce from his estranged wife, Genevieve.
JERUSALEM, Wednesday, July 2 -- Israeli commandos continued to carry the war to the enemy last night, attacking three Egyptian army posts on the Red Sea coast.

JACKSON, Miss., July 1 -- The N.A.A.C.P. has received a $173,760 contract from the Department of Housing and Urban Development to provide the agency with a survey and analysis of minority group building contractors across the nation.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., July 1 -- Mutually antagonistic bands of militant Negro and white youths continued to keep this picturesque city of 35,000 people uneasy and racially polarized today as Mayor Kenneth J. Dooley ordered a 9 P.M. curfew for the second night in a row.

Your June 20 editorial "Chaos at the Airports" merits close attention and analysis by your readers and all of us who fly. We are told that the disruption and confusion resulted because the tower operators were following strictly the rules of air safety.
Soybean futures dominated the news in the commodities futures markets yesterday.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 1 (AP) -- A crack East German crew, containing five Olympic finalists, arrived today and had a workout on the Thames in practice for the Royal Henley regatta. The four-day event gets under way tomorrow.

REMARKABLY detailed color pictures of the pageantry and family drama of the investiture of Prince Charles as Prince of Wales successfully circled the globe, yesterday morning as communications satellites over the Indian and Pacific Oceans were substituted for the disabled satellite over the Atlantic.
The need for new approaches to the use of television is urgent.

WICHITA, Kan., July 1 -- Vice President Agnew told the Governors of 10 Middle Western states tonight that they could not expect any increases in Federal aid while the Vietnam war continued. He put the blame on the critics of President Nixon's war policies for prolonging the conflict.
A Forest Hills man said yesterday that he saw trees in a neighborhood park -- which residents have charged was a haven for homosexuals -- being cut down deliberately one night about two weeks ago.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 1 -- Officials here were ordered today to speed up preparation to orbit this month a new communications satellite to replace the one over the Atlantic Ocean that failed last week.
Menley James Laboratories will be looking for a new agency for Contac, the country's top-selling cold product. The billings are about $10-million.
Pedestrians, briefly carefree with the sun on their backs instead of the looming shadows of automobiles, love carless Nassau Street in lower Manhattan these days.

Bronx Borough President Herman Badillo, who said after his defeat last month in the Democratic primary that he would not run for Mayor, is now "seriously contemplating" making the race on an independent line, sources close to Mr. Badillo said yesterday.
DAYTON, Ohio, July 1 (UPI) -- Nine champions are back to defend their titles in the women's Amateur Athletic Union track and field meet starting here tomorrow.

PARIS, July 1 -- Among the French painters of the 19th century who were responsible for the innovations of impressionism, none was temperamentally less suited for the role of an avant-garde rebel than Edgar Degas.

JACKSON, Wyo., July 1 -- Warren E. Burger, in his first official appearance since becoming Chief Justice of the United States, said today that he would take the lead in reforming the administration of justice in the country.

The United States Steel Corporation lost yesterday a major portion of its suit to recover $27-million in income taxes paid in 1950. The action is believed to be the largest civil tax case ever brought in the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, July 1 -- A study group of the National Education Association recommended today that the Federal Government pay at least one-third of the cost of public schooling in major cities to help meet "an unparalleled emergency."

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- With the favorable House vote yesterday on the extension of the tax surcharge, the Nixon Administration passed the first test of its ability to work with a House of Representatives that is controlled by the Democrats.
ST LOUIS, July 1 -- The St. Louis Cardinals stopped collapsing long enough tonight to sweep a double-header from the New York Mets in the grand manner.
There seemed to be some confusion earlier this week when William McChesney Martin Jr., chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, testified before the House Banking Committee.

The Big A of college basketball will make his New York professional debut on Saturday night, Oct. 4, when Lew Alcindor comes to town with his Milwaukee Bucks teammates to face the Knickerbockers in a pre-season exhibition game at the Garden.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- After more than a half century of assigning serial numbers, the United States Army today began using Social Security account numbers for its men.
Johnny Carson, the host of the "Tonight" show, has signed a long-term contract with the National Broadcasting Company that reportedly will bring him a big boost in salary.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, July 1 -- Governor Rockefeller tonight encountered the largest and most enthusiastic reception since he and a group of experts embarked upon a "listen-and-learn" tour of Latin America two months ago.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Representative Emanuel Celler, the dean of the House and one of its rare classicists, defended today his reputation for literary quotation.

Richmond Borough President Robert P. Connor presented City Clerk Herman Katz yesterday with more than 30,000 signatures calling for a referendum that would give the five borough presidents more autonomy.

CAERNARVON, Wales, July 1 [AP] -- Following is the text of a speech by Prince Charles today after his investiture as Prince of Wales. The speech, during the course of which the Prince replied to the "loyal address" by Sir Ben Bowen Thomas, president of the University College of Wales, was delivered partly in Welsh.
"The students," Plato said, "are filled with lawlessness."
CAERNARVON, Wales, July 1 -- Charles Philip Arthur George was invested today as Prince of Wales and Earl of Chester by his mother, Queen Elizabeth II, in a ceremony rich in tradition and pageantry.

Mainly because of confusion, great numbers of New York City voters stood in long lines at the polling places and then found that their votes did not count in the recent primary election, Maurice J. O'Rourke, a member of the Board of Elections, said yesterday.

Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson said yesterday that he would campaign for State Senator John J. Marchi, the Republican candidate for Mayor, and all other Republican candidates in the state who asked his help.
Private druggists who had been refusing to fill Medicaid prescriptions because of fee reductions ended their action yesterday, after eight days of protest.
STUTTGART, West Germany, July 1 -- The Stuttgart Ballet returned home today in triumph.

Nigeria's hardliners have won an important political debate in Lagos and the immediate result is likely to be the deaths of hundreds of thousands of innocents, mostly children, in the blockaded Biafran enclave. Mass starvation is a certainty if the relief airlifts, mounted by the International Committee of the Red Cross and Joint Church Aid, remain in suspension.
LOS ANGELES, July 1 -- A Federal plan to lay down a vast blanket of a highly toxic pesticide in Texas is arousing protests from conservationists across the nation.
Prominent members of the Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association accused their own group of "cannibalism" yesterday in its latest dispute with the New York Racing Association.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- Congress can do nothing about high interest rates except fight inflation generally William McChesney Martin Jr., chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told the House Banking Committee today. Mr. Martin emphatically rejected suggestions for a Government-imposed interest ceiling.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 1 -- A convoy of South Vietnamese armored personnel carriers rumbled into the Benhet outpost late today over a road from Dakto that had been closed by North Vietnamese troops for a week, military spokesmen reported here.

Student leaders at Long Island University agreed yesterday to drop their court suit to restrain the trustees from appointing a new chancellor in return for a promise of consultation on future appointments of officers.

James Earle Jones, star of "The Great White Hope," yesterday received 90 per cent of the votes cast in the new Drama Desk Awards for the top performances of the 1968-69 New York season. Earlier he won a Tony for the role.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Federal Trade Commission moved ahead today toward promulgation of a regulation to require a health warning in all cigarette advertising but disavowed any intention of thwarting the will of Congress.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 1 (AP) -- Stocky Cale Yarborough blazed to a world closed-course record of 190.706 miles an hour today to win the pole position for the Firecracker 400 stock-car race on Firday.
LONDON, July 1 -- The pageantry in Wales today provided little distraction for the House of Commons, where it was parliamentary business as usual.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Senate Agriculture Committee voted a broadened food stamp plan today, but backed away from giving the Department of Agriculture clear-cut authority to require local areas to participate in food programs for the poor.
Time Inc., the world's biggest magazine publishing empire, has begun a reorganization that it hopes will restore Life as the "hot book" for advertisers.

FOR reasons I can't quite place, I have begun to mistrust ever so slightly novels with omniscient narrators, because they implicitly demand that I simply take their word for what happened. I like to think that this feeling does not reflect a loss of imagination or a breakdown of my faith in the novel.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Three scientists contended today that the Soviet Union could easily overwhelm the Administration's proposed Safeguard missile defense system by adding fewer than 50 missiles to its attacking force.
At long last the state's 137,000 civil service workers are getting a chance to express their own views on the unions that they want to represent them in collective bargaining.

SWEDESBORO, N. J., July 1 -- After apprehensively studying the experiences of nearby Wildwood, N. J., distant Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Zap, N. D., under onslaughts of teen-age and college-age groups at play, the borough council of this quiet, South Jersey community has decided, among other things, to ban kissing in public and improper attire.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The "leading indicators" of spending on national defense appear to have shown their first significant downturn since the start of the war in Vietnam.

Like Joan Towe (letter June 13), many enrolled voters were disenfranchised in the recent primary elections because they moved within the city and did not know they were eligible for a transfer of enrollment.

TEL AVIV, July 1 -- A Tel Aviv judge today gave police officials until Thursday to show why Dick Scott, the American leader of an immigrant settlement group, should not be released on bail. The United States wants Mr. Scott extradited.

The $2.33-billion Massachusetts Investors Trust and the $1.21-billion Massachusetts Investors Growth Stock Fund, Inc., plan to form an external investment advisory concern to manage the two giant mutual funds, it was disclosed yesterday.

WIMBLEDON, July 1 -- Arthur Ashe has reached the semi-finals at Wimbledon and Clark Graebner three times had match point to make it, only to drop a heartbreaker over five sets to second-seeded Tony Roch as rain dribbled down.

DOVER DOWNS, the $8.5-million horse-and-motor park in the capital of Delaware, will open its auto-racing facility on Sunday. The occasion will be the Mason-Dixon 300 for late-model stock cars, sanctioned by the National Association for Stock Car Auto Racing.

The lucky prospector who struck it rich is a dramatic figure in the legend of nineteenth-century America. From Sutter's Mill to the Comstock Lode to the Klondike, miners in search of a personal bonanza were the archetypes of a people who saw nothing wrong in plundering a continent for private gain.
MINEOLA, L. I., July 1 -- Nassau County plans to test a program of guaranteeing jobs to poor persons, possibly by putting them on the county payroll, in an effort to reduce the welfare rolls.

CHARLESTON, S. C., July 1 (UPI) -- Negro workers began returning to their jobs at the State Medical College Hospital today after settlement of a 14-week strike, but many of the County Hospital workers who had walked out in sympathy found themselves without a job.
Agreement on terms to end the 16-day-old strike of deck officers against the operators of 65 American-flag tankers was reached last night.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- A bill seeking to quell campus disorders was shelved today by the House Education and Labor Committee after weeks of bitter discord.

The credit markets, squeezed by new Federal Reserve moves to restrict bank lending and by heavy withdrawals by savers for reinvestment directly in fixed-income securities, continued to deteriorate yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Julie Nixon Eisenhower led 25 surprised tourists around the upper floors of the White House today to show them her father's hideaway study, a secret staircase she used to escape from a party and other intimate corners of the mansion.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Federal Trade Commission's authority to promulgate a regulation requiring health warning in all cigarette advertising was challenged today by the tobacco industry.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 2 -- The resignation of the Most Rev. James P. Shannon as Auxiliary Bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of St. Paul-Minneapolis was never sent to the Vatican for final approval, according to the Most Rev. Leo Byrne, Coadjutor Archbishop of the archdiocese.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- The Small Business Administration has guaranteed a $135,000 bank loan to Lou Brock, the high-salaried baseball star, under its program for disadvantaged businessmen.
George B. Munroe, 47 years old, was elected yesterday as president and chief executive officer of the Phelps Dodge Corporation, the second largest producer of copper in the United States.
ROCHESTER, July 2 (AP) -- Gene Scott, the 30-year-old New Yorker, was seeded No. 1 today for the United States amateur tennis championship starting Saturday at the Tennis Club of Rochester.

SPOLETO, Italy, July 1 -- At a time when New Yorkers are increasingly caught up in the issue of law and order, the artistic license and friendly chaos of the Festival of Two Worlds here come as a pleasant restorative.

The 52 Federal judges in New York, Connecticut and Vermont have called on the United States Judicial Conference to postpone its directive restricting outside activities of Federal judges and requiring annual financial reports from them.

BOSTON, July 2 -- The Rev. Dr. Robert V. Moss Jr., new president of the United Church of Christ, pledged his denomination today to "pursue relentlessly and with singleness of purpose absolute equality for the black man and his right to determine his own destiny."

Noticeably absent in most discussions about nuclear deterrents is the massive destructive capabilities of a minimal retaliatory strike. Too often the military insists that the threat of total destruction is necessary to deter an attack. On the contrary, however, the destruction of only a few key cities would suffice.

CHICAGO, July 2 (AP) -- The president of the American Medical Association said today that "in a true sense" the group never opposed the nomination of Dr. John H. Knowles to an important Federal health post.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that President Nixon would discuss increased trade, among other things, with Rumanian leaders when he visits Bucharest early in August.

ROME, July 2 -- The number of Roman Catholic priests asking and receiving dispensation from their vows of celibacy in 1968 in order to marry was more than 10 times that in 1963, according to a secret Vatican report disclosed today by the Turin newspaper La Stampa.
Three detectives raided a Third Avenue apartment yesterday, arrested four persons and confiscated pistol, narcotics, two detective badges and master keys for major hotels in the city.

MOSCOW, July 2 -- Soviet officials have told Western diplomats that President Nixon's visit to Rumania offers no obstacles to arms control talks or to the general improvement of Soviet-United States relations.
Seventy-two letter carriers and clerks of the Kingsbridge post office branch in the Bronx were suspended yesterday following their failure to report for work Tuesday because of "illness."
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Air Force directed its bases today to withhold the use of a highly toxic pesticide.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The White House was reported today to be reconciled to the likelihood that its voting rights proposals would receive secondary consideration, at best, in Congress.
LONDON, July 2 (AP) -- Labor trouble in Britain's big ports spread to London's Tilbury dock today, trapping nine ships and their cargoes and preventing 11 more from docking and unloading.

The accident involving two Long Island Rail Road trains in Pennsylvania Station on June 23 was caused "by a failure of one or more railroad employes to adhere to prescribed operating rules," according to a joint statement issued yesterday by the Long Island Rail Road and the Penn Central Company.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) -- The Government took the first step today toward requiring "air bags" in 1971 model cars, buses and trucks as a safety device to back up the seat belts that most American motorists do not use.
SACREMENTO, Calif., July 2 -- Democrats in the California Assembly refused again today to approve a 1969-70 state budget after nearly reaching agreement with the Republican Governor, Ronald Reagan.

A FESTIVAL gala is shaking the floor at the St. Marks Playhouse, where the Negro Ensemble Company last night opened "Man Better Man," a musical that shelves for the moment the brow-furrowing issues of the day.

W. T. Piper Jr., chairman and president of the Piper Aircraft Corporation, said yesterday that the company and certain stockholders had filed a suit seeking to remove two officers of Chris-Craft Industries, Inc., from the Piper board of directors.
NEWARK, July 2 -- The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra and Local 16 of the American Federation of Musicians have resolved the dispute that has kept the ensemble inactive since the end of last February.

STOCKHOLM, July 2 (UPI) -- Jurgen May of West Germany outsprinted Ron Clarke of Australia, the world record-holder, in the stretch and captured the 5,000-meter run in 13 minutes 33 seconds, the fastest time in the world this year, at a track meet today.
GENEVA, July 2 -- The presentation by Britain of a plan for outlawing germ warfare will be one of the highlights of the session of the Geneva Disarmament Conference that starts tomorrow.

ST. LOUIS, July 2 -- The New York Mets almost made another contribution to the revival of the St. Louis Cardinals tonight when they blew a four-run lead in the eighth inning. But they somehow survived all kinds of adventures after that until they coaxed two runs home in the 14th to score a 6-4 victory.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., July 2 -- Marvin D. Cristenfeld was elected tonight to succeed John F. English as chairman of the Nassau County Democratic party.

BUENOS AIRES, July 2 (Reuters) -- More than 200,000 metal workers went on strike here today to mark the funeral of Augusto Vandor, a moderate labor union leader who was gunned down in his office by two assassins Monday.
While some parents may not realize it, putting teen-agers to work in the summer can be a financial blessing in more ways than one -- especially with regard to income taxes.

For the second time within 24 hours, the team with the best percentage in baseball was beaten yesterday -- and by the Yankees. This unusual night-into-day combination happened to the Baltimore Orioles, this time by a 3-2 score.
Vandalism is against the law, no matter what the reason. It is a disgrace that the Police Department will ignore destruction to a Queens park, done to weed out homosexuals.
The state's new Medicaid economy rule requiring people with low incomes to pay 20 per cent of their medical bills was kept from going into effect yesterday by a Federal court order here.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Interior Department officials and spokesmen for the American Public Health Association gathered today on a pier overlooking the Potomac River and cited the river that flows by the nation's capital as "Exhibit A" in the country's water pollution problem.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Discussing the celebration of the Declaration of Independence in Philadelphia in 1776, Charles Biddle, vice president of Pennsylvania, who was there, said: "There were few respectable persons present."

MINNEAPOLIS, July 2 -- "The Past Rediscovered: French Painting 1800 to 1900," which is the title of an exhibition opening to the public tomorrow at the Minneapolis Institute of Arts, reads like a paradox.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (AP) -- A complex system to keep track of gasoline and oil sent to United States forces in Vietnam broke down in 1967, says a private report by Pentagon auditors, leaving the Air Force unable to account for $21-million in those products.

A group headed by Dr. Arthur S. Flemming, president of the National Council of Churches, urged President Nixon last night to take "new initiatives to end, and not simply de-Americanize," the war in Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- A presentation depicting scenes from the life of Frederick Douglass, the 19th-century American Negro leader, is being staged at the Smithsonian Museum of History and Technology.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Criticism of the Administration's Vietnam policy welled up again in the Senate today as Senator George McGovern, one of the most outspoken doves, urged that the United States withdraw all its forces from South Vietnam within the next 12 months.
GOSHEN, N. Y., July 2 -- Enshrinement in harness racing's Hall of Fame, an honor that few have achieved during their lifetime, was realized today by four prominent figures in the sulky sport.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 2 -- Secretary General Thant called on all governments today to agree to halt development and stockpiling of chemical and biological agents for warfare "and achieve their effective elimination from the arsenal of weapons."
Prices moved ahead in moderate trading yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
BUCHAREST, July 2 -- Advance parties from the White House are expected to arrive here within the next few days to work out the arrangements for President Nixon's visit to Rumania Aug. 2 and 3.
The American Advertising Federation wound up its annual convention here yesterday with a minor violation of the principle of truth in advertising.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Internal Revenue Service said today that it would make a special audit of the income tax returns of an estimated total of 10,000 doctors who had each received more than $25,000 a year in Medicare and Medicaid payments from the Government.

HENLEY, England, July 2 (Reuters) -- An Olympic finalist, Werner Zwimpfer of Switzerland, overtook Jim Dietz of the New York Athletic Club today in the first round of the Diamond Sculls of the Henley Royal Regatta.

The general public and responsible physicians throughout the nation have followed carefully the incredible five - month struggle between Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare Finch and the American Medical Association over the appointment of Dr. John H. Knowles to the vital post of Assistant Secretary for Health and Scientific Affairs.
The Treasury announced yesterday that it planned to sell $3.5-billion of tax anticipation bills next week -- the Government's first financing to raise cash in the new fiscal year that began Tuesday.
WICHITA, Kan., July 2 -- The Governors of 10 Middle Western states said today that they were encouraged by President Ntxon's apparent commitment to some form of sharing Federal taxes with them.
DETROIT, July 2 -- New car sales in the final third of June topped their levels of last year and pushed the June sales rate to a record, the four major car manufacturers reported today.

CAIRO, July 2 -- The United Arab Republic's chief spokesman, Dr. Mohammed H. el-Zayyat, today scorned Israeli commando attacks along the Suez Canal as futile. He said they only strengthened Egyptian psychological preparations for the "battle of liberation."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., July 2 -- Following is the text of the conclusion of a United Nations report on chemical and bacteriological weapons and their effects, made public today:

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 2 (Reuters) -- Ninety-two Deputies of the South Vietnamese House of Representatives sent a letter to President Nguyen Van Thieu today asking him to change his Cabinet and dismiss Premier Tran Van Huong.

Tucked away in a corner of Kennedy International Airport is a passenger terminal that is never seen by most of the 20 million people who pass through the airport every year. Judging from the reaction of those who have seen it, the others aren't missing much.

The commercial paper market, which has been attracting attention in Congress as a possible route to escape the pressure of tight money, soared to a new high during May, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- John S. Foster Jr., Director of Defense Research and Engineering, told Congress today that only 4 per cent of the 5,000 research and development contracts with universities involved secret work.

This letter comes to you in the interests of journalistic responsibility, and in protest against its serious violation on the part of a generally respected newspaper. I refer to the story by John Leo in your June 11 edition, headed "Negroes Elected President of Three Classes at Andover," and I'd like to set the record straight.
BENHET, South Vietnam, July 2 -- The defenders of Benhet crawled out of their holes today and began to rebuild their battered but still standing fortress.
U. S. Plywood-Champion Papers, Inc., announced yesterday it had received a $600-million contract for the sale of Alaskan pulp and lumber to a Japanese company.
OAKLAND, July 2 (UPI) -- The wife of Eldridge Cleaver, the black militant, has joined him in Havana, the Black Panther party said today.

TRENTON, July 2 (AP) -- A $1-million damage suit was filed today against the commanding general of Fort Dix and state and local police officials for alleged "harassment" of employes and patrons of a coffeehouse in Wrightstown, near the military base.
Cocoa futures prices rose in fairly active trading yesterday, closing at 25 to 51 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) higher on the sale of 1,625 contracts.
DUBLIN, July 2 -- John Lynch was re-elected Prime Minister and named a new Government tonight that included a Protestant as his deputy.
For more than four centuries the crowned heads of Europe and their kin have been plagued by a hereditary disorder known as porphyria, according to a study by two British physicians.
Acting at the request of the city, and because of "community concern,' Governor Rockefeller yesterday indefinitely postponed the construction of a $28-miilion state office building in Harlem.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Representative L. Mendel Rivers, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said today that he intended to hold hearings on reform of the draft law "as soon as committee business permits."
In what the police said might be an underworld attempt to move into the frozen custard business, Mr. Frostee garages in Brooklyn and the Bronx were robbed early yesterday.
Trading at the New York Stock Exchange will take on a new look next Monday when the exchange opens a new trading room that incorporates a variety of technological advances.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 2 -- Until recently Po Yang was one of Taiwan's most popular novelists and an editor of a major Taipei newspaper. Today he is in prison, awaiting sentence for allegedly having been a Communist agent in 1949.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers reported today that enemy combat activity and infiltration in South Vietnam had recently decreased. He said if these conditions persist, the pace of American troop withdrawals could be affected.
A meeting of the Bronx County Republican Committee broke up in fist-fighting and general tumult last night as opponents and supporters of Mayor Lindsay traded punches and overturned furniture.

W. R. Grace Co., a diversified chemical and shipping concern, reached an agreement in principle yesterday with the Marlene Industries Corporation under which Grace would acquire the business of Marlene.
The police confirmed yesterday that a patrol car did go to a park in Forest Hills, Queens, on the night that a grove of trees was reported to have been mysteriously cut down there.

MIDLAND PARK, N.J., July 2 -- "This is going to be a rough funeral," said Richard Crak, a local undertaker. "Every one of this kind of funeral we've had has been larger and larger. This time we'll just throw open the doors."
Prices on the London Stock Exchange eased at the close yesterday following a firm opening.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Nixon Administration is reported to be preparing for a brief round of Middle East talks with the Soviet Union in Moscow in response to a Soviet proposal.
PARIS, July 2 -- A worldwide effort to create a general history of Africa, using vast sources of new evidence now coming to light has been approved by specialists from 21 countries meeting here.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- High-ranking officials indicated today that the United States might be willing to seek an international agreement limiting arms shipments into Nigeria and Biafra.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, July 3 -- Hanoi radio said today North Vietnam would release three American prisoners of war, apparently pilots, an would permit others to receive mail on the Fourth of July.

The introduction of a provision in our draft laws to recognize selective conscientious objection is a praiseworthy suggestion of your editorial "The Selective Conscience" (June 23). As Americans we must ask ourselves whether we can allow citizens who disagree with a particular war to live freely and constructively in our society.

ALBANY, July 2 -- The Appellate Division today overruled an order by former State Education Commissioner James E. Allen Jr. and held that the Mount Vernon school district did not have to reassign pupils to overcome racial imbalance.

Prime Minister Ian Smith can now proceed at will to proclaim Rhodesia a republic and to clamp racial apartheid on a helpless African majority that outnumbers the whites, 21 to 1. It is as necessary to concede that nothing can arrest these deplorable developments at present as it is to point up their probable long-run consequences.

The American Jewish Committee has withdrawn from the Interreligious Foundation for Community Organization, a coalition that has been seeking funds for a group that is demanding "reparations" for in justices to black Americans.
PRINCETON, N. J., July 2 -- Most Americans -- 51 per cent -- oppose extension of the 10 per cent tax surcharge, according to a recently completed Gallup survey.
The nation's three leading merchandising chains -- Sears, Roebuck Co., the J. C. Penney Company and Montgomery Ward -- reported yesterday the highest sales in their histories for June.

Five graduate students from a field of 37 entries were named winners of the second annual Sam S. Shubert Foundation playwriting contest, it was announced yesterday by Lawrence Shubert Lawrence, board chairman of the foundation.

JACKSON, Miss., July 2 -- A Negro professor from Harvard University criticized some advocates of black studies programs today as "dilettantes jumping on the bandwagon and acting out all the trappings of something new and exciting."
CAERNAVRON, Wales, July 2 (AP) -- Cheering yachtsmen and spectators ashore greeted Prince Charles today at the vacation resort of Llandudno as he began a four-day tour of his restive principality.

Capturing the imagination of just about everyone except fans in Oakland, Reggie Jackson last night continued to rocket toward baseball's most glamorous record with three home runs as the A's whipped the Seattle Pilots, 5-0.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Eight Congressmen's families ended today a week of meals on a welfare budget.
The price of lead is being increased, for the fifth time this year.

C. V. Whitney's The Archer won the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday in a tight finish in which three fillies were closely grouped at the wire. A Pleasant Sort of the Hobeau Farm was the runner-up, a neck back of the winner and the same margin ahead of Isidor Bieber's Parida.

PITTSBURGH, July 2 (AP) -- Leonard (Red) Kelly, who coached the Los Angeles Kings into the National Hockey League playoffs twice was appointed head coach of the Pittsburgh Penguins today. The Penguins an N.H.L. team for only two seasons, are the only club that has not made the playoffs.

A pharmacist awaiting retrial in Manhattan on a five-year-old allegation that he administered drugs to three women and sexually molested them was held in $20,000 bail yesterday on an almost identical charge.

The General Tire and Rubber Company had disappointing results in the three and six months ended May 31, reflecting the poor showing of Aerojet-General and Frontier Airlines, the report disclosed yesterday.

Despite current rumblings, neither Herman Badillo nor anyone else to the left of center in New York City politics is likely to put himself forward as an independent candidate for Mayor. There is simply too much to lose and too little to gain for those toying with the idea of an independent alternative to the party nominees, Democrat Mario Procaccino, Republican - Conservative John Marchi and Liberal John Lindsay.
LONDON, July 2 -- Britain announced today she had repaid debts of $56.6-million in June and had increased her gold and foreign-exchange reserves by $28.8-million during the month.
Stock prices continued to move ahead yesterday for the third straight session -- a record string of advances the market had not compiled since early May.
For a music hater, the best advice this summer in the city is: keep your windows closed.

Antiwar demonstrators got into the offices of 13 local draft boards on the ninth floor of 321 West 44th Street Tuesday night or early yesterday morning and vandalized files covering 200,000 draft-age Manhattan men.

Now that the city has scraped its way out from under another placard infested political campaign, City Councilman Joseph Modugno has introduced a measure that promises some protection from the next one. He would hold individual candidates financially responsible for removing their own posters and stickers from city property.
WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The United States Forest Service, a mining company and a band of conservationists are tangled in a new controversy over mining in national forests and wilderness areas.

A sweep of the first four places in the saber, individual, and an expected victory in the saber team event has put the New York Athletic Club in a commanding lead for the Martini Rossi Trophy that goes to the team champion in the national championships of the Amateur Fencers League, which have reached the halfway mark at Los Angeles.

OTTAWA, July 2 -- The Government conceded officially today that it lacked the power to block the proposed acquisition of the Royal Securities Corporation, Ltd., a Canadian underwriting and brokerage house, by Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner and Smith, Inc., the biggest brokerage concern in the United States.
Representative William F. Ryan announced yesterday that he was "seriously considering" an independent Democratic race for Mayor.
WHEN I.B.M. delivered its long-awaited announcement on pricing last week, Wall Street reacted positively although nothing startling appeared in the new schedule.

Huntington Hartford promised yesterday that Show will show again. He has entered into an agreement with two men formerly of The Hollywood Reporter and they expect to have Show on the newsstands by January.

LOOK at the Baltimore Orioles, running away from the rest of the American League. And look at the St. Louis Cardinals, floundering under .500 with the season half over. Then look back and appreciate how remarkable the New York Yankees used to be.

THE dog days -- the hot, sultry ones of the summer -- officially start today and will last until Aug. 11. For the scientific-minded, this is the time of the heliacal rising of Sirius, the dog star, the brightest in the constellation Canis Major.
Early one morning this week, 1,550 youngsters began to line up at the Grand Central and Port Authority terminals.

IT WAS less a love affair than a doomed flirtation. The Marxists and the existentialists went hand-in-hand to every postwar Popular Front in France. But between fronts there were spats about purges, slave labor camps, personality cults, Hungary. And the principals (and principles) were philosophically incompatible: on one side, crude materialists convinced of historical inevitability; on the other, Pascalian drunks who kept trying to carry on a dialogue with the nonexistence of God.
Jerry Lee Lewis, an early rock star turned country-music artist, gave a concert in Central Park last night as part of the 1969 Schaefer Music Festival.

THIRTY-SIX miniature furniture designs that look like Rube Goldberg contraptions go on view today at the showroom of U. S. Plywood-Champion Papers Inc., 777 Third Avenue (at 49th Street). The show will probably make desginers of multifunction furniture green with envy. For the 19th-century Lilliputian creations exploit almost every camouflage device and mechanical innovation known to furniture manufacturers today.

Charging that the $6.9-billion budget submitted by Governor Rockefeller at the last legislative session was a "sham" and unconstitutional, three New York City Assemblymen have asked the state courts to stop any further expenditures under its provisions.

An alleged "soldier" in the family of Carlo Gambino, the reputed Mafia chieftain, and three other men were arrested early yesterday on charges of conspiring to sell, transport and conceal $25-million worth of heroin, Federal agents reported.

MOSCOW, July 2 -- Col. Frank Borman, the first American astronaut to visit the Soviet Union, was greeted amicably by three Soviet astronauts today but without the traditional bear-hugging and cheek-kissing.
WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) Senator John Sparkman, Democrat of Alabama, today said he was considering legislation to regulate interest rates charged by banks.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- The Justice Department said today that it had opened a preliminary investigation into charges by the insurgent candidate for the presidency of the United Mine Workers, that he had been beaten over the weekend by union officials supporting the re-election of W. A. (Tony) Boyle, president of the union.

The city has begun a major revision of the emergency ambulance service by opening outposts to provide a faster response, by starting a central control system with 24-hour supervision and by shifting vehicles from the quieter midnight tour.

WASHINGTON, July 2 (UPI) -- Ralph Nader, the consumer advocate, said today that new studies in the fish processing industry had turned up evidence of salmonella, the food-poisoning organism, "almost everywhere -- in shrimp processing plants, fish meal plants and crab plants."

Senator John J. Marchi criticized Mayor Lindsay yesterday for attacking the Nixon Administration's defense expenditures on the ground that Mr. Lindsay did not have sufficient knowledge to make a sound judgment.
SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, July 2 -- Governor Rockefeller's Presidential study mission swept into the Dominican Republic this evening after a 40-minute flight from neighboring Haiti.

HENLEY, England, July 2 (AP) -- Three girls in their early twenties, each escorted by a group of men, collided with a stone wall of tradition when they arrived to watch the Royal Henley Regatta today.

Ted Van Dyk, a lean, drawling Westerner who for the last six months has been the voice of the Columbia University administration, will resign as vice president for public affairs at the end of the month.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 2 -- War action in South Vietnam in the last 24 hours was at the lowest level since June 4. The lull then was followed by a large upsurge in fighting, however, and intelligence sources have predicted another upswing in the next few days.

PHILADELPHIA, July 2 -- The head of a National Education Association committee reported today that, after five years of work, "all but the last" step had been taken to integrate racially every N.E.A. state affiliate.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- President Nixon has once again denied Continental Airlines a coveted new air route to Australia and New Zealand, extending the politically charged trans-Pacific route controversy that he inherited from President Johnson last January.
PORTLAND, Me., July 2 -- The Atlantic Richfield Company announced here today that it had taken an option on 3,500 acres of land in Machiasport as a possible site for a refinery.

Johnny Carson, host of television's "Tonight" show, assailed The New York Times last night for what he said was "a gross and ludicrous" exaggeration of the financial terms of his new contract with the National Broadcasting Company.

Charles Chaplin, who celebrated his 80th birthday on April 16 and who has not been involved with movies since he wrote and directed the 1967 film "A Countess From Hong Kong," will return to moviemaking this month in London.

NEWARK, July 2 (AP) -- LeRoi Jones, the Negro poet-playwright, and two co-defendants were acquitted today in their retrial on charges of illegally possessing weapons during the 1967 Newark riot in which 28 persons died.
JERUSALEM, July 2 -- Israeli pilots downed four Egyptian MIG-21's today in a 20-minute dogfight over Egyptian territory west of the Suez Canal, defense officials reported.

Arthur Miller, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright, has rejected an invitation to have his play "The Price" and other recent works by him published in Greece in protest against the "repressive" policies of that country's military regime.
YONKERS, July 2 -- Another late-closing series, this one restricted to 4-year-old pacers which did not earn $75,000 in 1968, will get under way tomorrow night at Yonkers Raceway.
PHILADELPHIA, Miss. -- After 139 years of submission to the state laws of Mississippi, the Choctaws have established their own law and order.

Assemblyman Samuel D. Wright resigned yesterday from the governing board of the Ocean Hill-Brownsville demonstration district, charging that an "atmosphere of fear" made it "impossible for any teacher to teach" in the district.

The Nixon Administration has been talking vaguely about its intent to create imaginative new education programs in the future. Imagination is essential to the improvement of American education; but imagination without money will not go very far, and the money is needed -- not in the future but now.

THE veteran grandmaster Count Alberic O'Kelly de Galway, chess champion of Belgium, was the chief referee during the recent championship match in Moscow between the Soviet stars Tigran Petrosian and Boris Spassky.
AMAGANSETT, L. I. -- "What," someone asked, "would happen if everyone came and brought potato salad?"

DUBLIN, July 2 -- In 1966 John Mary Lynch -- Jack Lynch to the Irishmen who remember the athletic feats of his younger days -- reluctantly acceded to the needs of the governing Fianna Fail party and became caretaker Prime Minister.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 2 -- The way was cleared today for the Apollo 11 astronauts to take off July 16 for man's first landing on the moon.

LONDON, July 2 -- Two laborers with an eye for modern art say they came across 25 paintings in an old store they were demolishing here. Today Scotland Yard confirmed that the paintings, stolen in April from the London home of Sir Roland Penrose, were valued at $720,000.

TRENTON, July 2 -- The New Jersey Legislature meeting in a one-day special session tonight passed two waterfront anticrime bills designed to crack down on organized rackets said to be widespread on the Jersey piers.

The domestic shoe industry's problems are growing because of the increasing competition from foreign imports. Thirteen New England shoe producers have gone out of business since January under the combined pressure of burgeoning imports and rising wage scales, Mark Richardson, president of the National Footwear Manufacturers Association, said here yesterday.

FLINT, Mich., July 2 (AP) -- With most of the glamour golfers bypassing the event, a trio of nonwinners this year -- Bruce Crampton, Dan Sikes and Frank Beard -- are among the favorites for the top prize in the $125,000 Buick open.
A City Council investigating committee that had promised "major changes" in the Human Resources Administration split during a long closed-door meeting and failed to agree on its report.

CLAP hands. By next fall, gloves may be fun again. While other accessories -- belts, scarves and handbags -- have been in a whirl of change, gloves have been threatening to become as extinct as hats, at least with young women.
In Martin M. Mosho's June 30 letter he praises and asks for support of the Jewish Defense League. No.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 2 -- Three North Vietnamese regiments -- about 7,500 men -- have pulled back across the demilitarized zone into North Vietnam during the last three weeks, according to United States military officials here.
An alleged Mafia figure was directed in Manhattan Criminal Court yesterday to answer questions put to him by a grand jury investigating the fixing of prizefights.

Now that two of your columnists have plugged their own pet, and separate, candidates for the Fortas vacancy (or any vacancy) on the Supreme Court, may a mere letterwriter put in a word for a man far abler and more deserving than either of their choices?
The Mayor's office announced yesterday that the city's new experimental methadone research program to combat heroin addiction had received a Federal grant of $1.061,700.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 3 -- It will be Billie Jean King against -- and now, wait for it! -- Ann Jones of Britain for the Wimbledon women's title.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 2 (Reuters) -- The five African and Asian members of the Security Council -- Algeria, Nepal, Pakistan, Senegel and Zambia -- tonight drafted a resolution urging all states to stop sending arms to Israel until she gives up the former Jordanian sector of Jerusalem.

The appointment of Herbert I. Wexler as senior vice president of Macy's New York in charge of housewares, major appliances, radios, television sets, music, sporting goods, toys, books, photography and other leisure-type goods, as well as leased departments, was announced yesterday. The appointment is effective Aug. 1.
The world champion New York Jets will open their training camp Tuesday with 35 men scheduled to report to Coach Weeb Ewbank at Hofstra University.

The Automobile Club of New York and the Port of New York Authority warned yesterday of extremely heavy holiday congestion, beginning this afternoon, on highways and in public transportation facilities in the metropolitan area.

WASHINGTON, July 2 -- Kevin Thomas Duffy, a 36-year-old New York lawyer, was named today as head of the New York office of the Securities and Exchange Commission. He replaces Mahlon Frankhauser, who is now on the staff of the New York Stock Exchange.

ST. LOUIS, July 3 -- Things have got so bad for the St. Louis Cardinals that they were in trouble today from the first pitch and never recovered.
The secret draft report on the City Council inquiry into the Human Resources Administration recommends that the present job of welfare commissioner be abolished.

Further inquiry into the new contract between Johnny Carson, host of the "Tonight" show, and the National Broadcasting Company established yesterday that The New York Times was in error in suggesting he might have a weekly income of $75,000 to $85,000.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 3 -- Despite a 12-day lull in fighting in which contacts with the enemy are reported to have dropped to one of the lowest levels of the year, 241 Americans were killed in combat last week, military spokesmen reported today.
OTTAWA, July 3 -- The Government disclosed today that it spent about $50-million of its foreign exchange reserves in June in limited support buying of the Canadian dollar.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- A mysterious airborne irritant, described by one chemical warfare expert as poison gas that had been dumped by the Japanese in shallow water during World War II, sickened crew members and forced the evacuation of a Coast Guard station at Peale Island in the Wake atoll last year.
NEWARK, July 3 -- Newark city and police officials moved swiftly today to prevent a wildcat "sick call" of policemen in one precinct from becoming a crippling general walkout.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The nomination of Henry Alfred Byroade today to be United States Ambassador to the Philippines marks a turn upward in a brilliant career that has been marked as much by the shadows as by the light.
GRAND BLANC, Mich., July 3 -- Homero Blancas equaled the course record of 65 today in the first round of the $125,000 Buick open and R. H. Sikes duplicated the performance some 5 1/2 hours later.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 3 -- Rod Laver, the defending champion, will meet sixth-seeded John Newcombe for the Wimbledon crown Saturday.

South Africa's Nationalist Government has rammed through its Parliament a monstrous bill that will further curb civil liberties, erode the rule of law and hamper administration of justice -- but this time it must be uneasy about the extraordinary opposition it has provoked.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- After five months of internal debate, the Nixon Administration issued today a policy statement saying it intended to hold Southern school districts to the September, 1969, deadline for desegregation except for those with "bona fide educational and administrative problems."

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Secretary of State William P. Rogers moved today to improve his department's foreign policy planning and bring its long-range planners into closer contact with day-to-day problems.

The Federal Reserve System kept the nation's money markets under heavy pressure during the week ended Wednesday, banking figures published yesterday showed.

LONDON, July 3 -- In the summer the London tourist's fancy idly turns to thoughts of dance -- or so it seems. At present there are three dance companies playing, and only last Saturday Alwin Nikolais's Dance Company ended a sensational two-week season at the Sadlet's Wells Theater.

In the June 27 editorial "Delay on Latin America," The Times sees an "urgent need for a viable hemisphere policy." The concern is refreshing, since for many years the complex problems of Latin America have been largely ignored by reporters and editorial writers alike.
CHARLESTON, S. C., July 3 -The Rev. Ralph David Abernathy walked out of jail today, confident that a stormy hospital strike he has helped lead since March was in its final hours.
The Coast Guard this week sent a 20-year veteran of search-and-rescue work, the Grumman HU-16E amphibious flying boat -- known as the Albatross -- into honorable retirement.
Stokely Carmichael has resigned as a member and as prime minister of the Black Panther party, it was made known yesterday.
ANKARA, Turkey, July 3 (Reuters) -- A new joint defense agreement between Turkey and the United States was signed at the Foreign Ministry here today.

NEW ORLEANS, July 3 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit struck down freedom-of-choice school desegregation plans for 25 Mississippi school districts today and ordered new plans implemented by Aug. 25.
KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., July 3 (AP) -- President Nixon appointed today a successor commission to one named by President Johnson to plan a celebration of the country's 200th birthday in 1976.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The State Department disclosed today the lifting of the ban on credit sales of arms to Peru and Ecuador.

Dike, the late-rallying colt who upset all expectations by making the pace in the Belmont Stakes, will try the $100,000 added Suburban Handicap at Aqueduct today.
