WASHINGTON, July 3 (UPI) -- Savings bond redemptions totaled $71-million more than sales last month as savers continued to pull their funds out of the investment which the Nixon Administration concedes is not profitable enough.

ALBANY, July 3 -- The State Court of Appeals said today that it would hear argument in a suit that consumer groups hope will permit victims to file suit as a class, rather than as individuals, thus opening new evenues for redress.

ZURICH, Switzerland, July 4 (AP) -- Willie Davenport of Baton Rouge, La., equaled the world record in the 110-meter hurdles today in an international track and field meet. His time was 13.2 seconds.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July 4 -- Gallant Bloom won the $27,700 Post-Deb Stakes at Monmouth Park today, but not before her anticipated "match race" with Process Shot developed suddenly into a threehorse battle royal.

HINGHAM, Mass. -- For as far back as she can remember, Georgette Nickerson has been involved in the baking of the best, the thinnest, the lightest of Syrian flat bread. Her consuming interest in it is understandable; she's the fourth generation of a family of bakers.
KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., July 4 (UPI) -- President Nixon sent a radio message today to Thor Heyerdahl and his crew aboard the Egyptian papyrus ship Ra in the Atlantic.
CLEVELAND, July 4 (AP) -Thunderstorms smashed across northern Ohio tonight killing at least eight persons and injuring hundreds as trees fell before high winds and boats sank in Lake Erie.

The United Federation of Teachers bought tickets to fundraising events in the mayoral primary campaigns of Controller Mario A. Procaccino and State Senator John J. Marchi, the union's newspaper has reported.

ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, July 4 -- English is to be eliminated as an official language in Pakistan within six years under changes planned in the system of education announced here this week by the military government.
A missing 3-year-old Brooklyn girl was found yesterday sleeping in a bus used to transport her from a day camp. The child had been missing 11 hours, the police said.

The tempo was exactly right for the music-oriented Mr. Right in the $107,000 Suburban Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Running as if he were regulated by a metronome, the 6year-old New York-bred who now represents the Dansar Stable, of which Frank Sinatra is part owner, won the 1 1/4-mile contest by a head over the heavily favored Dike, with C.V. Whitney's Chompion next in the field of five.

NEWPORT, R. I., July 4 -- Sun Ra, the jazz pianist and keyboard specialist who has been leading his Solar Arkestra for almost 20 years, long ago insisted that his music was at least based on vibrations that he receives from outer space.

CORTLAND, N. Y., July 4 (AP) -- Six persons -- three in one family -- were killed today when the twin-engine airplane in which they were riding crashed shortly after taking off from the county airport here.

PARIS, July 4 -- The United States has told South Africa that the major Western monetary authorities are prepared to buy its gold only if the freemarket price falls to $35 an ounce, informed European sources said today.
KARACHI, Pakistan, July 4 -India and Pakistan signed a series of maps today delineating the border between them in the long-disputed Rann of Cutch.

OTTAWA, July 4 -- To be cheerful about it: The Canadian Government is pressing hard on the fiscal and monetary brakes and yet the official forecast is that real economic growth in 1969 will equal or surpass 1968's robust 4.7 per cent.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 4 (AP) -- A military tribunal sentenced the publisher of a Saigon English-language newspaper today to five years in prison on charges of "actions detrimental to the national order."

ROME, July 4 -- Outraged Italian critics almost unanimously attacked today a new production of Gioacchino Rossini's opera "L'Italiana in A1geri," performed last night at the 12th Festival of Two Worlds in Spoleto. The critics complimented the American conductor Thomas Schippers for "saving" Rossini's music but heaped scorn on the French director Patrice Chereau for his conception of the piece and for adding a 45-minute prose prologue to it.

MINEOLA, L.I., July 4 -- Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson urged Governor Rockefeller, who is making a tour of Latin America for President Nixon, "to come home to your own state and make a personal tour to observe the human suffering caused by the cruelty of your budget cutbacks."
GENEVA, July 4 -- Japanese diplomats revealed today that a small Japanese freighter was hit last month by wreckage from a Soviet spacecraft while cruising near the coast of Siberia.

OTTAWA, July 4 (Canadian Press) -- The Bank of Canada has progressively reduced the rate of growth of the banking system for the last 18 months in an effort to stem inflation, but cannot roll back high interest rates by force, Governor Louis Rasminsky of the Bank of Canada said today.

YONKERS, July 4 -- Even though he did not win a bet, John Derrico was one of the happiest persons among the 23,000 at Yonkers Raceway tonight. The 26-year-old son of Dr. and Mrs. Nicholas T. Derrico of Pelham Manor, N. Y., a frequent visitor to harness racing ovals, was on hand for the first time in the role of owner.

PARIS, July 4 -- A new aerodynamic system originally developed for the French supersonic fighter-bomber, the Mirage, is being tested on the French prototype of the Concorde, the French-British supersonic airliner.
THE HAGUE, July 4 -- Dutch air traffic controllers refused today to halt their work slowdown despite a Government ultimatum to resume normal activities at noon.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 4 -- With the relative lull in battle action continuing for the 13th day, military spokesmen reported that 11 allied outposts and installations were shelled last night and this morning.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The Permanent Council of the Organization of American States held an emergency session here today to weigh Honduran allegations of aggression by neighboring Salvador. Salvador denied the charges and filed counter-charges against Honduras.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- A leader of the rank-and-file movement for health and safety reforms in the nation's coal mines warned today that thousands of mine workers might stage protest strikes that could paralyze the industry if Congress failed to pass a strong mine safety law.

WATERBURY, Conn., July 4 (UPI) -- The state police have arrested the 30th person named in a special grand jury investigation of crime and corruption involving the police, politicians and underworld figures here.

OTTAWA, July 4 (Canadian Press) -- Canada and Peru completed a $14-million wheat deal today under which Peru will purchase about 7.5 million bushels under a Canadian loan. WASHINGTON, July 4 -"This movement for delegate selection reform is the only dynamic thing going in the Democratic party right now," Senator George S. McGovern said in an interview this week.

VIENTIANE, Laos -- The gold trade of Laos -- which once accounted for more than a third of the Royal Lao Government's tax income -- is well into its second year of recession. CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) -Cragwood Stable's Hawaii, the South African champion, won the $57,600 Stars and Stripes Handicap today before a crowd of 27,336 at Arlington Park.

ROME, July 4 -- The Socialist party, the major partner of the Christian Democrats in the coalition that has governed since 1963, split today, threatening Italy with a major political crisis.

Within the past two decades there has been an outbreak of fascinating foreign soups to tempt native palates -- everything from gazpacho (cold chopped vegetables with oil and garlic) to senegalese (cold curried chicken). But there is probably nothing more tempting than a plate of old-fashioned, homemade tomato soup. It's good hot. It's good cold. And with or without croutons.

MOSCOW, July 5 -- The Soviet Communist party's Central Committee nine days ago pledged to combat the policies of Mao Tse-tung but held open the possibility of eventual reconciliation.
MIAMI, July 5 -- The Nixon Administration asked today for time to show critics that its new policy on school desegregation will work.
ATHENS, July 5 -- Aristotle S. Onassis offered Greece a $600-million investment deal today in exchange for a lucrative oil refinery concession that was put up for bids in Athens.
ST. LOUIS, July 5 -- Twenty St. Louis church leaders rejected this week black militants' demands for financial "reparations" but pledged themselves to work for elimination of racism and poverty.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 5 -- The detective who was elected Mayor here on a law and order platform announced his first three appointments this week, including two assistants who have police records.

BABYLON, L. I., July 5 -- No fewer than 16 skippers are bidding for clean sweeps in the annual three-day invitation regatta of the Babylon Yacht Club. That was the number of sailors who posted second straight victories today under conditions which were surprisingly ideal.
A JUNIOR equestrian team composed of 13 riders will compete in the Netherlands next month under the sponsorship of the People-To-People Sports Committee.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Mr. Nixon's interesting plan to visit Communist Rumania provided a headline that helped divert public opinion from the Knowles fiasco; but White House sources have since made it plain that the Asian leg of the President's journey is what he considers most important.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (UPI) -- Savings bond redemptions totaled $71-million more than sales last month as savers continued to pull their funds out of the investment the Nixon Administration concedes is not profitable enough.

THE tournaments of the Interscholastic Chess League, individual and team, were played as one during March, April and May at the Manhattan Chess Club and the Chess House. First among the seniors was Joshua Fluk of Benjamin Cardozo High School, who scored 7 1/2-1/2.

PARIS, July 5 -- Jean Cardinal Danielou, a French theologian and writer, today rebuked Leo Cardinal Suenens and other critics of the Vatican, and appealed to Roman Catholic bishops to rally around the authority of the Pope.

JOHN W. MACY JR., president of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, did last week what the National Association of Broadcasters should have done years ago. SEOUL, South Korea, July 5 -- About 1,500 students from four universities in Seoul demonstrated briefly in streets near their campuses today against a proposal to allow President Chung Hee Park to serve a third term.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 5 -- Prof. David Riesman, the sociologist and educator, returned to the Harvard campus the other day after a quiet student-less year on leave at the Center for Advanced Study in the Behavioral Sciences at Stanford, Calif.

THE big event at the Tate Gallery this summer is the retrospective exhibition devoted to the work of Ben Nicholson on the occasion of his 75th birthday. NAHA, Okinawa, July 5 -- Armin H. Meyer, United States Ambassador to Japan, arrived here this morning for a two-day tour of the military bases on the island. The status of the bases will be a key issue in the United States-Japan negotiations on the reversion of the Ryukyu Islands to Japan.

By the first week in July the day lilies at the roadside and the brown - eyed Susans in the old pastures splash the countryside with van Gogh orange. The hot, tropical shades leave no doubt about the season. Tawny hawkweed might have been imported from a Mexican landscape, and even its rather pale yellow cousin, Canada hawkweed, has a hot-climate look about it.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 5 -- Joseph F. Dorsey, sailing Sheila in the International Class, and C. Stanley Ogilvy, with his Etchells-22 sloop, Flame, led at every mark on Long Island Sound today and won 10.7-mile races during the 15th championship regatta of the Yacht Racing Association season. WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Robert S. McNamara, president of the World Bank, has declined a second invitation from a Senate-House economic subcommittee to give his view on defense procurement methods.
TRENTON, July 6 (UPI) -New Jersey has received a $196,000 Federal grant for a program to fight the problem of drunken driving.
An integrated production of "The Pajama Game," the 1954 hit musical directed by George Abbott that won six Tony awards and ran here two and a half years, is being brought to Broadway in November.

Attorney General John N. Mitchell yesterday appointed Daniel Holman, a Justice Department lawyer, to head the nation's first Federal-state-city "joint strike force council" against organized crime.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) -- Emperor Haile Selassie's arrival tonight for talks with President Nixon tomorrow was interrupted by Ethiopian students who took over their country's chancery and picketed across the street from the White House.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Federal Trade Commission has quietly shelved charges of monopolistic news practices against the Washington Post Company and its local radio station, WTOP.

A state legislative committee has recommended setting up family allowances -- a monthly payment for each child -- as a technique to aid "the working poor." It has also called for dependents' allowances to be included in unemployment insurance payments.
Traffic on a seven-mile stretch of Hillside Avenue in Queens will be controlled by a computerized electronic signal system beginning this morning, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.

Hearings on a petition for reorganization of R. Hoe Co., printing press manufacturer, under Chapter X of the Bankruptcy Act were held yesterday in the Federal Court for the Southern District. Intention to file was announced last Thursday.

Major producers of paper, including newsprint, said yesterday their records had been subpoenaed by the Justice Department for submission to a grand jury in what one company spokesman called an "antitrust investigation."

ONE of the reasons -- in retrospect, the soundest reason -- why I went to Harvard was to watch Ted Williams play baseball for the Boston Red Sox. They were his declining years, but all of us should so decline: .388 in 1957 (at age 39!), .328 in 1958, .254 in 1959 (pinched nerve, cervical collar, Joe Pepitonic batting average), and .316 in 1960 (homering his last at-bat).
President Nixon has not really changed. He talks differently. He "comes off" differently. But what was so apparent to us just a short time ago is rapidly becoming a transparency.

TOKYO, July 7 (UPI) -- Hiroshi Kobayashi, the world junior lightweight champion of Japan, exploded a left hook on the jaw of Victor Ramos and knocked him out at 2:43 of the second round tonight in a nontitle bout.

WASHINGTON, July 7--In a prompt follow-up on its promise of firm, even-handed action against racial discrimination in schools, the Nixon Administration filed today two desegregation suits--one in the North and one in the South--and cut off financial aid to three Southern school districts.
PRAGUE, July 7 (Reuters) -- Premier Stanislav Razl of the Czech Republic said today that the economy was in extraordinary difficulties and drastic measure would be taken to overcome them.
LONDON, July 7 -- The Welsh opera singer Geraint Evans was knighted today by Queen Elizabeth II.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Senate killed today a proposed ceiling of $20,000 on Federal farm payments to any one farmer.

While The Times is to be commended for its June 20 editorial on the "Ordeal of Voting" it must also be stated that there is much more to be said with regard to the inherent inequities regarding the electoral process as conducted by the Board of Elections.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- With the big-power talks on the Middle East deadlocked on several major issues, the United States announced today it was sending a high official to Moscow later this week to try to put new momentum into the talks.

The military dictatorship of Greece has just named a square in Athens for Harry S. Truman in gratitude for the American aid that was instrumental in helping crush the Communist-led insurrection of twenty years ago. On the same day that Truman Square was dedicated, the junta again trampled its own Constitution by expanding its assault on Greece's independent judiciary.

BUCHAREST, July 7 -- A qualified Rumanian Communist party member said today that negotiations between Bucharest and Moscow on the renewal of the friendship treaty were continuing and that a Soviet delegation of a lower level than originally foreseen might come here this month to sign the pact.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., July 7 -- Preston Martin, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank board, announced today that the agency would make five-year advances, instead of one-year loans, to savings and loan associations in an effort to pump more money into housing mortgages.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Children from all over the country may get a chance to cruise on the 104-foot-long Presidential luxury yacht Sequoia, Mrs. Richard M. Nixon said today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 7 -- Secretary General Thant told the Security Council today that "open warfare has been resumed" throughout the Suez Canal cease-fire area.

The Space Science Board of the National Academy of Sciences (U.S.A.), the advisory body of NASA, formerly suggested that the person to make the first trip to the moon should be a "hard-rock" geologist, capable of determining the composition of the moon's surface on landing, etc.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- On the eve of the Senate debate on the Administration's Safeguard antiballistic missile defense system, the bipartisan opposition assumed today a no-compromise stance toward the White House.

The Madison Square Hotel on the east side of Madison Avenue between 25th and 26th Streets facing Madison Square Park, is to be sold to a building concern that plans to replace it with an office structure.

Having read in the June 28 Times of the behind-the-scenes manipulations which figured in the "de-selection" of Dr. John H. Knowles for Assistant Secretary for Health and Scientific Affairs, I feel constrained to raise at least one small public voice.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 7 -- Nina, the United States Merchant Marine Academy's Cal 58 schooner, was the apparent leader late this afternoon in the 360-mile race from Marblehead, Mass., according to sketchy reports from the United States Coast Guard cutter Decisive.
LONDON, July 8 (Reuters) -- About 80 Royal marines have been secretly dispatched to Bermuda to help local authorities maintain order if needed when a black-power conference starts Thursday.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 7 -The No. 99 blinked green on the computer keyboard at the center of the cockpit panel.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, July 7 -- When President Nixon comes to Indonesia this month, he will find a country that has moved from economic chaos and runaway inflation into a condition of surprising stability.

Rival factions of Students for a Democratic Society clashed in a fist-swinging, chair-throwing melee at a New York University student center last night during a regional meeting of the militant organization.

YONKERS, July 7 -- Yonkers Raceway's $95,000 late-closing pacing series for 4-year-olds rolls into its semi-final round on Thursday night with two $15,000 divisions. Adios Waverly and Golfer Mir, an opening-round victor in 2:02, are both rated at 2-1 in the morning line.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- A Queens doctor and an institution that billed for what was described as an "overwhelming number of treatments have been named in the Senate Finance Committee's hearings on the soaring costs of Federal medical care programs.
The Ford Foundation yesterday announced 20 grants, guarantees and loans totaling $2,602,175 and primarily intended to increase the quality and quantity of moderate and low income housing.

LYTHAM ST. ANNES, England, July 7 (AP) -- The Royal and Ancient Club of St. Andrews, arbiters of British golf, chalked up a black mark today against a young American who came here to try to qualify for the British Open championship, only to breach a rule of etiquette.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The title Commissioner of Education, Rr. James E. Allen Jr. is rapidly learning, means one thing in Albany and something rather different in Washington.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- President Nixon has canceled arrangements to dine with the Apollo 11 astronauts on the night before their take-off for the moon, the White House said today.
A policeman was shot and wounded yesterday when he encountered two men who the police said had just robbed a Queens supermarket of $708.

The attorney for the Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association said yesterday the State Racing Commission apparently does not intend to consider his group's charges of conflict of interest and abuse of power in the conduct of thoroughbred racing at Aqueduct, Belmont and Saratoga.

The poor go hungry in America as the nation, in an unconscionable paradox, lavishes subsidies on its large farm operations to encourage them not to grow more food. Yesterday, the Senate voted to continue these subsidies without ceiling in obtuse perpetuation of such indefensible policies.
Did a Yemeni Arab and his two sons, talking in the kitchen of their Brooklyn apartment last Nov. 7, conspire to assassinate President-elect Nixon?

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 8 -- A year ago, Denny Lyons won the Westchester open golf title as an amateur. Today, Greg Powers, a senior at Memphis State, threatened the pros in the same championship as he led by a stroke after the first round.
PARIS -- The biggest question in Western Europe today is whether the idea of a broader Common Market including Britain has now found its time or if that moment has already come and gone.

LYTHAM SAINT ANNE'S, England, July 8 -- Time was when a British Open was considered the property of Arnold Palmer, Gary Player or Jack Nicklaus, and a glance at the records reminds that only once in the last nine years have the Big Three failed to finish in the first three.

Robert S. Keefer Jr., senior partner in charge of foreign operations of Coggeshall Hicks, a small member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, changed his plea yesterday to guilty on three of eight counts of a Federal indictment.
All commuter and long-distance train service on the Penn Central from New York southward through New Jersey was halted last night by a power failure.

How unfair, biased and partisan is your July 1 editorial "O Jerusalem!" One need not go back 4,000 years when Jerusalem was a holy city of the Hebrews. Let's go back only 21 years, when Israel was declared a state and Jerusalem designated an open city.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (Reuters) -- United States military assistance programs in Latin America are under "deep review," especially those for military governments, a State Department policy adviser said today.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard told a Senate subcommittee today a sordid and harrowing story of conditions in the Ohio prisons, where he served 10 years after his conviction for the murder of his first wife.

MIDLAND PARK, N. J., July 8 (UPI) -- Hundreds of people in this small town, many of whose residents feel has done more than its share for the war in Vietnam, turned out today for the funeral of a seventh war victime.

There has been much discussion recently of rules to insure full disclosure of sources and amounts of income for legislators, government administrators and judges. I would suggest that the highest priority be given to a demand that the leaders, various Government officials and legislators of South Vietnam practice full disclosure.
The specter of possible wage and price controls revisited the stock market yesterday and sent prices tumbling in the biggest decline since last winter.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Federal Trade Commission confirmed in an announcement today that it had closed its investigation of alleged monopolistic news practices by The Washington Post Company and its local radio station, WTOP.

SUBIC BAY, the Philippines, Wednesday, July 8 (UPI) -- According to evidence submitted today, a radio message misinterpreted by a young United States Navy officer led to the collision June 3 between the United States Destroyer Frank E. Evans and the Australian carrier Melbourne. Seventy-four Americans lost their lives in the collision.

GRAND PRAIRIE, Tex., July 8 -- An electronic Big Brother that not only watches the speeding motorist but also records his identity and the evidence against him in a single photograph was displayed today by LTV Aerospace Corporation.

The front-page picture [Times July 3] of the Governor of New York in the triumphant arm-waving company of Dr. Duvalier, the most dreadful of the Western hemisphere's petty tyrants, is degrading to the great work of the Rockefellers in inter-American relations. [Editorial July 4.]

Judge Constance Baker Motley has ordered the convening of a three-judge Federal court to consider a challenge to amendments to the state Social Services Law under which welfare recipients outside New York City receive lower payments than those living in the city.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Would Arthur Ashe play in a Davis Cup challenge round against South Africa, or would he protest that country's apartheid policy by sitting out the series?
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Harvard's president, Nathan Pusey, left a Senate hearing room in a huff today after he was not called to testify as scheduled about student disorders on his campus.
LINCOLN, Neb., July 8 -- Nebraska's one-house Legislature defeated today, 20 to 17, a meat inspection bill complementing the Federal wholesome meat and poultry acts.

McCHORD AIR FORCE BASE, Wash., July 8 -- The first American troops withdrawn from Vietnam by President Nixon arrived home today to a welcome from Gen. William C. Westmoreland, cheering friends and relatives and a brass band.

WATERBURY, Conn., July 8 -- Mayor George P. Harlamon responded today to a threat of Federal legal action to end de facto school segregation by declaring that steps were being taken to correct the situation that prompted a Justice Department warning.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The State Department expressed concern today over the rising rate of violence against foreign embassies and embassy personnel in Washington while announcing that apologies had been extended for the latest incident, the ransacking of the Ethiopian chancery.

A garment center trucker and a lawyer received prison sentences yesterday in Federal Court for conspiring to obtain $250,000 in kickbacks for arranging a $1.5-million loan for a sweater manufacturer from the International Teamsters Union pension fund.

PETER BADER, of the Virgin Islands, a stocky 34-year-old with gray-tinged black hair, favors casually tailored black suits, colored shirts and gold cuff links. He sports a golden tan that reflects the quality of life in an affluent island community.

TRENTON, July 8 -- The State Commission of Investigation today questioned three reputed members of the Mafia family headed by Simone Rizzo (Sam the Plumber) DeCavalcante about organized crime and official corruption in Long Branch and other Monmouth County shore areas.
The United Aircraft Corporation has been awarded three defense contracts totaling $30.1-million to make helicopters for the Navy and the Air Force.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The national unemployment rate was virtually unchanged at 3.4 per cent of the labor force in June despite first indications of a slowdown in the demand for labor, the Labor Department reported today.
Interest rates once again are moving up to the highest levels in American corporate financial history.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Soviet Union has increased jamming of Russian and Ukrainian language broadcasts from the Voice of America.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- A new United States Attorney for New Jersey was nominated by President Nixon today as Republican efforts to line up a potential candidate for a similar post in New York City took a new turn.
DUBLIN, July 8 (UPI) -- Mrs. Billie Jean King and Rosemary Casals, the United States professionals, won second-round matches today in the Irish open tennis tournament.
LISBON, July 8 -- Premier Marcello Caetano flew to Brazil today for a five-day state visit, in a move to end Portugal's long isolation from her former colony.

There seems to be a "new politics" in the world after all. It is not the new politics of the left or the right that is in the news but the politics of the individual. PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, July 8 (AP) -- Lubomir Strougal, the No. 2 man in Czechoslovakia's Communist party, tightened his grip over the Czech regions of Bohemia and Moravia today.

MOSCOW, Wednesday, July 9 -- The Soviet Union announced today that a Russian river worker was killed and three were wounded by Chinese forces in an incident yesterday in the Amur River.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Senator Russell B. Long announced today a wide-open set of hearings on tax reforms to be tied to the income tax surcharge, thus creating the likelihood that no final tax legislation would be enacted until autumn.

Twin passenger seats resting on a single pedestal said to be 20 per cent lighter than present seats of comparable size, have been designed by Walter Dorwin Teague Associates for the Boeing 747 airliner.

PARIS, July 8 (Reuters) -- President Georges Pompidou met diplomatic representatives today and expressed hope for the disappearance of what he called the divisions that held back Europe in the first half of the century.

The president of a group-practice private medical facility that serves 250 people a day in Harlem charged yesterday that twin investigations by the United States Attorney and the Bronx District Attorney have affected the facility's credit rating and resulted in layoffs of 43 workers.

The Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corporation announced yesterday an increase in the base price of various electro-galvanized sheet steel products by $6 a ton, effective July 15. The product, Wheeling-Pittsburgh said, accounts for less than 1/2 of 1 per cent of the steel industry's total shipments.

PARIS, July 8 -- One of Europe's key central bankers has proposed a major modification of the world monetary system to diminish currency disparities and facilitate British entry into the Common Market.

FAYETTE, Miss., July 8 (UPI) -- Mayor Evers, starting his first working day in office, opened a clean-up drive today and instructed his all-Negro police force to enforce laws firmly but equally.

DENVER, July 8 -- Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the new United States Commissioner of Education, predicted today that public spending on education would total $100-billion annually by 1980, with the Federal Government more than tripling its share of the cost for elementary and secondary schooling.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 8 -- A preliminary consultative meeting of 51 nonaligned nations opened here today and decided, after a lengthy procedural debate, to let the Palestine Liberation Organization come to Belgrade to present its views to the conference.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 8 (UPI) -- Maury Koblentz, Ohio's Commissioner of Correction, said today that Dr. Sheppard's allegations were "an outright and absolute lie."

MONTEREY, Calif. -- "What can it profit a man," wrote John Steinbeck in "Cannery Row," "to gain the whole world, and to come to his property with a gastric ulcer, a blown prostate, and bifocals?"
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 8 (AP) -- At least five enemy rockets were fired into a Saigon riverfront district tonight and touched off a large blaze, officials said.

WOODSTOCK, N. Y., July 8 -- Since the establishment of an artists' colony here in 1902, this community has been something of a stage.

The city rejected yesterday the rules proposed by the real estate industry to stabilize rents in some 400,000 New York apartments.

Prices lost more ground yesterday in diminished trading on the American Stock Exchange.
Mickey Lolich, the Detroit Tigers' left-hander who upstaged his teammate, Denny McLain, with three victories in the World Series last fall, was upstaged by a rookie last night.
The high cost of losing the mayoral primaries -- and some relatively low-budget victories -- were inscribed yesterday in the record books of the Board of Elections.
Albert N. Halverstadt, a very important man to a lot of ad agencies, is retiring at the end of the month from Procter Gamble, where he has been vice president-advertising.

FORT DIX, N. J., July 8 (UPI) -- A young soldier convicted of being absent without leave for staying home two years awaiting orders to go to Germany, was fined today almost half his monthly pay for the next six months.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Secretary of the Treasury David M. Kennedy confirmed today that the Nixon Administration would recommend raising the interest rate on savings bonds to 5 per cent from the present 4 1/4 per cent.

BALTIMORE, July 8 -- The Baltimore Orioles lifted a page from the New York Yankees' book of lore tonight in Memorial Stadium.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 8 -- The last dogfight between Soviet - built Syrian MIG's and French - made Israeli Mirage fighter aircraft occurred last Feb. 24 when 18 Israeli planes raided Palestinian commando bases outside Damascus. The Syrians said then they had lost two planes and shot down four Israeli Mirages.

The pace of the automation sweepstakes on Wall Street accelerated yesterday as Goodbody Co., one of the nation's largest brokerage houses, announced the computerization of its stock delivering and receiving operations.
When Red Rolfe startled the baseball world by nearly winning the 1950 American League pennant with the Detroit Tigers, he was asked to explain his managerial secret.

Four of New York's giant banks reported record net operating earnings yesterday for the first half of 1969, but the gains -- ranging from 1.79 per cent to 11.6 per cent above the levels of last year's period -- were held in check by sharply rising money costs.

INTERESTING tactical possibilities can occur when a nonvulnerable side may need to sacrifice against a potential vulnerable game. It is not only the nonvulnerable side that attempts to outmaneuver the opposition by deliberate overbidding or underbidding.

LONDON, July 8 -- Whatever it was the Bolshoi Ballet imagined it was doing at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, last night, it should have had second thoughts about it. Come to that, it should have first thoughts about it, because the company, on the first night of its London season, went down like an over-inflated lead balloon.

A long-withheld report on air pollution in the Brooklyn-Battery and Queens-Midtown tunnels, made public yesterday, shows that employes there at times are exposed to a carbon-monoxide level of 100 parts per million -- twice that considered the danger level.

A joint legislative committee yesterday recommended immediate action by the State Health Department to eliminate a 20 per cent cut in Medicaid reimbursement rates for druggists that was instituted five weeks ago.

BONN, July 8 -- Hannsheinz Porst, owner of West Germany's largest photo supply house and a millionaire who is also a Communist, was found guilty today of having passed confidential Government information to the East Germans over a 14-year period.

The Democratic primary election of two Civil Court judges June 17 was voided yesterday and a new election ordered because voting machines in the Harlem district permitted votes to be cast for only one candidate instead of two.
Platinum futures rose yesterday, with a technical rally accounting for heavy activity -- S40 contracts changed hands compared with 443 the day before.
JERUSALEM, July 8 -- The Israeli Air Force downed seven Syrian MIG-21's today in a series of dogfights, Israeli defense officials reported. The Israelis said all their planes had returned safely.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Nixon Administration sought to press forward today on two domestic fronts.

The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to purchase Riker Laboratories, the ethical drug division of Dart Industries, Inc., for 1.5 million shares of Minnesota Mining common stock.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 8 (AP) -- The Apollo 11 astronauts practiced today procedures for escaping should their Saturn 5 rocket stray after next Wednesday's blastoff for the moon.

For seven years the Mets wasted their time on ordinary games, playing them one at a time (as the cliche goes), losing them at almost the same clip. But yesterday they discovered another kind of game -- the biggest game in Met history -- and they won it in a very special way.
CHUR, Switzerland, July 8 -- With priests demonstrating on their doorstep, officials of the Symposium of European Bishops reversed themselves today and agreed to meet with the insurgent leaders.
The Kroger Company, the nation's third largest food retailer, has established new divisions and elected presidents for each, the company announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The Justice Department told the school board of Waterbury, Conn., today that it must take immediate action to correct racial imbalance or face the first school desegregation suit ever filed by the Government in the northeastern states.
HONG KONG, July 8 -- Communist China charged today that Soviet gunboats, troops and aircraft had intruded across the Amur River frontier between the two countries and provoked an "armed conflict."

David Dellinger, chairman of the National Mobilization Committee to End the War in Vietnam, left Monday night for Paris, on the invitation of the North Vietnamese delegation to the peace talks, to arrange the release of three United States prisoners being held by Hanoi.
Prices sagged over a wide front on the London stock market yesterday as trading volume and investor interest remained at a low level.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The House of Representatives passed today a bill to give $12.5-million more to complete the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts, a gigantic structure now half finished on the Potomac River.
Representative Hugh L. Carey of Brooklyn yesterday dropped out of the mayoral race and all other involvement in the city campaign.
LONDON, July 9 -- The first large-scale study of race relations in Britain concluded today that the American tragedy could be avoided here if politicians led the way.

It is hard to envision anyone but Frank Aiken heading Ireland's delegation at the opening of a United Nations General Assembly. He was one of a group of able foreign ministers -- Spaak of Belgium, Pearson of Canada, Lange of Norway, Malik of Lebanon were others -- who had an impact on world affairs far out of proportion to the size or power of their respective countries.

TRENTON, July 9 -- Simone Rizzo (Sam the Plumber) DeCavalcante, boss of one of the six Mafia families that are reputed to control organized crime throughout the metropolitan region, was kept waiting for three hours today while the State Commission of Investigation questioned a minor underworld figure.
The stock market, weighted down by an assortment of worries, crunched yesterday to a new 1969 low despite an absence of selling pressure.

The Humble Oil and Refining Company, the chief domestic affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), said yesterday that exploratory wells in the Santa Barbara Channel indicated a "major oil discovery."

At least a dozen persons were taken into custody last night after a demonstration at Governor Rockefeller's Fifth Avenue apartmetn by New Left and antiwar groups spilled over into Central Park and adjoining streets.
HACKENSACK, July 9 -- Joe Moran jogged around the tiny sound studio, a half-filled container of coffee in one hand, singing along with Merle Haggard's nasal recording of "Workin' Man Blues."

DENVILLE, N. J., July 9 -The 49th annual $10,000 New Jersey State open golf championship got under way today over the Rockaway River Country Club and Alan McClay of Canoe Brook and Ken Burnette of Tammy Brook tied for the lead with four-under-par 68's.
Investors Diversified Services, Inc., and Jefferies Co., Inc., announced yesterday they had reached agreement for I.D.S. to acquire Jefferies, West Coast-based brokerage house.

The substantive proposals outlined by the President in his message on unemployment insurance would strengthen the country's defense against economic recessions. But he has unfortunately stopped short of recommending a key reform.
MITO, Japan, July 9--"I hope they relocate that bombing range soon," said Noriko Shima, an usherette at Mito's up-to-date ferroconcrete cultural center auditorium.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -Senator Henry M. Jackson led off the case for the Administration's Safeguard missile defense system today by arguing that the Soviet Union was "a dangerous, unpredictable opponent" with a "fast growing" military capability.
ARDSLEY ON HUDSON, N. Y., July 9 -- Mike Krak, a former field worker who became a golf champion, won the Westchester open title today in a playoff.

Fourteen boys and girls from deprived areas in New York City will spend a month as guests in private homes in Darien, Conn., while participating in the "Higher Horizons" educational experiment conducted in that suburban Fairfield County community.

The Advertising Council, through which the ad business funnels its great strength for the public good, is about to enter a major battle -- the fight against inflation.

The Christian churches, which only a few years ago were generally suspicious of Madison Avenue as representing something less than gospel truth, today are increasingly turning to advertising techniques to bring the Christian message to the media-oriented masses.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) -- Dr. Roger O. Egeberg, nominated for the Government's top medical job, told Congress today the cost of medical care had become so great that most people could not handle a medical emergency.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Rumanian Ambassador today discounted any suggestion that the Soviet Union was irritated over President Nixon's forthcoming visit to Bucharest and portrayed the visit as a "natural phenomenon" in an era of world travel by prominent leaders.
JERUSALEM, July 9--Two years after the Arab-Israeli war both sides have raised the ante along the cease-fire lines, the Arabs to change the situation and the Israelis to maintain it.

Rock was blended with an impressively wide variety of other musical styles last night at the Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park. An audience of 5,500 that filled Wollman Rink for the first of the evening's two performances heard folk music, blues, jazz and classical music mixed with varying degrees of rock by the Carolyn Hester Coalition and by Blood, Sweat and Tears.
Trading remained light and prices continued to wilt on the American Stock Exchange yesterday.

The Astoria for 2-year-old fillies had a most unladylike denouement at Aqueduct yesterday. Philip Godfrey's Sadie F. won the 5 1/2-furlong sprint by a nose over the Brookmeade Stable's Box the Compass. Next across the finish line was Corte Madera, a stablemate of the winner, while Cherry Sundae of the Shelter Rock Stable was fourth and last.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., -Although the unincorporated village of Locust Valley occupies only 1.0421 square miles, it's a shopping hub of an area in Nassau County that includes some of the oldest, most luxurious estates on Long Island.

FRESNO, Calif., July 9 -Farm income problems are being intensified by soaring interest rates, Secretary of Agriculture Clifford M. Hardin was told today. He attended one of a series of farm problem "listening" sessions scheduled in several farm centers.

LONDON, July 9 -- A high Government finance official, in an unusually candid speech, acknowledged today that Britain had no prospect of repaying her short-term debts on schedule. He urged substantial refinancing.
Six men were accused yesterday of stealing fork-lift trucks from Brooklyn piers, altering their identification marks and putting them up for sale or rental.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, July 10 (AP) -- American paratroopers walked into a Vietcong ambush 50 miles south of Danang and nine men were killed and seven wounded in a day-long battle, United States headquarters reported yesterday.
TEAM contests in which head-to-head matches are played and scored by international match points have gained greatly in popularity at the expense of the traditional "board-a-match" event.

BUFFALO, July 9 -- A possible link between cancer and the widespread use of certain pesticides was added to the growing concern over the use of such chemicals at hearings of a state legislative subcommittee here today.
Tom Seaver of the Mets thrilled the biggest baseball crowd in Shea Stadium history last night by coming within two outs of pitching a perfect game.

Jim Bunning's strike-outs, which had sent him ahead of Christy Mathewson and Bob Feller earlier in the season, passed Warren Spahn and put him in third place on the major league career list last night.

The Chase Manhattan Bank and 14 Negro plaintiffs agreed yesterday on a settlement of a 1967 complaint to the City Commission on Human Rights alleging discrimination against Negroes in job training and advancement.
Your interesting June 16 news article on the many uses of the Lincoln Center plaza and parks prompts a suggestion.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -President Nixon stuck by his position today that Congress should speedily pass legislation extending the 10 per cent income tax surcharge and not delay it by adding numerous tax reforms.
CHUR, Switzerland, July 9 -Roman Catholic bishops of Europe decided today, in a split vote, not to admit oppositionist priests to their discussion of celibacy and other aspects of the priesthood.

Judge Sylvester J. Ryan of the Federal Court for the Southern District said here yesterday that he would appoint a New York lawyer, John J. Galgay, as a trustee to operate R. Hoe Co., Inc., of the Bronx, manufacturer of printing presses and equipment.

The General Electric Company reported yesterday gains in total income, sales and net income for the first half and for the June quarter. Total income for the period rose to $4,308,033,000 from $4,074,009,000 a year earlier.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The United States Army's embattled Sheridan and M-60 tank systems came under renewed attack today in a Congressional report asserting that $1.2-billion was needlessly spent for their development.
WOODBURY, Conn. -- As one guest sprinkled cheese over his third helping of hot lasagne, he glanced at Carmine (Bo) Rosa.

LOS ANGELES, July 9 -- Under pressures from many quarters about the harmful side effects of "hard" pesticides, the Department of Agriculture announced today that it was suspending the use of DDT and eight other similar compounds in its programs pending a 30-day "review."

WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Representative Charles E. Chamberlain, Republican of Michigan, said today that 60 ships flying the flags of nonCommunist countries delivered cargoes to North Vietnam during the first half of 1969, a reduction from the 78 vessels in the same period in 1968.

F. Perry Wilson, the new president of the Union Carbide Corporation, said yesterday that sales in the second quarter would total about $732million, or 10 per cent better than in the 1968 period.

Negotiations resumed yesterday between the Metropolitan Opera Company and representatives of its employes. A spokesman for the opera said it hoped to go ahead with a scheduled Sept. 15 opening and play a full season.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, July 9 -- Sponsors and delegates here for the first regional conference on black power that opens tomorrow accused both the British and American Governments today of harassment and intimidation.

PRINCETON, N. J., July 9--Mrs. Richard M. Nixon's handling of her role as First Lady was approved by 54 per cent of those interviewed in the latest Gallup poll and was disapproved by 6 per cent. Forty per cent had no opinion, the American Institute of Public Opinion reported today.

BOSTON, July 9 -- The Director General of the World Health Organization counseled today against restrictions of the pesticide DDT in countries where the eradication of insect-borne diseases was of prime importance.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The Department of Transportation conceded today that it was making no effort to enforce "interim" Federal standards under the Natural Gas Pipeline Safety Act.

PARIS, July 9 -- Rhone-Poulenc, the French synthetic-fibers company, is planning to acquire the chemical interests of three other French concerns in what would be a major industrial reorganization aimed at increasing French competitiveness in world markets.

Representative Lowell P. Weicker Jr. said yesterday that Connecticut and New York State transportation authorities had been "principal proponents" of a controversial fare revision proposed by the New Haven Railroad involving nearly 24,000 commuters to New York City.

Tom Mboya fought throughout his brilliant if tragically short career to eliminate what he called "negative tribalism" from the political life of Kenya. Most Kikuyu chose him over one of their own.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Senator George D. Aiken, who holds what many observers believe to be the single most crucial vote on the missile defense issue, said today he would not vote for the Administration's Safeguard proposal unless it was modified.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The House Appropriations Committee asserted today that the Government's system for the education of American Indians was a "fragmented organization."

The Jehovah's Witnesses agreed yesterday to a request from Cesar Chavez, director of the United Farm Workers, to cancel all future orders of California-grown grapes.

EDINA, Minn., July 10 (AP) -- Mac McLendon and John Lively posted early 66's today then watched the scores stand up for the first-round lead in the $100,000 Minnesota Golf Classic over the 6,913-yard, par 71 Bradmar Golf Club course.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 10 -- Dr. Roger W. Heyns, chancellor of the University of California's Berkeley campus, hopes to expand his one-month vacation in August into a three-month period of rest and travel to "get my enthusiasm back."

SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, July 10 (UPI) -- Thor Heyerdahl radioed today that his six-man crew was "working desperately" to keep the papyrus craft Ra from swamping in heavy seas before an escort vessel arrives in the area Monday.

STRASBOURG, France, July 10 -- The 40th anniversary of the death of Sergei Diaghilev (1872-1929), the Russian impresario who, more than any other single figure, was responsible for establishing the ballet as a vital form of modern theater, is being observed here this summer with a splendid exhibition of the many artists who collaborated in this historic adventure.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., July 10 -- Gilbert B. Phillips, the president of the Automobile Club of New York, accused state officials today of a "strange" silence concerning the new breath-test law to detect drunken drivers.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- The House Ways and Means Committee tentatively adopted a tax reform plan today that would open the way for the taxation of interest paid on state and municipal bonds for the first time, committee sources said.

A Federal judge ordered the Veterans Administration yesterday to turn over to Consumers Union, a nonprofit research and publishing company in Mount Vernon, N.Y., the 1968 "raw scores" of Government tests of hearing aids.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Nixon Administration is making clear that the current lull in fighting in South Vietnam must endure for at least three weeks more before it can be interpreted as a reciprocal concession by North Vietnam for the withdrawal of 25,000 American troops.

A $56-million aid package for the New Haven Railroad is expected to be completed by the Metropolitan and Connecticut Transportation Authorities in the next two weeks Representative Ogden R. Reid said yesterday.

MOSCOW, July 10 -- Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko called today for a new era of friendly relations with the United States and indicated Soviet interest in a future conference with President Nixon.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- A State Department spokesman said today that no transfer of tanks by Turkey to Pakistan had been approved by the United States, but added that consideration would be given if a request were made.

About 150 people, mostly Puerto Ricans, sat in yesterday afternoon and evening at the offices of the City Commission on Human Rights to protest the dismissal Tuesday of Gilberto Gerena-Valentin as director of the commission's division of Puerto Rican and Hispanic affairs.

PARIS, July 10 (Reuters) -- A team of American pacifists will fly to Hanoi next week to bring home three American prisoners. David Dellinger, chairman of the National Mobilization Committee to End the War in Vietnam, said tonight.

PARIS, July 10 -- The United States told North Vietnam and the Vietcong provisional revolutionary government today that a negotiated settlement of the Vietnam war was impossible unless they modified their demand for the unilateral withdrawal of American troops.
James Farmer, Assistant Secretary for Administration in the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, strenuously defended yesterday the Administration's new guidelines on school desegregation.
The nation's largest bank reported yesterday a sharp increase in net operating earnings, a higher rate of return on equity, but a lower margin of profit in the first half.
Proponents of American arms aid abroad apparently never learn and never give up.
Improved earnings and sales for the second quarter were reported yesterday by the Allied Chemical Corporation and the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation.

The Mets march to the moon was interrupted yesterday when the Chicago Cubs scored five runs in the fifth inning and salvaged the final game of their tumultuous series, 6-2.

Bronx Borough President Herman Badillo received a letter yesterday urging him to run for Mayor as an independent Democrat. It came from Robert M. Ginsberg, a member of the law firm of Fuchsberg Fuchsberg.
The Federal Reserve System maintained its rigidly restrictive credit policy during the last two weeks, banking data published yesterday showed.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 10 -- The United States command announced today the lowest American casualty figures in six months as the current lull in battlefield activity neared the end of its third week.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 10 -- Despite a flurry of attacks from member nations representing both conservative and radical points of view, the consultative conference of non-aligned nations moved through its third day toward general agreement on holding a high-level meeting.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -A bill extending the Voting Rights Act of 1965 for a second five-year period was overwhelmingly approved by a House Judiciary subcommittee today and was expected to get full committee approval next week.

HECKLETOOTH THREE is a logging unit in the mountains of Oregon, "a half-mile square of stumps, dry-rot log chunks, gigantic Douglas fir limbs, four months of sandwich wrappers, racked tangles of steel cable, certainly a few hornets' nests, perhaps some mislaid dynamite caps."

PARIS, July 10 -- France will exact a high price from her Common Market partners before agreeing to start membership negotiations with Britain, but she has finally lifted her veto, Common Market experts said today.
PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., July 10 -- For the third time in three years, Mrs. Betty Weed Foulk was awarded the Syce Cup today, emblematic of the Long Island Sound women's sailing championship.
WATERFORD, Conn., July 10 -- At first blush, it reeks of summer stock -- blue jeans, hammering, outdoor lunch, green grass, boarding in the neighborhood and, first and last, endless enthusiasm.

Supreme Court Justice Samuel A. Spiegel dismissed for technical reasons yesterday two suits brought by the anti-Lindsay faction of the Bronx Republican organization, challenging the election of Dominick A. Fusco as chairman of the county committee. Mr. Fusco belongs to the pro-Lindsay group.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Federal Communications Commission said today that it would hold competitive hearings to resolve the issue of control of Channel 4 in Los Angeles.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Federal aid to New York City reached the $1-billion level for the first time in the fiscal year ended June 30.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 10 -- Premier Marcello Caetano of Portugal arrived today, halfway through a five-day state visit to Brazil, with his public appeal for help in maintaining Portugal's African territories pointedly unanswered by the Brazilian government.
A legislative committee heard conflicting testimony yesterday on whether the practice of attaching part of a worker's wages to pay off his debts should be continued.

The National General Corporation, a motion picture theater operator that has expanded into insurance, publishing and restaurants, has agreed to acquire a New York investment banking and brokerage house that specializes in large institutional accounts.

BERLIN, July 10 -- West Berlin gave its universities a liberal reform statute today, but faculty and leftist students at the two institutions affected -- the Free University and the Technical University -- immediately voiced their opposition and threatened to boycott the new system.

LOS ANGELES, July 10 -- The American Civil Liberties Union stepped into the Santa Barbara oil imbroglio today, charging in a lawsuit that residents of the area were being deprived of a constitutional right to live in a pleasant environment.

DETROIT, July 10 -- The Chrysler Corporation is retrenching because of fear that the Government's anti-inflation moves and soaring interest rates could hurt the automobile business, Lynn A. Townsend, Chrysler chairman, said today.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange continued to ease yesterday as the persistent weakness on Wall Street prompted extreme caution among traders. Trading volume remained small.
LONDON, July 10 -- The British Broadcasting Corporation announced plans today to trim its cultural spending and expand radio broadcasts of pop, light music and news.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Ford Foundation announced today a grant of $2.25-million to the National Urban Coalition, making the foundation the Chief financial supporter of the organization.

PARIS, July 10 -- President Pompidou indicated today that he intended to maintain an embargo on jet planes for Israel and said that the most he envisaged was a more flexible policy permitting the delivery of defensive weapons and "weak" offensive weapons as well as spare parts.

This was the predecessor of the present Royal Ballet School, which has become the largest and one of the most important in the Western world.

Harvey Lichtenstein and Dr. Firman H. Brown Jr. have won the first awards for achievement in cultural administration to be given by Arts Management, a national newsletter for those who work in the arts.

The new owners of Railway Express Agency, Inc., say they expect to restore that deficitridden operation to a profitable basis in the last four months of this year and to make a public stock offering within the next two years.

Author of a densely rich and allusive novel, "Hopscotch," Julio Cortazar is here serving up a dish of assorted fictional tidbits. Parable, fantasy, straight tale with a surrealistic overlay, eccentric incident (building a gallows in the front yard; taking in a tiger as a house guest) are all used in a nonchalant display of fictional brio.

Last fall on "Bonanza" Ben Cartwright and his sons, Hoss and Little Joe, shut down a pulp mill that was chewing up trees along the Ponderosa fence line. Have you ever wondered why they had to do it all over again in August?

The Citizens Committee for Postal Reform has been pleading with mail-users for support of the Administration's bill to turn the Post Office into a public corporation, somewhat on the TVA model. Like a plea from the Red Cross or the United Fund, the committee's proposal is beyond all partisanship -- signed indeed by Lawrence F. O'Brien, former Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, and Thruston B. Morton, once his Republican counterpart.
For the first time since the June 17 primary election, Mayor Lindsay and Controller Mario A. Procaccino met face to face yesterday.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., July 10 -- Honda, an unknown 5-year-old bay gelding, took the lead for the open jumper championship at the opening of the four-day Gaudeamus Farms horse show today by winning one class and finishing in a tie for second in another.
MAMARONECK, N. Y., July 10 -- Honors were divided as 96 amateur teams assembled today for the Anderson Memorial bestball tourney, a fixture in Eastern golf circles for 29 years.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Department of Justice filed two new school desegregation suits in Arkansas and Mississippi today.
NORMAN F. DACEY is on the march again, lashing out at mutual funds that don't pay redemption proceeds promptly to shareholders who cash in their shares.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 10 -- The editor in chief of The Rand Daily Mail, Laurence Gandar, and one of his reporters were found guilty today of having published information charging brutal conditions in South African prisons without having made a reasonable effort to verify it.

PARIS, July 10 -- It was in the same place and at the same hour. But millions of Frenchmen who listened to their radios or watched their television sets this afternoon got their strongest impression to date that the time of Charles de Gaulle really had passed.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 10 (AP) -- A Defense Department team met privately today at nearby Hamilton Air Force Base with families of American prisoners and servicemen missing in action in the Vietnam war.

MIAMI, July 7 -- The sale of 16 daily and 10 weekly newspapers owned or partly owned in Florida by John H. Perry and Associates expected to be completed this week for a price estimated at $70-million. The ownership of several of the dailies was transferred last week.

BROOKLINE, Mass., July 10 -- Professional tennis players, once outcasts on the international scene, took today's International Lawn Tennis Federation ruling as another sign that their game was finally moving ahead.

The decision of Secretary of Transportation John A. Volpe to refuse Federal funds for the proposed New Orleans freeway is a refreshing surprise. MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 10 -- Acting under orders from Gov. Albert P. Brewer, the Alabama state police seized six films being shown at drive-in theaters throughout Alabama last night and charged the theater managers with violation of a 1907 antiobscenity law.
The Manhattan Republican organization voted 60 to 10 last night to support Mayor Lindsay for re-election despite his defeat by State Senator John J. Marchi in the party's primary election on June 17.

LYTHAM ST. ANNES, England, July 10 -- A wild charge down the stretch by Christy O'Connor today set the British Open alight long after Bob Charles seemed to have a secure three-stroke lead at the halfway stage.
JERUSALEM, Friday, July 11 -- Officials announced early today that three Israeli soldiers had been killed and one apparently taken prisoner in an Egyptian raid across the Suez Canal last night.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that a company had violated Federal labor law by changing a health plan for retired employes without bargaining with a union.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Two former aides of Gov. Ronald Reagan of California are under consideration for relatively high-ranking political posts on the White House staff, Administration sources reported tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Senator Fred R. Harris of Oklahoma, the Democratic National Chairman, said today that the country was "approaching a crisis of leadership" because of what he called President Nixon's "indecisiveness."

ROME, July 10 -- Leaders of Italy's Christian Democratic party, keystone of governments for two decades, made it clear early today that they would not take on alone the task of governing the nation in political crisis and social ferment.

ROCHESTER, July 10 -- An early afternoon rainstorm postponed two men's singles quarter-final matches but Linda Tuero, the top-ranked women's player, and unseeded Patricia Cody advanced to the semi-finals today in the United States Lawn Tennis Association amateur championships at the Tennis Club of Rochester.

RUSINGA ISLAND, Kenya, July 10 (Reuters) -- The body of Tom Mboya was brought to the home of his parents on this island in Lake Victoria today. Thousands of Luo tribesmen crossed the lake in dugouts and dhows to pay last respects to the Economics Minister, who was assassinated last Saturday in Nairobi.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 10 -- At 8 o'clock tonight, the long countdown began for man's first attempt to land on another celestial body -- the moon.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Federal and New Jersey safety investigators are looking into a mishap that disrupted Penn Central service from New York southward Tuesday and damaged a high-speed Metroliner.
Soybean futures slipped yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade in liquidation, influenced primarily by a generally improved outlook for the crop.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Administration was pleased today by the conciliatory tone of Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko's speech signaling Soviet interest in a summit meeting with President Nixon and improved relations with Washington.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, July 11 -- President Nguyen Van Thieu, today challenged the National Liberation Front, the Vietcong, to participate in free elections organized by a joint electoral commission and supervised by an international body.

John Farley, convicted of murder despite his plea of not guilty because of insanity caused by a chromosome imbalance, was sentenced in Queens Supreme Court yesterday to a prison term of 25 years to life.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., July 10 -- Lisa Orr of Quogue, L.I., the top-seeded player, and Donna Stockton of Garden City, L.I., rated second, won semi-finalfinal matches in the girls' 16-year division of the Long Island girls' tennis championships at the Seawane Club today. WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Retail sales slipped further in June and were little above the level of last summer, the Commerce Department reported today.

LONDON, July 12, (AP) -- Searchers closed the books today on Donald Crowhurst, a round-the-world race voyager, with the theory that he had fallen overboard. His wife clung to the belief that he had died trying to rescue another sailor.

LAKE GEORGE, N.Y. -- One of the best-known landmarks in the southern Adirondacks has been demolished. It is the Fort William Henry Hotel, which stood on a site linked with the French and Indian War. Haskell Handicap at Monmouth Park today hours after he had been stripped of a track record at Philadelphia because of a positive drug test. The author is finely accurate, too, in sketching in the girls' family back-grounds: middle-class, bland, and menaced by freedom.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 13 -- South Africa appears to have sold practically all her gold production for the first six months of this year, worth approximately $531-million.
